<review# 305,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/10/2012,5/21/2013,76,131,11,13,11>I might need an intervention.After the former M. Wells closed, I committed to trying to show more restraint when the new incarnation was born.  Like a failed New Year's resolution, it lasted about a month... and last week I found myself feasting there with friends two days in a row.I'm ordinarily not a sensationalist, and I acknowledge that M. Wells has gathered an obnoxious amount of hype.  But try as I might to find something I don't enjoy, I can't.Chef Dufour's culinary wizardry genuinely is intoxicating.  Many chefs have said that at this point in history, no new dishes are created anymore, merely reinvented.  But M. Wells actually defies that, turning flavors on their head and smacking you in the face with something refreshing, playful, sometimes decadent, but almost always exquisite.Do you have to wait sometimes for a table or even dishes?  Maybe.  But the payoff is well worth it.  What you contribute is what you get back with the staff.  Come in a hurry wanting to rush your experience, and leave disappointed.Come with an open mind to have great conversation with friends, doodle with crayons in the desk while awaiting your food, ask your server her/his personal favorites, stop and observe the faces of fellow diners around you in awe over their dishes... and you will have a wonderful, unique experience.There is nothing else like it... anywhere.  And I simply love it.
<review# 306,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/25/2013,5/20/2013,383,301,8,11,8>First time here the other night for a gathering/birthday event. I was pleasantly surprised by the venue!Food: there were complaints from my friends that some of their items were slightly high in salinity, specifically the noodles, but I was very impressed by everything else. The "Yan Su Ji" or Taiwanese Style Fried Chicken "Nuggets" are so good here that they rival some of the neighborhood authentic Taiwanese places! The fried dumplings or "guo tae" ("pot sticking/stickers") as per Elsie W.'s review, are phenomenal! Portions are smaller than I had hoped for, however. We made up for it by ordering multiples of each item. I must say that the Blue Moon Beer on tap here seemed very watered down. This made it lose one star.Service: extremely responsive! It took me a while to figure it out, but I could pick up the phone, press the middle button and tell the server(s) precisely what I needed. This is perhaps better than a system of pressing the "call" button and expecting the server to come in and hear your order over the KTV system.Decor: the small room for $60 (rate on weekends and Friday evenings) was probably large enough to fit 10 people. It's a great deal, until you realize that the food prices are slightly high. However, you get what you pay for. The bottles are on par with other competitors in Flushing. The sound system is amazing, though I found that there is a bit of a learning curve because the Karaoke song selection system is unlike anywhere I've been to. The bar area is slightly odd in the sense that there is hot pot being cooked at the restaurant very close by. It's an interesting mix, not sure how I feel about it. I need to spend more time at this bar to soak up the atmosphere (and the smell of cooking hot pots).Oh, and I must mention that Jando bought me a shot of Jameson for my birthday at this bar! He's the man!This will now become my go-to KTV place in Flushing. Since Zebra Lounge 1 is under construction and this is a significantly safer area to be in anyway, I may just drop Zebra 1. Kindly note that prices are slightly higher than competitors in the area but again, you get what you pay for (generally speaking).
<review# 307,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/27/2013,5/19/2013,227,484,8,11,10>I had to come a few times to try out the soup dumplings and other dishes before I could write my review.  Also I'm holding out on sharing with you guys because I don't want long lines at this new place.  This new place isn't centrally located and we wouldn't have known about it if we didn't drive by.  As everyone else mentioned, parking is sparse but is available.  You have to circle the block and go to the side streets for parking.  So after eating the steamed tiny buns 3x, we decided we like them.  The flavor inside is cleaner, less oily, and lighter than that of Joe's Shanghai.  The broth also looks clearer and the soup inside tastes sweeter.  I also judge my mini buns by the ability to stand up to my chopsticks.  No breakage is a good sign.  Breaking and leaky soup buns make me angry.  I've been getting a lot of breakage at Nan Xiang at Prince.  I believe they changed their recipe for the bun.I hate waiting in line at Joe's Shanghai and the skin on their buns are a bit thick.  They also put so much MSG and oil in all their dishes, it makes you so thirsty you have to finish a pot of tea.  I give this place 4 stars because their other dishes are pretty good as well and they have a large menu with a variety of Shanghai cuisine.  Their pan fried dumplings are awesome, not thick skinned, perfect golden crust, un-greasey, seasoned pork filing.  Cha Chiang Mien, Shanghai fried rice cake, stewed beef w/noodles, and watercress w/enoki mushrooms were very good dishes.The only thing that wasn't good that we've tried was the fried bean curd and bean noodle soup.  The soup was a little bland, was thinking it was just an off night, for the price and the portion I'd give it another try.A light must get dessert is the sesame rice balls in soup.  So good!  They take a while to order so place the order when you get your dishes.  Sometimes the service is a little slow, because the staff is young and they mostly speak Chinese.  During dinner hours there is barely a wait.  If I lived in the neighborhood, I'd be getting delivery at least once a week.

<review# 309,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/19/2012,5/17/2013,7,71,7,9,10>S Prime is A++ in my book!I couldn't say better things about this place!  This was my first time here and I couldn't wait to write a review.  I had an amazing experience and wanted to share it with the world!  We had 7:30 reservations on a Thursday nite.  To my surprise, there weren't any patrons inside.  I know this place has only been open for about 2 months now so the word hasn't gotten out...but it should!  I just can't get over the meal I had here. We were promptly sat towards the back at a rather huge table with super comfortable leather seats.  The table was a bit raised up right in front of an open display case of hundreds of wines!  I was already impressed and I haven't tried one thing yet.  We were greeted by our lovely waiter, Kate.  She was such a sweetie and answered all of questions from menu selections to wine/steak pairings.  By the way, the menu's they give out are quite gigantic!  I couldn't get over the vast selection of wines!  I'm no wine expert so I asked Kate what I should order with our steak and she recommended two bottles but also suggested by the glass.  I figured let's go all out and go with a nice reasonable priced bottle so we decided on the Siena? I believe that's what it was called.  The apps. came next.  Once again, our waiter suggested we try the Tartare's.  They had three kinds!  Steak, Spicy Tuna and Salmon.  I couldn't decide so we opted for the Trio Sampler.  You get a taste of all three! Yummy!  I enjoyed all of them but my favorite was the Spicy Tuna.  Maybe I'll do that next time.  Next Kate brought out a selection of breads - Multigrain, Pumperknickel and one other one.  We swallowed the bread like no tomorrow while munching away on the tartare. Wait! did I mentioned, one of the waiters brought out a sampling of a butternut squash soup on the house!  Yummy! Now the main course - Porterhouse for 2!  I've had this type of steak at many steak houses but this one actually blew them all out the water!  The main reason is that S Prime cooked my steak perfectly!  Sometimes you go into a place and you ask for Medium, they bring it out Medium Rare or in some cases, very well done.  You never get it just as you like it.  At least for me.  I love Medium to medium rare but I'm afraid it was going to be too rare so I had asked for Medium to medium well with a little pink inside as to not cook it too well and the steak came out perfect!  The steak just melted in my mouth.  My wife and I were some happy diners last night!  We ordered two sides - Cream Spinach and Garlic Mash Potatoes.  Both to die for!  Towards the end of our amazing experience, the manager or owner (not sure) brought us a complimentary sampling of another wine from one of their wine tastings. I was just lost for words at this point.  Dessert?  Nope.  Sorry.  Me and the wife were so full!  In summary, service was over the top perfect, the food was simply amazing and the decor was spectacular.  I can really go on and on about this place but I'm going to have to stop myself.  I really hope this fine establishment does well in the coming months and hopefully for years!  Forget about Manhattan!  Forget about Peter Lugers or Benjamin's Steakhouse or Uncle Jacks.  S Prime is where it's at!

<review# 312,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/27/2014,8/20/2014,64,138,6,11,7>Finally made it to Il Bambino! I don't know HOW it took me so long, but I promise you, Astoria, I'm planning on making up for lost time. Like a lot of the restaurants here (I'm discovering), Il Bambino is small, intimate and unpretentious. The dining room only has a handful of tables (in plain sight of a fluorescent meat counter and coffee bar), but with the candles and dim lighting it's elegant enough to meet up for a date or with relatives from out of town. The menu is here is simple: salads and small plate "tapas" appetizers, paninis, and crostini. It took us approximately 1,000+ hours* to make a decision because EVERYTHING LOOKS DELICIOUS. Everything, everything everything. And surprise! Everything IS delicious! We ordered the String Bean small plate to share (baby string beans with toasted bread, shaved parmesan and truffle vinaigrette), I got the Prosciutto Panini (with fresh mozzarella, roasted peppers, olives and rosemary aioli) and my friend chose the Mushroom Panini (with fontina, truffle spread, "dirty chips," and caramelized onions). Without going into FULL dish-description-mode, everything we tried was great. 600+ Yelp reviews aren't wrong: Il Bambino takes simple, high-quality ingredients and smashes them together into plates of awesomeness. And the prices (for food and wine) are totally reasonable. Definitely going to be one of my new neighborhood staples!*Delicious food tends to make me exaggerate. CONSTANTLY.

<review# 315,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/4/2014,8/17/2014,134,610,6,8,10>"Welcome to the party Pal!" - John McClane, Die Hard . . .  and me after my first of many visits to Transmitter Brewing.A nano-brewery, meaning they make beer 5 kegs at a time.  Sounds like a lot, but it's tiny, like back when you were a kid and made water colors with those little cups, so you'd have a bit of paint to work with.  Know what I mean?  Okay, maybe not, but it's a tiny amount.So that allows the good folks at Transmitter to use good ingredients, charge high prices (supply & demand) and make excellent beer on a small scale.  I love excellent beer made of good stuff, so this is in my interest.Transmitter itself is a small place in an industrial area near Fresh Direct, located almost directly under the Pulaski Bridge from Long Island City to Greenpoint.  You can drive there or walk (from the 7 or whatever) - use the stairs up to the Pulaski Bridge as your guide.  Once you're at the base of the stairs, it's 15 feet, across the street.  Yes, it really is located off of Borden, yes the road to get to it is across from the ramp off of the Midtown Tunnel, yes you have to cross the train tracks.  Cross those tracks after looking both ways, walk 300 feet and it's on your right.I went there on their 2nd week open after having one of their beers during Queens Beer Week - wow.  WOW.  Lovely saison, wild yeasts, belgian styling, so good.  Came here to try their beers, found a small tasting room offering free sips of their newest bottled items, with same bottled items available for sale.  First was good, second was better, gladly bought a bottle for $15.  Beautiful label, cork stopper, sits in the fridge for sometime to enjoy this week.Long Island City is quickly becoming a craft beer hot bed with Rockaway and Big Alice - Transmitter may yet be the best of the bunch.
<review# 316,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/1/2014,8/16/2014,275,34,10,13,15>We were told about Bakhter's by a family friend, and I'm SO glad we decided to give it a try. We've been back numerous times and it is truly the best Afghani food we've ever had. The white sauce isn't too thick and the portions are very big. We almost always order the Chicken Kufta and tika platter - you can split this with another person unless you're feeling extra hungry.The food is delicious, but service here isn't the best. You walk... choose a table and... wait. Sometimes you have to wait forever unless you make your way to the front and place your order, which I highly recommend. It isn't like most restaurants where you'll have a server and they'll consistently check-up on you. You grab your own drinks from the front and if you want to place another order, make yourself noticable. Bring cash!!! They do not believe in credit cards. *Also this place is not very vegetarian friendly.*Last piece of advice: If you're taking out, make sure you ask for extra white sauce and hot sauce because they'll give you very little.But all in all, the food is amazing.

The chicken didn't taste like the fake pieces you'll get with chinese take-out. It tasted like homemade chicken noodle soup. You can even drink the soupy part of the dish, the soup isn't salty, flat, or watery... I swear it's perf. They give you a hefty bowl too, so don't think it won't fill you up. It definitely will. Yum in da tum!~ The beef gyoza (which is sort of similar to a dumpling) is fried (or steamed) to perfection. They're not as thick as chinese dumplings, and they feel less heavy.The shrimp tempura rolls were SO YUMMY. The perfect amount of crunch, the teriyaki sauce drizzled on top, and the avocado all wrapped into one... I thank the sushi sensai of Japan for creating such delicacies.My friend ordered the chicken fried rice; compared to Dee Thai's fried rice (obviously they're two different types of asian cuisines) TJ had a healthier taste. Healthy is always better, yes? Yes, of course. SO LET'S GET MORE.To finish off, we had the tempura fried ice cream. Almost like the Thai fried ice cream, only the batter is fluffier and a tad sweeter (which I liked very much), and the green tea ice cream was creamy and sweeter as well. I personally like the Japanese version of fried ice cream better than Thai fried ice cream. I guess I just have a sweet tooth. :}The waiter(s) were super attentive and really nice. They refilled my glass like about 7+ times, lol.The bill came out to be almost similar to what's spent at a Thai restaurant, but at TJ's we had an appetizer & dessert included. Same pricing for the bill but more food involved?? What what! This place is great.Fresh, tasty, clean, welcoming... I like this. I like this very much.I believe I have a new spot. ;)**AND they have take-out/delivery. Oh boy. I think they have a new favorite customer.(Note that delivery might take a while. They make sure your order isn't rushed, so it can be freshly made and not sloppy. It's worth the wait!)

<review# 321,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/7/2012,3/29/2012,262,613,7,8,11>There was a character on the legendary Mel Brooks/Carl Reiner comedy album called "Corin Corfu".  He was a painter who turned out to not even be greek.Why do I mention this? Besides having the same name as the restaurant under review, the album was "The 2000 Year Old Man."  (About the average age of the typical forest hillian-- I jest, I jest!)Greek cooking goes back that far, if not much, much further into antiquity, with Zeus in Olympus likely having a fondness for grilled seafood.And I was able to get my grill on here during a recent lunch. First, a logistical note: Corfu is located in a bizarre mini-mall on Austin Street, in the heart of what Corfu's web site calls the 'trendiest part of Queens'.  You'll ascend a flight of stairs and enter a small spot with a blue, oceanic theme. Poseidon adventure, anyone?Our group of four felt like it was taking up almost half of the establishment but it's not really that tiny. Decor and feel is probably a step above a typical diner. You won't find any booths here, however, despite the proximity to Booth Street.The staff isn't particularly effusive, bubbling with false Greek hospitality for people who expect to enter the warm embrace of a big, fat Greek wedding. They are efficient and get the job done, which is far more important than wide smiles and open arms.Portions prove that austerity hasn't yet entered this corner of Greece. We could have easily filled up on appetizers alone, starting with an order of felafel and an order of stuffed calamari. The felafel played second fiddle to the calamari creation, which for a moment I thought was canneloni pasta. The outer tube structure was grilled calamari and it was filled with delicious feta cheese. Also included in the appetizer presentation was warm pita and tzatziki dip. Note that entrees come with salad and also lemon potatoes, rice and fava beans. At first I thought there was a choice but no, you get it all. I could have done without the salad but it does add a modicum of healthy greens and serves the purpose of reassuring me that I really am making healthier choices in life.I continued my cephalopod crawl by ordering grilled octopus with olive oil. Pure tentacle pleasure, my friends. I'd shake this octopus' little hand-like structure if it was still alive. Sometimes octopus can be as tough as rubber but here, a few chews and a flavor sensation of the highest order permeates my mouth. I am transported back in space and time and feel like a god, peering down from the sky as my people harvest octopus and squid, grilling it in my honor.The check arrives and stirs me from my Clash of the Titans fantasy. But wait, the clash isn't exactly causing me to give up that much cash. Two appetizers, four entrees and about $20 a head. For the brunch inclined, there's a 11am-3pm $10 or $15 program, the former offering unlimited coffee,soda (dangerous) or juice, the latter unlimited bellini, mimosa or sangria (dangerous). Points to Corfu for having their brunch and lunch menus peacefully coexisting at the same time. Sometimes at 1:30pm a man feels like octopus, thank you very much.

some tasty broth are good to soothe the cold.  It's my version of chicken noodle soup.I wasn't sure what to expect, a Thai place serving hot pot sounded strange.  However they did get some great reviews from my friends, so after holding onto my LivingSocial deal I decided to put it to good use.This is a small place that's long and narrow, and has a small bar.  It is somewhat of a tight fit, but it wasn't very crowded for a weekend.We got their steamed new zealand mussels steamed in mild lemongrass basil broth.  The mussels that arrived were ginormous, we didn't expect them to be that large.  They were lightly flavored in lemongrass, just a subtle hint as to not overbear the freshness of the mussels.  This was a great start to the meal along with our tall refreshing glasses of Thai iced tea.Next we both got our Lemongrass Tom Yum hot pots.  They turned on our heaters and showed us how to raise and lower the temps.  I proceeded to the condiment bar which has a very low sneeze guard* to protect it from germs.  I made our standard satay bbq sauce, and then I grabbed their pre-made bean sauce and their hot pot sauce.  We really liked both, the hot pot sauce was spicy.  The bean sauce had a sweeter flavor with sesame seeds in it.  The ingredients tasted familiar but we couldn't determine what was in them.  Ah we would fail the usual blindfolded taste test on Top Chef or Hells Kitchen.  As they brought out our package hot pot sets of surf & turf, and beef, they neatly placed everything to make room.  The servers were so friendly to show us to place in the Japanese pumpkin, corn, and taro first since they take the longest to cook.  As all of our sides arrived tofu skin, fish tofu, and pork dumplings, they helped us consolidate and were constantly stopping by to pickup empty plates.  Which was helpful because I was fearful I'd spill my iced tea.  Service was very attentive, helpful, and I appreciated it.I almost managed to finish my entire hot pot, except for the noodles.  I really enjoyed the Tom yum broth, it wasn't too spicy and the pre-made sauces were delicious.  My seafood was so fresh and the portion I got for the price of $17 was a great deal.  I know it sounds comparable to a bunch of hot pot places in Flushing, but you won't get such service, freshness, and flavor for $17.  You typically get some fresh and some frozen pieces of seafood, but not here!  My fish, squid, and octopus was glistening with freshness (just look at it glisten, yelp.com/biz_photos/jycF).  I have never seen that before except at a real seafood restaurant.  I was really surprised to find it here.They also serve your typical Thai dishes and they must be good because a good 50% of the tables had either standard food or hot pot for dinner.  This is a good choice for people because there are just a few people out there that don't like hot pot.  If you can't agree for hot pot or Thai, just come here because they serve both!Steve and I have agreed to make regular visits as we've found such a great hot pot place.  We want to bring our hot pot loving friends to give it a try.  It's helpful because the neighborhood is clean, safe, and parking is readily available (unlike Flushing).  I vote this place as the next UYE! Come on guys, winter is coming and I need something warm to fill my belly. *I'm short so for this to be under my nose, it's very low.

<review# 325,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/8/2011,3/25/2012,366,339,14,6,9>I almost got killed today while waiting in line for my coffee.I was half monitoring the line's pace, half perusing the overhead menu; an even 20/80 split.., whoops! Out from nowhere pops out this third cashier, and she barked aloud, "Next on Line!"Being that I'm quick with foot (and with wit!), and a little afraid of her thunderous voice, I stepped forward, and shouted back out at her, "Coffee-Black!, please?" Unbeknownst to me, I had skipped someone (slow) in front of me. He made it known to me though. This older gentleman said, directly and resolutely, 'HE-AY!' Yes, he turned a one-syllable word into two. He was serious. I turned around, and realized my fault!. I apologized, "Uh, I'm sorry :-(" and said politely, 'I don't want to die today.'At this point in time you may keenly be wondering, what the F are you doing in Panera Bread Tony C?? I like to read my book, but I was sleepy so I needed an injection of coffeeeee...Panera Bread is different than your typical (shhhh!, starbucks) coffee shop though. They balance more towards dining. And, what do people do when they're eating? They like to talk, sometimes while they're actually chewing or swallowing too, go figure. So, you'll hear more noise in Panera Bread than you would in your typical (ahem, starbucks) coffee shop. Though, the type of interesting conversations you can eavesdrop on can be quite amusing. What isn't amusing is when they catch you laughing at them. That's when it helps to stare incessantly at your phone or book while you're laughing, pretending that you're laughing at something else. Save!But, then it's not my fault that I can overhear a couple's conversation from 4 tables away (I blame it on bad feng-shui!). I don't really want to hear about his indigestion problem, or her discomforting and ongoing wedgie issue. And, if that wannabe hipster over on table number 4 says, "Oh my God!" one more time, I might start flinging hot coffee, or slapping people.And, why is this (strange) fellow on my right conducting a business call with his mouth full of Chipotle Chicken Panini? I wanted to say to him, "at least have a LITTLE bit of shame!" But, I didn't because, again..., I didn't want to die that day, and he was a lot hairier than I was. Location-wise, this Panera Bread was comforting. I must have loitered there for at least three hours. The space is Huge compared to what I'd find in Elmhurst, Jackson Heights, or Manhattan. And, I discovered that you just pay $2.50 for all-you-can-drink coffee! Interesting that you can get a buzz off 3 cups of coffee. Bathroom situation?, clean and accommodating, all 3 times.The most important thing? I had fun while I was there.

<review# 328,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/14/2012,3/22/2012,677,794,9,17,13>When I heard about Queens' first Michelin star, I bookmarked it and watched it sit on my list of "must-go" places for a good solid year. Seeing all the positive reviews and the constant crowd gathered at Danny Brown piqued my interest enough and I finally got up the nerve to go. I had with me a gentleman who has quite a wealth of knowledge with regards to wine which made my time at Danny Brown nearly effortless. All i had to do was drink when he selected. He selected a Bordeaux. We started with two appetizers. The grilled calamari with white beans as well as the roasted beet salad with warm goat cheese and caramelized onions. While the appetizers look small, they are quite filling. I recommend they be shared. The grilled calamari was supple while the white beans were creamy. The roasted beets were sweet and tender, combined with the warm goat cheese- pure perfection. The entree, for me was not so stellar. Suffice to say, i only ordered a burger at a Michelin star restaurant. There were other things on the menu but they were out of hanger steak and a few other things that seemed to, as the waiter said, "fly off the shelves". In my mind, the burger should have been just as good as everything else. The burger was cooked the way i asked, Medium. It was served on a toasted english muffin. The english muffin was very hard to get through so i used a knife and fork to eat my burger sans bun. The meat was probably a little too lean for my liking as the burger, though cooked perfectly, was dry. The Duck Confit managed to be fall-off-the-bone tender yet had a crispy skin on the exterior. The dish was balanced and definitely something that I would consider for next time, providing they are not sold out. Luckily, the beet salad was of epic proportions and I was quite full from that so the disappointing burger didnt really matter. The staff here are great! Combined with the warn decor and relaxed ambiance, the service here makes for a perfect atmosphere to enjoy a fantastic bottle of wine with a delicious meal and leave out all the pretenses that make fine dining snobby and awkward. For this neighborhood, Danny Brown might be out of the way for people but it really is a diamond in the rough.Would I come again?In the words of Mr. Big from Sex and The City, Abso-F*cking-Lutely! (but i will NOT be ordering the burger)

<review# 331,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/7/2014,8/1/2014,211,584,8,11,8>Finally, great eats are coming to Ridgewood!Ltauha was much needed in our neighborhood, and they're serving up excellent lunch, brunch and dinner fare.I'm always quite surprised when we walk by and find that Ltauha is a little bit vacant, but I'm kind of glad that it's still a bit of a secret and not crowded yet. We've been here for dinner three times, and for lunch/brunch once. Each time, service has been great and the food has been delicious!My favorite menu items are the branzino (a special), the soft-shell crab sandwich (a special), and the BBQ ribs.The branzino is amazing. They serve it whole, seemingly pan-friend, over a bed of succotash. I could seriously eat this everyday. It's a huge portion, so be prepared to share. The fish is always cooked so perfectly, and it just falls right off. Perfection!The soft-shell crab sandwich was not only perfectly cooked, but you could tell that the crab was fresh. A pet-peeve of Russell and me is when you're served soft-shell crab that has been frozen and it's just full of water from defrosting. But not here! The crab here is so tasty, served on a huge, delicious sandwich. You must try this!And lastly, the BBQ ribs...I'll be honest, at first, I was a bit skeptical. The menu here seems a little bit too fancy for BBQ, but these are always cooked perfectly and topped with lots of sauce. Also, I've noticed a trend in many BBQ restaurants where the food is not very hot, but these ribs were steaming and the meat comes right off the bone. It's served with a side of coleslaw (that has tomatoes in it, I think? Different, but so refreshing and good). Again, you have to try this...in fact, you'll want two orders, trust me!Sorry for all of the exclamation points in this review, but I'm really excited to have Ltauha in the 'hood. Not only is the food awesome, but the service and atmosphere are even better.

Entry is via the yard gate in the rear of the building.The space is high ceilinged and has the feel of being inside a very large, old kitchen. <review# 343,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/3/2011,4/18/2012,80,212,16,13,13>I didn't have the live octopus at Sik Gaek.The so-called foodies probably already stopped reading this review -- isn't the prospect of eating writhing tentacles the whole point of Sik Gaek? To a non-Korean, perhaps. And I am not Korean. But when a Korean co-worker invited me to join him and a few of his Korean friends there, I knew something more than food thrill-seeking was afoot. I agreed immediately.Sik Gaek is something of a Korean version of what the Japanese call an izakaya -- a drinking den that also serves food tailored for the inebriated. This does not mean that the food is an afterthought. Far from it. These are Asians we're talking about, after all: eating is never going to take a total backseat.We started with complimentary eggs fried overeasy right in front of us, a curiously compelling egg custard dish, and the classic ddeokbokki (thick rice noodles in a spicy gochujang sauce). An odd set of palate cleansers, but when the makgeolli (fermented rice wine) started to flow, it somehow all made sense. The lightly alcoholic drink, served from an amusingly downscale plastic bottle into shallow silver bowls, was a refreshing mist over the proceedings.Then, our main food event: a cauldron full of the sea's bounty, bubbling on the table's built-in burner. Here were mussels, multiple kinds of clams, abalone, rings of squid, shrimp, and who knows what else. In lieu of octopus (not present because monsoons in Korea had interfered with export), a live lobster was vivisected and deposited on top. Thin slices of raw rib-eye were quickly cooking as well. Udon noodles, cabbage, and my favorite kind of mushrooms, enoki, rounded out the toppings. All was partly immersed in a gochujang-based broth: spicy, deeply flavored, and only growing more so as the seafood released their juices into the soup. The servers gave us floor buckets to toss shells into -- now that's the kind of utilitarian addition I'd like to see at Le Bernardin.Other reviews have complained that the disparate elements get cooked to different levels of doneness. The solution is obvious: eat each element before it gets rubbery. This means starting with, say, the squid, then moving on to the clams, etc. It's really quite simple in theory, but the cauldron is so huge that it would take at least five normal people to do it appropriately. In point of fact, when the stew first came, only three of us were seated, but three Asian males counts as AT LEAST five normal eaters, so.But three more convives arrived at this stage, diving into what we hadn't already razed. This also triggered an alcoholic escalation: a bottle of the soju appeared. Someone asked for an empty kettle and, incongruously, a glass of Sprite. He then combined aliquots of the makgeolli, soju, and Sprite into the kettle, mixed it all up, and poured out a dangerously smooth, addictive low-rent cocktail. Now THIS was more like the Koreans I'd known and loved. All this was happening in a little booth under dim lighting, a call button embedded into a corner of the table so that we could keep the makgeolli rolling in. I'd be hard-pressed to come up with more conducive environs for steady inebriation mixed with solid food.Time passed. The mound of seafood eventually dwindled, the broth quietly reducing into more of a sauce. We were more than two hours into the meal, but a kicker still awaited. Another press of the button, and a server appeared with a huge bowl of seaweed-topped white rice. (I love sushi rice, but does anyone make consistently better straight-up white rice than the Koreans?) The server threw it in the pan, mixed it thoroughly, and left us to it. I almost reached for the ladle, but the lone girl among us said, "You think it's ready. But it's not." If a lifetime of eating has taught me anything, it's that whenever an Asian woman tells you to lay off a rice dish, you lay the fuck off the rice dish. A few minutes passed while I learned more from my reveling convives about the vagaries of Korean club life and early 90s K-pop, which was continually playing on the restaurant's sound system. The aroma of the seafood/gochujang fried rice, crisping on the edges like in a dolsot bibimbap, was driving me insane. When it finally came time to dig in, it did not disappoint: only a sense of decorum and the fact that I'd already crammed down several pounds of seafood prevented me from inhaling more of the stuff.It is not every day that you get to experience something like this, a glimpse into neither the highbrow nor lowbrow of an ethnicity's food, but into its youth culture, the social bonding aspects of its eating. I felt a little out of place, but not unpleasantly so; mostly, I felt privileged to be there. That the diners of NYC continue to support venues like Sik Gaek which encourage this... Who can be down on that?Probability of return within 1 year: I sort of need to get invited again by a bunch of Koreans; 100% if I am
<review# 344,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/9/2011,4/17/2012,170,240,4,5,5>I'm definitely a loyal customer for life and I'll give you two reasons, ELAINE & WILLIAM, they're both amazing stylists. Ok, long story short, Elaine & William came from another Salon also located in Elmhurst called Joy's Hair & Nail Salon.  There was just something about them that kept us (us, meaning my mother, sisters and myself) going back to them and when we found out they were moving, well we followed them, obviously.Elaine & William have been my hair stylist since I was 14/15 and obviously my sisters were younger then and we just haven't gone to anyone else. I've actually cheated on them a few times and it was a fail every time and I always ended up going back to Elaine & William because they just know how to work my hair, is it an Asian thing? Maybe? They're just that good at what they do and they're always honest. Just yesterday I got my trim and color with them and I couldn't be any happier with the results, Elaine has done it again (William was out for the day). If you're wondering how it came out, it's actually my default picture at the moment.Oh, before I forget, their prices are cheap too, we're definitely customers for life here, Elaine & William know it too ;)
<review# 345,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,11/14/2011,4/16/2012,56,100,8,5,4>Jollibee, I've heard so much about you. I've various Filipinos in my life and have taken on being an honorary Filipina. One of my lifelong best friends is Filipino and she's told me all about you, your deliciousness, and the awesome chicken, made out of cellulite that you mass-produce. I came on Yelp and people tell me you're an expensive date and can be cramped. Let me start off by saying, there is a constant stream of people coming in and out of Jollibee's and the seating is first come, first served Asian style. By Asian style, I mean hovering over people who are not quite done but almost done and then dashing into the seat once they're out and reserving all other ones for you and your friends. Lucky, I'm super Asian in that sense! If you're too slow, well...tough noogies. Have fun standing and eating your chicken joy. When people meant small, they meant small. This place is crowded, tiny, and my butt was knocking over things on other people's tables. With the combination of a loaded(read:heavy) tray and a protruding backside like I have, it's an obstacle course from hell. I was coming back from the line with my tray and nudged an empty chair to the side that held some lady's Louie Vuitton bag and she glared at me. *Shrugs* WELPPPP, shouldn't have your empty chair in the middle of an aisle, lady.  I HADDDD to have the fried chicken and because I heard about the small portions, I ordered a three piece spicy chicken meal with rice and it was prettyyy good. Portions are not small but they're not American sized either. Is it expensive? It's ok. I mean, a combo meal at MickeyD's is kinda expensive these days too, don't you think? So would you rather have some burger that's been floating in warm water or some Jollibee's chicken? I vote Jollibee. The tables are cramped and small, I legit felt like I was eating with everything on my lap. One wrong move and it could send your companion's halo halo flying. I wish I could go back and try everything on the menu. I got the famous peach/mango pie and it was pretty good. Deep fried goodness. McD's apple pie doesn't have shit on this tropical flavored beauty. I'm probably going to catch a heart attack after eating all that processed/fried food yesterday but I'll die happy today knowing that I had Jollibee's for the first time since hearing so much about it.

I'm not sure if it's a busy or not thing, or if the type of material is factored in. My only gripe would be that I wish the font size was a tad bigger. There's a lot of room on the available space on the medal, so it would have been nice to fill that up, but otherwise it looked fantastic.

<review# 351,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/17/2013,7/25/2013,50,17,17,32,21>First, let me just get this off my chest... I PASSED MY ROAD TEST!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Now let's get down to the actual review. Everything about this school is high-quality and professional. The receptionists are always friendly and give you a reminder call about 1-2 days before your driving lessons so that you don't forget. If you knew me, you'd know how bad I am at remembering appointments so that was huge plus for me. I purchased the package that included the 5-hour pre-licensing course, five 45 minute driving lessons, and use of the car for the road test. Most places that offer the 5 hour class just pop in a boring, outdated video, and proceed to torture students with it. This was thankfully not the case at Learn-Rite. The class was so informative and fun. They showed YouTube clips and it was way more interactive than I expected. They even had us try walking in straight lines with beer googles! Let me tell you, it is not an easy task.. haha.For the driving lessons, my main instructor was Wendy. She is an outstanding teacher who really knows how to guide her students to success. She not only gives you great tips to pass the road test, but also pinpoints all of your weaknesses and finds ways to work around them. Another thing I liked was that the car I used for the lessons & test was in much better condition compared to the other driving school cars I've seen.Also, I wasn't aware of this during my lessons (I guess I didn't really need to?) but they also record the lessons via camera on the inside and outside of the car, as an option to see how your lessons are going. I personally hate the idea of being videotaped but I suppose it helps to see things from a different perspective.They offer the option of coming to pick you up at your house for the lessons, however, just a little warning - if you live far from the school, it may take them awhile getting to you, thus cutitng into your lesson time. My personal recommendation would be to make your lessons back-to-back or double lessons so that you maximize your learning time.If you truly want to pass your road test on the first try-not that anyone actually enjoys taking it more than once-then take my word for it and go to this driving school. On the day of my road test, there were 3 Learn-Rite cars there, with about 2-3 students per car. Everyone in my car passed with flying colors, as well as the other students.I would have had a near-perfect score if I hadn't forgotten to put my left turn signal on when making my U-turn. Total face-palm moment. However, 5 pts off is nothing short of a miracle, considering I failed my test with 60 pts 3 years ago. After we all passed, Wendy took a group picture of us and sent me a copy of it in the mail. If I didn't look like such a bum, I would totally frame it *sigh*HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!Final Verdict: 5 stars *****

I like it because they also serve fresh dofu fa (the warm kind) which is tofu soy pudding. You can get a half and half of the hot and sour soup mixed with tofu pudding. if hot and sour soup is too intense for you this is the way to go. The extra tofu pieces balance out the spicyness.they also have scallion pancake goodies and tea egg. I have come here close to closing time and they have made a fresh batch of dumplings for me. Dont forget your utensils and napkins and to add sauce to your dumplings when you do take out. Avoid sticking holes in your bag and into your side (ouchie) by placing your forks spears up or wrapping it yourself.They also sell bags of dumplings you can bring home to make yourself. Come here if you are craving dumplings to grab a cheap meal in the quieter part of flushing.yelp 100 challenge: review #6

<review# 355,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/26/2013,7/21/2013,108,429,6,12,8>I've never been a fan of sushi buffet places that are not made to order, so I was quite skeptical about all the good reviews on Yelp. But, this place exceeded my expectations in terms of the quality and variety of sushi.Raw Foods: They offer small plates of sashimi, sushi pieces, and rolls. The fish was fresh and they even had Ikura, but no Uni. (update: came back again and they had uni!) I really liked the seasoned tuna sashimi plate. You can smell the hint of sesame oil they put in it. I've noticed that tuna is not as tasty in NY, but they did a good job with it. It's (ALMOST) similar to ahi poke in Hawaii, but not quite there yet. I also really liked that they seasoned their raw oysters! I've never been to a buffet that actually puts sauce and a small piece of lemon on their oysters (most places jsut shuck the oysters and leave it out as is). The beef tataki was yummy too.Hot Foods:  I usually don't eat the hot foods, so I can't really say it's good or not, but I did see a decent amount of variety. You tell the lady what kinda fruits you want in the crepe and she'll make it for you!Service was excellent. Staff was friendly and had smiles on their faces. The restaurant itself is very clean and spacious. Some of the tables in the middle are close to each other and you're probably not going to be able to fit in there if there's a morbidly obese individual on the next table. Other than that, the food was good and displayed in a very organized way. I wish I knew about this place earlier!
<review# 356,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/19/2013,7/20/2013,38,105,6,9,7>I was hesitant to write a review for the Turkish Cultural Center (TCC) of Queens, especially in promoting their limited space Turkish cooking class.  But in keeping with Turkish hospitality, I decided to be generous with my experience.  To spread Turkish culture the center offers a variety of programs to the community.  Anyone is welcome the last week of Ramadan to a three course meal provided by center volunteers in a public park in Sunnyside.  Although not well executed, center volunteers put on a traditional shadow puppet show in the Sunnyside public library.  In a public library in Astoria, the center hosted a Sufi musician.  I would have enjoyed the performance a lot more if the little kids in attendance were not yapping and running down the aisle like screaming banshees.   But oh well, that's what happens when the center promotes the event by offering free gifts to kids.  (Where's my gift for sitting silent and actually listening?!  We did get baklava and apple juice at the end, so it's all good). I have yet to attend, but the center also hosts a Turkish movie night once a week, I think with subtitles.   Also they hold talks, cross cultural dinners and fund raising lunches.    My favorite event put on by the TCC has been a once a month Turkish cooking class.  The center located on the second floor of a building is small and space is limited.  For $25 attendees got to watch a cook affiliated with the center (not a professional chef)  prepare and cook a three course meal.  Personal preparation of the food by attendees is not possible due to limited space.  The cook provided instructions and helpful tips along with a handout of the recipes.  I would have liked had she consistently woven anecdotes about Turkish culture while making the food but she seemed anxious fielding questions while providing instructions.  And she was a bit disorganized when it came to her prep work.  But she made up for it with her humor- I laughed out loud a few times and she was friendly.  While the food was being prepared we were free to help ourselves to Turkish delight and pastries, along with unlimited refills of Turkish tea served on lovely glassware by the courteous center volunteers. At the end of the session we all got to partake of the food (that's just a fancy way of saying we stuffed our faces while, hopefully, no one else notices cause they're also stuffing their faces too.  How meta!).  I've only attended one cooking class and was pleased with the dishes.  The appetizer was a carrot yogurt salad that contained nuts and pickles, the main course a yogurt eggplant meat dish and the dessert, mini pastries sitting in simple syrup.   If getting to Queens is difficult, the TCC can been found in other boroughs and in the surrounding tri-state area.

<review# 359,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/22/2013,7/17/2013,44,100,4,13,9>I'd recommend this restaurant for those who aren't shy about the generous application of cumin and chili, the numbing sensation of Szechuan peppercorns, and heaps of raw cilantro. The food here is a far cry from the things labeled "Hunan" in your standard Americanized Chinese restaurant, and I could think of no better place to educate yourself on the cuisine of the region.Compared to other restaurants in Flushing, the staff speaks English and can provide direction with the menu--this is especially helpful since some translated text is not completely accurate. Example: There is a section titled, "Chinese Dishes" which turns out, ironically, to not be Chinese dishes in the "authentic" sense (they are, instead, the dishes found in your standard Chinese-American takeout place). Most dishes can also be made without meat by request (such as the mapo tofu and eggplant casserole), so speak up if you're a vegetarian.Below are some of my top picks from the restaurant:* Pickled Cabbage, Hunan Style - Essentially a Chinese version of cole slaw; simple, crisp, and dressed lightly in rice vinegar and fresh chopped chili. The rest of your meal will likely be so packed with flavor and heat that this serves as a nice accompaniment to cut the heaviness.* Pumpkin Cakes - These fried, panko-crusted morsels remind me very much of Japanese-style croquettes, but made from mashed, slightly sweet pumpkin rather than potato. Very filling.* Fish Filet w/ Hot Chili Pepper - For diners eating alone, this dish offers a little bit of everything for a balanced meal: tender, boneless fish coated in a thick sauce of cumin, Szechuan peppercorns, and chili, served over stalks of steamed baby bok choy.* Hunan Spiced Crab - These medium-sized crabs are stir-fried in a dry sauce of sliced green chili and that irresistible combination of cumin and Szechuan peppercorns (if the formula's not broke, don't fix it?). No worries about picking out scraps of meat if you struggle with eating crab; the shells are fried so thoroughly that you could eat them like chips.* Eggplant & Minced Pork in Casserole - Eggplants are lightly battered and fried before being tossed in a slightly sweet, slightly sour, and abundantly garlic-y sauce. The casserole comes intensely hot off the fire, with the sauce still bubbling as it arrives at the table.

<review# 366,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/12/2014,9/25/2014,1195,408,14,18,16>DISCLAIMER: As an extremely proud and nationalistic son of the Philippines, as well as a lovingly adopted son of the outer borough of Queens (specifically in the section of Astoria), I will do my "damndest" to write the most objective review possible.Anyway, the unadulterated joy that I felt after finding this place was staggering.  After being scared into thinking that this place was wiped off the face of the earth (the Yelp map is so wrong), a quick look at the address remedied this problem in a snap.Even after visiting this place a couple times, I still can't believe that a place like this even exists (for the past two years apparently).  Esoteric Filipino condiments, snack foods, and other things adorn the shelves, along with your typical bodega-esque assortment of good things.  What's even crazier is how cheap some of these items run.  Given the not-too-common nature of the goods sold at this joint,  one could half expect a massive markup.  However, I found it a struggle to spend over $10 at this place ($10 being the credit card minimum).  My backpack literally ripped open when I got home because I was carrying so much in it.The older gentleman dude who runs the counter is also pretty cool, as we discussed the difficulties of trying to sell Filipino beer at this place.  When I told him that a Red Horse in the city sells for $6, I saw his eyes quiver, as if there was no more hope left in the world.  Thankfully, because of this place, I still manage to hold on to hope... no matter how desperate situations can get.
<review# 367,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/27/2014,9/24/2014,61,33,5,12,8>When a girl falls in love with a lemon and everything sour, she has to try RAD Filipino food.This is the best Filipino food in Queens & dare I say NEW YORK CITY! Not only does it taste authentic, but the price won't burn a hole in your pocket either! Filipino food includes (not limited to) a lot of vinegar, tamarind or lemon. So, if you love sour...this cuisine is perfect for you (& me)! There are a lot of signature dishes, but here are my MUST TRY:SIZZLING SISIG (Finely chopped pork belly marinated with lemon and hot peppers, served on a hot plate)-This dish tastes different in every restaurant, but I like that they give you a lemon wedge to squeeze more sourness to this sizzling platterSINIGANG NA BAKA (Beef Soup cooked with Asian vegetables with a tamarind base)-You can get this sour broth with seafood, pork or beef, but I really prefer beef!DINUGUAN (Pork stewed in vinegar and pork blood)-This might scare people who are not used to eating pork blood. Trust me, you can't taste blood or iron at all! The dish comes out very dark, almost black, but it is quite tasty. The vinegar really knocks it out.CALAMANSI JUICE: -This fruit is a combination of lime/orange. It's a small citrus fruit that is green and smaller than a lime, but round like an orange. The flesh is a light orange. The flavor is exactly what you'd think...a combination of orange & lime!I am in love with this place. I can't get enough of it! There are several other must try dishes on the menu that I have to go back for!
<review# 368,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/6/2014,9/23/2014,83,142,9,10,6>Korean-American ComfortThis Korean boon-shik ( easily prepped, or fast food) joint is a little disjointed. The service here is not the best. The speed of service is not exactly expedient.  Also, the young workers often forget what you asked for and aren't particularly polite. It wouldn't hurt to see a hospitable smile, hear a hello or even a good evening.The wifey and I ordered their "pizza-rice cake, spicy tuna kim bab, and donkatsu (fried breaded pork cutlet). The spicy tuna kim bab wasn't at all what I expected. I thought there would be only spicy tuna maybe a few carrots and pickled daikon, however, the kim bab had everything from eggs, pickled daikon, some kind of synthetic-fish ham, spinach, and only a sliver of spicy tuna. I was expecting the spicy tuna to be the main-character but it was just lingering in the background, like the A/V squad during school plays. Then came the donkatsu or Japanese-fried breaded pork cutlet akin to it's European cousin the schnitzel. The meat was thick and juicy and the breading was thin, but the breading wasn't clinging to the meat. The sauce drizzled on top of it was a mixture of honey-mustard, traditional donkatsu sauce, and Korean-American dressing AKA Russian dressing. I enjoyed the dish besides the nitpicking. Not bad for just 10 bucks. The highlight of the evening was the pizza-rice cake dish which took forever to arrive. This gorgeous thang comes in a ceramic lasagna pan. This was worth the wait, but sadly we finished most of the kim bab, which is extra delicious with a dunk into the spicy ddukboki sauce. The consistency of the sweet and spicy red-pepper paste based sauce was thin which wasn't a bad thing. It should be re-named a ddukboki pizza soup. The cheese they used was amazing. I think it was a mixture of Mozzarella and American. Underneath the ooey gooey cheesy top were some fish cakes, bell peppers,mushrooms, and not to forget the chewy rice cakes. The desirable chewy consistency of the rice cakes was spot-on. An overly cooked mushy Korean rice cake is a no-no.  I highly recommend this sweet, spicy and savory dish to a cheese-lover who can handle a little kick. I suggest adding some ramen to it which would make the dish epic.Tip: skip the kim bab and go for the pizza-rice cake. It is an exemplar of Korean-Americana.

<review# 373,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/12/2011,10/11/2012,142,338,1,10,9>Okinae is somewhat of a confusing place, at least to me. It has "Korean Restaurant" right in the title, but the name conjures up the similar and more recognizable Japanese island's name. When we first walked in, the groups at other tables were speaking Chinese, and the staff was talking with them. It turns out the restaurant is run by immigrants from the Dongbei, or "northeast," of China near the Korean border. The menu is in both Korean and Chinese, as well as some form of English.The foods here share influences from northern Chinese cooking, but are decidedly Korean in presentation. Plates of banchan are brought to the table even before you order, and the tables have a BBQ pit in the middle and a fan above.Other tables were swarmed with many sticks of BBQ and bottles of Coors Light or Budweiser, so we decided to fall into form and do the same. Since we only ordered six sticks, our grilling was done "off-site," in the front of the restaurant. I guess you need to order a certain quantity to be worth getting everything dirty, which makes sense.The small sticks of BBQ are all in the $1.19-$1.99 range, and all delicious. The lamb, beef heart, and pork belly stood out for us.As we were munching all of our items, a nice dish of steamed chive and egg dumplings came out, on the house. Other tables received one too, so friendliness and generosity might just be the policy of Okinae. The side of chili dipping sauce that accompanies it is excellent.The main dish we went for was the cumin chicken Jane ($10.99), a plate full of all parts of chicken and large, well-cooked pieces of garlic. All the meat is crispy and satisfying, covered in cumin and carrying plenty of spice and seasoning.Since we had not expected the dumplings and were expecting to be full of meat, we also ordered the simple garlic spinach ($9.99), which is exactly what you expect. The garlic sauce makes the dish very Chinese, but it goes well to add some green to your table anyways.After we finished, we were also given a free plate of crispy shrimp chips and ordered a couple more $3 Budweisers, as there is no OB or Hite on offer here. All in all, a wonderful experience and a thorough feeling of being somewhere very foreign.
<review# 374,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/19/2012,10/10/2012,142,211,6,12,14>Sitting in the corner window at Phayul, the smallish Tibetan noodle and momo restaurant in Jackson Heights, you feel that you are perched on the highest point in the neighborhood. This is an appropriate motif afterall, since Tibet is often nicknamed the rooftop of the world. You can feel the fresh air rattling through the windows in this clean little food spot. The waitress fills your cup of salty-yet-rich Tibetan butter tea. You ponder the sounds of the neighborhood activity below you, as you wait for your steaming plate of momos (try the beef and veggie varieties, the former bursting with meat juices and cumin, and the latter drawing on the flavors of grated cabbage and potato). Phayul is a unique place, not only for its aboveground setting (and further by the fact that it's walls are shared with a Himalayan hair salon), or by its authentic salty butter tea. But rather, for its authentic Tibetan offerings. Whereas other restaurants in the neighborhood specialize in a Himalayan cuisine that is more akin to Nepalese food (with simple thalis overflowing with dal, fermented pickles and bitter greens), Phayul has a tailored Tibetan menu. There is a whole section on the menu dedicated to thukpa, which is the Tibetan plateau's version of broad noodles served meat and vegetables in a milky white beef broth. Other dishes like mixed khatsa, which combine beef tripe with mouth-numbing chili, garlic, cilantro, and sesame seeds; or blood sausage, which come with a hint of Sichuan peppercorn, challenge your taste buds and your preconceived notions of Tibetan food.

<review# 376,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/24/2011,10/7/2012,5,21,13,12,9>Gather around my people, for I am about to share with you one of the greatest hidden treasures of the ages.I will unequivocally state without any hesitation that this bakery is my #1 guilty pleasure on earth - bar none.I could regale you endlessly with Hobbit-like tales of glorious gluttony; halcyon, golden days filled with huge, doughy, fluffy, flaky Colombian croissants, rich, buttery, cheesy almojabanas, yuca bread and bunuelos... Misty memories of palmiers (elephant ears), arequipe (caramel) stuffed figs and crispy, caramel filled pastry horns... Sigh..This is the kind of carbohydrate nirvana one can only achieve when one has found a place that truly can do no wrong - where everything has the hallmark of culinary genius; where you can taste the chef's love and the years of practice made into perfection instilled into each and every bite. Such a place is the Colombian bakery Las Americas on 82nd St.This place is an institution and has been around for decades. My dad used to take me and my older brother there when we were but wee lads in the early 1980s and we would return home like victorious hunters carrying the spoils of the day in large paper bags made semi-transparent from the butteriness of deliciousness ensconced within.Over the years they've introduced an occasional new item here or there, each one bearing the high born stamp of their lordly origins.My current favorite is the Spanish cheese filled croissant which is worth not eating anything else for the rest of the day and doing 5 miles on the treadmill for.If you go early in the morning, or just before 11 AM (when I believe the next fresh baked batch comes out) you'll be treated to piping hot breads - the cheese filled ones still bursting with the juices of the almost gooey white cheese filling. It's enough to start a riot. They say man cannot live on bread alone... Challenge accepted!
<review# 377,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/23/2012,10/6/2012,472,510,7,13,9>This was THE discovery of my weekend.  I can't believe in all the years (20+) I've lived in Queens and relatively close to Rego Park, that I had never once ventured into Ben's Best.  Shame on me.  Well, the tides are about to change especially after my bf and I came here on Saturday night for a quick and simple, shared dinner of a classic pastrami on rye sandwich, a spinach knish, and a warm, homemade apple strudel.  The pastrami was absolutely perfect.  I loved how moist and tender the meat was, and appreciated that there wasn't any fatty globs on the edges of the slices as I've had the unfortunate pleasure of experiencing with other pastrami sandwiches eaten elsewhere.  Additionally, the meat was seasoned well with black pepper which was a unique and tasty treat.  There's a very homey feel to Ben's Best, the walls of this deli just sing of local flavor and history.  It's full of character and texture as we discovered they've been in operation since 1945 (that's 67 years and counting)!  Service was pretty average but everything else about this special nook of a delicatessen was charming.  I see Ben's certainly becoming a mainstay in my rotation of favorite Queens eats.  I'm glad we discovered this place, which to me is like the Katz's of Queens albeit, Ben's Best stands perfectly solid on its own two feet without the need for comparison.

The interior is simple but it works. Walls are olive, floors are stone and furniture is leather and ratan. Hopefully they will have a few pictures on the walls soon. One lone plant by the front door is begging for company.  The only picture I saw was in the waxing room.The four pedicure chairs are the massage kind but they have bubble wrapped the remote so it was difficult to see the controls.  There are five manicure desks, two in the front and three in the back.  The waxing bed was comfy and the lighting in the room was well done and in mind for staring at the ceiling.The prices are comparable with the neighborhood and since three places around here are one big monopoly and the wait there is astronomical, there is plenty of demand in the neighborhood.  If they keep up the good work I think I might have found a new home.
<review# 379,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/14/2012,10/4/2012,168,160,8,10,10>Like the Siren Song in the Odyssey, when you pull up into the parking lot to pick something up from Home Depot, the smell wafts its way into your noseand begins calling out to you. The moment you hear your stomach grumble and the thought fills your head, "that smells good." it's over for you, it's a foregone conclusion, you have to stop by on the way out to pick up a Philly cheese or an Italian Sausage. Either of these picks are good. I like mine with a lot of veggies and they are not stingy about it, when you ask for extra they are more than happy to oblige. but you have to know this, it's really a glorified food truck, this is not a restaurant so there is no real seating, you could sit outside on one of the picnic tables but even that can be really dusty. the food is really good, I prefer the Cheese steaks, and it really does not disappoint. as others have said it can be a bit pricey, $10 for a large hero. I don't know if i would go so far as calling this place the best cheese steaks in the city, butthen again i don't know if a better one comes to mind so maybe... it's really the bread that makes it good, soft chewy and delicious. next time you need some hardware go to the Home Depot and let the smell draw you in....you won't regret it.

<review# 386,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/16/2012,8/28/2012,116,655,4,21,7>While lasers and eyes shouldn't go in the same sentence together, the idea of having perfect vision without glasses is kinda appealing. I considered doing LASIK for a while, mostly because I'm blind as a bat without the sonar (-7 with astigmatism). I found Astoria Medical Center on LivingSocial and called to make a consultation before doing the big jump. The building is sparkly new, with super A/C, bright and clean, and... empty feeling. The center is a combination of a medical, dental, and LASIK practice, but I guess since they're so new, there just weren't many people around. I was the only person waiting during my consultation and the rest of the office was quiet.Dr. Menezes met with me on time. She was great about explaining what would happen and what she was looking at, which made me feel at ease. She's cheerful and chatty and let me ask all the questions I wanted. Dr. Mendez is the opthamalogist - as in she checks your eye health and prescription, but isn't the actual surgeon. She said I was a fantastic candidate for lasik because I had really thick corneas (and therefore the procedure wouldn't be very risky). After chatting about my options, I made an appointment for a month later to go under the laser. Although I had found the place via LivingSocial, the office, doctors, and experience reassured me that this place wasn't going to steal my money and my kidneys, so I'd probably be safe in surgery.Dr Bonanni is the actual surgeon. While my time with him was limited (seriously folks, we're talking 20 minutes), he was professional, kind, and efficient. The whole surgery takes less than 10 minutes and feels a lot like being abducted by aliens. You're awake and watching everything happening to you. They give you two stress balls to hold so you can take out your anxiety on your hands and not your face. There's a lot of whirring and flashy lights, so it can appear rather scary. But the procedure is brief, uncomfortable, but not painful, and Dr. Bonanni talks reassuringly to you through the whole thing. Afterward, had a friend take me home (since I didn't want  walk blindly back). I slept for several hours and woke up bleary, but with 20/20 vision. I'm still going through recuperation, waiting for my eyes to fully heal (it takes about a month to fully recover) but I feel great. The post op appointments I've had were brief and positive, and everything seems to be progressing just fine. I was back at work after taking a day off to recover and while my eyes felt tired the first two days, it gets remarkably better after a week. I would recommend the Astoria LASIK Center to anyone in the area. It IS a hike to get to if you don't live here, but the service, quality of care, staff, and friendliness are a big plus. The staff worked with me extensively to reschedule several appointments and were really good about getting to me promptly if things changed. The doctors are capable and patient. They were also great about calling me a car service to get home and are efficient on the phones. Lastly, the value was terrific!UPDATE NINE MONTHS LATER...  I've had a surprising number of Yelp messages about this review and I'll try to address some of the repeat questions here.I'm doing great. I have had no adverse side effects or complications and I really am glad I went through the surgery. I went from -7 to 20/20 with no problems. I've had questions a few times about things (crying felt weird the first month) and Dr. Menezes was super about getting back to me. My apartment is also really dry in the winter, but I've been fine for the most part and didn't have considerably drier eyes than in years before. I still have some halos, but unless you're an air force pilot or midnight drag racer, it probably won't bother you. Its kind of like being a just a bit more sensitive to lights. The only additional fees are for the prescription meds. I was prescribed an antibiotic, a steriod, and Restatis, which promotes tear production. The antibiotic and steriod are only for the first six weeks and the Restasis is for three months. All together my meds cost around $150. They may also prescribe you Valium if you need the chill pill before surgery, but I didn't need it. Taking the meds for the first month is annoying, since you have to put them in around every four hours, but they're worth it. The post op checkups are pretty frequent. I think it was a one week, two week, one month, three month, six month, and year appointments. They're quick - around 15-20 minutes, but I appreciate the reassurance and check in. Dr Menezes is super nice and I would also recommend her as a regular opthamalogist.

<review# 388,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/27/2012,8/26/2012,29,97,6,22,6>This spa is set up like spas / sentous (bath houses) / onsens (hot springs) in Asia, hence the all nudity rule in the gender separated areas, as well as the uniform rule for the co-ed areas of the spa. Spa Castle specifically adheres to Korean sauna (Jjimjilbang) standards. Therefore, for anyone coming here, it's not just a spa experience- it's a cultural experience as well.The spa is set up into 4 sections. The main floor is split by genders and you must be fully nude for this area of the spa. I know a lot of people have a problem with this, but this is how they do it in Asia. (Queens is, after all a very culturally diverse part of NYC) Frankly put, it's nothing to be nervous about since everyone is naked and everyone is thinking about enjoying the pools themselves. Here you can also find dry and wet saunas where you can just be in a towel, as oppose to being uniformed upstairs.The second floor is the general sauna area and I absolutely love the big Loess Soil sauna room. Here there is also a salad and fruit bar... but as expected it's extremely expensive.The third floor is the outdoor pools. The fourth is the Korean restaurant that serves ok Korean food. It's also kind of expensive (if we are to compare with outside restaurants), but what choice do we have? Expect to pay $12 for kimchi jjigae and $15 for bulgogi and rice.Three things that come to mind with this place:1) In both Japan and Taiwan, they hand you towels as you enter a bath house so that you can cover your privates while you walk around and get to the showers and pools in the gender separated areas. Here, you have to strip down and walk yourself into the bath area to get a towel. I really wished that it weren't like this. But I assume they do it this way so that you can't get towels while you are in uniform.2) I notice that a lot of the clientele nowadays completely disregard the uniform only rule for the second floor sauna areas. They'll walk on down from the outdoor pools to the second floor in their bikinis and swim shorts. I hope that in the future, they'll have staff to regulate this. Let's keep the nakedness strictly in the first and third floor.3) I also notice that these days a lot of the clientele likes to hug or make out in the open outdoor pool areas. Can we stop this please? My body and my eyes are there to relax... not to be grossed out. If there's one thing that's ruining this spa, it would be the new influx of clientele that are loud and not following the rules.Overall, while to me the price of entrance is kind of expensive to take a bath and enter a sauna, it's still a very unique place in New York to just get away. Have an open mind with the nude areas, bring a nice swimsuit and bring lots of money- it'll be a great time there!---Update November 13, 2013It's been a while since I've been back to Spa Castle. The upkeep has definitely declined for this place. In the shower area, most of the shampoo/body soap dispensers don't have their caps anymore and they've mixed both with water as it seems. It used to be where they had placed this nice smelling Korean face lotion in the guys area... now we just get Vaseline lotion. Gross.

<review# 390,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/25/2012,8/24/2012,93,365,2,9,8>I'd really like to try something other than the Nasi Campurayam Bakar, or Grilled Chicken, but I never seem to order anything else. Coming from me, that's really saying something: I've been known to shy away from any and all dishes containing coconut milk, but I make an exception whenever I visit Mie Jakarta. A hard boiled egg and handful of shrimp chips may seem like random additions to those unfamiliar with Indonesian cuisine, but they're both very common, and help provide a variety of textures and flavors that round out the meal nicely.I've heard people balk at the serving sizes. And it's true, if you have an especially large appetite, then a single entree here may not do it for you. But, at only $6.50 a meal, feel free to go all out and embark on an ordering spree! For what you get, the value truly can't be beat. The food is made with love and care, and the quality of the food is incomparable to whatever else you may be able to scrounge up for the money.The restaurant is sparse, and likely seats no more than 15. There is no ambiance to speak of. The menu is limited. None of these are bad things. On the contrary, it's what makes this little hole in the wall endearing! The employees here can best be described as efficient, but timid. However, they always have a smile ready and the food never takes very long to make it's way to your table.
<review# 391,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/31/2014,6/12/2014,262,613,7,11,9>While I am horribly jet-lagged after a 14 hour flight from Dubai to JFK, having spent such an inordinate amount of time on an Emirates Airbus 380 makes all the difference: I may be tired from the unavoidable drain of air travel but I am hardly miserable.I have had my share of flights on other airlines with faulty entertainment screens, rude and frankly miserable looking flight attendants along with the inevitably wretched slop that passes as an on-board meal. Simply take the extreme opposite of all of those experiences and you have a clue as to what a flight on Emirates is all about.If I had known about the quality and quantity of food on board my outbound flight from JFK to Dubai I wouldn't have wasted an obscene amount of money on overpriced snacks from the nearby terminal eateries.I flew coach but was treated like an actual human being, one who can be trusted with non-plastic utensils and given an entertainment system that ranks up there with the great library of Alexandria for sheer choice of material alone. The 12.5 hour flight featured two meal services and a pizza snack. Each meal service presented me, the passenger, with a choice and not just between pretzels and peanuts. Lamb with basmati rice? Or maybe chicken curry? Vegetarian option? And for breakfast, how about a hot croissant with an omelet that tasted as good as any I've had while on the stationary earth.I was initially apprehensive about a middle seat but even in coach class there's enough space between seats so as to prevent elbow rubbing with strangers. If the person in front of you leans their seat back, it's not necessarily an in your face intrusion. The flight attendants are young and attractive. It's like the way air travel was in the golden age of flight in the US during the days of Pan-Am. As the center of economic power shifts eastward, it's obvious that the caliber of air carrier follows suit. Emirates is the comfortable chariot to the land of tomorrow that is Dubai.

Halal half chicken, chicken and beef kababs, cooked year round over charcoal. Absolutely delicious, and though the other reviewer felt the platters weren't a good value, I have to say I disagree. Platters are amazing, if you get the half chicken, it comes with two soups typically(depending on supply) and a salad. Its served over two types of rice, and though I usually get this platter for myself, the meal could easily be shared between two people. At ten bucks, well worth it. This is my favorite dish here, though the kabab sandwiches are great, reasonably priced, and served on toasted bread with the dough pulled out. A couple of tips here, Sundays and dinner time hours you'll find yourself waiting for a long time, so be prepared to wait. It takes at least ten minutes even when there isn't a long wait. Though it says they deliver, I don't think that they do. I think they're overwhelmed with orders, and won't answer the number listed. I've tried, on several occasions, to call ahead for pickup without any luck. The last thing would mention is to ask for tahini. They used to only serve tahini and hot sause, but with the popularity of the ubiquitous white sauce, think they caved because everyone asks for it. Really great charcoal grilled food here.

Found this gem of a place (which I later found out is the go-to soup dumpling place for most of my friends) and was not disappointed.First: oh dear lord please don't try to drive here! You will spend hours looking for parking, and the Main St. Flushing 7 stop is only a few blocks away. Wait it out on the train and save yourself the arguments.Now the good stuff: Their scallion pancake is delicious! A bit greasy, but that's fine by me. It's super crispy which is definitely better than some of the limp ones I've had in my past.We also ordered a noodle and beef dish, which was tasty but I found the sauce to be a bit thick and sweet for my taste. The boyfriend gobbled it up though.Finally, the soup dumplings (we got pork). This was my first experience with soup dumplings. Let's just say it was a struggle for me to figure out how to eat it. I think next time I need to watch a youtube video. I did however, watch a guy tackle these expertly at the table next to ours and tried to mimic him. I think I just don't have the finesse, I spilled most of my soup on the spoon and my lap. Thankfully I managed to slurp up enough to know that this place has AMAZEBALLS soup dumplings. I'm addicted and planning a reunion visit for after the holidays. Go!

No idea what the dessert is, it just tastes like a awesome combo of a mildly sweet Napoleon cream in phyllo dough.I get the complaint of a pricey menu, but EVERYTHING was super generously portioned for their prices which weighs heavily on my grade.
