<review# 399,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/30/2014,6/4/2014,149,122,5,9,7>Open Karaoke is situated in the heart of Murray Hill, right across the street from the LIRR. The best karaoke joint in the neighborhood, if you've been eating and imbibing in this area and are in the mood to sing, no need to travel out to Northern Blvd! I don't believe there's an English sign, but it's brightly lit in neon pink lights across the street from GugongTan.This clean establishment is run by a friendly Korean man and a few staff. The rooms are a bit smaller than their Northern Blvd counterparts, but there are a couple of huge rooms if you were planning to have a huge group here. Their mics are cordless and they provide those sanitary mic covers. The songs are updated frequently. The service is generous; it's not uncommon that they'll bring you a couple of soft drinks (They have a decent variety of Korean drinks like Milkis and Sacsac Grape! Of course, they have Coke and Sprite as well.) or even beers on the house. Also, they give you a bowl of Shrimp chips as well. Open late everyday, Open karaoke is a great way to end the night on any day of the week!
<review# 400,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/10/2013,6/3/2014,45,115,5,9,8>When you go here, go hungry. Came here because of their Amazon Local deal and returned due to the food and service. We were greeted by Brian, each time with a smile and given the option of sitting in or not in a booth. There are a plethora of TVs there and they always have on a game of some sorts.The menu is large enough to satisfy all your BBQ wants without being overwhelming. There are two choices of ribs (Memphis and St. Louis), brisket, pulled pork and chicken. All are awesome. The meat falls off the bone of the ribs and chicken and the pulled pork is soft, moist and melts in your mouth. The BBQ sauce and rubs have an awesome flavor.The sides are equally delicious. The baked potatoes are the size of Cadillacs and are perfectly baked. Whether you get it loaded or not depends on how much room you think you will have in your stomach after you gorge yourself on BBQ. The beans have just the right about of pork in them and the cole slaw compliments the meal sublimely.If you call for reservations, ask if they have smoked chicken wings. They aren't on the menu and are cooked as a special from time to time. Smoked then finished on the grill and sauced with any sauce in the house you want on them. They are the best wings I've ever had.

<review# 403,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/3/2013,1/22/2013,42,175,6,6,7>"So this Australian restaurant opened up in Astoria, want to go?""What? Australian?! Pfft, sure!"Behold, the hook, line, and sinker to initially get you into the doors of The Thirsty Koala. I came here the other night with a friend, excited to try a cuisine that.. well, I never considered the existence of before. When you think of ethnic food, you generally think of something with a bit more pizzazz and crazy spices, but Australian cuisine is a just a stone's throw away flavor-wise from solid, home-y flavors Americans would enjoy.First, the ambience is casual and relaxed, the decor is impeccably new with a nice sense of humor in the giant stuffed koala found on the counter, and the service was perfect. The waiters/waitresses were all very friendly and attentive, and one of the owners, Christine, made it a point to speak to all the guests personally. You can tell there is sincere graciousness and a genuine love and passion for this restaurant. FOOD:I ordered the pork chop appetizer and the smashed mint peas (which apparently no one else has dared to try since they've opened). I ordered the pork chops as medium and they were ever so slightly cooked a bit over medium, but somehow still maintained perfect flavor, juiciness, and tenderness. They were rolled in rosemary and some other simple seasoning, but I can't stress enough how well they were cooked, and how much you could tell they used quality meat.This came with a side of diced roasted pumpkin which was delicious, not remotely mushy, and had a nice slight sweetness to it. Lastly, there was an unexciting, basic salad consisting of rocket leaves, pomegranate, and some kind of vinaigrette. Not bad.The smashed mint peas were actually awesome! If you like peas/greens in general, there's no reason not to order this. I was told by Christine that this dish is served with meat in Australia the way Americans serve mashed potatoes. It was awesomely simple: peas gently mashed (but maintaining integrity) with a little vinegar and some mint leaves. They are not vinegary at all, just simple and satisfying. For dessert, I wanted to order the Tim Tam Tiramisu (I freakin' love Tim Tams) but they were all out! Instead, they used another type of chocolate covered biscuit. Not quite the same. The tiramisu was served in a cup, and the biscuit lined the bottom. Unfortunately, I don't think the chocolate bits of the coating work well texturally with the tiramisu, but besides that, the flavor was good, not overbearingly sweet, and the homemade cream was quite nice. Overall, The Thirsty Koala is an awesome asset to Astoria. I will absolutely be returning here and would suggest this place to friends without any qualms. For a full 5 stars, I'd definitely need to try some more things on the menu and maintain that the service is consistently awesome.PS. I have an absolute crush on the woman with the labret piercing and slouchy hat who works there. Be nice to her, or I will kill you.
<review# 404,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/26/2012,1/21/2013,1515,3351,7,14,8>Originally built as a Civil War fortress, now a 60.39 acres shared site for New York Fire Department, the U.S. Army Reserve, U.S. Coast Guard, and NYC Parks.A beautiful park well maintained for the grounds is clean and resonate beautiful views of Throgs Neck Bridge and Long Island Sound on a clear day.  On a relaxing Sunday to attain inner peace and expel poison from what life has blocked me from achieving happiness, Fort Totten Park fends a nice walk-a-thon.  The Parade Grounds serve as a soccer and events field to the public including a outdoor swimming pool.  A jetty path is accessible by foot only which fends a clear view of Throgs Neck Bridge as the scenery of Long Island Sound is beautiful.  Grounds are a secure site for a gated security admits visitors.  Here lies U.S. Army Reserves where militarists serve their remaining passive years.A Visitor's Station is available to host as a small museum of authentic artifacts from the Civil War era.  Kid friendly grounds and best of all--FREE!  Fort Totten also inhabits a "Greenway," a park area designated exclusively for Bicyclers and pedestrians.  For any avid history buff or those who truly enjoy the great outdoors, Fort Totten presents both without question.
<review# 405,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/20/2012,1/19/2013,1195,408,12,10,12>Now whenever I'm about to complain about NY's lack of offerings for Filipino cuisine, I slow down, take a breath, and remember that Tito Rad's is bike ride away from my Astoria apartment.And yes, you will need to make the ride (the exercise will be necessary after all the pork you eat).  Dudes, you gotta eat the pork when you go here.  I know that the specials are fish, which I hear is pretty damn tasty in their own right, but the pork is where it's at.  It doesn't matter if you get the sisig, the lechon kawali, the crispy pata, or the BBQ... just do yourself a favor and get it.  I just don't believe how cheap they dish their...dishes... out.  A whole shank of pork for under $10?  That's a meal for two people (or for one... me).  Just ride your bike after if you feel guilty about it.

Can't complain about the service here for sure :). Long live the power of yelp!
<review# 407,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/23/2012,1/17/2013,628,678,12,21,15>I don't make a lot of absolute statements but here's one: Nan Xiang Dumpling House has the best xiao long tang bao in NYC.Let's be honest, soup dumplings are as much about construction as they are about flavor... if not more. Nan Xiang does that construction especially well. The soup dumplings here are huge, plus the skin is so so so thin with just a bit of bite on top. Soup dumplings are made by tucking a piece of the broth (naturally solidified into gelatin when chilled) into the wrapper with the filling. They use a LOT of that here, so your dumplings will be FULL of soup. Just about perfect.Get the crab variety: $6.50 per order of 6 (pricier than the norm, but reasonable). The classic pork ones are soupy goodness as well ($5.50), but neither kind has a strong "classic soup dumpling" flavor - so you might as well go a slightly different route with the crab. Our little group came here after already being STUFFED with everything else in Flushing, and we still ate and ate and ate. While walking out I noticed Mr. Michelin on the window. Huh.I've been here before for a traditional breakfast (hot soy milk + Chinese crullers!), but it's their xiao long bao that can't be beat. Worth inevitably burning your tongue for.

<review# 410,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/28/2012,1/14/2013,149,276,5,7,6>For my 100th review, I was thinking of a place that was good, not extravagant and I often visit. This is a local spot for me and I go at least once or twice a week. I have brought friends and colleagues which also agree good food in a nice spot. The main reason I like it so much is it covers most of the food groups like meats, grains and vegetables, hey they sometimes even have slices of oranges for the fruit portion and you can buy Acai juice there, but I being a Carnivore Lover go for the meat. The Brazilian Churrascaria isn't table service like some other restaurants, this is a casual buffet like atmosphere. You wait on line and choose what goes in your plate from the bins of buffet food (rice, beans, fries, marinated meats with gravy, yucca, fried pork, plantains, salads) then when you get to the racks of BBQ meat select sausage, hearts, cheap rib eye, flank steak and chicken (sometimes with bacon). Waiting on line seems better before lunch or after on the weekdays. The place is packed and line fills up the little area where the food is on the weekends. Actually it use to be better and more popular couple years ago until they changed management or staff, though the food seems the same or similar, maybe the popularity toned down a bit. The food is not spectacular but very good. It really depends, sometimes I have had the BBQ meat a bit on the chewy side and other times, I just giggle with satisfaction. I think some of the photos by Nga C. and Wilkie J. show a very good description of the food you're getting. It is priced based by the pound on what's on your plate (approximately $7-$8 a pound for meat and buffet - don't quote me on that), just meat might be pricier, meat and salad, meat and buffet, just buffet or just salad (cheaper by the pound). I think this place is above three stars and only slightly below four stars, if maybe they improved the decor, food and basic seating instead of such a random/average seating arrangement just a little bit I see way more potential than a local Churrascaria, but that's why I like it: basic. Copacabana is a simple, not an overrated, good quality and priced Churrascaria. The staff seem friendly enough and the bathroom is clean as it can be for it's popularity.
<review# 411,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/27/2013,6/5/2013,628,678,23,26,24>For the purposes of statistical reliability - VERILY, IN THE NAME OF SCIENCE - I had to come to Kyedong repeatedly over a short period of time to confirm its awesomeness.This tiny space is humbler than other Korean fried chicken places, but packed on the days and times you'd expect. On a Saturday night once, I was actually directed to their sister location (Kono) a few blocks south, since the Kyedong staff determined that one of the 7 tables opening up was too much to hope for. No, they don't have a stocked bar like BonChon, or the cheery-mod interior of KyoChon, or the extensive non-chicken menu of Mad for Chicken. ...But you know what? They've got chicken. Plentiful, inexpensive, and excellent chicken. Isn't that what we're here for?You know about Korean fried chicken, right? Chicken coated in a sticky, garlicky glaze that hardens into a thin shell that magically replaces the skin? It is soooo perfect here. Big, hot, juicy, somewhat more conservatively glazed. Not tiny (ahem, K-town KyoChon). Not burnt (ahem, K-town BonChon). Not cold (ahem, Flushing KyoChon). Not dry (ahem, 2nd Ave BonChon).The coating on Kyedong's chicken is a little lighter than how most others make it: still delightfully crisp, but thinner and not as sweet or salty. For how well the chicken is prepared, the less assertive flavors are a good choice. I mean, would you rather have Doritos or a really good tortilla chip? (Don't answer that.) Likewise, Kyedong's "spicy" is not very spicy. You usually do half soy garlic and half spicy? Opt for all spicy here.Platters arrive with your chosen chicken parts arranged in a random frying pan. The pan is carpeted with french fries, in case the dopamine assault on your brain heretofore wasn't enough. Time for a PSA: Weeks ago, a couple who left after we were seated left most of their food on the table, uneaten: pork belly, an entire plate of kimchi, a pile of chicken. I was hoping some intrepid waiter would secret it away in his bus tub, but nope! In with the trash it went! Let me be honest: I wanted to punch them both. WHO ARE THESE PEOPLE??? To everyone: If you still have massive quantities of untouched food remaining, wrap it up! Take it somewhere! Eat it later! Give it to ANYONE! Don't just pick cutely at it... UGH SHIT LIKE THAT MAKES ME SO ANGRY.....Anyway, Kyedong is awesome on multiple fronts - most importantly, the quality of the chicken - and has rocketed to the top of my KFC list despite its limited menu. Go there; revel and luxuriate. Just don't be an anal sphincter (technical term, duh) and waste great food.

<review# 413,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/5/2012,6/3/2013,366,339,11,9,11>I must've been delirious from all that high altitude hiking earlier in the day, but I came in here, sat down, and I ordered a salad! I remember asking quite a few foodies in my past dining adventures, "what's your favorite vegetable?" And, on an alarming number of occasions the response I received was something that I have never tried before, roasted beets. I just saw it on the first page, and I didn't want to look any further into the menu. It was a Roasted Beets Carpacio Salad with baby greens, red onions, goat cheese, and toasted almonds tossed in a balsamic viniagrette. It was an amazing salad. The beets had a woodsy note to them, almost like wild mushrooms. But, then they are juicy too (think cranberry sauce), so they offset the texture from the grilled chicken. The different textures really melded well together. There was the dry leafy greens drizzled with the tart viniagrette dressing, woodsy & juicy beets offsetting & complementing the lean grilled chicken, crunchy almonds, crunchy red onions, and soft smearably crumbly goat cheese. And, then of course, with each bite, you can mix up those flavor and texture profiles as you like by how you combine them. Ingenius! It was pretty too. It looked like a christmas tree in my bowl (with grilled chicken as ornaments).I came here with some peeps, enjoyed some good brews and a great eating experience through a wonderfully designed salad.
<review# 414,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/25/2013,6/2/2013,173,244,9,11,11>As I enter Zabb Elee I'm greeted by the faint but noticeable smell of fish sauce; immediately I'm transported back to Bangkok.  'Sawadee Krap' is followed by 'Sawadee Kaaaaaa' and it feels like Chiang Mai.  The Northern Esan food they serve here is as authentic and often better than the food I've eaten in Thailand, especially the Sam Tom, which is a real thing of beauty.  My mild Thai obsession is always satiated by the amazing, complex, inexpensive food served at Zabb Elee.Thai food is an aggressive and exhilarating assault on the tongue.  Each dish seeks a balance of sweet, salty, bitter, spicy and umami.  There are no "appetizers" or "entrees", most dishes are medium size, enough to share, which is very Thai and always comforting.  Try and order a good balance of hot and cold, spicy and mild, oily and dry, saucy or not.  Use your fork to pile food onto your spoon and enjoy Thai style.I've tried to eat my way across the menu and have succeeded in trying most options.  My favorite food in the world (at least as of this review...) is Som Tam.  The spicy green papaya salad served with crunchy peanuts, pork rinds and bathed in a bright acidy sauce with lime, a few sweet elements and fish sauce, ordered as spicy as you like it.  In Thailand I found this dish to be underwhelming no matter where I had it.  Here it's a magnificent 'salad', which should really be eaten with Khao Neow (Sticky Rice) to soak up the remaining lime dressing.  The portion is huge, the price is small, sharing this with friends and family is a real pleasure.  A recent special was Strawberry Som Tam, which was a bit sweeter but delicious.  Never thought I'd eat let along absolutely love strawberries with fish sauce, pork rinds, peanuts, and other savory bits, but they complement each other perfectly.Aside from the Som Tam, my favorite dish here is the Dark Noodle Soup with Beef.  It's a version I assume of Boat Noodles, beautifully thickened with pork blood.  Tangy, rich, luscious mouth feel, and served with the traditional Thai sides allowing the eater to adjust the level of spicy, sweet or fish sauce to their own palate.  Highly recommended dish.  The beef is much more tender than the pork version, and I prefer this dish with the wide noodles.Esan food is spicy and somewhat simple compared to different regions, but the food is every bit as interesting and the flavors as intense.  Esan cuisine does not offer many curry dishes, so neither does Zabb Elee, but recently their Green Chicken Curry special was excellent and enjoyed by all at my table.  My wife claims the Pad Thai to be the best she has ever had, including the famous (infamous?) version on the street in Khao San Road in Bangkok, but frankly I find it too sweet.  They are a bit heavy with the tamarind, perhaps reflecting the American palate.There is another Thai place 6 blocks south that is much bigger and more popular, and while I find their food amazing, the vibe and service is always lacking.  It is true that in Thailand once they drop your food off, they don't often return to ask how you are doing, and they are not very attentive to empty water glasses.  Some of that is true at Zabb Elee as well, but they are markedly more friendly and patient.Each day they seem to have a different dessert.  I'm partial to the Durian over sticky rice, but aside from the first time I visited Zabb Elee, I have yet to be offered it again.  The braised Bananas or pumpkin in coconut milk is another excellent choice, but I'd avoid the shaved ice dessert, it's a bit medicinal.Bring your friends and over-order, the food is just as good the next day.
<review# 415,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/19/2013,6/1/2013,180,152,6,7,5>Now where do I BEGIN with this place? There are so many things about this place that it gets done right. I live only a couple blocks from this place and I can't believe that it's taken this long to discover it! It was my friend's birthday so we had a party of about 10 people come out a little bit early to enjoy the happy hour and then get dinner together.First of all, the decor. Wow, this place just feels like a European discoteque or something. There are huge glass chandeliers everywhere, giant booths with comfortable couches, and a massive dance floor big enough to fit a hundred people comfortably. There is a clubby feel to the atmosphere, which I liked. I didn't like the weird, neon light lighting though because everything becomes a weird blue or pink tint... The happy hour special for Wednesday was the 2 for 1 deal on select cocktails. Just to watch out on this one, if you order a drink, they give you two of the same drink right away, so make sure you order with a friend and go halfsies so you don't end up with too many drinks on the table. I had the Coquitini, this guava juice with champagne drink, and another one with tamarind juice. I thought the Coquitini was the best. It was milky and creamy with just the right amount of cinnamon. The other two were good, but I'd definitely stick with the Coquitini. Each one is $11, but with the deal, you get two so I'd def suggest it!Wow, the dinner is amazing! First off, the foursquare deal! You get a free drink (wine or sangria I believe) when you check in! The sangria was slightly more bitter than I'm used to, but who doesn't like a free drink? The food, omg, is phenomenal. The menu is pretty vast and it's not the cheapest food in the world (ranges from $15-$40), but considering how much food they do give you, their food is a steal! I ordered the Roast Pork on recommendation from my friend and I received a plate of pork that has to be the biggest hunk of meat I've ever seen served at a restaurant! It was quite literally the size of my face (and I have a huge head). I cut out a slice for everyone at the table, and still what was left was the biggest piece of meat I've eaten. It wasn't just quantity though - the pork skin was soft and fatty, while the meat was moist and not at all dry. The combination of the hard and soft meats of the pork, mixed with the excellent seasoning and sauce, made this an unforgettable meal. My friends ordered many other dishes that were equally ridiculously ginormous and delicious. If you are into large portions, this is the place for you. But be warned, splitting a plate costs an additional $10, so I would recommend just getting your own food and getting a doggy bag. We didn't know, so when they overcharged us, we asked them if they could let us off, and they did! So the least I could do is repay them with a 5 star rating here. It was clearly marked in the menu but we had no idea that it was there, so they were really generous! They also gave us free coquitini shots (wooo!) and free dessert for our birthday boy. It was tres leche cake and it was delicious!This place is on my radar now and I will not fail to frequent it!
<review# 416,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/11/2013,5/31/2013,241,315,11,11,11>Taiwanese comfort food done right. Admittedly this is Flushing so competition is a-plenty and I know very little about Taiwanese foods, but having been to my fair share of Taiwanese places (like Gu Xiang) I will say 66 is one of the best.A few forewords:1) This place speaks Mandarin. The menu has English but the waitress' English are very limited.2) The decor is not impressive. Hell, there's barely any decor at all. But then why would you go to a Flushing place for the decor you weirdo.3) Place looked a bit dirty. But I'm giving 4 stars for the food alone. That's right. Setting precedence for myself here.Gua bao. Everyone loves it. Pork belly in mantao. Anyone who has been to Momofuku (which by the way is derived from the word "motherfker" - real story) knows about it. Baohaus embellishes it with every other imaginable ingredient. But man, the gua bao at the 66 is *the* shit. The pork... half skinny and half just pure fat is what Chinese people are famiarized with. And its so, so, filling. JESUS! You hate cilantro? You won't after this. Oyster pancake - Move over pajun. You don't need to pay an arm and a leg to have this at a Korean restaurant. The oyster pancake was bursting with seafood freshness. Oily, filling, just the way I like it. For those who prefer a crisp and non oily version, I'm done with you.Pork chop over rice - Everyone in our party wanted it. So we asked for an entire huge bowl of it to share and got individual bowls of rice. This is what I'm talking about. The perfect crispy and flavorful skin leading way into the juicy meats. The bite sensation just separates it from the rest. Depending on my mood, better than sex.One thing did stink though. Oh you guessed it - stinky tofu. Might as well lose your stink tofu virginity here kids. Even though its not exactly the best, but whats a better time to have authentic stinky tofu than with all these other great dishes?If you know Chinese, the waitresses can be a hoot. But that's basically the gist for service in every Chinese restaurant. Whether you're a newbie to Taiwanese cuisine or a seasoned veteran searching for your favorite childhood eats that nai nai made, do give 66 a try.

<review# 419,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/14/2013,5/28/2013,364,373,10,16,15>Singlecut Beersmiths is a Home Run. This place is awesome. I am a strong supporter of local business and with beer being the product, well let me say that I will support every day.As I walked in, I felt I was at home. The brewery was very inviting with 6 communal tables that accommodate 10 fans each. A bar with 10 or so seats was on your left and a back bar where all the tasty beers are served. A band stand high above the crowd was cool across from the bar.Singlecut Beersmiths has five year round beers:Olympic White Larger - ABV 5.2%Queens Larger - ABV 5.4%Mahogany Ale - ABV 6.0%18 Watt IPA Billy - ABV 5.0%Half Stack IPA Billy - ABV 6.6%Now to critique beer from a brewery is very personal. Not everyone will like everything, but some beers stand out better than others. With this said I enjoy the brewery experience. The passion that employees and ownership have for their product, is no different from a parent has for their child. They are proud to serve their beers.I am a big fan of IPA's for their distinct taste. It has a full body with that hop and bitter taste. They are well balanced and I just find them tasty. The Billy IPA Half Stack does not disappoint. It was just delicious. The beer was served a bit cold, but as you let it open up, the flavors will come out. It has a nice finish and you can have more than one easily.Overall, this brewery is awesome. Plenty of space to chill and enjoy some delicious beer. The music is at the right level and they play records. Yes records with that crisp sound. I enjoy the brewery experience for various reasons, but to have one 3 miles away in my hood, outstanding. Singlecut Beersmiths is doing things right and I will support their Tap Room. Their beers are good and tasty. Good job Singlecut Beersmiths.

(Chicken on the run) was pretty damned good. The waiter (ever helpful) explained to us that it was "chicken that's made.. well, on the run.. Pretty quick with peppers and onions and olives. I think it's a real hidden gem on this menu." Boy, I'm not sure why it isn't more popular. The chicken was perfectly moist, the peppers were delicious and this disappeared damned quick. Once it was gone, the french fries were promptly dunked into it. And the fried yucca. And the rice. 4.75/5Sweet plantains were moist and sweet. I've had this dish several times and it's always been either too dry or too sweet. Not this time. Definitely get this as a side. 5/5I'm afraid we had no room for dessert, but not to worry. This will surely be updated soon when I bring my family to enjoy this spot. Definitely a new go-to.
<review# 424,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/20/2014,4/20/2014,324,115,10,14,12>I must visit Astoria pizza about 4-6 times a month. Every time I have visited, the service has been quick and the pizza hot/flavorful. The overall appearance from the outside and in, isn't anything impressive...heck it's a bit depressing haha. Also, although the service is quick, I will agree with some other Yelpers that the employees aren't up for any awards for personality/friendliness either! What matters to me in the end though, is their cheese and their pepperoni slices. After trying all of the other pizzerias from 28th street to 45th street on 30th avenue, Astoria Pizza (aka Halal Pizza) is by far the landslide winner! This very unassuming and small hole in the wall of a place dishes out some quality pizza. The sauce is flavorful and not overly sweet and/or runny, there's just the right amount of cheese, and the crust is moderately thin and has a bit of a crunch. Also, let me clarify, I've had Astoria Pizza late at night while drunk off my ass, AND dead sober during the week, and I still thought it was the best! Finally, does it pass the "fold test" ultimately??....meaning, does it fold well and not become a runny and disgusting mess that drips all over your plate/hands??Absolutely passes with flying colors! The entire pizza stays intact from the first to the last bite. Now ask yourself this: when have you had a great slice of pizza that doesn't pass at least the "fold test"?? "Fuget-About-It"!!So overall, I'm not saying it's the best pizza in NYC, but it's definitely the best pizza in this area in my opinion. I absolutely recommend this place to all of my fellow Yelpers!

You could eat most of it with an spoon. It is that melting-in-your-mouth kind of amazing food. Except for the meat around the large bone which deserves its own mention. I can't get enough of this dish.Even if sushi and sashimi seems to attract most of clientele at first (and everyone should surely give it multiple tries), Takesushi offer also a wide variety of "everyday" Japanese dishes from tempura, udon and donburi among others. I get particularly delighted with their fish offering. Whether is sashimi and sushi or the aforementioned Toro kama together with the Grilled Spanish Mackerel, Tuna tartare, Monkfish liver or Octopus vinegar (Tako) the quality of the fish is beyond excellent. Cooked on a simple way to fully experience quality, but reaching perfection at the same time on the seasoning to enhance the flavor, Takesushis's account among the most enjoyable food all around, and not only in Sunnyside I would dare to say. Curious about this place, it happens that the owner is no joke about fish (findeatdrink.com/Index/R). He is been for over 35 years in the import-export fish industry in this area. It is no surprise that he surely knows the best to offer not only at the current location, but previously with equal success. Take a look: yelp.com/biz/takesushi-n. As we all know (or realize over time) "wisdom comes with age" ** and so it is in the kitchen. Service is friendly and charming. I love how nothing seems enough for them to please you. Even when due to lack of communication between them, mistakes happens, the house make it up for you. The times that I have get take out, you can have a seat while enjoying hot tea and water. Always an smile. The space is simply decorated, clean and bright and always buzzing on clientele, which I hope will continue in a similar way for the longest time. What if you are not in the neighborhood often? should you "bother" and make the trip?. Let me challenge you. Go, try (at least) the Toro Kama and tell me later if you still need an answer to such a question. ** intentionally ignoring what is certainly truth as well by Oscar Wilde "With age comes wisdom, but sometimes age comes alone"

<review# 433,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/4/2014,11/8/2014,104,231,5,8,7>I've been there twice and both times the food was good and plentiful.I'm guessing this restaurant is relatively unknown right now since the 2x's we went on a Friday evening at 7p and there were only 2 other tables or less of diners when we arrived. As much as I would like to keep this hidden gem to myself, I also want to spread the word so they stay in business!The waitstaff are young but so friendly and so courteous. We had dinner with our rambunctious 16 month old child and they were always accommodating with our requests for extra bowls, napkins and high chair. I try my best to clean up after her but she is at a stage where a quarter of her meal usually winds up on the ground or in her seat.The servers are pretty good at describing the dishes and making general recommendations which is very helpful when trying new ethnic cuisines. If you are coming with a group, the meat lovers dish is great for sharing. It comes with about 5 different kabobs and a GINORMOUS platter of rice. They even let us customize the kabobs and rice. We definitely prefer their lamb over the beef. This dish is probably good for 3-4 people. The kabobs are very well seasoned and flavorful. Everything we have tried so far has been very moist and not dried out which can often be the case with grilled meats. Entrees come with a salad, choice of rice and roasted tomatoes and thinly sliced onions. The salad is simple but very delicious with their yogurt dressing. My hubby likes to douse the rest of his food with the dressing as it adds a nice tang to contrast with the other spices and flavors. The 2 different table sauces are also very good. Not exactly sure what they are except that one is red and the other green.On our last visit we figured we would give dessert a try. We got the baklava and pistachio ice cream. The baklava was okay. Not very big for $6. The pistachio ice cream was not your typical pistachio. It was actually a cream color -- a plus that it doesn't have food coloring and had a decent amount of mint mixed it. I wasn't really a fan of the texture or flavor. Both would be a pass for me in the future and I would have rather not finished the meal on a down note. Even still, this is a great little restaurant and will be on our list of neighborhood good eats.

I can have it for lunch today!!! Finally, the coconut tapioca pudding $5 -- SO GOOD! It isn't blended perfectly, but the flavor is good and refreshing.Service: 4 StarsThe service (considering how busy it is), is pretty good the majority of the time. You will see more servers helping you with your needs during peak hours, but pre/post-rush hour service becomes a bit more lackadaisical.We had a hard time getting the attention of a server during our last visit, but I'm not going to let that change my overall views because of my previous experiences.Ambiance: 3.5 Stars (Will be higher after construction is complete)Mad for Chicken has gone through a lot of changes in the last few months. They are currently expanding (It may be completed by now as I ate there in August) and there was quite a bit construction noises in the background during my meal. Gone are the little TV's in the wall and the small walking space between the tables. Everything is a lot more crisp an open. The bar is spacious, the TV's are huge, refrigerated drinks are in an easy location for the employees to reach instead of being next directly behind one of the dining tables. Overall: 4 StarsOnce construction is completed I believe the restaurant will be very accommodating to all patrons and cut down waiting times significantly. The enlarged menu is another worry because it is 3-4 times larger than their original menu. It will be harder for the chefs to handle such a significant increase in dishes and a dining room that will have doubled in size.The recipe for the chicken has changed a handful of times, which worries me a little because the overall flavor of the chicken has dropped since I started eating here originally.It is (in my opinion) the best fried chicken in the area.

<review# 441,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/26/2014,7/2/2014,186,102,5,10,7>Our 15 year old cat, Bella, somehow injured one of her back legs yesterday.  She was limping pretty badly.  We decided to wait until morning to see if it improved, since she wasn't wincing or meowing when she stepped on the leg.  Unfortunately, the limp hadn't improved over night, so we decided to take her in to be seen.We adopted Bella from my husband's sister a few years ago, and we did yet not have a veterinarian for her in Astoria.  We checked Yelp for veterinarian's in the area, and decided on Steinway Court Veterinarian, due to the many 5-star reviews.  Their office opened at 8:30 this morning, but we were anxious, so we called a little early.  Not only did they pick up the phone before their business hours, but the woman who answered the phone was extremely friendly.  We asked if they saw walk-ins, and she told us we could come right in.  When we got there, she welcomed us in, and got the paperwork started right away. We were there by 9:00, and Bella was being seen by Dr. Glasser by 9:08.Bella is an extremely friendly, well-tempered old kitty, but she was very scared.  She hissed a lot, and did a good share of growling.  I was absolutely blown away by Dr. Glasser's "bedside manner."  He talked to Bella the whole time, telling her he understood that she was scared and hurting, but that everything was going to be ok.  He warned us that she might get pretty loud when he checks her leg, but that he was going to be very thorough.  His concern for our feelings made quite an impression on us.  Bella had no broken bones, so we are going to wait to see if it heals on it's own.  He did notice some problems with her eyes, and told us, after examining them, that she has retinal disease.  He explained everything very clearly to us, asked us several times if we had any questions, and never once made us feel bad for not having her in for a checkup before now.  In addition, his veterinary assistant was incredibly gentle and kind to Bella.I have never had such a fantastic experience at a veterinary clinic before.  We will definitely be taking Bella here for her routine checkups from now on.  I HIGHLY recommend Dr. Glasser and his staff to anyone with a pet.  His passion, care, and concern for animals is apparent and exceptional.
<review# 442,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/13/2014,7/1/2014,62,321,12,10,8>My wife and I walked past this place one night and it was devoid of life but for who I assume is the family that runs it sitting in the back looking forlornly toward the door, begging us with their eyes to enter. Sometimes in life you have to throw caution to the wind and judge a book by its cover. If we're not supposed to, as the cliche instructs, then what's the point of having book covers at all? Their very existence hinges on pertinently reflecting the content of the books they embrace. I mean, it's not as if you'd ever see a picture of Captain Ahab hunting a ham sandwich on the cover of Moby Dick now, would you? Though, to be fair, I think that would make for a far more interesting novel. So we did not enter that empty restaurant.But the vision of that huddled little Venezuelan family kept gnawing at my conscience. I finally gave in and ordered takeout. I tell you this culinary experience was like seeing a likeness of the Virgin Mary toasted into the bottom of your tortilla. Spiritual, surprising, thoroughly delicious and unmistakably South American. The Arepa Pabellon, veggie arepa, Pabellon Criollo and Pabellon de Pollo were all so incredible I wanted to run down the street to that little plaza storefront, fall to my knees, kiss their shoes and apologize in person for my hasty judgment. The stewed chicken and beef were impossibly tender and served up with a huge helping of sweet black beans, rice and creamy fried plantain. The veggie arepa was loaded with fresh avocado, black beans and plantain as well and perfectly accompanied by a tropical fruit salsa with heat that made my eyes water- though I may have been weeping for joy. The joy of having discovered this food. The joy that comes with knowing I had righted a terrible wrong. So please...I beg of you Yelpers...support this family. Support this restaurant and try this food. And for the love of god, will someone please write a sequel to Moby Dick featuring a ham sandwich.

<review# 444,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/15/2014,6/29/2014,152,243,7,9,8>This review is only about Weekend Lunch Buffet: $16.16 per person. Wear your Thanksgiving pants! It's gonna be a pork-a-thon. I really can't think of any, so plus one there. Two, a Filipino Buffet, never heard of such a thing! Plus two! The buffet is under $20 per person, OMG, really under $20 sometimes I can't even eat lunch for under $20, this place is heaven!Come one, come all, and most of all come hungry. Warning Filipino food can be fatty, so be ready with the heart burn medicine.The food is good, not the best but really good, on par with other Filipino restaurants and did I say it was a buffet!! The lechon, can be a little dry but put with some sauce with it. What is Lechon, you ask? It's a whole roasted pig, head and all! Usually I don't get this unless it's a huge party, so it's a huge treat for me to see it at the buffet line. The selection of food changes from time to time and it isn't labelled so have a veteran help you out if your new to Filipino food. FYI, for my peanut allergy people out there, there is one dish called Kare Kare that has peanut butter in it. Ask the servers to point it out to you, to prevent any unwanted attacks. Not the cleanest looking place, the floors are a little sticky but that's the charm. The country of the Philippines isn't a wealthy nation and thus our restaurant aren't super fancy and rightfully so. The restaurant and pastry shop downstairs correctly celebrate our culture. Go, Eat and Be Merrily Filipino for an hour or two!

<review# 449,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/17/2014,6/24/2014,406,1092,6,8,6>Good ramen in Queens? Can it be true?! I was intrigued and have been wanting to try this place out, so of course I did. The place is fairly modern & industrial. Japanese art plastered on the walls. Simple wooden tables, beer-garden style and 2-person tables. In the front is an 8-person table and several 2-person tables. Additional seating is found in the back with 2 more 8-person tables and a couple smaller tables. If at all possible, I'd try to sit in the front. The back smelled like old socks. In between the two dining areas, is the open-layout kitchen and a waiting area. While you wait for your table, you can watch the chefs work their magic.For appetizers, we started with their Pork Gyoza, which includes 4 gyozas in a thin skin filled with primarily ground pork and scallions, then complimented with a small side of soy sauce. The skins were crispy, meat flavorful, making for a fairly good gyoza, but somewhat pricey and standard-fare. We also ordered the Pork Belly Kimchi which was top-notch. The kimchi was fermented nicely to give it a nice pickled (sour) flavor, with a hint of heat. The chunks of pork belly really took it over the top. For those not aware, this dish is garnished with katsuobushi (bonito flakes), which some may find weird as they move around. But don't worry, they are not alive, but just curling up caused by the heat. If you're looking for an appetizer, the Pork Belly Kimchi is a must-try.I tried their house special ramen, Hinomaru Ramen ($13.00) with Poached Egg (+$1.50). This consists of creamy pork broth with 2 slices of chasu (pork belly), kikurage, scallions, menma (fermented bamboo shoots), bean sprouts, a fish cake with a monkey face on it, nori (seaweed), and then topped with a fireball. What is a fireball? It's a ball of spicy ground meat thrown on top. Take a small bite and you'll realize it's got some heat. Not mouth-numbing, but enough to get your palate going. Mix it in with the broth to give it an added layer of flavor and spiciness. The pork broth is not overly rich, but complex and flavorful enough to give it two thumbs up. Definitely my preferred consistency of broth. Don't expect your modern clean-palate broth that Ippudo makes. The ramen noodles are your thin and straight kind, soft yet firm to give it some texture. They were not bloated, signifying that they were not sitting in the broth for a long time in the kitchen, but soaked enough of the broth to give it good flavor. If you're more into the bouncy and curly ramen noodles (like the one's in instant noodle packs), ask the staff which ramen dishes offers those noodles. The two pieces of pork belly were amazing! Tender and flavorful, and the fat on the belly was gelatinous, almost jello like. Delicious!! I didn't think it could get any better, but the poached egg was divine. When I think of a poached egg, I usually think that it's somewhat solidified with a creamy yolk. However, this completely blew me by surprise. The egg white was blob-like yet cooked enough to preserve the the yellow yolk inside. It was so delicate, bordering liquefied. When I put my chopstick through the egg, the yellow yolk oozed out in liquid form. It was soooooo good!!! I have no idea how they could poach their eggs so perfectly but I am a huge fan and will be ordering their poached egg with my ramen every time I come here. Everything about the Hinomaru Ramen screamed delicious. Balanced, rich flavors, fatty pork, liquefied egg, mmmm...... I'm definitely a fan of HinoMaru and will be back soon. Our waitress was really cool when she greeted us informally like old friends. And when she brought over several pairs of missing chopsticks, she said "My Bad!". Great ramen and table service. There's nothing not to like. Check it out if you haven't already!! And don't forget the poached egg!!

<review# 458,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/10/2014,10/13/2014,115,200,5,9,8>Not sure what I like more- things that have cute animal mascots or things that involve bears. I really like the name of this place Big Bear because their logo features a chubby funny looking bear drinking a bubble tea. my elmhurst friend told me about this place and we just wanted somewhere to catch up and sit for awhile. She suggested big bear and once the words came out of her mouth I was totally interested.came in here and already overwhelmed about what kind of toppings and crepe I wanted to get. Their crepes come in two catagories- japanese and rice flour. The japanese crepe is supposedly softer and features whipped cream as one of the toppings. The cream can be vanilla, green tea or you can substitute low fat yogurt. The rice flour crepe is a little crispier and is served warm and cannot be ordered with cream because the cream may melt. Most of the crepes here are sweet crepes and they only have one savory crepe- the volcano crepe which I was told was very spicy. The sweet crepes have toppings like sliced almonds, crushed oreo, nutella, caramel, chocolate sauce and mango, bananas or strawberries. I tried the featured crepe which was called the Naughty Monkey and it came with crushed oreos, cream, bananas, almonds and chocolate sauce. The crepe can be served in a cone shaped sleeve or folded into a plastic take out container. We ate in the store and it was served on a single paper plate nothing fancy as long as it didnt break under the usage of my knife and fork. None of these are gourmet ingredients and the crepes are not overwhelmingly large just big enough for a snack or a sugar fix. There is also a bunch of bubble tea drinks mostly green, milk and black teas and matcha, caramel, thai, taro, mango and passion fruit flavor as well. I ordered a passion fruit green tea and my yelp check in scored me a topping of fruit jelly. They also have regular tapioca boba, passion fruit popping boba, coffee jelly, matcha pudding and they even have grass jelly even though its not on the menu. I asked what the big bear tea was and was told it was traditional black milk tea.there is only seating for about 8 people in here at all times since it is mostly cafe chairs and cafe tables and a long bench. At the time I came only a demure looking little lady was staffing the store. She takes the orders and makes the crepes/drinks so be prepared to wait. Overall a nice little addition to the elmhurst area for crepes and bubble tea.
<review# 459,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/30/2014,10/12/2014,393,406,14,21,18>This location was a staid looking Italian restaurant for many years, but when Il Falco opened, we thought it was worth a try last night. I'm very glad we did.When you walk in, you are greeted by approximately 35 folks in tuxedos. This place is wildly overstaffed, but everyone was very friendly. We opted to sit on the back patio since it was a beautiful night.When we sat, before getting menus, we were offered drinks and given complimentary bruschetta. That was not something I'm used to but it helped set the tone for a relaxed meal. The bruschetta was excellent - I don't normally love tomatoes, but these were delicious and it was loaded with fresh garlic.Our waiter was super old-school and seemed to be from South America but had an Italian shtick going with long, drawn out "grazies." He was very nice and sold us on all sorts of fun dishes.We started with 6 enormous Blue Point oysters. Quite delicious. Next, we had a special side - pappardelle with red sauce, mushrooms, and sweet sausage. It was truly remarkable. The sauce was light but complex, and the dish came together very, very well. The pasta was also clearly homemade and wonderful.For dinner, I had a bone-in veal chop stuffed with homemade mozzarella, spinach, and surrounded in a mushroom cream sauce. It was outstanding. A dish like that can easily become overwhelming or sloppy, but this had some seriously good flavor and nuance. My wife got the whole branzino, which was presented for show then de-boned and served with very light seasoning. It was perfectly cooked and we both liked it a lot.We were too full for dessert, but were given complimentary dessert wine when we were done.If I have any critique of Il Falco, it is the dissonance within the restaurant, and to the surrounding neighborhood. As I mentioned, this place has way, way too many people working for the number of tables. Everyone is in tuxedos, but only about half of the staff clearly has fine dining experience. Those that do come across as very old-school waiters (in a good way), but others feel like they are playing dress up and seem nervous. Similarly, this place has patio dining, a small seating area, and is in an area of LIC filled with semi-casual diners likely to be in jeans. It remains to be seen if that will end up clashing with tuxedoed waiters serving $30+ entrees. I never felt underdressed or that a single person was snobby, but it does present a bit of a mismatch.All that being said, our meal and service were wonderful and I can't wait to go back.

<review# 467,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/13/2012,11/7/2012,42,38,3,8,4>One of the most overlooked kebab houses in NYC. Located literally a stone's throw from the last stop on the Queens side of the N train, a hike to Balkh Shish is definitely worth it.Balkh Shish is the most authentic Afghan food you will get outside of Kabul. Upon entering the restaurant, the grill and brick oven are to your left and pictures of every Afghan president are on your right. Once you are seated, two tv's showing Afghan programming ensure you are never bored. The pictures of Afghanistan and the map of the country with its provinces outlined also make for interesting decor.I always start off with the samosa. The samosa is fried to a crispy perfection and the ground beef inside of the pastry is seasoned with blends of saffron, cumin, and tumeric. A chilled glass of sweet lassi, which consists of yogurt and dough, is the perfect companion for the samosa.For the main course, I usually get the salmon kebab or the chicken kofta palow. The salmon is simply grilled and marinated in lemon juice, saffron, and cheyenne pepper and served with Afghan brown rice and fresh salad. The chicken kofta palow is basically two enormous chunks of ground chicken drowned in brown Afghan rice and accompanied with a generous helping of traditional Afghan chicken curry. The curry is the perfect texture and goes great with the dry chunks of ground chicken. The Afghan bread is toasted to perfection and the white sauce they serve is homemade and cools down the spicy taste in your mouth.To top off the evening, I usually get the Firni, which is traditional rice pudding. The pudding itself is a piece of art, topped with pistachios and creamy. Down the pudding with green tea and your night is complete. The service is great and the servings are plentiful. Be prepared to leave with a doggie bag and you might want to walk around the block a few times before hopping on the train.
<review# 468,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/29/2011,11/6/2012,203,182,4,6,6>Burgers are big business these days in NYC, and come in all stripes. You got your horseradish-cheddar cheeseburgers at Black Iron Burger; the Breslin's famous lamb burger; or DuMont's signature sandwich.But at this throwback to 1980s Yugoslavia, you can try something bigger, and arguably better: pljeskavica, a dinner-plate-sized burger of beef, pork, veal and fatty lamb sandwiched between two buttery halves of pita. (I can't be completely certain of the meats in this particular burger, but those are the usual suspects in 'Balkan burgers.')To up the flavor factor, you'll want to smear on some smooth kajmak, a sour-cream-like spread with a lactic tang, and ajvar, a roasted red pepper and olive oil paste. Then, dig in and let those juices flow. (from your mouth, and dripping from the burger) If you feel the need for a little greenery, a side salad, simply dressed with oil, vinegar and salt, comes for an additional $2 -- at $12, this is an unbeatable price for a burger and salad.There are a few nice sidewalk tables, where my friend and I sat. Indoors, it's red vinyl booths and wood paneling--it almost seems as if you've walked into someone's dining nook. And that's how you'll be served, too--as if you're a friend of the family, just stopping by for a quick bite and something to drink. The friendly waitress is Bosnian and informed us that some 5000 Bosnians live in Astoria alone, though she said that many of the once plentiful Bosnian restaurants, like this one, have been closing their doors lately. Let's make sure that doesn't happen to Stari Most.
<review# 469,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/11/2012,11/5/2012,2,5,4,8,7>A few weeks ago, I had my birthday party at Butcher Bar, and I can not say enough about how spectacular my experience was.I had a party of about 30 people and they let me use their back patio for an entire afternoon.  Teddy, the manager, was so kind and really great as my plans changed and numbers increased.  Everything went smoothly and everyone had a great time.  Since the place is BYOB, I asked my guests to bring whatever beer/wine they wanted to drink.  The managers and waitstaff were so unbelievably accommodating!!  They kept our beers/wines in their fridge, got rid of all our empty bottles, and kept our drinks cold and full the entire day.Our waitress, Anna, was unreal.  She was so sweet, patient and absolutely awesome to us.  My guests all came at different times and she made sure everyone was fed and had drinks, and she even took it upon herself to make sure our little cooler stayed full of ice and beers without anyone asking her to do so.  Even though we were a chill and friendly bunch, I know how much of a pain in the ass a group like ours is, so MEGA PROPS to her for being so amazing.The food, as always, was delicious!  I had the pork belly, lettuce & tomato sandwich.  Yum!!  AND, to top it all off, they brought out a piece of cinnamon cake for everyone that was there (about 25 ppl) free of charge, to celebrate my birthday.  Candle, birthday song and a total surprise.  :-)  SO NICE!We were having such a wonderful time that the 10 of us left at the end of the party stayed well past out 4 hour window.  Even though the managers had every right to ask us to give up the table (I told them to let me know if they needed it) they didn't.  We felt so amazingly welcome, like we were in their backyard.  I put a lot of stock in how a business treats its clients/guests, and Butcher Bar is one of the best I've ever encountered.  They made my birthday so special and I will always be grateful.
<review# 470,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/11/2012,11/4/2012,11,6,2,7,4>I do not give out 5 stars that easily.This restaurant surpassed my expectations. Spanish food--particularly from the Andalusian and Galician regions of Spain hold a special place in my heart, and of course, my palate. I've been to Galician style cangrejadas, and have become well acquainted with Spanish paella thanks to our wonderful family friend Maria Belén--who lived almost all her life in Galicia. I will always be grateful to her for introducing me to the decadent pleasures of traditional Southern Spanish and Galician/Portuguese cuisine.We ordered a number of plates, and I sampled a little from each. I've had their Salmon and Spanish style capers and signature saffron yellow rice, Spanish blood sausage, their weekend special of slow roasted Pork, tongue appetizers, caramelized dates wrapped in bacon, and some salad mostly made up of mixed greens.If you're feeling adventurous--try the tongue. A cold, salty appetizer that has a hard, rubbery texture--as if you were biting into hard cheese in the beginning, but I promise you'll be surprised, and go in for a second, or maybe a third. My favorite appetizer though, are their dates wrapped in bacon. I don't have the vocabulary to describe the concoction of flavors that conspire to titillate your taste buds to gustatory orgasm! They are an absolute MUST.Of all I sampled, I have to say the quality of the food is amazing. Not to say I am a professional food taster--but the food is good enough, I believe one can tell it isn't bought from Key Food. The Salmon doesn't have a fishy smell, and the meat is so soft and very well seasoned it melts the moment you put it in your mouth. Their blood sausages are unlike any I have ever had--I love the sweet aftertaste and the soft texture, hinting its freshness.As for their drinks? I recommend their white Sangria. It has the gentle sweetness of Moscato wine, a known refreshing summer drink. With their golden yellow walls and rustic Spanish decor, you could almost escape the winter blues.The staff is attentive, friendly adding to the enjoyment of your experience.What can I say? You don't even eat THIS good in Manhattan. Eat better and for the quality of food you get--pay less. Come to La Rioja and buy a little bit of bohemian Southern Spain.
<review# 471,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/20/2013,3/24/2014,287,270,6,12,10>Hard to believe I haven't reviewed Astoria Bier and Cheese yet considering I practically live in there. Have a friend visiting from out of town whom you want to impress? Bring them to Astoria Bier and Cheese. Want to soften the painful effects of annoying relatives? Bring them to Astoria Bier and Cheese. Date? Bier and Cheese. Need some cheese/beer for a party you're throwing? You know what to do. It's pretty much the answer to everything.Though they don't have full on entrees, you can eat and drink pretty inexpensively here, and the service is pretty unbeatable. The guys and gals behind the counter are very enthusiastic about charcuterie, cheese, and beer so they are always happy to give you samples and help you choose your perfect cheese plate or grilled cheese sandwich. I literally go out of my way to come here when I am throwing a party to buy my cheeses since they are so eclectic and fresh. Not too many other places I can get truffle cheese. One of my favorite nights out is sitting in the back patio with friends noshing away at various plates of cheese, pickled onions, and charcuterie and sipping on various beers. They always have a great selection of beers on tap, and I almost always go for one of the IPAs because I'm a hop junkie. When I come here just with my boyfriend, we almost always get either two interesting grilled cheese sandwiches or a cheese plate, and split one of their snax (get the beer cheese and ale bread). One of the guys who works here has gotten to know us so well that he makes recommendations specific to our tastes when we come in.One of my favorite things about living in Astoria is coming here every once in a while and trying something new.
<review# 472,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/2/2013,3/23/2014,1007,752,13,13,12>"Wow that sh*t was good!", those were the words that kept coming out my mouth throughout the drive home.A buddy of mine who's from this area has been telling me about Los Verdes, Los Verdes non-stop over the past month so I finally gave it a shot today and it did not disappoint! The food looks and taste a whole lot better in person so please don't judge by the photos.Food - The Verdolaga burger is a beastly burger! This came to me as a real big surprise because it consist of a few things I usually hate.1. Sesame burger bun - I generally hate most sesame buns but at Los Verdes it works. It wasn't your commonly found cheap burger buns from Deli and Grill spots or Fast Food joints. The quality of the bun was great. Firm and toasty.2. Chicken breast - Ask any asian, most of us hate white meat unless you're a fitness/health fanatic. We like our legs and thighs. By now, you're probably asking yourself "What? a Chicken burger?" and the answer is nope! That's not all!I usually dislike eating chicken breast. I don't mind eating it but I won't enjoy it. In this case, the chicken breast in this burger works! Chicken breast was nice and tender, not over cooked, and not super dry.3. Ham - I like ham but was never too crazy about it but...in this case, it works! 4. Burger Patty - Excellent. Nicely cooked (I asked for Medium), Juicy patty, great flavor.5. Bacon - Self-Explanatory. Bacon is bacon, that stuff is crack! Nuff said.All topped with pebble size chips which I like to refer to as "sprinkled crack", mozzarella cheese and cole slaw! Now is that a burger or what?! It also comes with wavy fries which I also usually hate because it reminds me of crappy soggy school and white castle fries. But the fries here were actually legit! Golden crispy fries!We also ordered a chicken quesadilla which was also great. They weren't cheap with the cheese and it was also topped with sprinkled crack. Freakin delicious!Drinks - Ordered a Blackberry juice w/ no ice. Good taste, didn't taste watered down.Service - Excellent. Our waitress was very friendly and fast with our order.Verdict - By far the cleanest restaurant I've been to in long time in this part of Queens. Freakin place looked spotless. The restroom was super clean and even had a TV in there. There are plenty of flat screen TV's that run along the walls in the restaurant. If you haven't been to Los Verdes yet, make sure you bookmark it and order their Verdologa burger. You will have an orgasmic experience running through your mouth! I'm putting this burger on top of my list. As of now, this is my favorite burger of all time.
<review# 473,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/16/2013,3/22/2014,127,319,5,14,8>There are two things I really appreciate in life: Good Company and GROUPON! We used a Groupon deal for 4 and I haven't had so much fun eating my food in such a long time. Simply Fondue is also one of the cutest places I have ever gone to. This is my second time going to a fondue place and I recommend this place over Max Brenner in the city. The decor is VERY ROMANTIC with comfy booths. It's CASH ONLY, but they have an ATM inside. Our 3 hour dinner consisted of 5 rounds:FIRST ROUND: Calamari Appetizer (which the waiter totally forgot about), but no worries! He apologized and we were cool about it. It was actually a blessing in disguise that it was cancelled because our main courses were very filling. ROUND 2: Each of us got a salad. I HIGHLY recommend the Spinach & Strawberry. This was actually the highlight out of my whole entire meal. They used a unique sweet cider dressing that was AWESOME! ROUND 3: We ordered 2 Cheese Fondues (Spicy Pepper Jack and Mediterranean) served with bread, raw vegetables, and fruits. Personally, I liked the Mediterranean more because I like pesto and sun-dried tomato. With both dishes, they started heating up beer with garlic and and then they slowly added different cheeses and other ingredients together and mixed it up. Round 4: You get to choose a specific cooking style with your entree. Our entrees consisted of a combination of chicken breast, beef tenderloin, black tiger shrimps, scallops (super small by the way)  and veggies and we chose the Vegetable Bouillon (which is a garlic and spice broth) and a Cajun broth as our cooking method. It basically mimics an Asian Hot Pot style, where you dip your raw meats into a boiling broth pot. They provide 5 dipping sauces as well (honey mustard, curry (my favorite), ranch, asian style sesame dressing, and teriyaki sauce). It was okay, but I didn't think the broth was strong enough. It was also a total mess because the food kept slipping off the skewers and we basically had to scoop our food out with a spoon. Fun times though because it was like a mini treasure hunt in our pot. Next time, I might go with the Fondue Grill cooking style.Round 5: By the time we hit round 5, I felt like I was going to roll out of the restaurant. But we still ordered 2 chocolate fondue pot: one white (Bananas Foster Fondue) and one dark (Raspberry Cabernet) and they lighted both of them up! I find white chocolate to be too sweet for me, but the Bananas Foster Fondue actually become my favorite! It wasn't overwhelmingly sweet and it was topped with bananas! YUM. I can pass on the raspberry cabernet.OTHER THOUGHTS: 1) I couldn't stop chuckling when I went to the lady's room. The stalls were spacious I thought it was really cool that there was a metal hand reaching out from the floor with fingers wrapped around in toilet paper rolls. GENIUS!2) It also seems like Simply Fondue had karaoke nights there. I found it very odd because it didn't fit with the place. Throughout dinner, we had random people singing completely off-pitch, which was a little bit annoying.

<review# 475,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/9/2014,3/20/2014,681,925,10,13,12>For both the business-to-business and business-to-consumer segments of my business, it is crucial that my marketing collateral is high-quality and professional looking.  What is distributed to clients often leaves a lasting impression and is very much part of creating a public image for the company, for the brand.  I've tried to have leaflets, brochures, and recipe cards printed "on the cheap" through Vistaprint, and what a nightmare that was.  The customer service was non-existent and the quality was reminiscent of dot matrix printers from 1992.  Let's not visit those bad memories (of Vistaprint, not 1992) and instead talk about Prestone Printing.Wanting to support a local Queens business, I contacted Prestone for a variety of print jobs I needed to have done: postcards, holiday greeting cards to send to clients, and customer loyalty "punch" cards.  I had very tight deadlines for all of these print jobs and was worried that I would be spending quite a bit to have everything expedited.  Enter Carlos and the team at Prestone Printing.  After requesting quotes for each of the projects, Prestone was the most economical option!  And if you want to see your emails responded to at the speed of light, definitely contact Carlos.  Whenever I had a question, whether it be about card stock availability or getting my print job a day early, there would be a response from Carlos in my inbox 5 minutes after I had sent him an email.  And talk about great service: it can be difficult to park in this rather industrial area of Long Island City, not to mention carry numerous boxes filled with 40 pounds worth of printing (especially since I had injured my arm at the time...lifting heavy wine boxes).  Carlos and his colleague made sure that my car was safely double-parked in front of Prestone's offices and loaded my car with all of the boxes.So now that you know that the customer service is fantastic, how does what REALLY counts when it comes to impressing clients (the marketing collateral) look?  Prestone created sharp, professional, and vibrant materials.  In fact, I was so pleased (and many customers as well) with the work that Prestone has done that I will be commissioning them to print an additional 1,000 postcards, a paella recipe leaflet, and business cards for my entire team.  And those are just the current projects on the horizon!If you need further evidence that Prestone is THE print shop to use if you're looking for affordable, yet high-quality materials with outstanding customer service, visit the Prestone website.  Prestone has managed to keep an impressive client list pleased with the excellent work that they do.
<review# 476,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/12/2013,3/19/2014,105,138,5,10,8>4.5 if they keep up the good work!Food Bazaar is in the midst of their Grand Opening.  And it is surely grand.  This place is HUGE.  After an hour and 15 mins in this place I had to leave and still didn't see the whole of it.  It's taken the place of the old Pathmark (and good riddance to that dump).  The layout is very unusual.  You're met with large produce meat and seafood areas followed by a separate section of rows and rows of grocery on a diagonal.  I was giddy as a school girl.I immediately fell in love with the fresh produce.  I'm talking your everyday fruit/veggies like berries, apples, potatoes, oranges followed by Japanese pears, dragon fruit, star fruit, passion fruit, kumquats, an entire row of chilies, aloe vera and loads more.  The meat?  Amazing selection with a butcher counter and rows of refrigerated and frozen.  Ox tail, chicken feet, an entire case of different kinds of ribs.  The seafood?  A counter where they cleaned the fish I chose myself from three rows, a live crab tank, whole fish, fish filets, frozen items, fresh items.  And tons of it!I don't know if it'll be a regular thing, but there were many sample tables going including a fresh sashimi tasting.  He sliced the fish right off the filet for us.  Yum!  I hope they start selling sushi grade fish for us sushi-at-home makers.  The manager said they were hoping to soon.There are multiple "International" rows of exciting products.  It seems this Food Bazaar is Asian owned and operated so the Asian selections was comparable to Hong Kong Supermarket and other like it.  But there was also an excellent selection of Latin American products.  The only reason it falls short (at this moment) of a perfect 5 stars is that the organic dairy, chicken and eggs options/prices is a little scant and expensive.  $5.49 for a half gallon of organic milk, though not surprising, is pricey and I may still do the dairy and chicken shopping at TJs or WFs.  But if this place had reasonably priced organics as well, then look out!  I will be a regular shopper and, fingers crossed, hope to award that final star.
<review# 477,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/6/2014,3/18/2014,102,494,6,11,8>Assuming that you have access to a car, do yourself a favor and avoid the aneurism that is attempting to go to the TJ's in Manhattan and drive out to Rego Park to hit this TJ's. While it can still get unwieldy on the weekends and peak hours, it is still SO MUCH EASIER to shop here than in any of the Manhattan locations.FOOD: in the world of supermarket food (not the super fresh stuff you can get from your local bakery, butcher, etc.), TJ's tends to deliver. Their produce, meat, and dairy are all fresh and high quality. They also offer some "ready to make" fresh items like a pork roast that's already seasoned and sauced, chicken tenders in pesto and marinara sauce, etc. Their "processed" (frozen) food is made with organic ingredients, and almost always turns out well. They cover many categories of frozen food including Indian, Mexican, Chinese, etc. I absolutely love their selection of fresh stuffed pastas. One package generally feeds two people, and I believe the most expensive one is $3.99. PRICES: speaking of the most expensive package of fresh pasta ringing in at $3.99, you will almost always be able to purchase a TON of food for less than $80-$100. If you're buying their coffee, that can sometimes run up your total at the end, but the prices here are just great. The last time I made a TJ's run was at least three weeks ago, and we still have food from that run (obviously of the frozen and dry variety). Since everything is so cheap, you won't hesitate to try new things.BEER/WINE: most people know TJ's as the origin of "two buck chuck" (which by the way, is actually $2.99), but this TJ's does NOT have the accompanying wine store. That said, it does have a decent selection of craft beers as well as its own brand of beers. I tend to always go for the TJ brand of Hefeweizen or something else that catches my eye because it tends to be around $5.99 to $6.99 for a 6-pack, and often tastes better than the 6-pack you'll get at your corner store for $10.99.SERVICE: the cashiers at the front are very quick, and often make fast work of long lines when they form. The people on the floor generally tend to be running around stocking things, and I don't think I've ever had an actual conversation with anyone in trying to find something. That said, my shopping style is "I can find it on my own thank you very much," so it doesn't bother me, but might bother someone who's attempting to ask them something.Overall, love TJ's, and this is my favorite TJ's in the city. I've walked into Manhattan locations only to see the line stretching all the way to the back of the store and around, and have just walked back out. Not to mention it feels like a game of roller derby without the skates or the awesome trying to actually shop in the Manhattan TJ's.
<review# 478,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/19/2013,3/17/2014,65,227,4,10,7>This place is super affordable and delicious! For a Friday, this place was packed every minute, with lines out the door. And it seems to be authentic since I see many Filipino families dining here. My friend and I only got drinks, entrees and a dessert. I got the calamansi drink and it was refreshing. It was very fragrant and citrusy. For the main dish, I got the beef kaldareta and my friend got Tito's chicken. The kaldereta was super delicious. It's a beef stew cooked with olives and spices. I was hesitant in ordering the dish because it was stewed in olives, and I don't really like them, but I didn't really taste them. Instead, it was tomatoey, a tad spicy and full of other spices. It's similar to a beef stew, but far more tasty. There were huge chunks of beef, but it melts in your mouth.My friend's chicken on the other hand was too salty. It was prepared with black bean sauce and soy sauce. It you like salty foods, this might be your thing, but for us, it wasn't that good at all. For dessert, skip the halo halo. I find it to be very bland and all it tasted like was sweet ice water. It was not even very sweet at that. I'm not sure how halo halo is really supposed to taste like, but I've had it at Jolibee's and that place definitely has much better halo halo. Although theirs is a bit sweet, the part that I like most is that it's chunkier. The halo at Rad's was just watery. The turnover time at this place takes forever, and that can be due to the fact that a lot of the tables accommodate 4 people. So I noticed that there were a couple of tables that had empty spots, but nothing can be done. I just hope they use more appropriate tables as an upgrade so that no space is wasted, and the place is quite small.I give this place a 4 for the awesome beef kaldereta, and the fact that there are many more things on the menu that I'd like to try, especially given the very affordable prices for the portion.

Definitely not.Sweetleaf is better known as a place for coffee & tea, which happen to be extremely good as well in all the other locations I have try. Who would have tell they do such a wonderful work when in speakeasy/lounge mode. During my very good friend's birthday gathering a couple of months ago, we had for our party the small room in the back. Exquisitely decorated on a vintage style, great music, cushion sofas and easily accommodating about 10-12 people. In spite of being located at the back of the place with no chance of communication with the servers other than getting out of there, that situation didn't happen at all in the entire time we were there. This speak itself about the service at Sweetleaf. Every once in a while we had our waitress coming to check on us for anything we demand. Not only her, but all the staff is friendly and pleasant. Since Sweetleaf is a master on all things coffee, my choices were on the caffeinated side of the menu, of course they serve homemade coffee liquor. "Kona Swizzle" was equally good and fun at the same time. I loved the display on a tall glass, beautifully glowing on a golden color and filled up with ice. Repeating on the rum and coffee liquor, Kona Swizzle contains also fresh lime juice, definitely noticeable and that  matched so well and house mad orgeat, which I just found out is a syrup made from almonds, sugar and orange flower water. I like everything almond and now I recall that taste on the drink. Lovely. My friends went with more classic type of drinks and all were excellent. Balanced, flavorful, strong on the right way and served with lots of personality. If you are a speakeasy chaser and heard of  Dutch Kills you then know what to expect from Sweetleaf since they collaborate with Dutch kills's cocktail master on their creations. You see? they are, that good. The difficulty to get there this days is obvious because MTA seems to be boycotting any trip in the city, but particularly to LIC lately. Even so, don't give up. Plan your trip a bit in advance if you need to get there on a specific time, get your smart phone ready to google map, enjoy the wonderful views of the city that never sleeps while walking towards Sweetleaf door .. and put yourself similarly in a non-sleep mode during a wonderful evening with Sweetleaf coffee- based cocktails. I warranty, you will not regret the trip

<review# 483,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/16/2011,7/21/2012,356,239,3,9,8>Astoria Park is a little known secret that Astoria residents enjoy. Although it isn't as large or magnificent as Central Park, it's charming, safe, and offers many ways to exercise in the outdoors. The Park is really pretty and nicely landscaped, especially in the spring. During the summer it's nice to have a picnic on the lawn. I love jogging in Astoria Park. The hills are steep enough to give you a bit of a hill work out and there is a good quality rubber track if you're in the mood to run laps. Jogging by the water, under the trees, with the wind blowing through your hair, and looking out at the NYC skyline is a real treat. Astoria Park hosts many events including its own Shakespeare in the Park. They had a great Pre-4th of July firework display, and they offer several concerts. The nice thing about Astoria Park is that unlike Central Park it's not crowded during the summer and overrun with tourists. There are so many different sports you can play...tennis, skateboarding, basketball, swimming, and tanning (I am sure some people consider that a sport). Bring your dog to the park, play Frisbee, and pack a picnic. Astoria Park is definitely a fun and inexpensive summer hangout.
