<review# 485,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/17/2012,7/19/2012,183,187,5,14,9>Support the good place, ppl! Come to Tian Fu. As the recent Mala XiangGuo frenzy stirred up by LaoMa, I was in doubt when my coworkers recommended Tian Fu's big pot instead. I'm a super spice fan and am usually loyal to the establishment that hooks me first onto a food. "Their spice is better", the colleagues said. Ok, I try you out. Price: Same as LaoMa. Some ingredients are $7/lb, some $8/lb. Ingredients: Uh oh, get ready, cuz there are selections here that weren't at LaoMa. Fried sweet potato - this is EXCELLENT in ur pot! The outside crunchy, inside soft & flavorful (after it comes out from the wok). This one is our favorite. Fish tofu - a lot like the fried tofu sponges, but smaller and smooth on the inside (not spongey like the tofu). Also an excellent flavor-absorbent. Kuan fen AKA clear flat noodles - chewy & bouncy if that's how ya like your noodles. Spice: So I've heard some problems about LaoMa being too overwhelmingly numbing and most importantly - oily. Your problems are over here at Tian Fu. While you can still select your spice level, there are minimal oil and they use chopped peppercorn as opposed to whole peppercorn that induces the numbness. Same spiciness, more convenient for your tongue! My fingers are getting tired typing this on the iPhone, but you won't regret giving this place a try the next time you crave for spicy pot. P.S. They give you TWO BIG BOWLS of rice for free unlike elsewhere that charges extra for a smaller bowl. They also place your meal neatly with utensils and napkins on a tray when you pick it up. This level of service (from Chinese ppl) just makes me so happy :)
<review# 486,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/23/2011,7/18/2012,3,5,6,8,6>Summary: the best pizza in Astoria.The long version: I initially wrote a really brief blurb but on second thought just had to update my review.As a native New Yorker raised on the stuff, I take pizza very seriously. And Rizzo's is simply some of the finest pizza I have ever eaten.The sauce is tangy, the cheese is creamy, and the crust is always fresh and crispy. It simply tastes so good they MUST to be using quality ingredients. Either that or they are slipping Crack into the dough.I was just talking about Rizzo's to a friend yesterday and said "If Rizzo's were in Brooklyn and not in Astoria it would be on all the foodie blogs and there would be a line out the door!"  And I meant this as a good thing. Rizzo's is one of THE BEST spots for great food in Astoria. I'm glad that there isn't a line out the door. Instead I exudes this great feeling of a small, local shop serving great food to it's nearby community.In my initial review I mentioned that you should "be prepared to wait for delivery - this isn't fast food." And that also isn't a dig. Don't treat Rizzo's like Dominos. It may take you a little longer to get your pie delievered, but it's always been worth the wait. I've never gotten a re-heated pie that was probably lying around all day delievered to me. For some of the best pizza in New York, you might have to wait a little bit longer and pay a little bit more - but it's worth every minute and penny. And also notable is that Rizzo's employes the friendliest staff. Whether I've stopped in for a slice or have waited to pick up a pie, I've always been greated warmly and professionally. I can't reccomend Rizzo's enough.
<review# 487,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/13/2011,7/17/2012,115,88,6,8,5>A great neighborhood spot.This place is on my way home from the subway, so I have a tendency to stop in for some take out for dinner. All the food on the menu if have tried has been great. I'm a huge comfort food fan and this place really hits that niche for me. I usually order the crab cake sliders. Finally I have found a great crab cake in NY. They say it's a Maryland crab cake, and it actually tastes like one! The chorizo burger is also a very good choice, very filling, and the empanadas are nice and puffy.I've been here for both brunch and dinner, and while they do have a great brunch, I prefer the dinner menu. I guess I feel it's more "fatty" for my "fatty" taste buds. This is also a great bar just to hang around at. The staff are always friendly, and in the warmer months they have great outdoor seating in the rear. Top it off, two for one drinks on Tuesdays!
<review# 488,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/5/2011,7/16/2012,38,124,4,8,7>Yes, Yes, Yes!!!!!!This is one of those places where you find yourself in a conundrum ordering because everything is good. I come here with my bf like once a week and we often order delivery from them mid- week. Their omelets use high quality cheddar cheese and crisp bacon, their french fries are perfectly crisp (the sweet potato fries and curly fries are even better!), the hash browns are never greasy, and they serve bagels from Astoria bakery (yummmmm)!! My bf is currently obsessed with the chicken limonato, though the burgers are also an outstanding standby--juicy, cooked to perfection on a grilled bun with sharp cheese. Rene, the main waitress is AWESOME!!!  She knows all the regulars' names and what they typically order and makes you feel like you just walked into a dear friend's home when you get there. On weekends, you can also take advantage of their brunch which features bottomless mimosas for $18. Overall, Krave is outstanding if you're looking for something casual and cozy with American food that far exceeds diner quality but doesn't kill your wallet. By far, my favorite spot in Astoria!!
<review# 489,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/21/2012,7/15/2012,205,184,5,15,9>I have a beach cruiser and knew that it was time to upgrade when I decided to ride in the Five Boro Bike Tour. I had already been shopping around for a new bike but had not found exactly what I was looking for. The last bike store had nice bikes, but not the color I wanted and I'm not down for dropping $500+ for a bike I half like. So I decided to visit Spin City and I'm so happy I did. Right off the bat, their sales guy Yoshi made more sense than any other shop I went to. He knew the science behind what bike would be best for me and was generally very knowledgeable. He sized me and made sure the bike I was looking at was a perfect fit. They let me test ride the bike which also really helped in making my decision (make sure you have ID and a credit card on hand if you want to test ride a bike). I also really appreciated that he wasn't pushy. When my husband and I needed a second to talk, he was very sweet and did not pressure us. Their prices are fair (you get what you pay for!) and their selection is great. They have adorable tricycles all the way up to professional bikes. They also have a wide range of accessories and helmets. The owner (manager?) was on hand and was also very customer friendly and helpful.  I am very happy with my purchase and highly recommend them if you are looking to buy a bike.

Seriously, the best halal cart in the entire city - i can say that, because i've tried like 20 of them. The Kinds finally got their hard-earned Vendy award a few years back - and it is well deserved. I always get the chicken pita wrap with extra veggies, extra white sauce. The chicken is savorly seasoned and perfectly balanced. Also, a shout out must go to their tasty shawarma (lamb, goat, chicken, turkey, beef) on the spit, spinning around for all to enjoy. I have lived directly across the street from these culinary geniuses, and come to rely on their delicious cooking to hit my nostrils as soon as I get off the subway. They are practically perfect - and some of the nicest, funniest guys you could ask to be served by. One of Astoria's foodie secrets - as the guys would say, YAHHHH BABY!
<review# 492,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/11/2012,8/12/2012,30,76,10,5,6>Since I don't have a music blog or any blog for that matter, you fine foodies here at Yelp will just have to put up with what will prove to be an unjustifiably useless review of K&K Super Buffet because, despite it being a restaurant, not a bite of food was to be had.In fact, the reason I had left Queens (...to go to Manhattan to go through Brooklyn to get to Queens...) was to catch a show. You see, like the mild-mannered Dr. Jekyll, for one night the otherwise conventional K&K Super Buffet underwent a Mr. Hyde-esque transformation, assuming Mr. Hyde was a lot less of a sociopathic murderer and much more into Bon Iver.Thanks to the efforts of Todd P., a frequently name-dropped figure in context of the NYC DIY music experience, the buffet stowed away steam trays and opened its doors to host a few DJ sets (who I was too late to catch and am now too lazy to look up), The Babies, Black Dice, and the headliner Real Estate who are originally from Ridgewood, New Jersey and is the inspiration for the clever transposition of towns.Seeing as how:A) Real Estate's latest album, Days, was the soundtrack of my life for a week,B) Tickets cost less than a Subway $5 Footlong (Okay...tickets were actually $7 after fees, but still kudos to Todd P again for keeping the price unbelievably low),C) The venue was a CHINESE BUFFET,There was no way I was going to miss out on the experience.Apparently, neither were hundreds of other people because, despite the size of K&K resembling what I compared to as a "Townhall for a middle-class southwest American suburb" or a friend saw as a "McChurch", the place was packed out. In fact when we first got there there was a line that stretched the entire perimeter of the parking lot to get in. I was actually shocked on how orderly and professional the entire situation was given that the sheer amount of people lined up on a Saturday night was more than enough for a fiasco. Say what you want about hipsters, but they can queue up patiently like champs. Perhaps it's because I imagine most Chinese buffets to be minimally decorated food landfills with a layer of grease coating plastic covered furniture but K&K was rather nice and clean looking. The bamboo (or faux bamboo) wall decor fit in nicely with the mini-waterfall up front though it seemed more Japanese inspired than Chinese. I did think the crystal ship chandelier was a bit gaudy and more befitting for the house of a pirate hip-hop artist. The tables were dull though and while I'm not even expecting dinner cloth, it didn't have to look like the inside of a bowling alley.I actually couldn't figure what the stage was made of, so I am unsure if there was make-shift or if the buffet actually sported one but either way, it was sufficient. A wish that I had made to my friend earlier, that the audience would be placed amongst the buffet tables, was joyfully realized as I watched most of the show from what I would guess to be the dessert section.The acoustics were an audiophilic wonder and sound levels were mixed to the perfect blend of  fidelic euphony...nah, I'm just kidding, I have no idea what I'm talking about.  But I do know there was a shit ton of amps and it was loud and it was awesome and it was a Chinese buffet so who cares.
<review# 493,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/18/2011,8/11/2012,316,405,12,8,7>Zabb Elee (recently renamed from the tamer "Zabb Queens") roughly translate to "wow, that's really spicy!" in Thai.It delivers...and could even put my grandmother to shame.One thing to remember is that this is not your usual Thai place.  Sure, there's a banner proudly listing Zabb next to Spice (vomit) but you won't find an inkling of Thai curry or Pad Thai here!  This is Esarn Thai ... from the Northeast region of Thailand - bordering (and sharing the flavors of) Laos. "Medium" Thai spicy here will light a Thai family on fire...yet leave them begging for more (how sadomasochistic). The larb and som tum (papaya salad - offered four styles)  are off the charts. A Thai native would find this place homey.Come and feast...but I caution you: If it's spicy going in, it's spicy coming out.
<review# 494,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/2/2011,8/10/2012,104,231,,9,4>What a charming little place. This is the kind of nice neighborhood restaurant to enjoy a good meal and then linger over coffee and catch up with friends. I ate here a few weeks ago on a Saturday night in celebration of a friend's birthday.  It never got crowded but there was always a flow of tables clearing and people coming in.  For our table we ordered the fried calamari app and hot antipasto. Both were pretty good. I really enjoyed the baked clams in the antipasto platter. You actually get a whole clam and not a half shell full of baked bread crumb glop. I recommend getting the hot anitpasto to try a little of everything. I think it also came with NZ mussels, 2 jumbo shrimp and stuffed mushrooms. Its a good app for 2-4 ppl for about $19. The tomato sauce they served w/mussels were really good for sopping up with bread.  For my entree I split the chicken marsala with a friend since it comes with 2 portions of chicken breast plus a side of pasta or potato croquettes. I think next time I will get the pasta. The croquette was ok-- tasted like a deep fried mash potato log. We couldn't decide on which dessert to get so the manager created a little sampler platter for us and even stuck a sparkler in and sang happy birthday to my friend. They make a homemade ricotta cheesecake which is definitely worth a try. Tiramisu was pretty good too.The service here is excellent and the manager treats diners like welcomed guests in his home.

If you go here in the winter always wear a sweater because the downstairs bathroom is close to one of the outside doors and it's freezing. I always order the crabs because they are delicious. The best part is your given a bib. Yes, you have to work to eat this food but that's what makes it wonderful. They are made in this awesome garlic and herbs sauce. Messy food is always the best food in my opinion.

<review# 500,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/18/2012,8/4/2012,366,164,8,7,11>Yummy in my tummy!I believe I have found my go-to Korean place in Flushing!  This place has every kind of Korean food to satisfy your cravings, from kimbap to kimchi fried rice to donkatsu.  My mouth is starting to water as I type this review, but my stomach is saying "No more!  I'm still trying to digest the dukbokki that you fed me earlier!"Between three girls, we shared an order of Ramyun Dukbokki, Spicy tuna kimbap, and beef sesame leaf kimbap.  Okay, if you have never tried kimbap with sesame leaves, YOU MUST!  It's delicious!  The sesame leaves (also called Korean perilla leaves) gives the kimbap an upgrade in taste with a crunchy bite.  It mixes perfectly with the beef, especially if you dip it into the sweet and spicy dukbokki sauce.  If you're not a fan of beef, you can also order tuna kimbap or salmon kimbap with the sesame leaf.  Next time I'm in Flushing, I'm going to order all three!  Hey, it's only $5 each.  How awesome is that?!

You're going to want - need - to concentrate on the specials. All of them.After introducing himself your waiter will run off the list like a school-child reciting his ABC's at double-time. You should expect at least a dozen each of appetizers, pastas and main courses. Fortunately your waiter also doubles as a cassette tape, so don't be afraid to ask him to pause and rewind (unfortunately you can't slow the pace down, but he can speed it up to sound like the Chipmunks); if you don't have a photographic memory you'll need make use of this feature. Once you recover from the shock get ready to place your order. One of the nice things about L'Incontro is that in the event that none of the specials sound appealing to you, simply ask your waiter if they can prepare a dish as you'd like it and they can make it happen.While waiting for your food to come don't hesitate to reach for the flatbread in your breadbasket and dig into the sundried tomato spread or tear through the freshly baked, light, fluffy regular bread - they're both very good.I've eaten here a few times and I've tried a lot of different dishes - sardines, meatless meatballs, salads, fish, boar, osso buco, etc. It's been a while since my previous visit, so I'll only make note of what I had this weekend.We started with the smoked tuna, fig salad and apple ravioli. The tuna, lightly smoked and thinly sliced, served under a bed of crisp, peppery arugula and nutty, planed parmesan, was refreshing and a good way to open up the palate for the meal. The fig salad - also served with mixed greens in a light olive oil and balsamic vinegar dressing and shaved Parmesan - was simple and good, although mostly redundant with the tuna (that was totally my bad). The ravioli - described as apple with marscapone - let me down because they were mainly marscapone (I like apples. A lot. For real. I just made a puffed apple pancake - that's how much I like apples. Boom. The best apples are mutsus and jonagolds. Try them). I could detect the texture of apple, barely, but not the taste. They were good for what they were, but I wouldn't advertise them as apple.For main dishes we had the Chilean sea bass - toothy fish! - over a cauliflower puree, chicken with mushrooms, venison and stuffed grouper. All came with the same vegetable of the day, which was green beans sautéed with garlic and butter. You can never have enough butter and L'Incontro gets that loud and clear. Good job, L'Incontro. The sea bass was cooked well, lightly crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. The chicken with mushrooms was close to a marsala, but without the wine; the chicken breast was sliced thinly, which helped to keep the meat moist. The venison, sliced into medallions, was the best dish of the bunch, deliciously cooked medium rare to an almost melt-in-your-mouth consistency. Thinking about it is making me salivate. The grouper was stuffed with ricotta and spinach, which made it a very happy dish that was cooked well, like the others.To top off the meal we had the chocolate banana bread pudding, tiramisu and pear sorbet. The bread pudding was good, but could have been more moist, the tiramisu's flavor was great, but it was a little too dense for me - I like a light and airy tiramisu (Serafina does this really well) - and the sorbet was nice.While not cheap, when compared to similar restaurants in Manhattan, L'Incontro's prices are noticeably better. Our bill was definitely at a discount to what we would have otherwise paid.The space is large, but often packed, so I'd make a reservation to be on the safe side. The crowd is something of a mixed bunch. You're already on Long Island, so I wouldn't say B&T, but I would say LIE.Every time I go to L'Incontro I have a solid meal. I'd be hard-pressed to tell you that it's the best Italian food I've ever had, but the food is consistently very good and never disappoints. It's all around a very good and appreciated dining experience. I'm totally going to use my voice recorder app on my phone for the specials the next time I come. Why didn't I think of that before!?

<review# 510,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/11/2011,2/18/2012,142,211,5,12,11>I really wish I had Wafa's in my neighborhood. It is kind of the perfect restaurant. First of all, it's authentic Lebanese food (although it hides under the guise of serving "Mediterranean food"; maybe it has a broader appeal that way). Having been to Lebanon just this past summer, I'd say the distinguishing characteristic of Lebanese food -- other than fresh herbs and vegetables and quality meat -- is the art of restraint. It's a less is more philosophy. Wafa's practices what it preaches. The hummus is well balanced, with a hint of garlic, a hint of citrus, and a hint of tahini. Baba ganoush also has a roasted egglplant undertone, but nothing too offensive. The shish taouk was out of this world, tangy and citrusy, white cut meat, moist on the inside, grilled on the outside. Lamb kebabs were also super flavorful, with a little chew and a litttle char. All platters come with a choice of spreads (e.g., hummus, baba ganoush, labneh), vegetables (e.g., tabouleh, cauliflower) or bulgur/lentil-filled mujadarah.Second of all, everything is super healthy. Other pluses: it's BYOB, which is rare even in Queens. It's casual yet not a hole in the wall. It's clean. It's a family restaurant, with a staff that actually wants to chat it up with you, all the while you can see Mama Wafa making your dishes in the back. You can count on paying ~$15-$20 per head for an enormous plate of food. What more do you want?The cons are it's location, in the southern borderlands of Forest Hills. Relying on public transit requires you to take the E/F to Forest Hills and then the Q54 to Metropolitan (about 30 mins total from Roosevelt Ave). I also wish Mama Wafa would instill a special of the day for the adventurous. Some raw kibbeh would be awesome. Or Lebanese fish. Or something more obscure. Man can't live on shish taouk and majadarah alone. Finally, dessert menu (baklava or rice pudding) was a little lacking. Where's the knafeh (pastry with white cheese, nuts and syrup) or halva? I am still infatuated with Wafa's, and I will gladly sit on the Q54 bus to get my fill of Lebanese love.

<review# 514,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/13/2012,12/20/2012,101,229,12,15,15>Bear is this little restaurant off the beaten path on 31st avenue close to Vernon Blvd.  Walking up 21st street from Broadway, you'd have no idea that an upscale Manhattan-ish restaurant was here.The bottom line with this place?  The food is delicious, but sadly the portions are meager especially for the price.  However, drinks and desserts are reasonably priced and the ambiance is really relaxed and mellow.  My verdict:  go here for the drinks and the desserts, but stay away from the entrees if you have a big appetite because you will leave hungry.  If you're looking for a smaller portion of food that will tantalize your taste buds, then by all means enjoy their entrees because they really are quite tasty.I went here tonight with a good friend of mine in search of a good time.  He ordered the crawfish pasta and I got the pulled pork.  My pulled pork was really flavorful: a blend of various herbs and spices adorned the meat and it fell apart fairly easily using only my fork.  It was perhaps a little bit of a fatty cut for my tastes, but not terrible at all.  There was also a little mushroom salad that accompanied the pork with a vinegar sauce that was actually quite good.The service was excellent.  We got our menus soon after the waiter took our drink orders.  The food also came out fairly quickly after we ordered it (not more than 15 - 20 min tops).  In short, our service was polite and prompt.In addition, the menu seems to change every day.  We were handed a hand-written sheet of paper with all of the different choices and associated prices.  The customized experience definitely felt very upscale.To be honest, I think this place needs some standard fare that is more reasonably priced.  They can always mix up their special menu in addition to having a few simple favorites.  I just don't see myself (with my appetite) going back to have dinner here even despite the incredible flavor of the food.That being said, I do see the place becoming a bar where my friends and I can have drinks before going back to my place and I anticipate having good times here.  They've definitely got the bar / hangout atmosphere down.Stop by, give the place a try and see what you think.  My experience was not the nightmare that some of these reviews claim.
<review# 515,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/12/2012,12/19/2012,142,211,7,13,9>Hotteok must be one of the greatest street foods, and now Queens is fortunate enough to have a place dedicated to preparing them. Meet Pajunia, a new cheery, yellow painted mini restaurant-stall situated on the one block stretch of Korean businesses behind the Roosevelt Avenue-Jackson Heights transit hub. Pajunia specializes in hotteok -- the cult favorite Korean nut pancakes, filled with warm mixture of brown sugar, cinnamon and crushed peanuts/walnuts/sesame. 4 mini pancakes for $5 and you get to watch the friendly husband and wife team prepare them on the griddle so that they reach that perfect consistency -- crispy on the outside, gooey on the inside. Savory food menu is still evolving (and I think this place is eventually going to be pajun or savory scallion pancake joint), with literally only 3-4 meet-over-rice items and maybe 2 variations of ramen for sale. They pale in comparison to the hotteok and take up valuable gastro real estate. Save the room for the sweet stuff. There really is no reason not to try this place out when passing by Roosevelt Avenue, given proximity to the subway and the option of purchasing just one blissful hotteok for $1.50. You can thank me later.
<review# 516,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/27/2012,12/18/2012,54,130,7,11,7>After the demise of the sad excuse for a wine bar that existed prior to Jack and Nellie's, I was almost afraid to hope for a chill, cool, adult, wine bar with good wines and yummy food.  Yet from the second I walked into Jack and Nellie's, I was pretty sure it was an entrance I would be making again and again.  And again. The mac and cheese is out of this world - seriously. THAT will definitely happen again. The hummus was nothing crazy special, but solid, and the crispy chickpeas on top are a nice touch.  The portions are tapas, so nothing is huge, but that's what I like about Jack and Nellie's - good wine and delicious snack. These are the basic ingredients for my own slice of Heaven.Decor is nice - dark wood, dim lighting, cozy. Bartender was cool and knowledgeable (we sat at the bar), and we met the owner, who was super friendly and welcoming. I'm definitely glad to report that Jack and Nellie's is doing it right. Far far away.

<review# 520,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/4/2012,12/14/2012,168,160,9,8,12>This is it! Review number 100! I was going to go out and do some fancy tasting for this momentous occasion. Per Se perhaps or Chef's Table but that would require much coin and I my wife would basically kill me if i spent our money on that instead of paying my son's tuition. So for the sake of keeping our happy home, happy, and getting our son literate, i opted to go at it another route, one closer to the heart. And that is what food really is all about anyway. That's what Joe Shanghai is all about for me. I think i first heard about Joe Shanghai back when i was much younger from my cousin who mentioned that he happened upon a shop in Chinatown that served the most amazing dumplings ever.  He said when he took a bite out of it all of this juiciness just poured out of it. But the problem was he wasn't sure what it was called and he didn't remember where it was located. Thus began the legend of the soup dumpling, the hunt for the holy grail. It wasn't until a few years ago that I had Joe's Shanghai after asking some of my Chinese friends about this legendary dumpling. I first went to the Elmhurst location (subsequently closed down) and upon first try, i nearly cried... it was so hot! haha. no but seriously it was SO SO good. I soon discovered that it's not really just the soup dumplings but the Shanghai fried flat noodles, the pan fried noodles, the General Tso Chicken, the beef with string beans, and on an on... all of it was so good. And so began my love affair with Joe Shanghai. Joe Shanghai was instrumental in how i came to marry my wife too, of course i wanted to introduce the love of my life to these amazing dumplings and she came to love them too...but then as we would come to the end of the steam basket (8 per order) she would always hold back and ask me to take the last one. turns out she was sacrificing the last one because she knew how much i enjoyed them. Now that is love! that's how i knew i had a keeper. And yes since then I've had a couple of kids and yes my kids love it here too. When they have no appetite and they don't want to eat anything, my wife and i know that we can entice them to have Joe Shanghai. They often ask for it by name! When we bring the kids they get basically all of the soup from the dumplings, this is our way of showing love to them. we would drain the soup and let them drink it from the spoon. Joe Shanghai even provides them with an attachment to the chopsticks that helps them use them. over the years Joe Shanghai has had a very special place in my heart not only for the food but also for the memories. Today many of the servers know us by face, they've watched me and my wife lug the kids in, in their car-seats, and watched the kids fumble around with the chopsticks trying to eat, they watched as went from 2 orders of pork dumplings to 3 orders.  Joe Shanghai is everything that we love about eating out. good food and good memories.
<review# 521,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/14/2013,4/3/2014,35,103,4,12,8>I love science museums, particularly ones with lots of hands-on activities, and the Hall of Science is PACKED with hands-on activities (in fact, there were very few pieces without some sort of demonstration component). In addition, the staff of volunteers were circulating pretty regularly and would step in to explain or help you when it seemed useful. Also, there was a live dissection of a cow's eye with really good explanations of each step - I had been considering doing something similar in class, so it was cool to watch a museum worker do it for a group of visitors.My husband and I made an afternoon of it and found it entertaining and fun even for two 30-somethings with no kids - including the "science playground" with water features, musical pipes, and the like. My only gripe would be that the Rocket Park mini golf course needs a bit of attention. I realize it's probably costs a good penny to keep things clean and fresh, but couldn't you have a volunteer at least sweep the leaves out of the course at the beginning of the day? Overall a good time, definitely would bring kids, and will probably go back for more fun myself.
<review# 522,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/14/2014,4/2/2014,43,102,6,10,9>$8 suggested donation for adults, and my three kids (ages 3, 5, and 8) were free.  The newly renovated space is beautiful and we stayed for nearly two hours...not an easy task to keep three kiddies entertained for that long, but the artwork on display really caught their attention (and the adults, too!).My hands-down favorite exhibit in the entire place is the Panorama; it is a 3D expression of the five boroughs and was originally installed decades ago.  It has not been updated, so you will see the original World Trade Center and other buildings that are no longer current, but native New Yorkers should enjoy spotting familiar places.Most people gravitate to Manhattan, but as a Queens native, I spend more time perusing my borough and trying to identify local landmarks and areas that hold personal meaning to me.  It's like Google Maps before there was Google Maps.  I could literally spend an hour or two just with this one exhibit.  If you are from NYC, if you have a fondness for detail, and/or if you enjoy spending a quiet moment appreciating the passion and craftsmanship that artists pour into their work, you should definitely make time to see this longstanding exhibit.At an $8 suggested donation, the Queens Museum is well worth your time and money.

Just ask! Did I mention this market is open 24 hours?!

<review# 526,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/21/2013,3/29/2014,174,120,5,12,6>I'm a big fan of the saying "The dirtier, the better!" This especially applies to food establishments, as I've found the sketchier a place looks, the more authentic it tastes. Of course, there's no science behind this, and I'd rather there not be, because the most important thing is the taste! And the fact the food comes out within 5 minutes...mind-boggling. Phobang hits it on the money and it's my favorite place for pho. Ever since I first came here in high school, they've always been my go-to spot for a bowl of that special sumpin' sumpin'. The broth isn't salty and very drinkable, compared to most other spots, and the noodles are cooked perfectly. The meat and tendon and whatever the hell else they put in their #1 is superb. I never look at the menu anymore, all I ever get is the giant bowl of #1, don't bother with any other number! Their pork chop over rice is also decent, but it can be pretty dry sometimes, very hit or miss. Their Che Ba Mau, or 3 color ice, is a really good after meal dessert drink, on the rare occasion that good ole' #1 doesn't fill me up, I always go for it. It's super colorful and has a bunch of different beans mixed in there with coconut milk. You also can't go wrong with the Bánh mì, I haven't had one in a while so I can't recall how much it costs, but it was dirt cheap for a practically footlong sandwich with a bunch of meats, pate, and vegetables. Service here is pretty straight forward: don't come here for it. The staff will seat you quickly and get you out quickly, but the taste of the food makes up for it. No one will be rude towards you, but they won't go out of their way to put on a fake smile. I'm totally OK with that.

<review# 528,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/5/2014,3/27/2014,66,77,6,12,6>This place makes one amazing chicken cutlet. You have to try "the beast" (chicken cutlet, bacon, onion rings, swiss cheese and brown gravy). They even list it on their menu as one of the things they are known for. Let me break it down as to why this is a 5 star sandwich. First of all the chicken is so moist. This is the heart of the sandwich, a dry cutlet makes a terrible sandwich, unfortunately this is way to common in other delis.  The breading on this is also magical. It somehow stays slightly crunchy. All other delis that I've tried come with a cutlet where the breading is soft with sauce. Secondly the bread itself if soft and thin. I don't know about you but I hate biting into a hero that comes with a thick piece of bread. I hate having to tear though the sandwich with your teeth. It completely messes up the ratio of meat to bread but this place does it well. Its soft so you don't have to resort to being your favorite carnivorous animal to eat it. This is also one of the few delis that compress a cuban. The sauerkraut that came with it was soggy which takes away from the cuban but I can forgive that. Get the chicken cutlets.

<review# 532,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/9/2012,9/11/2012,289,416,9,17,11>If you have an unresolved case of the missing waistline, don't even think of going to Salt and Fat.  Otherwise, the fact that that the interest of your taste buds does not necessarily match that of your waistline will be further confirmed. Having missed the first invite here from Elle P.and Amy S. a year ago, I was excited to finally try Salt and Fat with a group so we can share the small plates.  It was the perfect night to eat as there was no wait for a table of six.  After getting a bottle of Cabernet, we gave our order for ten (10) dishes to the staff.  In my opinion, the following items were brilliant and worth another visit:   ~~Persimmon salad  (baby arugula, prosciutto, spicy candied walnuts, goat cheese, honey-lemon vinaigrette)  - Perfection!  The contrast between salt and sweet as well as between richness and freshness will initially puzzle the taste buds until the brain adjusts to the beautiful sensation evoked.  The goat cheese was delivered with a very light touch so it doesn't overpower the dish.  I'm so excited to replicate it given that our family loves persimmon.  Actually, I thought this item should be the banner dish of Salt and Fat.  ~~Yellow tail tartare  (scallions, yuzu gel, cassava chips)  - We were advised to mix the beautifully presented tartare with the yuzu gel and the scallions, scoop it out on the cassava chips and prepare to be surprised.  The crunch of the cassava chips with the delicate yet rich taste of the tartare was nicely done.  ~~Shaved Hudson Valley Foie Gras (with cinnamon mandarin oranges and bacon brittle) -  Although I'm a fan of foie gras, I'm on the fence with cinnamon because it is a strong flavor.  Somehow the blend of sweetness and earthiness of cinnamon with the citrusy orange and the salty bacon brittle is surprising, yet comforting.  ~~Panna cotta with yuzu sorbet - It was the perfect end to the very rich meal.  The yuzu sorbet was citrusy and fresh and yet delicate with a hint of sweetness.  I love making panna cotta and am excited to replicate their lychee version.The other dishes that we tried were: ~~Fried chicken (with pickled daikon and spicy herb ranch)  It would be difficult to go wrong with fried chicken.  There are four (4) pieces of the fried chicken which tasted more Southern style than Korean style.  ~~Scallops ( with roasted carrot puree, truffled corn salsa, capers) - I was excited to order this dish.  Perhaps due to the strong flavors of the other dishes, it seemed it lost its identity.  The corn salsa is heavenly though and the scallops were firm and fresh.  ~~Shrimp and grits (with slow cooked egg, bacon and scallions)  The moment I tasted the dish, I felt my taste buds swell from the extreme saltiness.  Surprisingly, when I looked again, we finished the dish.  ~~Braised pork belly tacos (with pickled onions, kimchi salsa, queso fresco) The queso fresco was a nice touch but the pork belly itself was dry.  ~~Oxtail terrine (caramelized onion puree, roasted mushrooms) It was a bit dry for me. The others in our group waxed poetic about this dish from previous visit but perhaps because there were so many dishes, it did not impress me.  ~~Crispy Pork Trotter Torchon (with slow cooked egg, spicy mayo) We call it their version of crispy pata.  It was alright but I didn't think it was crispy.  ~~Crack and Cheese - (gnocchi, bacon and cheese) Their version of mac and cheese would have been perfect if we did not order too many items. ~~Papardelle pasta (with slow cooked egg, roasted mushrooms and broccoli rabe) -  I can no longer taste anything by the time that we tried the pasta but the brocolli rabe had a crunch although there were some tough bits on the pasta. As I've said the yuzu sorbet was hands-down the best dessert but then again the trio of sorbets gave us such a thrill: apple miso, thai iced tea and white peach jalapeno.  It was a challenge to choose which we liked best so much so that we're already planning coming back. Did we mention that we also ordered the rice krispies and ice cream? It would have been a blast to meet Chef Daniel Yi, who grew up in Sunnyside too and who is bringing business to the neighborhood.

<review# 534,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/23/2012,9/9/2012,1007,752,16,25,22>400th review goes to Du Bois Pastry! This bakery has been around for a long time in Elmhurst. The pastries, cookies, pies, fresh loafs of bread, croissants, and cakes are traditional and delicious. They have a great location on Broadway. It's located right in between two major train stations in Elmhurst (Grand Ave Newtown and Elmhurst Ave) and they have a parking lot. DO NOT park in Walgreens' lot! I've seen some customer vehicles get towed a few times. Their parking lot is around the corner of St. James Ave.Pastries - Freshly baked everyday. They make this weird knot looking pastry and it's really good and inexpensive.Cookies - My FAV! They have a very nice variety of cookies on display. I remember as a child, I would come in here and get half pound or sometimes a full pound of cookies and just munch away on the walk home. Their almond cookies are heavenly!Cakes - They make a great strawberry shortcake and tiramisu. The strawberry shortcake is what their known for. The cream and fresh strawberries is delightful but their tiramisu is really good too. It's hard to dislike tiramisu. The ladyfingers are delicious! I usually alternate when getting cakes from Du Bois. The thing I like about Du Bois' cakes, it's not overly sweet. Places like Martha's Country Bakery and Carlo's Bakery, it's just a sugary overdose in my opinion. I like sweet but not obese sweet.Pies - Another one of my favorites would have to be their fruit pie. Excellent crust topped with mouth watering fruits and there's some type of tasty custard inside.Service - Excellent! It's a real bakery that produces a lot of goods everyday. The bakers been here for a long time. They're brothers and they are really friendly people.Verdict - It's a great bakery in Elmhurst. For them to be around this long, they definitely know what their doing. There's not much competition around here. There are plenty of chinese bakeries in this area of Elmhurst but it's a whole different type of selection. At chinese bakeries in Elmhurst, you're getting laxative laced buns and complete cakes that are just made out of cream and old fruits. If you're looking for a good quality bakery in Elmhurst, Du Bois is your best bet!
<review# 535,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/25/2012,9/8/2012,395,204,8,16,11>Juice for Life is pretty good. I started out drinking their juices but moved on to solid foods seeing that my co-worker recommended that I try it. A lot of these reviews will say stuff like it's really pricey or whatever. They're right, the food is pricey, but eating this food benefits you mentally cause you realize you're taking in a lot less calories than if you ate anything else. Most of their dishes range from 400 to 500 calories and their servings are pretty big, for the most part. I think the best values would be from the wraps, if you're looking for best value. Don't bother with the Lunch Box Specials, cause I don't think they're as big, in terms of serving size, when compared with the wraps or the meals. They deliver rather quickly. Our office is in New Hyde Park and we get our food between 30 to 40 minutes from when we make the call. You'll just have to plan in advance. That's just the cost of being healthy. You want to eat pizza or burritos or whatever, go right ahead, but the whole point of eating here isn't to just eat something that tastes good. The whole point is to eat something that tastes good and FEELS good after you're done. My favorite is the TKO meal. That's TKO as in Total Knock Out. It's 450 calories - Grilled Chicken marinated in Garlic Sauce and Ginger served over a bed of Brown Rice for $10.00. The flavor is subtle and the serving size is huge. The chicken isn't juicy or anything but I like it. I still don't believe it's 450 calories. I bet you it's slightly more, cause there's so much brown rice. Or maybe I just don't know anything about brown rice.The juice selection is okay. For those people who are into juicing, I'm pretty sure that they use a centrifugal juicer. It would be impossible for them to fulfill their lunch time rush juice orders if they were using a masticating juicer. You can taste some of the grind in the juice, which is fine, whatever. My favorite in terms of taste is anything other than The Hulk (#2) because everything except for #2 has fruit in it. The Hulk, without an apple or a lemon, tastes gross. My favorite in terms of being healthy is The Hulk, which is what I order most of the time. I say to myself, Jimmy, don't be a pussy, if you're going to drink juice, drink The Hulk. The Hulk = Celery, Spinach, Broccoli, Kale and ParsleyTry it out, but before you order from here, keep in mind that you're ordering from here because it's healthy and not just because you're hungry and it's time for lunch and you want to shove something into that mouth of yours cause that's what people do when they're hungry. You're ordering from here because you've made a decision to try to be a healthier person, at least for that meal.

<review# 537,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/15/2012,9/6/2012,545,1338,15,18,16>Momos for beginners, that's how I refer to Namaste Tashi Delek Momo Dumpling Palace. It took me awhile to find this stall, to brave past the Tandoori chicken and chaos. For an outsider who is used to everything so formulated in the restaurant business, it can be daunting to step inside the Merit Kebab and Dumpling Palace. People are shouting all over the place, the line is scattered, and the people are so engrossed in their food you will wonder how to break through that barrier and become one of them sinking your fingers into a plate of colorful orange, yellow, and hot pink rice.All the way in the back is Nepalese/Tibetan food. I like to buy their momos. They come eight pieces in a Styrofoam container. I started out with beef. Once, I watched the juice of the momos quickly coagulate. I now shy away from the beef fat and have moved on to the chicken momos. The veggie momos take 10 minutes to steam and I like my food fast when I'm starving off the train. I have yet to try the healthiest option of momos. The beef and chicken ones are just always readily available.  There are two dipping sauces that come with the momos- a buttery sweet Tamarind one or the put your mouth on fire tomato chutney one. I like to get both and switch back and forth. A lot of people say that the momos at Namaste Tashi Delek Momo Dumpling Palace are not the best but I like them. They are a nice introduction to momos and to me they most resemble a Chinese dumpling, plump and crescent shaped. The dough is not too thick. The wrapped is strong enough to hold the filling and hearty enough to warm the belly. I eat them like a meal. On cold days I like to buy the chicken soups with Thukpa thin noodles almost like spaghetti or Thentuk hand pulled thick noodles. The soup tastes homemade and are quite substantial. I like to put the soy based sauce into it with the peppers. It gives it a nice spicy, sour, vinegarish flavor.If you pay in cash, they charge $1 cheaper. The steam table looks good with lots of potatoes and chicken. You won't run out of options with  Namaste Tashi Delek Momo Dumpling Palace. You just gotta be a little adventurous.
<review# 538,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/22/2012,9/5/2012,262,613,8,8,7>Any restaurant that features a sign with a happy looking pig with a napkin draped around its neck catches my eye.Such was the case with Hornado Ecuatoriano and, thanks to Rachel A's review, I knew exactly what to order: the hornado!I'm an Ecuadorian eater newbie and without the power of google, would not really know what some of the platos tipicos were. While Spanish was by far the dominant language here, our waitress knew enough English to make ordering easy. (Without resorting to our butchering the language of Cervantes!)When you step in, you'll notice Valentine's Day decorations that are still hanging. It's like keeping Christmas decorations up all year: when december rolls around, you don't have to do any work!There are a few mirrors around the dining room too, which made possible for me to catch a scantily clad female posterior advertised on Telemundo which was on the ol' TV. (From where we sat I could look out and see "Romanticos" Gentlemen's Club across the street).Hornado is roast pig. That's all you need to know. But it helps to know about and consume with enthusiasm, the two sides that came with it: mote (hominy) and corn cakes. (I'll ignore the salad which I didn't bother with).According to Wikipedia, mote is the main ingredient of many dishes in Cuenca, Ecuador. I do know that Cuenca is quite an attractive spot for North American expats so if I ever escape from it all to Ecuador, I now know what to eat.Upon initial taste I thought this was a bit bland but I'm someone who eats oatmeal religiously...so I didn't mind at all. There wasn't much sweetness to the flavor but again, not a problem for me. I found that mixing it with a mashing of the corn cakes produced the ideal flavor combo.(And for my sci-fi aware fans, I couldn't help but think of "The Mote in God's Eye", a Larry Niven 1974 novel. Not quite the same mote...)Anyway, the arrival of the hornado demanded trumpet fanfare. I especially liked the inclusion of the roasted pig skin on my plate. Crispy with a little bit of fat, I was entering hog heaven. The rest of the was moist and juicy and stood on its own without requiring any sauce to liven things up. For $13 I was satisfied and ready to return for more. At this rate, the equator of the earth won't be Ecuador but my expanding belly!

  The guys tried the Elk meat in The Western and The Classic while I had the Pesto Red Pepper burger in Bison.  We swapped halves to try each others but my favorite was my bison burger.  The meat is very lean but meaty and had an earthy flavor with a slightly different texture.  A better choice than beef.  The elk tasted just like beef and looked just like beef.  Thanks the hostess recommendations, we were adventurous and the next time I came, I tried the Wild boar cuban sandwich.  I was expecting a ham like texture but it's actually very lean and not at all like pork.  It's a bit drier in texture but it went well with the Canadian bacon, mustard, and pickle relish.  Just one more to try and that would be the ostrich.You can bet I'll be back.  The fries and various dipping sauces are awesome.  And I can feel a good about making a decision to eat organic burgers instead of unhealthy pink slime.  As for sides, I don't recommend the Sweet Potato Croq's unless you really love mashed sweet potato balls.  Just a warning if your waiter doesn't tell you in advance, these balls are hot balls of fire!  Like literally so hot on the inside.  My favorite sides are the fried pickles.  These are the best I've had, really thick sliced in the perfect shell of batter.  Not too thin and not too thick, just right.  You don't even need the mayo dipping sauce.So glad FH finally got an upstanding burger joint, it's going to give Cheeburger Cheeburger and Johnny Rockets a run for their money.  I favor BB because of their quality pairings in toppings.  They're quality organic gourmet burgers for a decent price.

The food was very good.  I really thought this was a cool spot - i like that it's small and i was glad it wasn't crowded when  i went.  They have a second room downstairs that i was told is used as a venue for live music... <review# 542,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/25/2011,4/29/2012,92,206,6,7,7>When hubby told me he wanted to go to a panini place, my initial thought was, "Really? Panini? Boooooorrriiiiiiiiing!" The fried eggplant panini with roast mushrooms, goat cheese and spicy mayo is an excellent vegetarian choice. You can taste everything: the cheese, eggplant and mayo. Delicious! My favorite brunch item is the Sir Oink-a-Lot: sweet sausage, scrambled eggs, caramlized onions and basil pesto. I order it with extra pesto right in there and it is to die for! The one thing you must have is the tomato bisque, which they serve with pesto crostini. Share if you must, but you might want your own bowl. If you are vegetarian, or don't eat a lot of pork, don't let the menu scare you off - they will try to accomodate your requests, without any attitude. Service is always friendly and fast, portions are huge, and the restaurant is really cozy. Love it!
<review# 543,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/7/2011,4/28/2012,203,182,5,9,10>I've been going to Astoria more and more lately--discovering it has many delightful foods on offer! Cevabdzinica Sarajevo doesn't look like much from the street--in fact, not much different from a Burger King. But press on, dear yelper. For this is your one-stop shop for a classic Balkan meal of grilled beef cevapi (little sausages) and pljeskavica (balkan burgers), served with plenty of minced onions, buttery pita bread and ajvar, a roasted red pepper spread.I asked if they served beer. The woman on the phone said no. I asked if we could bring our own. She paused a second, and then said "ok, sure." It's that kind of place. They don't have a BYOB "policy."We were helped by a very friendly woman from Montenegro. She explained that the owner is from Sarajevo. We also saw a very old woman in a shawl eating soup--the owner's mother! It's a family joint--and you'll feel right at home.
<review# 544,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/30/2011,4/27/2012,42,54,23,25,24>This is the best ice and ice cream place IN THE WORLD.Seriously.Maybe I haven't actually been to every ice place on earth, but one taste of this stuff... And you'll be just as convinced as I am.This is as good as it gets.They have water ices, creamy ices, ice cream and frozen yogurt and their menu for each one is extensive. It's an alphabetized, wonderfully overwhelming list of creative flavors you wouldn't have thought of, with classic ones in between.Their ices have a smooth texture and don't taste like they have simply been injected with some cheap imitation flavors. Nope. These flavors are the real deal. I have no idea what their secret it but OH MY GOSH, they are spot on. I promise you will smile big and your eyes will pop out of your head a little when you discover how perfect their flavors are. On numerous occasions, my boyfriend and I can't help but say "HOW DO THEY DO IT?!?!"A small is $2.50 and gets you two generous scoops. You can mix flavors which is perfect since it can be hard to decide which one you want. The owner and employees are awesome and let you try a bunch of flavors. Even in the summer months, when the line goes out the door, they manage to handle the crowd well despite the time people spend selecting flavors. Nobody ever waits long.For those of you that like frozen yogurt, they have Only 8 frozen yogurt and usually offer six flavors. There's your typical vanilla, chocolate and pistachio - and then some others like raspberry, peanut butter and pomegranate. Like the ices, you can mix two flavors. Vanilla with pistachio is a personal favorite.My most recent mind-blowing flavor...CARROT CAKE. Carrot cake ice cream. I kid you not. It was incredible.Go here. NOW."But it's winter!" - you say...WHATEVER. They have a slightly smaller (though still large) menu during the winter months and it's so worth it. Just eat it in your heated car. DUUUUH.

<review# 556,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/31/2014,8/6/2014,29,52,5,11,4>I'm really excited about this place and I hope they do well. It's very basic, *classic* renditions of pho soup and banh mi sandwiches. No-one is trying to reinvent anything or putting a quirky spin on things, unlike practically every other banh mi place in the city. Just fresh bread, toasted perfectly, with good ingredients in the perfect ratio. It's not the kind of thing you can write an interesting blog entry about because the secret ingredient is the care that goes into the food. In fact they are so far outside of the usual food-marketing machine that the sandwiches are just called "sandwich" and the soup is just "noodle soup" as opposed to "Banh Mi" and "Pho".My recommendation is the BBQ beef sandwich, but they're probably all good. Also they're $5 and as big as your forearm.The soup has good flavor but needs a little work in the presentation. They keep the broth and noodles in the fridge behind the counter and just microwave it for you when you order, which is fine except that the noodles can get mushy from microwaving, to the point where they break into little pieces when you try to pick them up with chopsticks. Also they serve it in a wide, shallow, plastic take-out bowl which is ok, but a deeper bowl would make it easier to eat the soup. I would recommend maybe getting the soup to go (they'll give it to you cold, with the wet and dry ingredients in separate containers), and then heating it up at home.Vietnamese coffee is also quite good. Recommended if you're in the area.

<review# 560,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/26/2014,8/2/2014,174,201,8,9,7>This 700+ strong international hotpot chain finally arrived in Flushing a few months ago to great fanfare! I've only heard good things about this chain, so I was excited to try it out.The space is decorated nice and modern, without too much flair. Everything still has that new-restaurant sheen that I'm sure will get FLUSHING-ed down the toilet given enough time (geddit?), but for now it is clean. But décor aside, the food is the important bit!I am happy to say that the broth was among the best I've had. They seem to offer a pork-based, milky white broth livened up with deep flavors from various herbs and spices including cardamom and ginseng, as well as spicy sichuan peppercorns if you elect to get the firey broth.I was treating my parents to dinner here (and my father can't really handle spice -- Koreans everywhere shake their heads) so we got the yin-yang pot, which is half mild and half spicy broth. I elected to go spiciest on the spicy side (which turned out to have a nice heat that didn't overpower the deep flavors of the base broth at all or make the meal inedible).We also ordered a large variety of ingredients, including the vegetable combo, mushroom basket, tofu combo, lamb, beef, pork belly, surf clam strips, house meat and shrimp balls, and fresh noodles. Everything was very fresh and really good quality. There weren't any brown spots on any leaves, no frozen meat, and a nice variety of food was in each of the combos. Normally I'm wary of eating the tofu uncooked/heated through, but I ate the soft tofu with just a bit of sauce and it was great.My favorite items by far were the meatballs and the pork belly. The meatballs, all made in-house, were neither frozen nor pre-cooked. After being cooked through, they remained very soft and the texture was wonderful (especially the shrimp!!). The pork belly, as it cooked, added a lot of savoriness to the broth via the rendered fat and made it that much richer. The beef and lamb were both very tender and flavorful as well. The noodles (thick ones? first one on the list if I remember correctly) were really good with a great texture. We ended up ordering two large plates!The one ingredient that I may not order again was the surf clam (which was very tough, but that's due to the nature of the meat not really the quality of the ingredient).We also got a plate of Mongolian kimchi on the side as a palate cleanse and it was interesting. It was made with regular cabbage and was sweeter than its Korean counterpart. Sort of reminded me of the sweet pickled radish/carrot of Vietnamese cuisine.The sauce bar was great and had a nice selection of ingredients. I decided to mix the sweet soy sauce with shacha sauce, garlic, vinegar, sesame oil, and scallions.The service was pretty good, although they messed up twice; they forgot our kimchi and brought out scallops instead of clams (maybe we should have just kept them, they looked pretty fresh and may have been a better choice haha). But besides that they were pretty good and spoke English well (though they seemed to think I was Chinese, and while I can understand some basic stuff, I'm not!).My one problem with the place is probably the price. I hear they have an AYCE option, which might actually end up being way better than ordering à la carte as we did. While at one glance the prices seem pretty low, they do add up very quickly and we ended up dropping almost $140 after tax and tip for three people.But other than that, I'm very happy with the quality of the food, the service, and convenient location! Recommended for sure (be sure to get the in-house meatballs and pork belly. Skip the surf clams)!
<review# 561,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/18/2014,9/8/2014,118,139,4,11,9>There's always room for another spin on one of the worlds most diverse cuisines and this Elmhurst newcomer is off to a promising start.The staff here is exceptional prepped to welcome cultural crossover. I have some multicultural dining experience under my belt (literally) but I still appreciated the polite inquiries about our spice tolerance, familiarity with shrimp paste and other preliminaries that benefit the uninitiated. No worries regarding linguistic barriers for English speakers.We tried two dishes on our first visit. My partner said the super crispy catfish "was her faborite fish ever."  I'm careful doling out praise that high, but it was impressive.  A modest size piece of fish, miraculously transformed by frying, a merry crunch yielding quickly to an inside so tender you could eat the bones if you were inclined.  Creamy flavor. The tempeh, tofu and cucumbers rounded the plate out served over fragrant coconut rice. Use the condiments, sparingly if you are a newbie, but know the dish is meant to be dressed.  The crab noodles are great for late evening dining (we were there at 9 with 30 minutes till closing). Jaunty noodles with a solid spring to the bite but yielding.  Generously crabbed and including intense meatballs and dumplings.  Again, the diner bears some responsibility in the "post-production" here.  Add the laid-back broth provided with an eye towards soupifying without soggifying and add hot sauce per personal discretion and you will be able to claim a piece of pride in your excellent meal.Everything in the menu is priced $6-10 bucks (and weighted towards the cheaper end).Is this spot cursed? I hope not. A series of perfectly good kitchens have closed in this location.   This is not much of a retrofitting of the previous restaurant but a significantly different menu.  The decor and bright lights may be a bit quotidian but the food is definitely a cut above.I'm putting my blessings and dollars on this joint going long term.

He was such a sweetheart that I couldn't stop raving about how well he made his customers his number one priority!The interior is gorgeous, reflecting ceilings,  purple light against their white furniture, truly makes a romantic yet hip ambiance (it depends on your out look of romantic). Moist, tender, melt in your mouth; yeaa that was pretty much his out take on his dish. The fries we also on point, cooked to perfection!I had the Churrasco (well done) with home made mash potatoes & broccoli. My meat was bursting with latin flavor. I literally took 1 hr to eat, savoring each and every single bite! My mash potatoes had loved cooked into it and did not disappoint, my steak was tender and moist!! I was a very happy camper.The Coquito shots were on the house; and they did not disappoint at all_yummy_For dessert the staff brought was tres leches cake, while singing a happy birthday song for my baby! (it was beyond cute) The cake was super moist & was dripping with so much yummy juices we devoured it withing minutes.We decided to stay on the night club side for 45 minutes before we left,  this was my first time in a authentic latin night club. Nothing like the club I usually attend in Queens (which is a good thing) The DJ was playing a different style of mix music since the crowd was diverse, everyone was dancing and having such a great time. On the plus side they had many bouncers around to make sure everything went smoothly!!We thank the manager & our waiter on making the night so wonderful for us, plus on top of that the manger gave us 2 free drinks which won over my heart completely =) Yummy sangria!!I will definitely come back here at least once a month! Thank you Joesph for such an amazing night!
<review# 563,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/18/2014,9/8/2014,118,139,4,11,9>There's always room for another spin on one of the worlds most diverse cuisines and this Elmhurst newcomer is off to a promising start.The staff here is exceptional prepped to welcome cultural crossover. I have some multicultural dining experience under my belt (literally) but I still appreciated the polite inquiries about our spice tolerance, familiarity with shrimp paste and other preliminaries that benefit the uninitiated. No worries regarding linguistic barriers for English speakers.We tried two dishes on our first visit. My partner said the super crispy catfish "was her faborite fish ever."  I'm careful doling out praise that high, but it was impressive.  A modest size piece of fish, miraculously transformed by frying, a merry crunch yielding quickly to an inside so tender you could eat the bones if you were inclined.  Creamy flavor. The tempeh, tofu and cucumbers rounded the plate out served over fragrant coconut rice. Use the condiments, sparingly if you are a newbie, but know the dish is meant to be dressed.  The crab noodles are great for late evening dining (we were there at 9 with 30 minutes till closing). Jaunty noodles with a solid spring to the bite but yielding.  Generously crabbed and including intense meatballs and dumplings.  Again, the diner bears some responsibility in the "post-production" here.  Add the laid-back broth provided with an eye towards soupifying without soggifying and add hot sauce per personal discretion and you will be able to claim a piece of pride in your excellent meal.Everything in the menu is priced $6-10 bucks (and weighted towards the cheaper end).Is this spot cursed? I hope not. A series of perfectly good kitchens have closed in this location.   This is not much of a retrofitting of the previous restaurant but a significantly different menu.  The decor and bright lights may be a bit quotidian but the food is definitely a cut above.I'm putting my blessings and dollars on this joint going long term.
<review# 564,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/14/2014,9/7/2014,42,175,9,19,9>4.5/5.0 starsAlright, this place needs a real, informative, Queen Elite style review. Want to know what you'll get from CKO Astoria for your first class? Great, read on!Need to know:+Bring boxing gloves, Muay Thai gloves, whatever you have. You will need them for class. If you don't have any, they sell them on the premises. You can't take class without them.+Oh my God bring water. Just bring all the waters. You're going to need it.+Sneakers are worn in class. I'm used to training barefoot, so I felt this was a point to note.+There are two unisex bathrooms, which are the only private areas you can change in.+There is no locker room, but a small section of space with about ~30 small square lockers. Bring your own lock.The Setup:CKO is like thousands of square feet. This is the largest space I've seen for a kickboxing gym, and I've been to many. It's rectangular, and down the middle, length-wise, are two rows of heavy bags. So. Many. Heavybags. They have more heavy bags than all the Modells and Sports Authorities in Astoria have in their stockroom, I think. But seriously, there's like 50.There is a small "gym" area which consists of 1 bench, 1 Roman chair (with pull-up attachment) and some free weights and plates. Quaint, but useful. Plus lots of jump ropes.The Introduction:First class? Great. An instructor will do a personal mini-lesson on how to throw a jab, cross, hook, and kick. That's all you need to know, they're the most basic building blocks of kickboxing. It takes just a few minutes, so show up early.The First Class:Started off with some minimal stretching, followed by jogging laps around the room, which were occasionally interrupted by switching up on cue a different movement. So, run run run SQUAT. Run run run PUSHUP. Etc. There's tons of cardio. Hell, the whole class is cardio. Scottie likes to do (half) pyramids, which means, you'll do 1 rep, then 2, then 3, etc. all the way up to 10. The other half a pyramid involves going back down, but thank goodness that didn't happen. I barely made it to 8.You'll definitely see a variety techniques. This is not one-dimensional. You'll do lots of punching combinations with jabs, crosses, hooks, and elbows. You'll be throwing Muay Thai style kicks, low and high, teep (forward thrust) kicks, knee strikes, side kicks, and crescent kicks. There's a learning curve with some of these moves if they're unfamiliar to you.Everything is constantly getting switched up on you in 10 or 20 second intervals. Doesn't sound like a long time? Then why did I want to throw up all over the place less than halfway through the class? I'm not a wuss and I've done hard work outs, but it's been awhile since I got my butt kicked this hard.You're never pushed to do anything you're uncomfortable with, but you are encouraged to try your best. If you need to modify or stop or drink water, you won't be bothered about it.The class ends with some Plyo-type work outs, focusing on core and whatnot. This includes crunches, leg raises, etc.You will not want to move for awhile when you're done.When class is over, grab a sanitizing wipe from the dispenser nearby and clean down the heavy bag you used. Don't be gross.Tuition:+1 year membership is $69/mo, plus a $50 enrollment fee. If you sign up when you go, the enrollment fee is cut in half, to $25.+There is an NYPD/FDNY discount for the 1 year - $10 off a month.+There is a month-to-month option for $99/mo, but done for an initial 3 month commitment. No enrollment fee.+I think there was a 6 month plan, but I kind of ignored it. It's something like $79/mo, no fee.+You can buy a 10 class package for $150 ($15/class) to use whenever.+If you cancel a 12 month commitment early, there is a $250 fee.+You will continue to be billed your current rate after your commitment period is over unless you cancel.*IMPORTANT* If you want to terminate your membership after your commitment period is over, you MUST give 30 days notice by certified letter to the gym. THIRTY DAYS. PAY ATTENTION. And don't get all angry when you didn't do that and still got billed, because now that's your fault. Extra Info:I will always, HIGHLY suggest handwraps. You can take class without them, but I can't stress enough how much they will protect your wrists and all tiny bones in your hands. Get the 180" ones, none of that 108" bullshit. Ask someone to teach you how to wrap up. The ONE time I didn't use hand wraps in the past, I sprained my wrist throwing a punch and couldn't use it properly for about 3-4 months. MONTHS. THAT'S A LONG TIME. USE WRAPS. I'M YELLING.The class is coed, but predominantly female. Everyone seems nice enough.You WILL burn a ton of calories. You get back whatever you put into it.-.5 star for anyone who wants constructive criticism on technique during class. But! There will be a pad-work class coming soon. That sounds awesome.
<review# 565,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/14/2014,9/6/2014,628,678,15,19,20>There's more than Sripraphai!! Actually, Woodside/Elmhurst are home to a ton of Thai restaurants whose offerings have far more pop than any Thai in Manhattan. It's easy to get overwhelmed (oh no, too much good food, woe is me), but Playground is up there with the best of them.This self-described "bar and bistro" is next door to Zabb Elee (yelp.com/biz/zabb-elee-w), but definitely has a different feel, and serves a noticeably different (more local, more Thai) clientele. I'd initially assumed Playground was some dingy, second-rate place looking to cash in on Zabb's popularity. Turns out their relationship is less parasitic: Of course they're competitors, but Playground often has more customers. Its interior is cute and eclectic, more relaxed than Zabb even though both have the same narrow footprint. Art made of nail heads covers one wall and paper butterflies flutter above the bar against flatscreens playing Thai music videos.The best thing about Playground is that the whole menu is accessible AND interesting - more so than Zabb, more so than Sripraphai, more so than Ayada, more so than Thailand's Center Point. As someone who lives nearby, I know I can come back 20 times, find something new I want to try each time, and actually enjoy it each time.Everything starts at $8, which is spectacular. Branch out beyond fried noodles! The BBQ pork with Isan sauce is delicious (though I wish the sauce were spicier). The jungle curry is more of a soup: the fiery broth includes tons of add-ins like sprigs of green peppercorn and pretty bulbs of Thai eggplant. (Midway through the bowl is when your ears start sensing a change in atmospheric pressure due to the spiciness.) There are dishes here I've never even seen on other menus: for example, Yen Ta Fo was a sweet and tart noodle soup, stained bright neon pink by specially fermented tofu paste. Also, they serve fried grasshoppers (!!). Yes, really. Playground is one of the only spots in the neighborhood open late (til 4am, rivaling the Irish pubs!). They also deliver later than most - til 1am, officially - but aren't on the usual delivery websites. Communication via phone can be tough if you don't speak Thai. Eating in is more fun, anyway.Years ago I gave Sripraphai 5 stars. It's still great for what it is, but the Thai scene in Woodside has evolved and diversified. Playground's fun (ha) food and ambiance, cheap prices, and ridiculous hours put it on top.
<review# 566,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/15/2014,9/5/2014,227,1291,7,8,9>Holy moly, I walked by here last week and it looked like an honest to God hole-in-the-wall taqueria. Now, for those of you unfamiliar with what that is, it's basically like a dive bar but for tacos, burritos or tortas. No fusion, no high falutin 'infusions' or creme fraiche. Just thin tortillas, stuffed with well seasoned meats and some veggies. The bonus of this place is that it's good-probably the best Mexican I've had in New York. The guacamole is good and plentiful, coming in a big tub and big plate of fresh made chips coming in under 10 bucks-which is probably some of the best value guac wise compared to other places. One avocado mixed in with small pinch of cilantro in an impressive but shallow stone bowl doesn't make for good guac.The tortas also come packed and it's hard to hold onto it without it crumbling under its own weight. The chorizo was well done and you could taste the flavor as the big chunk of avocado mixed in with the other veggies. The milanesa was flattened out and crispy which was practically spilled out over the edges of the soft, tasty torta bread, The burrito which-can easily be split by two very hungry people-or 4 small children is under 7 bucks and with a Jarritos it's a feast for under 10 bucks. Cash only

<review# 569,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/19/2014,9/2/2014,161,90,15,19,19>Before Baidu, Little Sheep, Little Lamb, or any of the hotpot places I've gone..this was my first Shabu experience outside of home. This place is great when you're sick because you get your own pot. your germs stay in your pot, and not anybody else. You order by meals or sets which includes a pot of soup (additional charge for different flavors) and a small plate of meat, seafood, or both. There's a sauce station on both the lower area and main floor for convenience. Everything in the sauce station are fresh and always filled, so nothing runs out. The portions that they give out is a little bit more smaller than most places, but I'm not complaining much because most of their things are super fresh and clean. The service is also on point. They always fill your pot with soup when it gets low. It's a great place to take first timers because they can get a feel of it and it's not as pricy as AYCE and a la carte places like Little Lamb.

I forgot the song they played then riri came on...lol..we looked at each other and just laughed. I liked that the music wasn't obnoxiously loud also. Give this gem a try if you like my review.
<review# 571,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/14/2013,3/15/2013,286,298,10,22,17>The best cure for the winter blues? Hot pot with friends! When one of my best girls was in town the past weekend and suggested hot pot at Little Pepper based on the suggestion of her friend, I couldn't say no. Ever since my favorite hot pot place in Flushing went downhill I've been on the hunt for a new go to hot pot spot and Little Pepper has been on my to-try list. Hot pot at Little Pepper starts at a base price of $24.95/pot. First choose your soup base: spicy, original, or combo. Combo is the way to go! Why pick one when you can have both? With the combo pot, you'll get a split pot of the spicy broth on one side and the original broth on the other side. The spicy Sichuan broth is filled with chili peppers, hot oil, and peppercorns (note: they can make it more spicy if you're not satisfied) and the original broth is a lightly seasoned tomato and veggies broth. With the per pot flat fee you also get a veggie platter (napa cabbage, watercress, bean sprouts, corn on the cob, and wood-ear "mu-er" mushrooms) and a shabu beef platter. Anything on top of that is priced per item. They have a handy dandy checklist for you to mark off the items that you want. I suggest starting out with about 2-3 add-ons per person in your group; you can always add more later if that's not enough.Their ingredients selection was alright; I was a little surprised at the less traditional hot pot items that they had available (duck tongue, kidney, chicken feet, quail egg, etc.) and at the standards that they were missing (tripe, beef tendon balls, squid, various dumplings, spinach, etc.), but no matter - what they had was enough to satisfy. I was impressed with the quality of their ingredients; the meats were perfect thin, frozen slices, and their seafood and veggies were well-cleaned and very fresh. I did note, however, that the frozen tofu (dong doufu) we were were given was actually fried tofu and their chrysanthemum greens (tong hao) were actually another leafy vegetable. Their sauce station has everything a hot pot connoisseur needs: Chinese BBQ sauce (sha cha jiang), soy sauce, sesame oil, cilantro, scallions, garlic, hot sauce, fish sauce, bean paste, and on and on. Just mix your favorites to your heart's desire. AND if you're feeling adventurous (or if you're Taiwanese) don't forget to ask for an egg (not on the menu, but available) to mix into your sauce bowl. Also located at the sauce station are extra bowls and utensils, ladles, and wire mesh ladles.The service is efficient and otherwise hands-off, which is how it should be at a hot pot restaurant. Hint: If you notice that your pot is running low on broth, you should know that the broth is refillable for free. However, they will fill both spicy broths and original broths with the original broth so I suggest that you don't refill your spicy broth unless you're trying to dilute it. *Cash only!
<review# 572,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/7/2013,3/14/2013,410,456,4,10,6>Before the massive renovations of this quaint little restaurant took place.. we use to just come here for  Pizza, nothing really special.....We've been living in the area for more than 16 years but never considered dining there.
