<review# 573,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/6/2012,3/13/2013,783,346,4,11,8>I'm not sure what just happened.  Somehow my friend who is newly moved to LIC was right about a hyperbolic statement like "I know where the best tacos are."   My friend even went so far as to claim that the Mexican food here was better than food in Mexico.   I don't know about overall Mexican food, but the tacos here do happen to be the best tacos ever.  I don't pretend to be a taco connoisseur but I know when my tastebuds like something.  And I know when they really REALLY like something.   This was the case here.   Suffice it to say I came here for the first time on a random Tuesday and was back on Thursday the same week to have other friends experience what I just did.  The COW TONGUE TACOS here are, in a word, divine.  I have not had a better taco.  The texture and flavors and juiciness are all perfect.  I could come here and just eat that.   There are 3 sauces that you get to try with the tacos and they are all fresh and delicious -- my favorite is the orange one.   I also tried the brisket tacos and the pork tacos.  The pork one was drier than I would have liked, but the brisket is also very good.  I haven't even tried the chorizo -- you can bet that's coming next.  The MEATBALLS are also amazing.  My co-worker liked those best.  They have a unique, almost sweeter flavor than other meatballs I've tried.  I would definitely would order those again.  I tried one entree here -- the PORK RIBS.  Very good.  Exceptional, even.  Falling-off-the-bone-slathered-in-sauce good.  But this came after the tacos and I was already so blown away I feel like I barely registered how good the pork ribs were.   I would like to come back and try the lamb.  Both times I've been here I got the guac as an appetizer, which IS good, but a very very small portion.  It's like $8 and they use one avocado -- enough for 2 but any more than that and it almost seems silly not to order more than one.  Lastly, the TRES LECHES CAKE.  Oh man.  I have not had one that even came close to this -- this is hands down the best of of the tres leches I've ever had.   I used to think I didn't like tres leches but now I know why -- I've never had them here before.  The flan and Mexican chocolate pot is also good.  I like the atmosphere too -- it almost reminds me of a Greek restaurant with the white walls and tables.   It's darkly lit with candles for dinner, giving it a more sophisticated feel than you'd think when it comes to home cooked Mexican.  I would celebrate a special occasion here with friends.  AND they currently are BYOB but in the process of getting a liquor license.  Which means any day now they will no longer be BYOB.   Sad.  Go soon if you want to try the food with your own alcoholic beverage.

<review# 575,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/17/2012,3/11/2013,76,131,5,11,10>Boasting a menu of 18 different pizzas, each pie bears a personal story. The Nonna features owner Stephen Menna's grandmother's meatball recipe; the Pistachianco--with the aforementioned green Sicilian nuts, fior di latte, and ricotta--is a shout-out to Chris Bianco. Another is named after his neighbor, who suggested adding raisins to a prosciutto pie, which ended up making the cut.Pizzas range from $9 to $16 per 12-inch personal pie, which which aligns the cost with Queens prices fairly well (Margherita pizza = $11 at Tufino and $10 at Basil versus $13 at Keste and $15 at Motorino).The fiery oven, which must warm up to around 1,000 degrees Fahrenheit, bears the mosaic moniker 'di Maria' in tribute to Menna's wife, who built him his first pizza oven in their backyard as an anniversary gift.So how is the pizza, you wonder?  It's not just good.  It's phenomenal, achieving what many of the city's neapolitan nooks cannot...  The sourdough is leavened naturally... a 200 year old technique that takes nearly two days.  Menna is an admitted admirer of Una Pizza Napoletana's Anthony Mangieri.  Like Mangieri, Menna counts the baking time in seconds, rather than minutes, with most pies averaging around 90. So an exquisite dough is gently hand-stretched like a dopey dwarf cap that falls loosely down the pizzaiolo's forearms as it twirls.  A shallow layer of choice toppings are meticulously applied (Menna places mozzarella crumbles as if setting jewels in a crown).  He then gently places the pie in the flickering dome opposite the embers in indirect heat, and the flames and pie have a staredown.  The pie rises slowly as if posturing, then gently blisters in the heat, as charred bubbles of condensed flavor arise on the outer crust.  And then just before succumbing completely to the heat, Menna retrieves the pie at its most vulnerable stage, carefully checking its underside with a long wooden peel before sliding it onto a metal disc to serve steaming to the table.Check out the edges, the flaky and chewy bubbles filling the puffy end crust, in contrast with a flatter, crisp inner crust...  After you eat the tip, you rip the edges as steam escapes, to dip the salty spongy sourdough in the spilled cheeses and olive oil.  The pies are served with a knife--unsliced--to avoid compromising the crust as toppings and sauces escape under the pizzas.  This also allows the guest to rip and tear at the gourmet rounds at their own pace.The addition of fontina to the Greek added an earthiness I loved, with those tangy (and pitted, thank goodness!) kalamata olives, but the sprinkle of oregano with the chilled mist of lemon juice added post-oven really makes the pie special, with flavors that pop.  On the San Gennaro, the drizzle of a playfully spicy picante honey makes the pie particularly special.  It's like what the street festival in Little Italy might taste like in a dream.  But there is always something to be said about an excellent margherita, which is the standard by which I gauge any pizzeria.  Although I now feel compelled to return until I have tried several other pies, I will most likely intermittently order the excellent margherita--whose simple, bright, satisfying flavors and scents are what we think of as pizza when we crave it most.
<review# 576,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/25/2012,3/10/2013,383,301,3,5,5>This is among the most authentic Hong Kong Style Tea Houses I've been to in New York City, and yes, I've been looking around. It's very difficult to earn five stars from me, but this place does. I come here once a week.Food: my favorite dinner/lunch dish is the baked curry with fried pork chop over fried rice (please excuse the literal translation from Cantonese). Be wary: they may run out of this item, so try to get there before the "rush." Other items such as Sing Chow Stir Fried Noodles and baked fish over fried rice were wonderful. Actually, I have yet to taste an item that wasn't good here. The bakery items do not disappoint, either!Service: the women behind the counter are extremely friendly and nice. Obviously, this isn't leave to piss them off on purpose, because, just like in Hong Kong, they'll be very nice one second and verbally decimate you the next. There have been comments about this being a no-nonsense type of place, and I agree, but if you're dealing with extremely rude customers all the time, you'd probably be the same way, too. However, I have found that smiling and being friendly helps a lot. Another tip: call your order in before you start heading there to avoid any wait time. Decor: it's a very typical setup of bakery/restaurant. Seating is limited and tables can be a bit oily. Wipe it down with a napkin before use!I love the large parking lot they have in the rear.
<review# 577,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/21/2012,3/9/2013,60,352,7,17,13>So... as much as I love this site-- and I do love it so-- I realize that sometimes it can lead you astray. I'd checked out the reviews for this place prior to going, and I'd noticed the dreaded 3 star rating it has gotten. So my first review was purely based on having drinks there, because I was skeptical about trying the food: "expensive" and "tiny". Then on a whim, I decided to try brunch there I figured as long as I wasn't bringing a date, I could afford to splurge on myself. So I enter, and again am grateful that this place is right around the corner from my house. Especially since I'm carrying a heavy bag full of Senior papers to grade. I get inside, and there is a small gathering of people at the bar in the back enjoying Sunday football and each others company. As er the first time, I'm greeted warmly by the chef. When I inquire about a table, she tells me that brunch had just ended, and they were cleaning up for dinner. But she give it a second thought and directs me to a table. Very nice. I sit and am brought all the necessary things for my table: water, bread, cutlery, and a menu. She discusses what she still has, and she gives me some suggestions. So since it's NFL Sunday, let's put it in those terms: so far the team is making no errors, and capitalizing on the other guys errors in my book. S the food Everyone makes a comment on the "portions". Notice that. Because I tried the veal tortellini, and from the first bite I can't wait to come back and try something else. The whole experience was suddenly "clear" to me: the decor, the welcoming manner of the staff, the music, the food. I was sitting in the lap of civility. Not she doesn't want to stuff food down my gullet as though I was some sow being fatten for slaughter. There is enough here to not be hungry anymore, full no. Bloated, hell no. The dish is exclaiming: "This is a exercise in precision!" I was worried from those previous reviews. I've been to places where you get "very" little to even gauge what the culinary experience was supposed to be really. Over before it started. Sitting there unsatisfied saying, "It's okay really. Happens to a lot of chefs." But as I walked home, I noticed how blue the sky was. Which is oft the inspirited feeling you get when you experience something exquisite.
<review# 578,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/27/2012,3/8/2013,83,197,5,7,5>Monster is really becoming a staple of KTV in Flushing. Right smack in the middle of the busiest area, it has delivered consistent ka la OK for years. Nowadays I even consider it to being one of the cheapest in the region with being $30-$35 a hour at night. Their rooms are more cramp compared to the other karaoke joints but they make it up by providing better service. Like most Chinese karaoke places, you can order food and drinks for free up to the cost of the room. Songs are fairly updated but it's hard to say since it feels like every Karaoke place uses the same touch screen tablet system and song database now. But what stays constant is it will be majority Chinese songs and even their English selection has improved. When you can't afford to go to DIYuan karaoke or feeling that you need a less shady place like CEO karaoke, Monster would be my destination.

<review# 580,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/22/2012,3/6/2013,193,122,4,8,6>I work at the hospital one block away so I buy breakfast at this bakery almost everyday. The buns come out fresh and hot around 6:45 each morning, however, I usually come earlier that. The guy told me to come back later for the buns. One day he actually made the buns earlier for me. Buns, cakes, and pastries are all so yummy. The stuff here are very different from your typical Chinese bakery (it's Taiwanese). Cakes are light and fluffy, buns are flavorful. Although they do have a smaller selection than most bakeries, overall, it's the taste and quality that really matters. One con would be that the coffee is not as strong as I would like, but not a deal breaker. There are so few chairs in there and no real tables for you to eat on. Lines can get long and the bakery is very small.

<review# 582,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/25/2013,2/21/2014,186,113,2,10,7>I've been to COFFEED numerous times and the experience has been consistent, which is great.The coffee is great, strong, and definitely roasted with care. We all can appreciate Starbucks/Dunkin when rushing around or strapped for cash. But, when it comes to having a real quality cup of coffee and this place really delivers.  It takes me about 20 minutes to get here on the subway in Astoria, with a decent walk from the subway to the shop, but I make the trip often. Astoria doesn't have anything close to this quality, coffee shops haven't really taken off there yet. (I love Astoria otherwise!) *Note: Yes, "Queens Kickshaw" is fantastic but I consider it a great lunch spot with great coffee, as opposed to a coffee shop, especially since the shut wifi off at noon*// DRINK //The 'cold-brew' here is strong and delicious. They use what looks like a science lab set to brew it (think Gale from "Breaking Bad") and it takes almost 2 days to brew it. It's extremely caffeinated due to this process so they need to water it down a little but it's great. I recommend if you live nearby you purchase the cold-brew flask. It's like $7 to refill and I get about 4 iced coffees out of it - because I cut a third with water (as recommended by them because it's basically a concentrate). 4 iced coffees inside COFFEED = $12.004 from the flask = $7.00// EAT //Baked goods here are 'ok' some are kind of dry but not bad. The brownie with powered sugar on top is RIDICULOUSLY good. The food is good, especially the grilled cheese panini. The greens and vegetables are farmed on the roof of the building! Which it think is really cool, that's some fresh veggies!// INTERIOR //The interior is warehouse like, high ceilings and has a huge window that they open on nice days. I came once the whole window (basically the wall) was open and it was pouring raining outside, no one was getting wet and it was awesome to feel like you were sitting in the rain drinking coffee. They recently doubled this place in size by removing a wall - it's huge and seems to have better seating. They could use a few more power outlets, there are basically none.// POSSIBLE IMPROVEMENTS //The only thing COFFEED needs to improve is customer service. Sometimes I feel like I'm imposing by ordering or asking a question (not always though, some employees are great) but it's definitely different than Brooklyn Bagel (30th Ave) for example, who are somehow always bright and welcoming.--------------------------// OVERALL //COFFEED is highly recommended, especially in the area. Best quality around. --------------------------// FUN FACTS //* During the warmer months you can visit the "Brooklyn Grange" 1 acre farm on the rooftop on Saturdays in the morning. (All the veggies they serve are from the farm)* On weekends they host the "Queens Urban Market" * They have a loyalty card, every 11th coffees(hot or cold) is FREE.* They serve "Single-Cut Brewery" (Queens, NY) beer on tap.

<review# 588,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/1/2013,2/15/2014,1196,94,11,8,7>I'm sure Batman lives somewhere around here. I'm sure he needs a new Robin so I will begin my quest to find him. Good thing I wrote this review on the first day of October, I hope I see him on the last day of it.A very tall glass building, one of the first in Long Island City (an area that has many similar or taller buildings coming up each year). Just looking at the building itself is a wonder (almost as if it has it's own personality); on a rainy day it looks mysterious, on a sunny day it's beaming, on a cloudy day it looks welcoming.This huge building is currently being occupied by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene on half of the first floor and all of the upper levels. The rest of the first floor is split into four other areas. To the left of the city agency's entrance is a large empty space, it's big enough for a club. Most of the activity here is 8am-4pm, the building is usually empty of employees by the time the sun sets. This makes that empty space an ideal location to host events, since there's no one to be bothered by loud music in the late hours of the day. To the right of the DOH is Chickpea which recently opened in 2013, give it a try when passing by. Next to Chickpea, is the loading dock for all deliveries for this building. Then next to that, there's an underground parking lot. This is where many Department of Transportation economy cars hide. If we see a really cool black car with spikes on the hood exiting out of it, then it will be official: this large space underground just might be the Batcave!Behind the building is a very large space, which is empty, it stretches for the remainder half of this block. Would be a great spot to open up a large parking lot or maybe even a mall. The city could really use this to create hundreds of new jobs, unless its preoccupied as the take-off strip for the Batplane.I could just imagine it now, New York City's name changed to New Gotham City.
<review# 589,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/9/2013,2/14/2014,2398,639,8,14,9>Aki gets three and a half stars and the half star bump up because, it is what it is.Aki is a discount sushi place with decent sushi.There is a lot of competition on the block for sushi.  Aki is the clear price winner, hands down, blind folded.There is no pretentious anything at Aki.  They have a menu.  They are well decorated and clean.  They half half price sushi.  They will take your order then leave you to whatever it is you do besides eat.  The rolls are really well priced.Every salmon combination I have tried is good, including the New York roll with apple and mayo.If you are looking to impress someone, there are places with nicer decor on the block.  If you want to eat, not break the bank and get a pretty no frills, cheap experience, without worrying about getting sick or having gas station like sushi, Aki wins hands down.  As a discount sushi spot, it gets four stars.  It is what it is, and it doesn't pretend to be what it is not.

They also sell olive oil, jarred and pickled veggies. On to the food... I ordered the Cobb salad, and a friend ordered the slow cooked pork with a side of braised green lentils. Food was outstanding! Yes, salad can taste good. The eggs were cooked perfectly. The chicken was moist. The one thing I wasn't happy with was the amount of dressing. It was realllly heavy. They're in that super healthy food category, and I don't really enjoy anything from that category, but when you cook lentils like this, how can I pass it up?? <review# 596,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/27/2011,12/8/2012,0,136,4,11,6>I miss living in Queens, but this place is so worth the trip back home to have some good ass dominican food. No matter how I get here, I love coming to La Brisa. They say the best way to a person's heart is through the stomach and in this case, I'm in love. It's a filet of fish with the lemon and wine sauce with a side of sweet plaintains. The Bistec Palomilla Encebollado (Steak and Onions) is also really tasty. I dislike beans but the dominican style rice and beans convinced me otherwise.  Whether you're dining or taking out, they usually give you a complimentary dominican salad as an appetizer. It consist of iceberg lettuce, tomato, onion, and beet slices with a side of an oil and vinegar diced red pepper dressing. It's so simple and yet so good! They accept cards and the price is very reasonable for the huge portions they give you.Overall, La Brisa is a great neighborhood restaurant and the ambiance feels very much like home when you enter. Although the decor doesn't look like much, it sure doesn't try to be something it's not. They usually play music from the jukebox unless there's a Mets game on. :) Gotta rep the borough!

I noticed I had a little smidgeon of hot sauce on my face when I looked in the rear-view mirror in my car before departing. They graciously provide a wet nap and a decent amount of napkins for they already knew what kind of sensual mess I was getting myself into. I might ask for no sauce on the sandwich next time and dip as I go. Although, I might slightly regret missing out on the fun of getting down and dirty with your patacon. When I got home I had a pleasant food high. (an episode of uncontrollable giggles)At $7.07 for a patacon full loaded with meat it's a steal for a glutton like me. Definitely going back to try the chicken and other menu items they offer.

<review# 599,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/10/2012,12/5/2012,93,365,2,8,5>Previous to dining here, I would have commented that having dim sum outside of Chinatown or Flushing was blasphemy. I was convinced that quality dim sum outside of these areas was an impossibility. East Ocean Palace showed me just how wrong I was.Upon entering, you'll find that it looks very much like your standard dim sum restaurant although significantly less hectic. There was an absence of the familiar, oversized banquet style seat covers that I abhor. Dim Sum restaurants can feel like zoos: chaotic, loud, bustling spaces with too much going on and too many people and carts packed into too small of a space. This was not the case here. Tables were spaced out nicely, leaving plenty of room for people and carts to maneuver efficiently without making the space and patrons feel cluttered.Immediately after being seated, we were swarmed upon and offered every type of dim sum available. I'm not sure what other reviewers were speaking of when they remarked on the employees not speaking English, or not offering up the names or descriptions of the dim sum they offered: on the contrary, they spoke very well and informed us properly of each item. We ordered a variety of things, and I think we may have sampled almost every type of shrimp dim sum they offered. Everything was served hot, fresh and very tasty. We also ordered the seafood pan fried noodles, which came in a generous portion and was equally delicious.Service was extremely gracious and attentive. We never felt like we were searching for assistance. In fact, I felt as though they made their best efforts to anticipate our needs. I'd venture to say that the service was far better here than I've experienced at various Chinatown and Flushing locations, and better yet, they serve dim sum until 4:00 pm! The rest of the menu is also very extensive. I took one to go, and appreciated the many vivid photos of their items, which provide helpful for those less familiar with Cantonese cuisine.

<review# 601,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/13/2014,5/13/2014,325,275,13,21,18>We used to come here when it was Dae Dong, our regular KBBQ place, but has now been reincarnated as BCD Tofu House.  Most of the gas table grills & overhead vents are now gone and replaced by sleek décor, except in the private rooms, which retain the grills, but I never saw them in use.The menu has been transformed, but retains many of the traditional Korean favorites, with a concentration on their namesake signature dish, tofu soup (soondubu), offering a variety of different types.  Many grilled meats including bulgogi, galbi & pork belly are listed twice, from the kitchen and grill your own.  The banchan variety is decent with 6 or 7 types, but they kept refilling our dishes (twice even!), so we were happy.  The variety rotates, but will always include 2-3 types of kimchi.  And everybody gets their own personal fried fish (yellow croaker) as appetizer!  Just be careful of the bones though.So we ordered the Dol Sot Bibimbap, LA Galbi, Jap Chae & the Seafood Soondubu.  The meat items were flavorful and everything came out scorchingly hot on clay platters or bowls including the white rice.  The rice pots were later soaked in hot water and made rice soup that I remember my mom used to make in the rice pot (in Chinese, we'd call it noong jook).  The Jap Chae stood out because it was served on a miniature deep-fried tofu fort, which is the only way I can describe it.  The soondubu was a little lacking with only one of each clam, mussel & shrimp, but the flavor was good.  For a Korean meal, this is one of the most affordable I've ever had.  Good deal, BCD!

<review# 608,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/15/2013,5/6/2014,241,315,23,23,22>A Chinese soldier returns home after fighting off the evil nationalists. He enters a tiny wooden store and pulls over a half broken stool. He dusts off the snow on his red star cap and leans his M1-Garand on the wall next to him."Auntie, a bowl of wonton! ""Hao lei!" replies a voice in the back. A minute later, an old woman comes out holding a big bowl of wonton noodles. The hot steam from the bowl furiously evaporates into the cold winter air, at the same time materializing hunger within 10 meters radius. Without a second to lose, the soldier slurps down the hot noodles*, once or twice pausing to wipe his mouth with his dirt covered uniform. He slams the empty bowl on the table, warm and full, and delivers a handsome smiles before the movie credits roll.==== review starts====Everything about White Bear makes me fantasize about the scenario above. The modest simplicity, or even the dirtiness of the store has an unsual warmth to it, especially in the cold of Winter. The naked, white cracked walls, the old and busted chairs, and the inexplicable need for an electric fly swatter (even though there were no flies) makes it feel so welcoming. Why is that? Wahed K, why is that??The one obvious feature of White Bear that usually knocks me right out of roleplay is the sheer amount of white people in here. As a matter of fact, the percentage of white-asian ratio here trumps every other Flushing place I know. I gotta give it to the white people though - this time they got it right.The wonton noodles are good. The noodles are flat soft noodles. It sort of breaks apart in your mouth, which is a completely different sensation as chewy ramen noodles, but still oh so good. The wontons are meaty and flavorful, like the ones I make at home with chicken bouillon with dark soysauce (and sprinkle it with a bit of salt, oolala)But the dumplings. Oh my Goodness. You buy 50 for 10 bucks raw or around 4.50 bucks for 10 cooked. One of the best dumplings I've had, ever since quality of dumplings have been deteriorating as of late (I'm looking at you, Golden Palace!) Get the leek ones. By the way I don't know the diff between Chinese chives and leek. In my experience the latter translation always turns out superior. Whats included:- Northern accented auntie.- Homey atmosphere- Good Northern food.- English menuWhats not included:- M1 garand.- Slurping. Fuck American culture.* You should always slurp:chowhound.chow.com/topic
<review# 609,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/2/2014,5/5/2014,783,346,12,17,13>Hello, egg tart of my dreams.  Where did you come from?  Sometimes life casually tosses not lemons, but pleasant surprises into your lap - that is, if you are so lucky or tenacious to be at the right place at the right time, armed with an open mind and ready taste buds.  The exterior of the Portuguese egg tart is promising: delicately caramelized surface of the richest, creamiest custard, which rests in a crust that can only be described as perfectly flakey.   The custard is very much like the crème brulee after you've cracked the shell with the culinary weapon of your choice.  This is not your gelatinous egg custards of TaiPan with a distinctly "eggy" taste.  This is much more of a dessert - it's sweet.  You should like sweet things if you expect to enjoy this treat.   The density of the custard is thicker than the typical dan tat, and oddly light at the same time.  It has a bit of the magical fluffiness of successful soufflé centers, and the grounded down-to-earth consistency of panna cotta.  The flavors are of slightly burnt caramel, vanilla, maple.  Having experienced such unexpected and unparalleled joy (at least when it comes to the very finite universe of egg tarts), the I found myself exhibiting similar symptoms to having fallen in love.  Daydreaming while in the clutches of the mundane, day-to-day. Getting tongue-tied around my friends ("you guys have to try these amazing egg tahts!" - accidentally fusing "egg tart" and "dan tat", and sounding suddenly Bostonian).  Realizing upon first bite that a part of me had always known, even in the midst of disappointing encounters, that such a thing of perfection was out there.  Suppressing the irresistible desire to gush to anyone within earshot.     If you want to get metaphysical about it, conceivably, every mediocre-to-bad egg tart experience of my past could have merely been preparing me to meet this one.  Hello, again.   I'm glad I found you.

<review# 613,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/13/2012,6/23/2013,29,86,4,4,4>What's a girl to do when she's sick and needs some good ole Asian comfort food? And mom's not around? Go to Sifu Chio's!Not only does Sifu Chio's have authentic HK-style wontons and shrimp & watercress dumplings in noodle soup, but they also have have some of the most authentic HK-style rice congee I've had in NY, and that includes Chinatown..Sifu Chio's rice congee is slow-cooked until the rice is disintigrated and the congee reaches a porridge-like consistency. You can tell that they don't use a cornstarch slurry to thicken their congee because it doesn't get watery after a few spoonfuls. I like that even their plain rice congee has flavor.. I got the congee with lean pork and preserved duck egg. You get a huge bowl for $4.50 and it has slices of fresh pork and an entire preserved duck egg cut into small pieces. Add a sprinkling of thinly sliced scallions and a dash of white pepper and you have comfort in a bowl!The menu prices have gone up again. The same bowl of congee used to be $3.75 and now it's $4.50. It's still a bargain but not as much as it used to be.. but at least they still use the same quality ingredients!
<review# 614,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/25/2013,6/22/2013,69,32,4,5,4>This is the place to go for Newari food (which is still Nepali food, but Newars are a particular ethnic group, and they have some unique dishes of their own). Their dhal bhat tarkari as well as their momos--the staples that all Nepali folks love to eat--is good. I also recommend their chatamari (Newari dish) and their fried fish (best Nepali-style fried fish that I've had outside of Nepal so far).The staff are super friendly, it's a family run business, and they will try to make your experience there as pleasant as possible. The interior could use some work, so I wouldn't recommend taking a date there. He/she won't be impressed. However, if you want authentic, home-cooked, Nepali/Newari food, this is a great little spot. You will mostly see Nepali folks dining out in this place--it's a local favorite.
<review# 615,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/21/2013,6/21/2013,262,613,8,8,10>After discovering that certain parks in Great Neck are resident only and feeling the sting of exclusivity, I browsed my GPS selection of attractions and found Crocheron Park.The name sounds like a sister planet to Princess Leia's home world, unless I'm mispronouncing the 'on' as an 'aan' .However, the Crocheron family name dates back to the late 1600's and includes congressmen and gamblers. Apparently the infamous political machine leader Boss Tweed sought shelter at the Crocheron House during the 1870's after he escaped jail. Eventually the Crocheron House and surrounding land was acquired by the City of New York and transformed into a park.We entered by the John Golden section of the park. Walking past tennis courts, I was impressed by the cleanliness and spaciousness of the park. Beautiful tall trees starting to blossom added to the grandiosity of it all. Making our way closer to the waterfront, we're presented with a some cliffside view of Little Neck Bay (and the Cross Island Parkway immediately below).There was a staircase and pedestrian bridge leading to the immediate waterfront area but we didn't partake this time.Bathroom facilities are present by the tennis courts and baseball fields. Unfortunately they were not open after 6pm when nature called.I spotted plenty of happy dogs wandering about as well. I'll definitely return for a walk or run along the many paths.

I really can't say enough good things about this place. I am happy they are here and I hope you will give them a try. I know I will continue to go here over and over again.....considering how close I am to them LOL  ( It's ok to be jealous!)

<review# 622,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/29/2012,4/8/2012,289,416,11,17,15>Cevapcici. The days are starting to get warmer and if  grilling is also one of your favorite activities, then Astoria is the best neighborhood to find different types of meat for the grill.   In addition to Brazil's "linguica", Greek "shishkebabs" and the other usual suspects,  "cevapcici", pronounced "shevapchichi" are Croatian sausages that would expand the variety in your barbecue party.It is sold for $10.99 for a box of eighteen (18) pieces in this store and you can just get a jar of the spicy sauce and the pita bread it is usually served with.   As you buy from this store, you'll also get service as warm as the air in southeastern Europe which makes you want to fire the grill all the more.  Just don't forget to invite me.

To me a restaurant is based on the food, the staff and the cleanliness of the environment. mad for chicken aces all three.  The first time I was in the restaurant my friend and I were greeted as if we were regulars.  The staff was and always is very friendly and ready to make your dining there very pleasant. It was some of the best chicken I've had in my life. it was spicy but not as spicy as he lead me to believe, but then again I've tangled with a ghost chili or two in my time so my tolerance for spice is high. ( I hadn't mentioned that to him). All in all a great dining experience. Most recently i went there with my girlfriend and she agreed it was as good as she's had too.  This time along with the chicken we ordered the Kim Mary which is a deep fired kimbap or a seaweed roll filled with rice and other goodies. fried to perfection it was so good I had to slow down eating it so I didn't accidentally bite the tips of my fingers. Lastly we had the kimchi fried rice.  I will never be able to have pork fried rice from the local Chinese place again  This was also some of the best I've had from the pieces of spicy sausage to the fried eggs on top it was absolutely delicious.if you are ever in the area you must stop by for some chicken you will definitely be back for more.

<review# 625,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/11/2011,4/5/2012,666,1833,5,7,6>Whenever I wander into Flushing Chinatown, this inevitably becomes a target. It's a surefire winner with an awesome selection, great service, and a knack for feeding any random craving I may have. I love the BBQ corn, which has a great kick thanks to all the spices it's rolled in, and one order is good to split between two people. The soups of all kinds are piping hot, a personal favorite is the three mushroom soup with vermicelli. You can pick your ingredients, down to noodle type, and slurp away. Don't wear a white shirt unless you have somehow magically figured out how to get hot soup and noodles into your mouth with a shallow spoon and chopsticks and not dribble it all down your front. If you have perfected this momentous feat, please teach me, because apparently I have the culinary grace of a two year old despite years of experience. The entrees and rice dishes are also great, a personal favorite is the fried seafood rice. Overall, I'd advise going with a group, or just one or two other very hungry people (or those whose eyes are bigger than their stomachs, myself for example). Get a bunch of stuff and share. Make sure to add some homemade pickle to everything, or at least try it, it's delicious! Regardless, you'll end up with leftovers. And that is always a good thing!
<review# 626,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/8/2011,4/4/2012,242,180,6,6,7>Let me mark my territory quickly before this place blows up. Contrary to what many people may think (*ahem* Serious Eats I'm looking at you), this isn't shaved ice. Yes. The concept, machine and execution are similar. But it is not 'tsua bing' or 'bao bing' .Snopo serves 'Xue Hua Bing', literally translated as 'Snowflake Ice'. To put it simply (yet vaguely), it tastes like flavored snowflakes or iced cotton candy or powdered slushie or any combination of those words. Instead of shaving pure ice, Xue Hua Bing is made by shaving a pre-made frozen mixture of ice, milk and flavoring. This creates a treat very similar to the the snowflakes that fall in your dreams and possibly on the set of "Cloudy With A Chance of Meatball". I've shared a plate with girls, I've shared a plate with guys, I've shared a plate with Asians, I've shared a plate with Albanians. Xue Hua Bing does not discriminate its fan base. One plate is more than enough for two and serves as the perfect capper to a dinner in Flushing. The portions are huge and remind me of the snowpile that accumulates after I finish shoveling my driveway. While the dessert is unique, don't try to get fancy with your order. All the bad experiences in reviews had people trying "Romantic Snowy", just go with the regular Mango Ice with condensed milk (included, no need to ask) and you're golden. Snopo isn't my first experience with Xue Hua Bing in the States, that honor goes to Cloud9 in Chicago, but Snopo's version had the biggest portions with the most robust taste and the most variety of flavors.

<review# 628,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/13/2011,4/1/2012,32,219,6,9,9>I popped over here to see what a million dollar renovation will get you in Queens. A lot, apparently. The lobby is very MOMA-esque, with the addition of a bright, space-age blue light leading into one of the main theatres. The very friendly front desk let us know that most films are free with general admission ($10, although I look 16 in direct sunlight, so I got offered a student rate). On top of their arthouse-y foreign film offerings, they're showing vintage Green Hornet episodes every half hour or so in a kitschy theatre off the film wing. The general collection is relatively (to Manhattan museums) small, but pretty cool -- for instance, nerds, there's arcade games so I never have to go to Barcade to play Donkey Kong again. And you can see Chewbacca's head! Or, the head Peter Mayhew wore to be Chewbacca, if you're going to be a buzzkill.My favorite part of the museum was the temporary Real Virtuality exhibit on the top floor. It's a curated play on "virtual reality," and definitely an interesting experience. Although it smelled a little mildew-y up there, the free guided tour was a lot of fun. It's not often something can be a great date spot OR a place to take your family. Check it out!

<review# 630,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/24/2012,3/30/2012,316,268,15,16,17>Service with a smile. An age old idea that hasn't survived our fast-paced, entitled lifestyles. However it lives on in this small halal cart on Queens Blvd. Most guys in their halal carts look and sound like they hate life. The guy here at Shah's smiles as if he was born to serve delicious $6 rice platters (+ soda) to starving commuters struggling with the mediocre offerings in the surrounding Briarwood area. No matter what time of the night it is, he's happy to see me. He smiles because he has one of the best lamb over rice platters I've tasted in NYC. Nicely seasoned chunks of meat tower over fluffy rice that when mixed with that white sauce, I almost always finish before going to town on the meat. Hot sauce that is flavorful yet gentle on both your mouth and bowels alike.. and of course a complete last minute meal with drink for $6. Shah's, thanks for making quick cheap meal options in the hood exciting again.

<review# 632,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/23/2011,10/23/2012,30,76,9,6,8>As a Sunnyside resident, I should be annoyed that most my buddies in Astoria have adopted Mosaic as their go-to spot for tipsy fraternizations. It is possibly the farthest bar for me to bike to except for the Con-Ed Plant's speak-easy which I like to imagine exists. But not a murmur of protest escapes my normally overly critical mouth because Mosaic does a splendid job in being exactly the bar/lounge I'd like to frequent. With most of my reviews I like start with a few lines about the decor. They are usually short throwaway anecdotes that I hope people glance over before they realize how pointless the statements are. But with Mosaic, the atmosphere is a huge draw for me and I would encourage any visitors to take a moment to appreciate it. It is Victorian-esque with playful color scheme but stops just short of being gaudy. It is what I imagine what Oscar Wilde's parlour room would look like while he exchanges witticisms with the Cheshire Cat. The seating itself, except for the bar, is largely self-contained so expect more intimacy with the group you are with rather than bumping elbows with strangers. Still though, the place is small enough to cheerily infringe on neighboring conversations and make new friends. The music selection has yet to be disappointing. Solid alternative tunes that sound hand picked rather than a playlist of popular Billboard listed tracks (They don't play Foster the People's "Pumped Up Kicks" on loop. I'm looking at you EVERYWHERE ELSE), More importantly, they play it at a reasonable volume setting that somehow eludes so many other bars.With these qualities in mind, along with the fantastic beer selection and friendly staff, Astoria should consider itself lucky to have Mosaic around. The worst part about it is the horrific squeaking sounds emitted in the area as I trudge on my crappy bike home from here.

They have catalogs, and if you like a particular bike that they don't have in store, they can build one for you so that you can test ride for a $200 deposit. You're not obligated to buy it, so no pressure. I really regret going to Bicycle Habitat to get my Specialized hybrid. It's so far, and my sticker for free tune ups came off! GBC is much closer, friendlier and more helpful. Although I don't trust Dean's comment about riding 100 miles on my hybrid, I will definitely go to GBC to upgrade my bike. I feel that with my hybrid, I will never be able to catch up with friends and sister who have the fancy bikes.It's true that Manhattan may be the mecca for bike shopping, but GBC definitely beats the city in terms of service and price. My next bike will be a Specialized road bike, and GBC, here I come, like a boss.

Crisp skin but the meat is moist and tender. If you're looking for a light meal, this is a good choice.Bisteca - I think it's flank or maybe skirt. Meat was cooked to medium rare served with greens. Of course we had to get dessert. We were full so we decided to share.Flourless choc cake with pistachio gelato - Sooo good! If I wasn't so full, I'd order one for myself.Tiramisu - I thought it was a bit too soggy but the strawberry compote on the side was delish! Apple tart with vanilla bean gelato - It was a bit too tart and the crust was too hard. It didn't taste fresh.Overall, we had a very enjoyable night. They didn't rush us and the servers were very attentive and friendly especially Julia. The reason that I only gave it 4 stars is that they must've turned off the a/c. By the end of the night, we were all sweating. We would've lingered a bit longer but we couldn't take heat anymore.

<review# 642,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/6/2011,2/16/2012,472,510,8,15,12>When the weather teeters around the low 50s and below, it's Hot Pot time.  This is a rule of thumb I tend to follow for myself during the fall and winter months.  Finally had the chance to come here a few nights ago with the bf and his darling mom.  She had wanted to go for hot pot in Flushing, but I suggested Shell Cove instead since it was fairly easy to get to, and parking is much less of a nightmare in Elmhurst.This new establishment is clean, contemporarily chic, and nicely designed with fitted booths (that can seat 4 to a table).  If you have a larger party, they can accommodate you as well with the open seating area that has longer tables -- just don't bring a wildly large crowd here as the hot pot style offered at Shell Cove is not family style, and it seems they won't be able to truly accommodate a bigger crowd as some other hot pot places can in flushing (Shanghai Tide, for instance).  Having said that, I still really enjoyed my experience at Shell Cove.  The modern and updated feel of this place, with individualized, electronic tabletop burners, and the open sauce making station, helpfully labeled in english with all the various sauces, was a major delight.  I also noticed they have rice, if you think the glass noodles that come with your order is not enough.  Or, you have a serious addiction to carbs.  Whichever.  The portion size was also very filling.  I had the chicken hot pot ($9.99) with the Japanese Kelp soup base, which was free (note, not all soup bases are created equal!  A couple are free, at no-charge, and most others will be an additional $1 or $2).  We also ordered the stuffed fish balls to share on top of our individualized hot  pots.  The meal was so filling that we couldn't even finish all our food, which is a very rare occurrence (we like to eat!).  Allow me then, to convincingly suggest not to order any appetizers or additional menu items because trust me, you will not need more food than your individual pots.  Along with the meat of your choosing, you get a nice, big bowl of glass noodles, fresh, chinese cabbage, mustard greens, mushrooms, winter melon, corn, and an egg.  This is more than enough to work with.  (They also have dessert, if interested).  You'll have fun creating your sauce masterpiece and enjoying it along with your hot pot selection.Bring your appetite and cold hard cash as they do not except credit cards.

<review# 650,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/30/2011,2/8/2012,238,433,7,14,7>The Dog and Duck (DD) is definitely a welcome addition to Skillman Ave and the Sunnyside community. Offering a traditional menu of gastropub/bistro fare with an emphasis on presentation and flavor definitely puts DD on the map as the preferred dinner destination for the trendy bar/pub crowd over the likes of Kettle Bar and Bar 43.The floor-to-ceiling windows and dimly lit setting create an easy elegance. The absence of flat panel television screens is a pleasant surprise, which helps focus patrons' attention on their actual company and the food and drinks. The menu boasts a handful of starters between $4 and $14 with mainly soups and salads. Main courses range between $10 and $21 with your ham/leek pie, fish & chips, lamb shank and a surprise or two.The Duck Liver Pate with Plum Chutney starter was a winning choice. It might not be foie gras quality, but the pate spread was very smooth. The flavor was strong and well-seasoned. The chutney was an excellent change of pace, but it was almost forgotten with the focus on the pate itself. An extra order of bread slices were needed to finish off the jar of pate.The Ham and Leek Pie ($11) was a hearty course with the perfect crust that breaks to reveal the juicy interior when you plunge your fork/spoon into it. The rich and creamy filling is buttery goodness, and the ham was tender and chewy without any hints of dryness. This is coming from someone who doesn't like ham or meat-based (shepherd's) pies. The Duck Confit with Wild Mushroom and Mash Potato entree ($18) was the 'money' course. The mash potatoes were soft and buttery, and the gravy was deliciously light. The duck was tender and moist, but the flavor and texture of the skin is simply Christmas on the tongue! The desserts were not particularly memorable, and we won't waste space on them.  Despite the dessert being a disappointing way to cap off the meal, the easy and trendy appeal along with the excellent entrees (at very reasonable prices) makes The Dog and Duck an ideal spot for repeat visits. The sky is the limit if they can improve on those desserts...

<review# 657,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/18/2012,4/18/2013,226,636,8,6,6>After reading a number of write-ups and hearing glowing reviews from a few friends in the hood, I finally stopped in with the lady on a Saturday night and all the hype surrounding this place is definitely warranted. Immediately upon walking in, two things hit us; "wow this space is so open and large, did a Blockbuster really use to be here!?" and then "ummm there is no table service? and there is a separate drink and food station? what do we do!?" Luckily, Strand had two handy-dandy hostess type girls who explained the whole setup - the bar and food station are separate, with the food station having a line that was first come, first serve. The layout is no-frills and chilled out; thick wood communal tables, each stocked with plenty of condiments. Although it got a bit crowded and even our table got a little bit tight, we were still comfortable throughout the night. Once we figured that all out, the lady claimed a table not to far from the performance stage and we headed to the front of the space, which holds the bar and food stations. Our first stop was the bar. Awesome selection of beer, with about 6-7 different cocktails to choose, with most of them including either whiskey or bourbon. The lady went with a hot spiced cider with whiskey and anise which was delish. I started off with a pitcher of beer from nearby SingleCut breweries which was outstanding and reasonably priced.  After sipping on some great booze, we made our way to the food station. This is where the insanity began.Duck pastrami that'll make you cum in your shorts. Fall off the bone ribs that were succulent, tasty and seasoned perfectly. Slaw that had perfect amount of tang and "slawiness" to it. Biscuits that were fluffy and hot. All for around $20 (no, this is not a Golden Corral commercial). We were speechless and completely satisfied. Some of the best BBQ I had in recent memory. Butcher Bar - meet thy enemy, this place is the real deal Holifield. Apparently we stopped in by on the perfect night. We beat the huge dinner crowd that eventually made its way in and a rockabilly group from PA just took the stage as we wrapped up our dinner! With some good background tunes, awesome drinks and brew, a good meal and shooting the breeze with the lady, it turned into a perfect night. A definite must visit if you're in the hood!

<review# 661,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/1/2012,2/13/2013,115,88,5,8,8>You really make me miss living in Sunnyside, Molly Blooms. Where were you when I was growing up there?!If you're familiar with Sunnyside, then you know that the last thing it needed was another Irish pub. We literally, and I mean LITERALLY, have one (sometimes two) on every block along Queens Blvd. So when I heard that a new one was opening up I wasn't quite floored by the idea, but as I kept tabs on the place I kept hearing such good word of mouth on the spot.After two visits I am definitely a fan. First thing of note that differentiates this Irish pub from the others in Sunnyside is light. The place is nicely lit in an incredibly welcoming manner. The decor has all the makings of the neighborhood haunt but with a sprinkle more maturity and sophistication. The small chandeliers are a nice touch as well as the decorated ceiling moldings. They also have a garden out back that is very spacious and is open all year round via a canopy and some heat lamps.The service is delightful and attentive. Our waitress was very quick to ask if we needed drink refills or to tell us about the happy hour specials that we were not aware of.Their menu is typical Irish fare, but done particularly well and generously portioned. It's like Momma used to make. That is if Momma was Irish as opposed to Filipino. On the two separate occasions that I've been here I've had the cod and chips and the Boylan's pasta. Their fish and chips are some of the best fish and chips I've ever tasted. Their tartar sauce is drool worthy. They accompanying mashed peas were delicious as well. The Boylan's pasta is comfort food heaven. Pipe rigate pasta bathed in cream sauce and adorned with thick pieces of Irish ham and peas. Great... now I want some more. Molly Blooms. Reason enough to consider moving back to Sunnyside.
<review# 662,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/13/2012,2/12/2013,5,46,14,36,11>I don't want to give this place a good review for fear that people will start defecting from Spa Castle and crowd up the place. It is very simple and no frills, but gives you everything you want in a Korean spa/bathhouse. $25 all-day access to the baths and saunas and then the price goes up depending on what additions you want like body scrubs, massages, etc. I plunked down $105 (tax and tip are all included) and spent a good five hours there enjoying the bath and getting a body scrub and massage to die for!For anyone not used to these types of spas just be aware of what you are getting into. When you walk in, you pay upfront at the counter. I am not sure if they take credit cards or not, but I just paid in cash. If you are female, head to your right and if you are male, go to your left. Once you are in the locker room, take off all of your clothes (yes, ALL OF THEM), grab a towel and head into the bathing area. Now, before you dive into the invitingly huge hot bath...TAKE A SHOWER! You see those stools over there by the low faucets? Sit down and start scrubbing. The amenities are rather sparse here, so if you are fussy about your shampoo and soap, bring your own. Once you are all clean, THEN hop into the huge tub. You can soak, enjoy the steam room or dry sauna, and take a splash in the cold bath as well.As for the scrub and massage...PERFECT! It is strangely gratifying to see the little balls of dead skin just sloughing off of your body. You will be scrubbed and rubbed by an older Korean woman in her underwear who will probably be rather brusque. Just go with it. When she tells you to flip. You flip. She tells you to wash off. Go wash off. And at the end of the scrubbing, the massage, the shampoo and a fresh cucumber mask (yes, she actually grated a cucumber a few moments before packing it on to my face), you will be squeaky clean and baby butt smooth. Oh and the snack bar is very yummy and affordable. The kimchee fried rice was MmmmMmmmm good! Leave your inhibitions at the door and enjoy!Price List:Entrance Fee - $25Body Scrub - $50Finger Pressure Massage (Deep Tissue) - $70Body Scrub and Beauty Massage (Women Only!) - $80

<review# 664,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/25/2012,2/10/2013,225,493,7,11,9>I give it a 4.5.We hadn't eaten since breakfast, the temperature was hovering around 40 degrees and what should have been a 15 minute drive took 45 minutes; so we arrived hungry, cold and stressed.  Luckily arriving shortly after 6pm, we were promptly seated.  Upon entering, the stressful drive just melted away as the ambiance is dim and cozy.  Love what candlelight adds to the room.As soon as we were seated, our water glasses were filled and a bag of bacon popcorn arrived, yes you read that right...bacon popcorn!  OMG, it's just so wrong, but soooo good.  It's hard to stop eating once you start.The menu consists of  mainly small plates and 4 larger plates.  We ordered 6 small plates.  Plates don't arrive all at the same time and the pace of the delivery was perfect.Scallops served with a roasted carrot puree, truffled corn salsa and capers; the scallops were cooked perfectly and the carrot puree added a nice richness that was offset by the corn.  A lovely dish which was a great start.Korean BBQ Wraps were pieces of lettuce topped with hanger steak, pickled daikon, miso and jalapenos.  The meat was tender and flavorful and the jalapenos offered a nice level of heat.  Quite tasty.BLT Pork Buns were excellent.  Tomato, lettuce & pork belly served with a spicy aioli.  They were reminiscent of the BLT you love, but with an Asian flair.  I could have used another round of those.Mussels, served in a flavorful broth loaded with onions, garlic and bacon.  The mussels were so tender and the broth delicious, definitely worth sopping up with the grilled bread that is served along side.Oxtail Terrine served with a caramelized onion puree and roasted mushrooms.  The plate arrived and by the looks of it it could have been a chocolate dessert, but this dish was as savory as they come.  The terrine itself had an amazing crispy exterior, so when you crack it open, you are treated to a succulent tender meaty goodness. The puree was silky and added just a hint of sweetness to the dish; the mushrooms, just kept the umami coming.  Absolutely amazing.Crispy Pork Trotter with spicy mayo, a slow cooked egg and scallion "mu-chim".  When you hear a dish being talked about as decadent, this is a prime example.  The egg had the perfect level of ooze.  When you cut into it, it ran all over the the crispy pork.  The crispy pork was unbelievable, not sure how they did it, but put the egg, pork, mayo and scallion together and you end up with the most phenomenal bite.The dessert menu offered 3 options, we opted for the Rice Crispy Treat with marshmallow ice cream.  I thought some kind of crazy krispie treat would come out, but I got exactly what it said and  was wonderful!  A chewy rice crispy treat with ice cream, I would have never thought that it could work so well and how did I never think of it!I was completely impressed by Salt & Fat and completely loved it.

<review# 666,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/30/2012,2/8/2013,173,244,7,9,8>In the year or so since I've first reviewed Queens Comfort, I've eaten here nearly 20 times.  It has become my go to place for brunch; when guests are in town and want something funky and fun; weekly dinners with my father who is notoriously picky but loves this place; even for Friday date night with my wife (which is appropriate because our pictures are on the wall). No matter the occasion (aside from perhaps a formal celebratory dinner), this is my place for local delicious food.  The servers seem like old friends, the chef/owner is thankful and passionate about what he serves, and they have an awesome collection of cook books for viewing.  This is a true neighborhood spot where you see the owners of other local restaurants splitting the mac and cheese and nearly every table has friends sharing a bottle of wine or a 6-pack, taking advantage of the BYOB policy, enjoying a few hours while a B-movie or classic wrestling moment play on the projector screen.They have listened to their customers feedback and incorporated change when needed.  Instead of the frozen lego, they now serve a thick fluffy homemade waffle with a Tabasco glaze and the most amazing boneless fried chicken breast.  They still serve alot of the delirious southern inspired comfort food with a twist, but now they serve more Mexican food.  The owner Donnie cooks wonderful Mexican food, my favorite dish being his free-form tamale and smoked pork.  The homemade Jalapeno Poppers are the best I've ever had.  Huge, plump jalapenos with the seeds included, fried to a perfect crisp, yet not greasy at all. I've had most of the menu and there is not much that is not memorable and delicious.  The Disco Tots with Tater Tots, Sawmill Gravy, Cheddar are a perfect fried snack to share, rich and creamy, and begging for the vinegary hot sauce.  The Billionares Salad with Brown Sugar Bacon, Mesclun, Blue Cheese, Poached Egg, Maple Vin is a fantastic spin on a cob.  The flavor is massive, its a great start to the meal.The Peanut Butter, Jelly & Bacon burger is amazing!  It is not as funky as it sounds, its actually a good balance of sweet, salty and umami.  The melting Peanut Butter looks like sharp cheddar cheese but the sweetness reminds me of ketchup.  That may be my favorite burger at QC, but all of them are fantastic.  Served with a huge pile of crispy house-made shoestring french fries.  Absolutely delicious.The other sandwiches are also worth ordering.  The house-made fresh bologna with a fried egg is excellent and has a very meaty rich flavor.  The Meatloaf Sandwich with Cheddar, Onion Rings, Bacon Ketchup is a huge mess of delicious tender meatloaf paired perfectly with the crunch of a thick Onion Ring.  Even my non onion eating father loved the crunch and taste of the ring.I love the music they play, the prices are very affordable, the service is attentive friendly and casual, and the vibe is perfect.  This place is a real neighborhood gem, and I look forward to many more meals here.

<review# 669,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/6/2013,2/5/2013,262,613,11,11,10>A slew of bad puns were exchanged in rapid succession when crossing the street to this restaurant along with fellow yelpers last night. I won't share any of them but to those reading this, you know who you are and what was said. To those who weren't, use your imaginations.Like explorers scaling Mount Everest, our party navigated through the confusing numbering scheme of Jackson Heights, Queens and landed at Himalayan Yak restaurant by way of a parking lot and Korean grocery store. Swinging the sturdy door open I recalled Marion Ravenwood's bar in "Raiders of the Lost Ark", located in Nepal, and the outdoor dropping outdoor temperature was appropriate.Inside, a sanctuary of warmth, life and a cuisine I'd never sampled before in eating explorations.At 5:30 the restaurant was fairly empty and dishes were delivered in rapid succession. By 6:30 the restaurant was packed and our second order took much longer to arrive. If we had stayed until 9 we would have heard live music which apparently occurs 5 days a week. A yelp check-in offer of a free rum was a great way to start the evening. This was not the kind of rum to devour in seconds but rather savor and let the burn warm the body slowly and methodically like polonium poisoning.Drinks under control, I studied the menu, conveniently broken into Nepali, Tibetan, Indian and Himalayan exotic food sections. Note to future yak eaters: check if yak is in season and available before coming here. One note of disappointment was struck when we discovered that yak was not available.Disappointed but not discouraged, I eagerly awaited our plates as we started with samayabajee, a nepali snack platter consisting of fried soybeans and chillis, beaten rice (What did this rice do to deserve such a beating?) and sauteed  internal organs of a goat. There was a well deserved spice icon of two peppers for this dish as I continued feeling the heat for awhile. Be aware that portions were in general small so if having a family style meal, be ready to order lots of plates.From the nepali kitchen, one standout I clearly recall was the Khasi ko masu or goat curry. It was the quality of the goat meat that was noteworthy, a case where fat and sinew was at a minimum. No fiery heat here either and a fine curry for dipping Tingmo into. (Tibetan steamed bread).There were other dishes as well, including the notorious momo dumplings. Clearly I'd be a mofo if I didn't try the momo. It appears that our table did not receive the various dipping sauces and accompaniments others did so I cannot attest to a proper momo experience. The  beef momo was acceptable but not a life altering bundle of joy. I will have to try again.Now for the most mind altering moment of the night: Bhakcha Markhu!As someone who has enjoyed many a plate of pasta, many a bowl of mac and cheese, many a noodle soup, imagine the intrigue and excitement I felt when reading the dessert list to discover this dish of hand made pasta, sugar, butter & grated cheese.Pasta, for dessert! Cultural worlds collided, the Buddha behind me smiled and I grabbed my fork and dug in to the bowl.A small bowl where the flavor of sugar is present, surprising and most definitely works. Dessert as comfort food that shatters my preconceived notions is one I especially like.Apparently a lunch time buffet is available which I will have to experience, along with the yak present in the restaurant's name. Prices aren't that bad at all, with most entrees under $15.

<review# 671,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/7/2013,9/24/2013,586,742,6,15,10>GangJong Kitchen is a small Tibetan restaurant located in Jackson Heights, Queens.  There's a lot of competition within a few block radius.  What makes this place unique to me is the cozy feeling.  Literally feels like you're eating in someone's kitchen.  The place is so small that it can easily be overlooked - at least I did anyway - that is - until I saw the Yelp reviews when I was looking for a new neighborhood place to try.What we ordered as a group: - Beef momo - Nepalese dumpling with beef- Chicken momo - Nepalese dumpling with chicken- Shabtak - Spicy sauteed sliced beef with onions and peppers stir fried- Jasha Sonam - Chicken with coriander brown sauce- Gangjong special fried rice - with fried egg on top with veggies- Ping shogo - Rice noodle with potato - considered a main Tibetan dish- Ginger honey lemon teaI personally think the momos, shabtak, and jasha sonam are the must get items.  A few of the other places don't give sauce with the momos.  This place does!  Sauce is flavorful with a spicy kick.  The fried rice was pretty good but a safe dish.  Ping shogo was good - noodles / potatoes in broth - also a safe dish - in my opinion.  Their main dishes are served with white rice or tingmo (best described as a pork bun without the pork - just the bread - YUM).Every time I walk past this place, there are always a few tables filled with Nepalese and Tibetan folks.  A very very local place - which is a good sign.  Definitely worth a try!Discounts:- $10 for a $20 Yelp deal - I purchased the deal on my smartphone as I was ordering the food.- I also just found out - 10% off Seamless web delivery.Pictures:- yelp.com/biz_photos/gang- yelp.com/biz_photos/gangENJOY!!

<review# 673,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/12/2013,9/22/2013,33,72,5,7,5>I have lived in the same spot in Astoria for two years and think it's pretty darn perfect, but I always wished there was a place to get a really good cupcake without me having to trek any great distance. But make an effort to find it and stop by. It's so worth it. The cupcakes are named after movies and TV shows. So fun and unique! Here's what I appreciate most about this shop:1) The cupcakes aren't too big and aren't too small. They're normal-sized cupcakes. 2) They use the right amount of icing. I can't stand the places where the pile of frosting is as big as the cupcake itself; the icing should be a complement to the cake, not overwhelm it. Sweets First gets it right. And the frosting is soft and mushy--in the good way. It melts in your mouth. Yum.3) The cake itself is nice and moist. 4) The Terminator 2 has a piece of Ferrero Rocher on top. The Breakfast Club is topped with candied bacon. These toppings = delicious.5) The cupcakes made a yummy breakfast the next day, after sitting in the refrigerator overnight. The cake still tasted delicious.6) For every ten cupcakes, you get one free cupcake. Way to keep me coming back. (Seriously, I'm already over halfway there. Good thing I have to walk to the shop or else I'd blow up like a balloon from too many cupcakes.)7) The staff were super friendly. Do I recommend this shop? Absolutely. I am super happy that I only have to walk a few blocks to get my cupcake fix, and they're actually really good cupcakes. Skip dessert at the chain restaurants nearby and come here for a cupcake.

If there are days where I know I can't make both weekend days, I purchase items to go and heat them up in the oven the next morning for breakfast. My absolute favorites are the croissants. I've tried all the varieties: plain, almond, chocolate, almond chocolate, almond raisin, and ham & cheese. Every single croissant is excellent, but the plain croissant has a special place in my heart. Flaky, buttery (you can actually taste the butter before biting into it), and just amazing! Try it with the complimentary jam on the table and you'll fall in love. Other favorites include the raspberry jam danish and their french baguette. The omelets, quiches, and sandwiches are pretty damn tasty too. It certainly gets crowded and seats are limited, but most patrons are pretty conscious about that and do not sit too long. Best part of it all is that it's a train station away from where I live, so I walk to the bakery and back. It makes me feel a little less guilty for inhaling that extra croissant I didn't really need, but can't help eating.
<review# 676,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/4/2013,9/19/2013,106,721,6,8,7>Hooray I found a replacement for Foster's which sadly shut down.  For what reason, I'm not sure but after trying several other soul food restaurants, Burgandy's will make a great replacement.  The store awning from outside looks like it's been up since the 70's and from the looks of everything, they have been here since the 70's.  This is truly a mom and pop shop with what appears to be the whole family who runs this business.  It's like having your grandma cook for you, that is if my grandma actually knew how to make delicious fried chicken vs fried rice.  Anyways, the prices are very reasonable here, definitely food for the masses where you don't have to lose an arm and a leg just to pay for lunch.  I ordered the fried chicken dinner which came with two sides and bread.  The fried chicken was awesome, super juicy, the breading stayed on, and salted just right (not overly salted like some places).  Although I wish it had a little kick like Popeye's spicy wings, I'll take good ole fashioned original wings too.  The candied yams were outrageously good and I highly recommend ordering them.  The mac n cheese was pretty standard and literally like your mom would make them, not a creamy cheese but chunky cheese with non al dente noodles.  The cornbread was super crumbly, and literally broke apart as I bit into it but loaded with butter goodness.  They may not deliver to the Navy Yard, but I'll sure as heck drive here to pick up lunch!

<review# 678,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/30/2013,9/17/2013,242,92,6,6,8>I did not want to write this review purely out of selfishness. I want Alewife to prosper... yet I want this location completely to myself. There is constantly a sufficient amount of patrons that make the atmosphere lively. A romantic glow illuminates from the meticulously strung string lights along the wall. The wrought-iron staircase leads upstairs to a second floor with plenty of seating. There are exceedingly comfortable leather couches that I had to PEEL myself off of. There is also a patio that I am looking forward to occupying as soon as the weather gets warmer. Alewife is nothing but a pleasant change from the overcrowded bars of NYC.This gastropub has a great list of beers, bottled and on draught. A few bottles ranged from $10-$39; the prices can be strong for LIC. Draught beers were decently priced from $7-$10 each. You can find the limited edition Game of Thrones beer here! It is a blonde pale ale called the Iron Throne from Ommegang, a Belgian brewery. This had a very effervescent, slightly hoppy, fruity and floral taste. This beer has been sold out almost everywhere due to the popularity of its TV series inspiration however, it is just nothing more than a solid Belgian ale. I also had the Maracaibo Especial from Jolly Pumpkin (Michigan). I accidentally ordered this bel strong ale thinking that it was pumpkin flavored! The Maracaibo was very hoppy and had a discreet tangerine flavor. I was not a big fan of the sour aftertaste. Service here was on point. Despite that my group kept moving from the first to second floor, our waitress constantly checked on us throughout the night. Great service at a bar... isn't that supposed to be a rarity? The rating that it currently has definitely is not a fair assessment.Things you should know before entering:Cards are accepted! Fully-stocked and clean restrooms. Comfy couches. Deals each day throughout the week: brunch with unlimited drinks Saturday, a deal for Sixpoint oysters and a pint of beer on Sundays.  $5 happy hour from 4-7 everyday! There is also a large selection of food at this gastropub including dessert. Did I mention the comfy couches?

Definitely a MUST GET!!Taiwanese Chicken Roll- Do they put crack in this thing? IT'S SO GOOD!  I can probably eat a few rolls by myself if I didn't have to worry about my figures. It's basically meat/fish paste warped with tofu skin and whole thing is deep fried. Crunchy on the outside, soft juicy inside, damnnnn so GOOD and so much flavor!! MUST GET!!!So far I have been to Mama Lee 3 times and they have not disappoint, they continue to pump out authentic Taiwanese goodies and Mama Lee is so friendly, she's always smiling and super polite, I think that's the way business should be run... you just can't beat Mama Lee's GREAT FOOD and GREAT SERVICE! Just remember to bring CASH!

<review# 691,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/2/2012,5/21/2012,472,510,10,13,9>A fairly recent addition to the pantheon of Forest Hills eateries, EXO Cafe can draw, loud, boisterous crowds to its sleek and contemporary restaurant / bar.  It's a spacious two-floors, and feels a bit like a sports bar with its dark interior and blaring music, outfitted by a decent bar scene on the first floor.  You can come here and blend in with the crowd by the bar, or surprisingly find yourself enjoying a slightly less intense experience on the second floor, which is what we did.  A group of four of us came here last night for dinner and sat upstairs.  We were seated right by the window, and though you get a decent view of Austin Street, there's not much to see except businesses and traffic.  Lucky for us, we were able to make the most of the last 10 minutes of Happy Hour and ordered some drinks and apps for half-price.  The guys said the EXO beer was very light and tasted decent, though they really only got it for the sole purpose of entering for a chance to win a 46 inch LCD tv.  I on the other hand, enjoyed one of their signature cocktails, the "coco", which had a very tropical flavor to it and was not heavy on the alcohol, which I enjoyed very much.  Appetizers were your typical bar food, slightly elevated.  I didn't have any of the beef sliders but my friends said they were decent.  I did however, enjoy the chicken poppers which were very similar to Chinese takeout sesame chicken, even still, it worked as I liked the flavor profile of the sweet and savory, moist chicken.  For my entree, I had the "Citrus Field Greens Salad" (with cherry tomatoes, cilantro, juicy pineapple, mandarins, fresh mozzarella slices, served with a honey glaze mandarin orange dressing).  To that, I added tilapia, which really brightened up the meal.  The salad was perfectly dressed, the citrus was pronounced but not too strong, the tilapia was light and flavorful, and the bits of mozzarella were delicious.  The guys each had similar positive remarks about their food.  One friend especially like the Chimichurri entree (minus the extremely greasy chips that accompanied his dish).  We all shared two desserts, the peanut butter bomb, and the guava tart.  I was blown away by the guava tart.  It was succulent, sweet, and just a hint tart.  The Guava taste was subtle, but the smooth and fluffy texture was a surprise.  I would happily come back for seconds any day.  I ordered the "BBQ Chicken Jalapeno Melt Handwich--that's what it's called" (Panini bread with grilled chicken, smoked gouda cheese, jalapenos, tomato and BBQ sauce), for my boyfriend, to go.  When he got home from work and ate this while it was still warm, he really loved it.  To be honest, I set the bar low for EXO Cafe, but after actually dining here, I'm amazed to say I really liked this place.  Initially I wanted to give this 3 stars, but for that incredible guava tart, and for the attentive service from our waiter, who the guys all said looked like 'Cam Calderon', the character from the now-defunct show, How to Make it in America, (imdb.com/media/rm4187459), I had to  bump them up to 4 stars.  They deserve it.  (And yes, he did look a lot like Cam!)To end, I can't tell you how especially tickled I am that EXO Cafe replaced the god-awful gimmick that was Mardi Gras.  Now if only something could be done about Brandon Cinemas...
<review# 692,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/30/2011,5/20/2012,153,123,2,9,5>Tucked away in a little street, this even littler shop tucked neatly into a little nook is easy to miss. If you're looking, look for the grand opening streamers (or those colorful triangle flag things on a line) blowing in the wind.They have a lucky 13 items on their menu, 10 of which are of a noodle variety, as their name suggests (myun=noodle) and the other 3 are a non-noodle variety--seafood pancake, kimchi dumplings, and the last being a pot of kimchi dumpling stew, usually big enough to feed 4.  Happily, the 10 noodle items are all authentic Korean noodle items, (although you can argue what constitutes 'authentic') varying from festival 'janchi' noodles, chewy 'jjolmyun' noodles, to the debatable udon noodles. They also have a steamed kimchi dumpling, which are made very korean home-style-- finely chopped kimchi mixed with ground pork in a thin wrapper. We had the kimchi dumplings, udon noodles, and the jjolmyun. Everything tastes like something out of my mother's kitchen, which is warm and welcoming, flavorful and bursting with love. The staff (I'm going to guess it was the owner) was quick with a smile and a recommendation, and was genuinely happy that we enjoyed his food.  They've just opened so they're having 10% off until January 20th. I say give this place a try!

There were the usual rolls with some I've never even heard of. Must be custom made by the "sushi chefs." They didn't look Japanese to me! Cheap labor I guess but it was still well made. There was also a crispy butter roll which was very delectable! I love them desserts! My sweet tooth was definitely satisfied. I forgot to mention, they also have soft serve ice cream.I ate 5 plates of food here. Two plates of regular food, one of only sushi, one plate of salad and one dessert. I was so full! Overall, the food is pretty good for a buffet restaurant. I would definitely go here again.
