<review# 699,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/6/2012,5/13/2012,68,233,4,9,8>Sarku Japan sets the bar for Chicken Teriyaki. Despite the fact that it's run/operated by Chinese people, you will never have Chicken Teriyaki better than here at Sarku Japan. I also like to point out that Sarku Japan doesn't accept credit cards. Like, at all. That's probably one of my biggest peeves when it comes to eateries and yet despite all this I still give it 5 stars.I think I've been ruined permanently by the chicken here at Sarku. Every time I see Chicken Teriyaki on a menu, it brings me back to memories of Sarku's CT. I can't help it, the chicken is just cooked that well. Sarku makes CT with dark meat, which is a big big deal if you're a fan of the dark meat like I am. On top of it, there sauce is just different. The typical chicken teriyaki sauce is soy sauce based and overly sweet. I believe Sarku's sauce is also based off soy sauce, but it somehow comes out different. The combination of the dark meat chicken, the flat wok and the freshness of the meal comes together to give you hands down some of the best food you can have for under $7.00. A lot of haters reviewing this joint : don't listen to any of them. Get the CT special, double meat if you really dare (only a dollar extra!) and try your best to find a seat among the baby carriages and teenagers.
<review# 700,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/2/2011,5/12/2012,93,365,3,8,7>I eat and crave food from all over the world. However, I very rarely crave Indian food. When the craving hit, I didn't know where to go or what to order. I'll admit that I am an Indian food novice. The few experiences I've had have been on or around 74th street and been relegated to a meager handful of cheap buffets.Delhi Delights was a breath of fresh air. The decor was lovely and understated and very different than the other restaurants in the area that I'd visited. The menu is lengthy, offering a healthy mix of flavors and dishes that will surely please the most finicky palate. We ordered a few dishes and took in our surroundings while waiting for the food to come out. I was shocked by how empty the restaurant was, but then again, Delhi Delights provides a more upscale feel that is definitely represented in their prices. To be frank, if you're craving Indian, you can definitely get it for cheaper at a lot of area places.But, if you choose to come here what you do get is worth the money. We started with the very first item on their menu, the Rasam soup, a south Indian concoction made with lentils, tamarind, chilies and tomato. The flavors were explosive. It was sour and sweet and different, a nice way to start our meal. Next came the Dahi Aloo Papri Chat, a mix of chopped potato, chickpeas and crisps in tamarind sauce. Again, this was something I'd never encountered before. In fact, I thought I didn't care for tamarind or chickpeas but these dishes proved me wrong.For mains, we went with a spicy lamb vindaloo and the shrimp masala. When the dishes came out, I was struck by how small the serving sizes are. I was more surprised by how full we became before we'd even finished our food. Indian food is filling, we couldn't finish what we'd ordered. And, we really wanted to because they both surpassed our expectations. The vindaloo provided us with fiery flavor and the masala's rich butteriness cooled down our taste buds.I previously expressed a mild distaste for Indian buffets, but I'd return to try the afternoon buffet provided here. I've heard that they don't offer as many dishes as other places. But, if the quality comes anywhere near what I enjoyed during the meal I described, it's an awesome value that I'd like to enjoy regularly.

=)The price is very reasonable and the portions are quite big.  $8.50 for a rice dish + 3 or 4 side dishes (depending if you dine in or not).  Definitely a good (affordable) eat!  Sometimes I eat half of the order and save the other half to bring for lunch the next day.  Very economical!Don't miss OUT if you are around the neighborhood with a Korean food craving.Note:  Sometimes the food may take a while, depending on what you order, due to a small kitchen space and limited chefs.  However, the food do get delivered efficiently and presented beautifully.  Please bare with the service in general!

<review# 705,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/20/2012,3/1/2013,107,167,5,7,6>You see the restaurant on the corner, and it's pretty unassuming. Looking like any other restaurant in the neighborhood. You could just walk by, and not have noticed something wonderful.When you walk in, you've walked into another world.  Jarritos lines the walls (and everything), and you're greeted by a massive case of various treats, from flan to chiliques floating in a tomatillo sauce, to Pan Dulce and everything in between. The persistent sound of Mexican polka plays over a stereo, that reverberates off the walls. If you're like me, a transplant from the Southwest, this is home. It feels natural, safe. I could just wedge myself into a space on the wall, and be pretty happy. We got a seat next to the window which was lined with Jarritos bottles. The natural light floating in creates a lovely kaleidoscope of colors, and you can't help but look at the textured bottles with various neon liquid within. I ordered a staple, Huevos con Chorizo.  She ordered Huevos Tapatios, but I'll get to that in a moment. I have a rule about Mexican restaurants, and it revolves around Chorizo. If it isn't flavorful, it's crap. Keep the grease to a minimum too.  Haab's is wonderful. It wasn't greasy and it was fully blended with the eggs. Take a scoop of that, some beans & rice, and smash that in a hot corn tortilla with some salsa verde, and you've got one hell of a delicious, filling breakfast. Huevos Tapatios are a whole different beast all together. 2 perfectly fried eggs (thick & runny in the middle) on top of two freshly fried tortillas, topped with crema fresca, chorizo & chile de arbol, with papas on the side is even better. If you are hungover, this is the cure for you. Even if you're not hungover, this is the cure for any ailment.  And the chipotle mayo is pure ambrosia.Service was great. Delicious coffee with lots of hot cream, along with ice cold hibiscus drink made for wonderful beverages. They even take cards. I'll be back. And you should go.

<review# 708,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/18/2013,2/26/2013,30,76,15,8,11>Although the DSM-IV would frown upon my liberal use of term "addiction", it is perhaps most convenient way to describe my relationship with certain foods at various times in my life. Ramen had consumed all of my thoughts. The Arepa dealers on speed-dial left no room for friends and family. I've been soaked in the cold, fever-dreamed sweat  of Empanada withdrawal. I keep these scars of my addictions close as a reminder of my weakness.When I went to Dosa Delight, I thought myself to be a stronger and more capable person; that the sordid details of my past addictions were reflections of an immature and impulsive kid. I had thought myself as cured.Of course, cures exist only in the hearts of the naive. You can't immunize against addictions, you can only hope to imprison them with the steel bars of sensibility and concrete walls of reason. But when I first saw my Pondicherry Dosa from across the room, I felt the addiction shake madly at the bars. When I smelled the dosa, the addiction began to tunnel under the walls. And upon the first bite of my dosa, my addiction hijacked a motorcycle and jumped a 10 foot barbedwire fence like Steve fucking Mcqueen.

<review# 710,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/8/2013,2/24/2013,134,610,9,12,12>Too cool for school, and it works.Coming here is a bit of a strange experience - walking into a museum (tell them you're there to eat and you get in for free to PS1) to hit up a classroom with small desks and menus on chalkboard.  It's a place to be seen, to say you went, but it's also pretty good for what it is.Seating note: as the resident giant yelper (6'8") the seats and table were a bit small, but workable for the time there.  The space between the seats and the tables are a bit small, so if you have big legs it might be a tight fit - I think a few of their tables or bar seating could work then.Lots of staff, and an esoteric menu without enough information.  Our appetizer we got based on nothing ended up being delicious, my brisket was bad because I had no idea it would be served cold (the beets were hot though).  Feel free to ask how it's prepped beforehand, be smart and you could be fine.  The smoked chicken of my girl was divine for me, not so much for her.If you are a picky eater or don't eat some things for religious reasons, this place can be a bit tough - at least half of the dining options included shellfish or pork, which doesn't work for me.  But there were a few viable options too for me.Lots of people walked in, looked at the menu, then eventually asked for a table - a few did leave though.  It's normal and accepted to do that, just don't take forever to make that call as you end up standing awkwardly in the middle of the restaurant right next to people eating while looking at the big board.  A minute or two is okay and acceptable, don't be a dick though.The pricing isn't horrible, and you get free admission to the museum with your sticker (or at least we did).  Decent beer (Sixpoint) options and wine bottles, if you want to be that person to order a $90 bottle in a classroom.  Trust me, nobody will judge you.Net net, it's hit or miss good food based on your tastes, in a setup that seems sweet for 15 minutes then just is, and is in fact cooler than you are.
<review# 711,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/28/2013,12/13/2013,45,63,5,7,6>The perfect place for a special dinner, Trattoria L'incontro has wonderful, inventive Italian food as well as impeccable service. Typically when I go to expensive restaurants, I expect snooty service (since I don't look like a high roller), but everyone was very nice. I would recommend dressing up a little if you come here, though I did see a number of guys in jeans. The waiter will tell you about the specials, and prepare to listen attentively... there will be more than a dozen specials, I'd say close to 20. They will patiently repeat the specials though, if you ask. Everything will sound amazing and delicious.Since my dining companion and I wanted to share everything, the waiter arranged for each of our dishes (including the appetizers) to come out on two plates, already proportioned for sharing between the two of us. This was more accommodating than I expected, and a nice touch. We ordered a bottle of wine, and the waiter would keep coming back to refill our classes. Our water glasses were always kept more than half full as well. Finally, we got a new plate, knife, and fork for every course.We started with a couple of appetizers, both specials. Upon recommendation from our waiter, we got the burata cheese wrapped in prosciutto. I have had burata cheese before, but this was by far its best iteration. The cheese was smooth and creamy, with bits of basil, pine nuts, and some type of sauce... wrapped up in prosciutto. We also got the wild game meatballs, which came with a type of mushroom sauce. I wish the portion of that were bigger (we only got 1 meatball each), but it was tasty.For entrees, we shared the mezza luna, a stuffed pasta dish on the regular menu. I wanted to try this based on the many recommendations here on yelp, and I was not disappointed. We also tried the braised short ribs over polenta (a special), and it was cooked perfectly, very tender. Finally, for dessert, we got the pistachio creme brulee... also a winner. Definitely a step up from your typical Italian restaurant, and the price and service reflects that. For the two of us, it came to around $150 including tax and tip, but it was completely worth it!

<review# 713,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/27/2013,12/11/2013,14,398,7,9,8>Just had dinner here for the first time last night with my girlfriend. Our experience was good. Bacorn! (Bacon fat popcorn) instead of chips or bread on the table was unique and something that we did not miss of forget from our visit. If you are coming here you need to go in knowing this is a tapas restaurant that has small plates with a few mid sized offerings for entree prices. The best way to go about eating here 2 people sharing 2-3 plates and drinks. However the Homemade iced tea was not overly sweet minty and a wedge of lemon. I'll say their prices are in line with the manhattan prices for tapas. We ordered the Long Island Duck, the Mussels and the Oxtail plates. Our favorite was the Oxtail Terrine which was served with a reduction and purée sauce mushrooms and small potatoes. It was amazing. The Long Island Duck was cooked perfectly medium and the dish as with all the others needed to be taken in balanced bites incorporating everything on the plate. The lychee, reduction sauce. the charred frisée. It was the perfect cooked duck that sold me on this dish. However at $23 it was something I tried but would not pay that much for again. The mussels were served in a lobster bisque soup with spicy chorizo, wheels of corn, onions and herbs. The toasted sourdough bread was a nice touch to sap up the soup. Our waiter even sent over some extra bread to lap up the soup. The food yielded 5 stars however the price on the duck was a bit steep for Queens and the service needed a little more attention as other people seated after us were taken care of (set up with water and bacorn) before us. I also wish the runners were about to reexplain the food we were about to enjoy as we had forgotten most of what was in each intricate dish we ordered. I hope service improves.

Cascon Cheesecakes has been a staple in Queens since the '70s. Even if you're not close by, it's well worth the trip. I had the benefit of living in this neighborhood for several years where I could WALK to this place. That was dangerous. Since I passed through Whitestone the other day I decided to go back and treat myself (and of course my husband :) to cheesecake. Luckily for us, they still carry the mini cheesecakes, so I got a few of those. If we had to get a whole cheesecake (as if that would be a punishment!) we would have inhaled it in little more than a sitting. And I wouldn't be writing the review right now; I'd have my butt at the gym in spin class to make up for calories.Back to the minis...I got an assortment of flavors: regular, marble swirl, black forest, pumpkin and Oreo. Holy Moly. They are exactly as I remember them. Ridiculously fresh and creamy. If you're a Junior's Cheesecake fan, I beg you to try Cascon - you may switch teams and fall for them.In addition to the minis, you can get assorted cheesecake flavors in larger sizes, cakes, pastries, assorted mousse, and of course bakery butter cookies. And they're so nice here! LOVE this place. You will too!

I have not once been disappointed in the taste or the service here. The restaurant itself has a very nice Greek  feel to it, the decor is simple and not overwhelming. Very relaxed atmosphere.The staff is so pleasant and helpful, they're always willing to accommodate me with my concerns over my food allergies and preferences, they always seem to have something on the menu for me to enjoy. The food here has never let me down and I've been here many times. They have the most amazing lemon potatoes, stuffed peppers, Greek salad. Their ingredients are always very fresh and delivered to them daily.Another reason why I love Stamatis is the fact that you can come here with a big group and fill yourself to the point that you won't be able to walk when you leave, yet without breaking the bank. Totally worth a visit if you enjoy Mediterranean/Greek food.

<review# 718,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/30/2013,12/6/2013,243,374,13,16,16>Hi, I'm team knife-shaved-noodles. All you hand-pulled-noodle lovers and go get soggy at the bottom of the soup bowl!Uncle Zhou's knife shaved noodles are kind of thin, width wise, but nevertheless they are good. I had it in the Lamb soup, which was a good white bone broth with some small tender cube of lamb meat. You have gotta dig the chopped cilantro on the top, it makes the noodle soup complete. Hubby ordered the beef hand drawn noodle soup. I wasn't digging the beef broth as much, it was not as flavorful as a consomme but more of a "clear soup" with strong herbal notes. They have small dishes towards the back of the restaurant, in the fridge display. Veggies ones are $4 a plate or $5 for a non-veggie dish. You can also pick any 2 on 1 plate. We tried the pork liver (most Chinese dishes involving liver, are cooked to well done or beyond. Unlike some French dish that stop at medium-rare to medium.) and the bamboo shoots. If you try the pork liver, don't forget to add some vinegar. The bamboo shoots while tasty and simple, had too many "old stalks" meaning they were occasionally a bit too fibrous for chewing. Our waitress was very nice and polite. This is a solid joint to grab a cheap but good bite.Cash Only.
<review# 719,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/24/2013,12/5/2013,121,334,11,8,7>What?!  How has Tonight Bar not been reviewed?  I realized this when I tried to check in on my iPhone. This place is SOLID.  The perfect dive bar in Flushing.  I came here tonight with a guy friend after eating three times our weight around the corner at 66 Lu's Seafood.  This bar is FANTASTIC.  The bartenders are absolute dolls; they know everyone and will clink glasses with you.  My friend is a regular, but this was my first time here.  However, the bartender acted as if we went way back-- which I loved.  The crowd here is über friendly and amazingly chill.  This is NOT a sketchy place.  There's a back room for karaoke, but everyone sitting at the bar just passes the microphone around and the bartender will play whatever you want to sing.  It made me feel as if I was in a small town, a real community.  Plus they give you free peanuts.  Who can pass up free peanuts?!No, there's no beer on tap.  But you don't come here for craft beer.  You come here because it's fun, because the people are sweet, because you can belt "Total Eclipse of the Heart" sober and no one will judge you, and because of the peanuts.
<review# 720,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/19/2013,12/4/2013,132,271,10,11,9>C'mon... be adventurous... ride rollercoasters, go bungee-jumping , sky-dive... eat kangaroo.When my sister told me about this place, I knew that my next trip home would have to include, "Visit family, eat kangaroo." Thankfully, she wanted to eat here for her birthday on the very weekend my husband and I planned to come back to NY.We made reservations and were seated promptly. We had a party of 7.Then we got our waters, and were approached by a friendly waitress that asked, "Have you ever been here?" When we answered "no," she then asked "Have you had Australian food before?" When we answered "no," again she lit up and looked so excited to pop our virgin Australian food cherries. And we happily let her.She was very enthusiastic about the menu. She described all the items on the menu in great detail, and made her suggestions. "Kumara is a root vegetable indigenous to Australia, sorta like a sweet potato." Then the kangaroo conversation came up. We all were there for this meat, so we were excited. She explained it as being close to venison and that it was best to have it rare. The kangaroo came in burger and steak form. Naturally, our large party had the luxury of ordering the kangaroo sliders, kangaroo steak, kangaroo burger with the lot, the fish special of the day (which I don't remember too much, but I remember saying "this is good!") and three orders of lamb lollies to share. (We all will probably go to hell for being gluttons.) All came with respective sides, the obligatory kumara mash, roasted vegetables and beet slaw. We also got a starter, Box Hill Stuffed Seasonal Vegetables... it had lemon rice, currants, goat cheese, pine nuts and dill. It was served cold, but it was still good! Kumara mash was sweet potato-like as promised, with a nice spice and herby flavor to them.The kangaroo burgers were delicious, they did not have too much of a game-y quality to them. The meat went well with what came with the "lot." That included grilled pineapple, bacon, egg, beet slaw and caramelized onion. The kangaroo steak was superb! I suggest that anyone who really wants to taste kangaroo, get this! It's lean and juicy (if you order it properly, which is rare), and full of flavor. So well done!Being my sister's birthday, my husband and my brother-in-law asked for specialty shots around the table. They served us this really smooth and cool tasting rum. We later learned that it was South Sea Australian Rum. Our waitress, (who coincidentally was also the co-owner!) explained that they had never served it and since we asked for something "special" she decided to open up a bottle! We still don't know if this was a gimmick to make us like them, but... we do anyway! : ) And they kept the rounds coming! I think it was 4-5 rounds of shots and we were glad to have them! (More brownie points for them!)I think the icing on the cake was that they let my (I think semi-tipsy) sister take a picture with their humungous stuffed koala! It was a very good experience and will be back again when in NY! Thank you Thirsty Koala for making my adventure a true Australian (food) experience!

<review# 723,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/16/2011,7/11/2012,94,16,9,12,11>I love this place!  Yes, hard to find, and it's sort of a random room down this hallway.  The soup is out of control GOOD.  I was a dummy for asking if they had a menu the first time I went - I mean the store is called "Lamb Noodle Soup" after all.  So food options were essentially: Lamb noodle soup BIG, or lamb noodle soup SMALL.  They do have a few other complimentary things too though.  The noodles were kind of haphazardly cut and were chewy & delicious.  The meat was tender, and the soup flavorful.I love how unpretentious this whole place is.  Just a bunch of mostly immigrant Chinese people sitting at really squished tables eating away and chillaxin in groups.  And the restaurant people are super nice - thank you for helping to break our stereotype of having sucky rude service!  It was kind of crowded when I was there, so I asked if I could get my soup to go.  The restaurant guy insisted that the soup was much better eaten immediately, and then rearranged the stools to make a space for me to sit.  While I was eating the place got even more crowded to the point that strangers were all just eating next to each other at the same tables and every stool was occupied.  (Yes - the soup is THAT good)!  I made a new friend while eating (who I never saw ever again, but that's ok - it was still fun)!I really wish there were more places like this everywhere.  Major ultra mega thumbs up from me!
<review# 724,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/27/2011,7/10/2012,343,884,3,8,4>I LOVE THIS PLACE.  I really do.  I really love everything about it.  Let's start at the beginning.I had been meaning to try this place, especially because it had received SO many great reviews.  While the weather is nice-ish, it's best to enjoy the back terrace, which is gorgeous and has a fabulous yet relaxed summertime feel.  What's most notable about Bareburger is the quality of the food.  Regardless of what you choose to order, you can rest assured that everything will be conscientiously selected with care.The sandwiches are made from organic, all natural, free-range, grass-fed meats, all natural cheeses and organic vegetables.  Bareburger boasts use of local artisans and sustainable farmers and I can't get enough.  These sandwiches won't come on your average burger bun.  Instead, you'll have the option of brioche or multigrain bun, lettuce, whole wheat, or rice wrap.  The beer selection is respectable and pitchers are your best bet.  If you're craving a side of some greasy grub, I suggest the onion ring/french fry combo -- but be sure to share it with 1-2 other people -- you definitely will not be able to take it to the face...unless...well, I won't even say it.  The dipping sauces are amazing.  Curry bbq, chipotle mayo, so good. One thing that you should be aware of -- these are not your average burger place and you won't be charged dollar menu prices.  Be prepared to shell out at least $30-$40 for a casual burger date for two.

<review# 727,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/16/2012,7/7/2012,316,268,18,18,18>Spank me if you will. I've been a very bad girl. Yes, I'm greedy. And selfish. And I don't like to share. But ya'll seem like nice folks so I'll let you have a taste of my Souvlaki Guy. The "Guy's" souvlaki cart is located right outside the parking lot of the Bed Bath & Beyond/Home Depot shopping center in East Elmhurst so one can conveniently pick up a snack/meal after you've shopped for boring home knick knacks, light bulbs, or Draino. However most times the conversation usually goes like this. "Hun, you want souvlaki for lunch?""Sure let's go.""Need anything from Home Depot while we're there?""Eh not really..."Yes, I'll take the drive 5 or so miles away to get here and souvlaki is usually the main reason for the trip. Souvlaki Guy is there practically every day until around 8pm unless the weather is bad, he's not in the mood (which is rarely ever) or he's away traveling the world as he seems to do every now and then. His pork souvlaki at $2.50 is always freshly cooked. If not, he will throw on a new batch of meat for you because he's cool like that. The meat is always succulent with the right amount of char. The salty burnt edges coupled with the lemon juice and hot sauce is what I sometimes wake up craving on weekend mornings. Chicken is offered too if that's your thing. Have your meat in a pita sandwich if preferred but the souvlaki here is best eaten in its purest form. He's good to his regulars and they will drive in just to get that delicious meat on a stick - cops, firefighters, nearby workers, and simply those in the know of where to get a delicious cheap meal. I'm surprised he's not on Yelp yet and if he is, well then he deserves a second listing. While most souvlaki carts depend on business from foot traffic, this one is situated in the middle of no where Queens that is only accessible by car or *gasp* bus. When I inquired if he ever moves around to different spots, he replied with ".. but who's going to feed all these people?"After visiting Souvlaki Guy for many years, conversing with him over anything and everything like an old friend, I hope you too will visit and support him so he won't retire and move to Greece like he always threatens me he'll do. Please don't make me chase him halfway around the world for my fix.
<review# 728,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/18/2011,7/6/2012,357,324,14,21,17>So, I've now had street meat from two of the Vendy winners: 53rd and 6th, and Sammy's Halal. Breakdown:53rd and 6th, the meat is finely ground up and so processed that it's kind of like eating mashed potatoes made from meat. The flavors run together, and the hot sauce is so violent that it could be used as a biological weapon.Sammy's Halal, the meat is in larger chunks, allowing you to appreciate how tender it is. Additionally, there's some cilantro mixed in so it adds a welcome depth to the standard flavor you're expecting from one of these. The hot sauce is slightly more flavorful than the other cart, and also scaled down enough that you won't hurt yourself or anyone you kiss/breathe on after you eat it. Plus they have green sauce. And if you don't know yet how I feel about green sauce at a halal cart, just ask Lizz K.Definite win goes to Sammy's because, well, it's cheaper and better. Doesn't get more clear-cut than that.

I can just imagine whoever made it stirring it continuously on the stove.  It was the best dish of the night in my opinion. ~~Polenta - 4 stars - although I am not a big fan of polenta, this dish just made me a convert.  I loved the texture, the taste and how comforting it was on the tastebuds. I can feel the love in the preparation although they did use truffle oil and I'm still on the fence about its use. ~~Lamb -  4 stars -  it was perfectly cooked (I want it a bit pink), tender and perfectly seasoned.  It was Evan's entree and he was generous in giving everyone a taste of his meat. I would have given five (5) stars but it was a smallish portion. ~~Guanciale -  3 stars I had it as an entree and I wanted to see how it compares to one of my favorite chef's version.  However, as far as I can recall that version used guanciale in a pomodoro base so it would not be an apples to apples comparison.  It was creamy and a bit overpowering so t I think the seafood risotto was several notches better. ~~Torta di Granchio or crabcake - 3 stars - I wanted chunks of crabmeat which were absent and the serving was on the small side.   ~~Fazzoletti with Veal Ragu - 4 stars -  This was Megan's entree and since all of us were tasting each other's dish, I had a good taste of this.  It was rich, comforting and perfect.  ~~Calamari -  4 1/2 stars - Moses, I mean Evan, gave me a bite of the calamari. It could be the robes and the decalogue he was carrying but I thought the calamari was sensational.  It was crispy, served hot, not flour-y, I loved it!  I also give four (4) stars for the Cabernet Sauvignon they served at happy hour prices ($7 per glass until 7:30 p.m.)  After happy hour, Raphael, Amy and I got a bottle of wine for $30 to go with our meal.  Five (5) stars for the service as everyone from the staff to the manager and even the owner, I think, collected coats, poured water, checked in on us, etc.  After our meal, they gave us a taste of most of their desserts, compliments of the chef.  That was a nice gesture for our big group. :) And in Astoria, it is often done by most restaurants. like Taverna Kyclades but Portalia went a bit further by giving a taste of ALL of their available desserts:~~Tiramisu was heavenly, authentic and not too sweet.  ~~Chocolate creme brulee was a nice surprise but I prefer the traditional one.~~Flourless chocoloate cake with pistachio gelato was the most elegantly    presented of all the desserts.  ~~Apple tart was perfection, and the dried apple was beautiful and delicious.  I     think this is the perfect dessert for the pork chop which Mike B ordered but     I never got to taste of because he was at the other table.   ~~The raspberry sorbet resonated as the perfect ending for me because it was a    beautiful contrast to the richness of the food. Bravo, Portalia!  I see myself and my best friend strolling to and from our home, pretending that we are in Bergamo.  By the way, they do offer brunch and by adding $7 to your entree, you get unlimited mimosas.  Finally,  molto grazie to Evan, our resident Moses who can even top feeding manna from heaven by simply bringing us to Portalia.  :)
<review# 730,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/15/2011,7/4/2012,108,1039,3,8,7>With a large assorted order to feed 7 people ordered to go a bunch of friends and I gathered to devour what so many have already been claiming as legitimate bbq.I'll have to preface this with the fact that since I had the food to go, I'll definitely have to go back and eat it fresh in the restaurant next time.One thing I will say is stand out is their cole slaw. It's very vinegary and acidic which is an absolute perfect pairing when you're on a meat fest adventure.The burnt ends are definitely tasty but I found the taste varied quite a lot between pieces. The fattier ones definitely better.The ribs are definitely some of the better flavored ribs I've had in NY. I must say though if you're one of those types of people who equate a slathering excess of sauce as "good" then you'll be disappointed. However if you're one to fully focus on the taste and seasoning, you'll find them delicious.The pork belly is a hit, but I say almost any place that serves pork belly is pretty much guaranteed that as a hit.Also tried the lamb sausage and while I generally dislike lamb, found myself liking the sausage.The brisket is just tender enough and flavored proportionately.At the end of the day though, I feel like the stand out dishes are the cole slaw and the ribs. These are the two things that will set this place apart.

I have no idea what the names of a lot of the options are because nothing is labeled. Samosas are excellent, so are the chicken spring rolls. You won't find a cheaper or more homey meal anywhere. I decided to get this with a scoop of banana ice cream. Yes I thought it might have been too much banana flavor but it was actually quite good. The crepe came in an ice cream cone form which you don't see very often. It was definitely enjoyable eating the crepe this way instead of with a fork and knife. <review# 741,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/20/2014,5/28/2014,42,175,12,14,10>Okay, first off, I rate places based on the type of restaurant/institution it is. Am I going to complain that a local diner didn't offer to hang up my coat, park my car, and use the finest imported fromage? NO. It's a dang diner! That's the idea with La Perrada de Chalo. It's a Columbian spin on American fast food that is a guiltily satisfying good time that's absolutely sure to leave you stuffed.The menu is ridiculously extensive, covering sandwiches, burgers, bowls, and most importantly (to me): Hot dogs. Seriously. These hot dogs are completely out of this world.My absolute favorite thing to get here is the Iraqui hot dog (super size). Sure, it's a regular old unimpressive hot dog. But then it enter the hands of whatever genius artisan craftsman is behind that counter. It's boiled perfectly and served on a toasted bun so that the outside has the slightest crisp while the inside is soft and fluffy. The iraqui is then topped with ketchup, mayonnaise, a smear of smooth pineapple sauce to give an incredible subtle sweetness, sliced hardboiled eggs, and crumbled up potato chips. Yes, you read that correctly, dang crumbled Ruffles or something. It's a freakin' party in your mouth, and a perfect crunch of slight saltiness.I also highly suggest the Maicitos Con Pollo Con Queso; it's a bowl based with chicken meat, sweet corn, sliced cheese, and sauce. Which is probably mayo. But so dang good. Think of it like a salad, but all that annoying healthy green stuff removed, and just meat, corn, and cheese. Mm.The salchipapas is pretty standard, having well cooked fries and sliced hot dog pieces cut to look like little fanning four tentacled octupi. That sounds unappealing, huh? It's good though, swear. The service here is very friendly, but honestly at least half the times I've come, the people behind the counter did not speak English. Luckily, I was either with my Colombian friend or used my broken high school level Spanish to get by. Also, if you order the hot dog (which you will, right?), just accept the fact you will be a disgusting hot mess trying to eat it. It's fine. It's part of the ritual. Just be sure to snag more napkins, because they certainly do not give you enough.

I can go on and on about everyone else's entree, esp how fresh the pastas are. But till next time! This place will be tough to top.
<review# 746,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/28/2011,6/13/2012,101,229,10,12,13>Shabu shabu, hot pot, whatever you want to call it, Shell Cove is a place where you cook your own food in pots at your table.  Some dear friends of mine invited me out to dinner at Shell Cove to celebrate the Holidays and friendship and to have me meet a fellow scientist.  First, you pick what kind of soup base you want and then you decide what goes inside (ie meat, fish, or veggie).  I went with beef and a kimchi soup broth because both are good.  Next, they bring you out a buncha stuff like all different kinds of veggies plus an egg.  Then, they bring you out a pot full of your soup base and you start cooking your food.  In between, you can order things like dumplings if you want them or other stuff to throw into your soup.  The dumplings we got tasted really good so I was excited.  There's also a "make your own sauce" bar and a rice cooker filled with rice.  What I like to do is eat most of my hot pot and then add a bowl or two of rice in with the remaining broth to mash up the rice.  I then scramble my egg and put it in with the rice and add my remaining beef.  The result is delicious.The price was right and the food tasted good here, my compliments to the chef (ie me).  But, the food they made tasted good, too (ie the dumplings).  And the waitress hit on me (ie winning).  I'll likely come back again when visiting with my Elmhurst amigos.
<review# 747,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/12/2011,6/12/2012,406,1092,7,9,8>I am so thankful that Francois Danielo has decided to come to the USA to pursue his baking career. He is a very talented baker and recently opened La Boulangerie proves that, with lines out the door on weekends. If you're not here early enough, certain baked goods will get sold out. So I highly recommend coming earlier so you will have the full spread to choose from.The establishment feels like something out of Europe. It's small and cozy, with a very rustic touch. The counterop and furniture are all made out of maple-like wood. The light color of the wood and floor to ceiling windows in the front allow enough ample to light in to give it a vibrant ambiance. After you get your order, there is a sugar station if you need to concoct your coffee drinks to your preferred level of sweetness. I highly recommend grabbing a seat to enjoy the ambiance. There are 4 tables seating 2 people each, and then a large communal table seating an additional 10 people. After you settle down, take notice of the 2 large glass windows on two sides of the establishment, so you can watch the bakers kneading the dough, shaping it and throwing into the ovens. It's a treat to see them work their magic. The nice ambient music is also very relaxing, what I would guess is a mix of French or jazz music. There is also a counter of newspapers and magazines that you can pick up and read. It all adds up to a very personal touch with a local feeling to the establishment that I can enjoy going to for years to come. But let's not forget why you're here, for some delicious freshly baked breads. We ordered a Cappucino (Small - $3.25), Cream Cheese Danish ($2.85) and a Pain Au Chocolate ($2.10). The Cappucino was prepared perfectly with the right ratio of espresso, hot milk, and steamed-milk foam. It was then topped off with some sort of powdered mix. The Cream Cheese Danish topped with 4 blueberries and powdered sugar was very good, with just the right thickness of the cream cheese and flakiness of the dough. The Pain Au Chocolat, similar to a Chocolate croissant, but not as buttery and flaky, was equally delicious. I do wish they added a bit more chocolate to give it that extra bittersweet chocolate flavor. But one pastry to rule them all is the Almond Croissant. Just think of the same croissant but with almond cookie-like batter baked on top. The sweetness of the batter is the perfect morning treat.In all, La Boulangerie is sure to please and I highly recommend stopping in for a coffee and a pastry. And don't forget to get one of their finely baked fresh breads such as their baguettes, pain bordelais, and pain aux cereales. Just remember to come early on weekends, because they go quick!!

<review# 752,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/7/2011,6/6/2012,132,92,4,5,2>This is my first review of a hair Salon so I don'y really know how to play it but....the design inside is very post modern and chic, mostly white and red hues so it makes me think of the mid-90s when a lot of places were sporting this design. Some places in the city still do...There is a seating area with many magazines with womens hair styles from Japan to Taiwan and Hong Kong and they seemed fairly popular with the clientele. The music is also your general Asian fare with popular songs from China, HK, and Taiwan.The reason however why this place gets five stars for me is their service and their excellent haircut. As an Asian male it is hard for me to find a place to get my hair cut; my choices are generally barber shops who dont know how to do "asian hair" or salons around the city which also really dont know how to do "asian hair". In the past I have resorted to going to cheap Chinatown or Flushing hair cutting places for men but most of the time I come out looking like I got a Chinese army haircut (however the prices are ridiculously cheap)Unlike either of those places, "Red Hair Salon" knows how to do my hair and I come out pretty satisfied with the haircut. While the price is around $30 for a shampoo cut and blow dry, it is well worth it to not look like I have just escaped enlistment. The service is also exceptional, similar to many establishments they will give you a shampoo and condition with a head massage followed by the haircut and they will wash it again to make sure the hair is out. By far this is one of the best salons or any barber that I have gone to. Note that sometimes on the weekends it is quite busy and it is good to come in with an appointment. The stylists/barber will generally give you their card so you can always call back.
<review# 753,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/14/2012,6/5/2012,270,686,2,6,3>Dumplings, Pan Fried Dumplings (difficult to find!), Noodles, Side Dishes: CHECK!The dumpling here are ridiculously good! It just doesn't get more authentic than this. I would consider this a hole in the wall (at the back of Maxim Bakery) but it's so clean! I personally like to plop down at the bar and watch them make the dumplings. The owner is so nice if you get to know him. My fav dumplings are hand's-down, the FISH DUMPLINGS! You just can't find any better out there! Get the Fish Dumplings! The rest are all awesome as well. They all taste good! The vegetarian one is good but a bit on the bland side, compared to the meat ones. And the Pan Friend Dumplings, can't find them anywhere really, not made the right way like here, two ends open. Entertainment: CHECK!They make the Dumplings right in front of you, they also cook in front of you so you know this is a clean shop!Great Price: CHECK!It's $3.50 (10 Dumplings) $5.25 (15 Dumplings) at sit down They also sell frozen ones ($13-$20) for 50 Dumplings   If you don't know how to cook dumplings, the asian way goes like this - 1. Add water to pot till it's half full, bring to a boil on high heat, and then add the dumplings. Do not defrost.2. Immediately stir the dumplings, so they don't stick to the bottom. The heat stays on high throughout.3. Once the water is boiling again, add 1 cup of cold water, bring it to a boil.4. Add another 1 cup of cold water, bring it to a boil. TaDah! Perfect Dumplings!Even if it's frozen, I would guess they are no more than 1-2 days old, the turn around rate here is ridiculous!
<review# 754,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/23/2012,6/4/2012,565,622,4,10,8>Whenever I'm in the Elmhurst area, I try to make a pit stop at Taste Good. If I have time to sit down and eat, I'll usually get the roti canai as an app. Though the roti is the same Malaysian paratha that you get in most Asian groceries in Queens, the curry that comes with it is top class. They also have other things in their extensive menu which I think are excellent options. FYI, the prices on the take out menu in these pics here are about 25c to 75c cheaper compared to the dine in menu: yelp.com/biz_photos/Zx44 yelp.com/biz_photos/Zx44 yelp.com/biz_photos/Zx44The laksas here are probably better than anywhere else you'll find in NY, especially since we're not exactly spoiled for Malaysian or Singaporean food choices. I've tried the Hokkien Udang Mee and it blew me away. In general,  the sambal flavors in their laksas are super addictive and delicious. I topped it off with their sambal chili sauce to give it an extra kick and couldn't stop eating till my bowl was empty. yelp.com/biz_photos/Zx44The Nasi Lemak and the two Nasi Gorengs on the menu are good choices if you want to try a rice dish. yelp.com/biz_photos/Zx44 The great thing about a Malaysian rice dish is that it comes with all sort of proteins, veggies and most of all - bold flavors! They don't hold back on the flavors here and you should know that they taste even better if you mix it up, put it in the fridge and eat it the next day.Meatwise, my favorite is the randang. Could it be anything else? Ever since I had wild boar randang in Malaysia, I've been a randang loyalist. They have two here - beef and mutton.  I love them both. They're also great for take out. Just let them sit in the fridge and marinade for an extra day. You're welcome! yelp.com/biz_photos/Zx44For something a little lighter, try the Hainanese chicken.Taste Good is a hole in the wall that serves up great food without any pretense. There isn't much of a decor which doesn't really bother me but I do wish the ventilation was better. It can get really hot in there sometimes.Less than a minute's walk from the Elmhurst Ave station on the R line, Taste Good is a must try on every foodie's list.
<review# 755,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/28/2011,6/3/2012,242,102,8,9,10>Had a friend who was a chef part time tell me to definitely check out this recently opened place last year. Deep in the middle of Queens, this is definitely a gem in the heart of Sunnyside. Located right under the 7 train line, Salt & Fat is an amazing Asian Fusion joint with unique concoctions and great beer selection.To start off my date, they brought over popcorn cooked in bacon oil, which makes a nice snack to compliment the drinks we initially ordered. The beer selection is quite impressive, I had the Mother Milk's Stout, which gives Guinness a run for its money, as well as the Ommegang Belgian Pale Ale, which my friend describes as Blue Moon on Steroids. Now, for the food itself, to start off the meal, I ordered the "Crack and Cheese" and the "Braised Pork belly Tacos." The "Crack and Cheese" is definitely the highlight of Salt & Fat and a must signature dish to have! The Braised Pork Belly Tacos was quite tasty, but since I had my share of Korilla's Kimchi Tacos, its nothing really special, but good nonetheless. For the main course, my date and I had the "Oxtail Terrine" and "Creekstone Farms Hangar Steak." The Oxtail Terrine at first look like a brownie cube, but thats is just how its cooked and presented since they rip off and consolidate the oxtail meat off the bone. Its damn good by itself, but with the complimented sauce and veggies, it makes it even better. The Hangar Steak ordered Medium-rare is quite bloody, but I like it that way, so I definitely liked it. However, it couldn't outshine the Oxtail. For the coup de grace, the dessert menu was short, but if you like unique ice cream, you must try their avocado or Thai Ice Tea ice cream flavors. Simply heavenly!Overall, the Salt & Fat experience was very euphoric and a hidden gem. Queens definitely needs more restaurants like Salt & Fat!

<review# 758,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/12/2012,5/13/2013,406,1092,4,6,7>Barosa is truly a hidden gem with affordable Italian pastas and pizza in the Forest Hills area. There are two locations, the main dining hall area with full service bar, plenty of seating, and a narrow corridor filled with tables and sliding glass panels that open to the outdoors. Adjacent to the main dining hall is where the pizzeria is, small and narrow, with 5-6 tables, and a small bar area seating 6-7 persons. Although not all pastas are included at the pizzeria establishment for those that are, prices are slightly cheaper by about $1.00.As is traditional at most, if not all Italian restaurants is a complimentary bread basket. This is not your ordinary bread. They are more like fresh out of the oven garlic knots. Warm to the touch and to melt the butter. YumIf you come here, you have to try their signature dishes, denoted with their logo beside select dishes. Their Rigatoni Barosa ($14.95) which is rigatoni with broccoli rabe, sausage & hot cherry peppers is a tasty dish for those looking to get their palates jumping. The butteriness of the pasta complimented with the bitterness of the broccoli rabe, and saltiness of the sausage makes for an already stellar dish. But add the hot cherry peppers, which are very sour, gets my tastebuds jumping every time. The dish errs to the ever so slightly side of greasy from the oil, but its a minor nuisance for one very enjoyable dish.The Penne alla vodka (11.95), made in light pink vodka cream sauce, is another delicious dish. Heavy cream is obviously used, and as is expected, but it didn't feel heavy at all. The sauce was thick and creamy and clung onto the penne nicely and full-flavored. It's one of the best that I've had in a while. In the restaurant location, this same dish goes for $13.95, with the addition of prosciutto, but I really didn't feel the need to add a salty component to it.With their recent complete renovations last week, I will definitely have to bring some friends along for some yummy Italian. This is one place not to miss.

<review# 764,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/9/2013,5/6/2013,2398,639,23,8,11>One day I was on an EPIC adventure with a friend who was in town for the weekend.  We were trying to start our adventure at a bar in Queens.  We went to Sunnyside, and went in every bar we saw on Yelp.  Each bar was a failure.  Often we walked in, and walked out.  Nothing to see there...In one bar, we stopped to see the end of the Knicks game.  These dudes were yelling and screaming and telling us the Knicks were going to lose.  They did not.  There were these girls there.  They were regulars.  They wanted no part of said dudes.  But they were cool and talked to us.  We told them we were looking for somewhere with music to chill that night.  One of the girls told us a story.  She said, "there is a place nearby called Sean Og.  It is a cool place and we like to go there.  Tonight is not their best night, but there should be music.  But be careful."  Careful?Then she told us that there are often a lot of Tibetans and sometimes, they get drunk and want to fight.  The story got crazier and crazier as we she told us of these crazy fights she would have with Tibetans.  She insisted that there were just some random people that would be rude and she would end up arguing and that they would be in these epic battles with a growing population of aggressors.  Males and females.So we asked - "Then why the hell do you keep going there?"Answer: "Because, Sean Og is awesome.  That's our spot..."These stories were so crazy, that we had to go to Sean Og.  We paid, and we left.  We walked straight to Sean Og.There was hip hop playing, there weren't many people but it was a beautiful bar and the vibe was nice, as was the bartender.  We were treated nicely, people were pretty awesome and we were happy chilling at Sean Og for the rest of the night.  We got comfortable.Despite the amazing stories we heard, the place was not full of Tibetans...Unfortunately, there was not a Tibetan in sight... ....Yet....As the night went on, people started to fill Sean Og.  Then, like the epic bar story fairy waived her wand, Tibetan women started to fill Sean Og.   Not 5.  Not 10.  At least 40.  It was kind of crazy.  Douche bags wandered in and tried to talk to them.  They usually got shut down.  It was like a great people watching event.  People danced.  The place was very ethnically diverse, but true indeed, there were lots of Tibetans. Noticeably, one of the Tibetan women was not a woman.  The poor dude that danced with that particular person had not gotten the memo...he kept saying "that chick is tall..." as he ordered more drinks...But I saw not a single fight.  People were nice.  It was great.  Everyone was happy, even the guy with the "tall chick" on the dance floor!And Sean Og Tavern was awesome.  It was worth the trip.Note: Initially I mistakenly recalled that the women were from Cambodia, for reasons unbeknownst to me.  I wrote my initial review using Cambodia.  Later, I received a message stating that the people were from Tibet and remembered that to be true.  I have updated my review accordingly.

<review# 774,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/24/2014,10/2/2014,133,62,18,20,21>It is agreed that every neighborhood needs a local watering hole, a gathering of locals and drunks and occasional newbees. That is what the old Donovans used to be and I really enjoyed it.  The neighborhood people used to be there as often as possible,  and whenever you went there you could always rely on a certain faction of them be there no matter what time of day it was. Its noon somewhere as the saying goes.  A few years ago it was taken over by new management. It lost a lot of old customers and was met with a certain resistance.  However, I am still drawn to it because you cannot, no matter hard you try, find better burgers anywhere else. The food is awesome pub food, and their specials are nice. The Guinness on tap is always smooth. The new owners completely renovated it and you know what  I discoverd?  Its actually nice to be able to see what you are eating! It has a spacious old world touch of class with accents in dark rich wood, open and airy feeling, tile floors,  tin ceiling. Its a wonderful place to end a long day or eat at for Sunday brunch. I have had  gatherings here with various friends and relatives on a Sunday.  The selection of  awesome; omelets, ham, bacon and sausage or for the non-meat eater you have salmon, which is smoked and delightful, pancakes, of course.  It is a classic. In short, out with the old, in with the new.  Same advice goes double for ex's. LOL.

Third, and I am sure some of you will disagree with this, I am glad they brought the drinks back, and reduced the alcohol content. I like to share a Miami vice with my wife, it is just part of our relaxation process. We don't like to drink a lot but it is nice to have a little something. Fourth, it is cleaner, but that has never really been an issue in my opinion, but I have never seen any issues with the pools, baths, or floors, and most people are polite.I cannot fault spa castle for the actions of the patrons, but sometimes you just can't get away from people being jackasses. I am thankful that the staff enforces the rules that keeps the place clean, like no bathing suits in the first floor baths and no outside footwear anywhere in the building. It seems to me some of the especially negative reviews come from people who it seems never even came here. I am being honest and forthright about my experience, and I hope this review lends an insight to what this place is actually like now that it has turned around for the better.Also, please don't complain about the no outside footwear, it is to keep the floors clean. Your sandals and flip flops have things you don't even want to think about on them from the filthy streets and sidewalks. Plus you are supposed to bathe and clean yourself before going upstairs. Anyway, I hope this sheds light on the improved spa castle experience!

I very much appreciate that. I'll definitely be back!

The sauce was awesome.The spicy soppressata pizza was delicious. Soft, light, easy to eat and by this I mean the pie was more of the personal size. Also, if you sit in the back area and face the kitchen; you will be blinded by the light in the kitchen. Very annoying.Overall, I have mixed feelings about this place. If I was going for a bottle of wine and enjoy some food; great value. Going for dinner, Milkflower is pricey for pizza. Like I said, I was still hungry and at $75, oh well. I know this is a quality product and not your dollar slice, but pizza is one of those food groups that is inexpensive and filling. I guess I am paying for that hipster ambiance. Remember coffee was 50 cents before Starbucks. I will certainly go back, but not when I am hungry. Maybe.....
<review# 781,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/6/2014,7/7/2014,65,129,13,21,11>I spent 2 years in culinary school. I've eaten at every "Famous" bakery in NYC. I've spent more than I care to admit on fancy plated desserts in fine dining establishments all over Manhattan.Not one of those places can hold a candle to the perfect Napoleon slice I had at Cannelle. I had never heard of this spot. A French bakery in my own home borough of Queens?! Renowned?  Classically authentic? Affordable? Wait.....it's where?! Did you say a strip mall? I was VERY skeptical and a huge pastry snob as my friend drove into the parking lot. I didn't even spot the bakery as she was parking right in front of it. I was suggesting that maybe it closed down and we should go elsewhere for our sugar fix. But, there it was sandwiched between two other shops, and when we stepped inside, imagine my surprise to see a line wrapping around the store!I only had to glance at the display case to realize that this was the real deal. The puff pastry on the Napoleons were crispy, brown, and slightly uneven- a clear indication that they made it themselves and didn't buy it from a freezer in a wholesale distributor. The mousses, the cakes, the breads.....WOW! I could wax poetic on the perfection of their execution, but this is a review site, not a fallback for wanna-be-writers.Let me explain why the Napoleon is always my benchmark of whether or not a bakery is any good. It's one of the first classic desserts I learned to make in culinary school and it is a labor of love. Making puff pastry from scratch is a long, arduous process that involves lots of flour, butter, a rolling pin and arms of steel. There is pounding involved, and precise folding and measurements....It's not for the faint of heart. REAL pastry cream is the same way. You don't just throw a bunch of ingredients into a Kitchen Aide and flip a switch. There is stove top cooking involved with constant stirring, and if you take your attention away for ONE second, your pastry cream is a burned mess. Many bakeries skip all these steps and buy frozen puff pastry, or prepared pastry cream (aka- vanilla pudding), or worse- use whipped cream, which should NEVER be acceptable. I wish I had taken home a box of treats. The line was just so long, but to their credit, they kept it moving and it was fairly organized despite the number of people there. My friend's slice of chocolate mousse cake was rich and decadent without being overly sweet. This location is NOT near any subway station and I didn't spot any bus stops anywhere nearby. It's smack in the middle of a residential area and you would be hard pressed to get there without a car. However, I did read that they are opening a Long Island City location soon, and I CANNOT wait for that!! If you have not experienced the pastry perfection that is Cannelle Patisserie, you are missing out on one of Queen's bests hidden gems.

<review# 784,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/22/2014,7/4/2014,111,198,7,11,7>I've literally been here 1 billion times since my first review, so an update is in order. This is my Greek husband's favorite place in Astoria with good reason. While Kyklades is a great seafood spot... there is no better place for octopus and a whole fish, than Telly's. Hands down, the freshest, most consistent fish I've had here or anywhere. The food overall is so simple and homey, it's like eating from a Greek grandmother's kitchen. Portions are big... I'd recommend picking your main dish, either a fish or meat (fish you can likely share), and get some sides/apps for the table to share and do it family style.SERVICE: Good, the owners are friendly.AMBIANCE: There are two sides, the side when you walk in which is uber casual and then the other side that is a little more formal. It's a very homey feel.FOOD:-Our favorite is to share a whole flounder, porgy, or tsipura. But I've probably had them all, and you can't go wrong with any of them (they have a huge selection usually). Whatever looks good. When you order a whole fish, up to you if you need it cleaned or not, they offer you the option. MUST: Ask for the Lemon Oil sauce with it... you pour it on with a little salt and pepper, and you're golden. It's the best.-The char-broiled meat has gotten much better, the lamb chops and chicken souvlaki are perfect. Highly recommended.-Sides/appetizers: +SPICY FETA DIP (get it with grilled pita to dip) - it's next level good. Do it.+TARAMOSALATA - it's described as a "fish roe" dip, it's pink and smooth in texture, It's tough to explain the taste, but let's put it this way: before I knew what was in it, I had no clue it was fish. It's amazing also on Pita.+LIMA BEANS - Forget what you know about lima beans, these aren't green squishy things you folded in your napkin as a kid to get past your mother. These are the real deal. They're white, in a tomato, dill sauce. So healthy and flavorful... everyone I force into trying this loves it.+GRILLED OCTOPUS - Said it before, I'll say it again, it's the best. Boom.+FRIES - perfect with oregano on top, yes.+LEMON POTATOES - also delicious, but I prefer the fries, because I then dip them in the spicy feta dip to say i'm not eating all the bread and being healthier, even though I have no proof of that.+GREEN SALAD - I don't like raw tomatoes which this excludes (yes I like Ketchup, do not ask me that.) This salad is my favorite, chopped romaine, dill, scallions, feta, olives, oil & vinegar. I could eat a large by myself. Get one for the table.+HALOUMI - It's grilled cheese, literally. It's a salty Cyprian cheese that you have to try. Chewy in texture.+SAGANAKI - I like cheese... this one is flambeed. Gooey and warm.+GREEK HOUSE WINE - I love the white, fairly dry, a little bit of sweetness but not too much at all.Now. Even if you have popped a pant button at this point... get ready for the free dessert that comes after: LOUKOUMADES (fried dough balls drenched in honey and cinnamon)... the only night they don't bring it is on Saturdays. If you like coffee, their Greek coffee is wonderful and they have some of the best LOUKOUMADES around.If you want an authentic Greek experience in Astoria, this will have to be very high on your list. I can't recommend it enough. Have fun rolling home.

<review# 787,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/6/2014,11/19/2014,47,10,15,15,14>What makes a difference between the hundreds of haircutting establishments throughout the city?  Well, here is why I believe "At the Buzzer" stands out. Nine times out of ten you walk into a conversation between everyone in the shop--it could be about sports, the economy, music, etc.  When or if when you add in your own feedback you never feel out of place or unwelcomed, which the staff makes sure of that.  There's this family vibe about the place.  The barbers really take to parents and their children.  I've seen numerous mothers/fathers bring in their troop to get haircuts--that could very well be because of the environment provided by the staff.  I've brought my teenage sons in for their cuts and they now just go on their own.Normally the shop maintains two barbers on any given day. They don't do or take appointments, they don't pick and choose their patrons and they don't rush you out the door; which I greatly appreciate.  In fact, they take their time to cut your hair and they never seem to have a problem touching up according to the desires of the customer.  The décor is simple and to the point; nothing much to the place.  If I had a complaint, it would be the long wooden bench that you'd sit, waiting your turn for a cut and its pretty uncomfortable.  They have TV's located in each corner of the shop and the owner has no problem putting anything on for the patron.  What motivated me to write a review about the buzzer? The simple fact that this shop has a modern feel to an old school barbershop tradition; I hope that it remains that way.

It's still a fun commuter and joy ride bike.Dahon Folding Bike #1 "Boardwalk" (Single Speed) - Still in excellent condition. The handlebar grips needs to be replaced. They can get a bit uncomfortable. The saddle has been replaced recently. I originally purchased this bike for my grandmother but she passed away from cancer shortly after I got it for her. Hopefully she's up there riding her bike joyfully through the clouds.Dahon Folding Bike #2 (With gears) - Completely busted and rusted. I originally bought this for my mother's birthday but she never rode it. So I took it to college briefly, didn't ride it much myself and decided to loan it to my roommate after I left. My roommate kept it outside, it sat through rain and snow. By the time my roommate returned my bike, it looked completely brown and disgusting. He tried brushing off some of the rust but it'll never look the same again. When I loaned this bike to my roommate, it was in pristine condition. It's now sitting in another friend's garage rotting away. Money well spent.....As for Spin City, they carry a variety of bikes. Mostly Specialized, Cannondale, Schwinn, GT, and a few bmx and children bikes. They sell a variety of bike accessories, clothing, helmets, and shoes. They also have some pretty great specials on their bike repairs/maintenance services. You could also rent bikes from Spin City.Verdict - If you're living in this region of Queens, Forest Hills, Rego Park, and Elmhurst. This is could be your go-to bike shop. The guys at Spin City are very knowledgeable, helpful, and guys like Jimmy are genuinely friendly and not trying to scam or hustle any customers into buying something they don't need. I'd be more than happy to come back to Spin City to purchase another bike in the near future. And another big reason I prefer coming to Spin City over other bike shops in this Queens region is because Spin City is really neighborhood friendly. Customer service is vital and whenever I go into Spokesman Cycles or other bike shops, I always feel neglected. I'm not a cycling fanatic like some of my relatives and friends but come on, a little customer service would be nice. Spin City Cycle offers that and that is a huge reason why if you live in this area, you should make this your designated bike shop for maintenance/repairs, questions or concerns, and purchases.
<review# 791,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/5/2014,11/15/2014,55,102,3,11,5>The Queens Museum recently opened an expanded space and it looks fantastic. The old galleries had an awkward shape. The panorama totally dominated everything, being so much bigger and taller than everything else, and the main galleries were just filling it out in a square. The exaggerated height and curved walls tapering into narrow corners were just completing the building, not serving the interests of displaying artwork. But the new galleries, in a former ice rink, are spacious and rectangular and very amenable to displaying all kinds of art. The NYC watershed map and tiffany glass collection (which always seemed like somewhat odd companions for the contemporary art that the museum usually shows) are still around but separated from the other exhibits in a more coherent fashion. Now there's a permanent display of memorabilia from the World's Fair, which maybe had been in the museum before, but I had never noticed it in the old configuration. The old, oddly shaped galleries are still in use, but the way movement flows into them from the central court feels elegant and now the variety of spaces that they contribute to spices up the experience of the museum visit. On my last visit a rounded wedge-shaped gallery featured works by Cuban artists, highlighting the diversity of artistic communities on display at QMA that you don't always find at the big NYC museums. Upstairs in the education area there was a small collection of unlabeled works--a project that encourages people to look at art without consideration of names, a gesture I appreciated. There was a denim jacket with punk stuff painted all over the back that held my interest for a while, and a painting that I'm pretty sure was made by Philip Guston (not that it matters).One of the exhibitions in the main space was the Queens International, a biennial exhibition featuring artists who live or work in Queens. There was a lot of good stuff here, and great variety. I won't go into detail about it but I remember one video piece with a hip hop soundtrack and a women shimmying around a kitchen in their underwear with hands duct-taped behind their backs that made my friend say "Art is the best!" The real highlight for me though was the exhibition "Peter Schumann: The Shatterer," which is about the activity of the Bread and Puppet theater, which has been doing performances and participating in activist demonstrations since the 1960s. There are larger-than-life paper-mache puppets, masks, books... It's so richly textured and full material - i felt like I would walk around, take a look from another perspective, and see a whole other layer of drawings and objects that I hadn't noticed before. From nonsense words and stories to grotesque body shapes, pointed renderings of expressive gestures and wistfully dashed-off ephemeral fragments, the two big galleries are packed floor to ceiling with details that are all worth stopping and pondering. It's up through March 30, 2014, and I would urge any art lover to check it out.All in all, the Queens Museum is great and keeps getting better. I feel proud to live in its borough.
<review# 792,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/25/2014,11/14/2014,315,250,14,15,16>Mini split Air conditioning systems are a wonderful addition to any home, but when they start to malfunction good luck in trying to find people competent enough to service and troubleshoot your system.When my mini split system was originally installed a few years ago. It never operated properly from day one. I should have contacted RichAir to do my install, but I was "a penny wise and a pound foolish" and had my friend who knew a friend who did my installation, bad move on my part!Unfortunately, there are many installers out there who are just that, installers only. During the last few years I had my share of HVAC techs who could not properly diagnose and fix the problems I was having with my system, they just went through the motions of charging and discharging the "freon" (R410a refrigerant)I was so frustrated and decided to give RichAir a shot. These guys were great! No, they're not cheap, but the technicians are factory trained and worked with the technical support department of the mini split manufacturer to fix the problem. A Big Thank you goes out to Kassim for diagnosing the problem, orderering the parts and installing it a few days later.The system is working like a champ now. It only took a few years to get it right though, that's on me for waiting!  If you want to get it done right the 1st time. Give RichAir a call, these guys are great and worth every penny!

Splendid textrue, almost like a flan.The whole experience was just wonderful - the service, the food, the environment. The man and I are already planning our menu for our next visit.
<review# 797,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/1/2012,9/21/2012,205,184,8,12,9>For my 100th review- I can't imagine discovering a better place to write about. I've had the Banana Royal and the Ice Cream Soda float and they were both nothing short of delicious.  Get ready for a time warp people because the decor is authentic. All of the signs, including the bar stools, floor tiles, and phone booth are original! How many places can boast that? Sitting at the bar is my favorite but there are also small tables/booths that seat up to four. The service is quick and the "ice cream masters" (that's what I'll call them) are hard workers. Don't forget to leave them a tip!The candy selection at the adjacent counter is just blah. Half of the options are what I refer to as cheap/fake candy you buy at the corner bodega for a kid to entertain them. The other half is some well known pieces- but nothing to write home about. If they whipped (ba dum dum! Thank you I'll be here all night!) the candy counter into shape- they'd have lines out the door. Curiously- I haven't seen a worker here who looked over the age of 18. Interesting. And for those of you who are prone to visit the powder room often, have no fear as their facilities here are in working order. If you're not from Forest Hills (and even if you are), it will feel like this parlor is in the middle of nowhere. But trust me for their ice cream- it's worth the trip.  Quick Tip: 1) They only accept cash.                  2) They're open till 11:30pm!

<review# 802,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/22/2012,9/16/2012,87,144,7,7,8>A native of Astoria, I've never had the pleasure of enjoying Mundo Cafe (despite the urgings of a friend). Today that changed - and so did a whole lot more.I'll start like this, Mundo is fantastic. The food dazzles the palate with an assortment of flavors - heavily indebted to Mediterranean, Levantine, and Middle Eastern influences. These flavors are married, happily, with traditional tastes from South America. We started with the Red Sonja - a lentil and bulgur wheat kofte wrapped in a cool lettuce leaf. The lentil is a global staple. At Mundo the earthiness of the bulgur and lentil is accented well by the mint and citrus. Our gastronomic odyssey continued; we traversed through shrimp scampi in roasted eggplant, quinoa salad with grapes, cashews, and a delicate vinaigrette, artichoke bottoms with an herby and oily stuffing - and what tasted like a fava bean pâté, and finished on falafel and hummus.   The ambiance in the restaurant is relaxed, off-beat, and welcoming. The space is small but comfortable; a bit like postmodern grandma's house (at least my grandmother).Ultimately, I cannot do these offerings adequate justice. Everything I tried was delicious. As a biracial kid/hybridized human - food like this is extra special to me. Perhaps my Levantine roots had me transfixed over simultaneously nostalgic and new tastes; but with food this good, this real, this unique-yet-common, you are bound to have your own special experience.

<review# 810,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/1/2013,3/10/2014,227,1291,5,11,6>If you're looking for a neighborhood deli look no further. I stopped in here figuring they had pancetta and I was right. From the outside I wasn't sure if it was just another bodega masquerading as an Italian deli. Thankfully, it's got that old school deli flavor with the brightly lit, spotlessly clean new school style. I went in after breakfast but before lunch so I was the only one, not knowing the procedure I went straight to the back and noticed the orders are taken up front. I heard some staff talking behind the counter and as I was about to approach another voice asked if I needed help. I put in my order and as he repeated it back to me in probably the most beautiful way I've heard pancetta pronounced. Seriously, I'd never heard it with an accent before. Anyway, as I was waiting I heard someone else yelling at my guy about how he should have asked if I wanted thin or thick cut. "What if he wants to make a sandwich?!" Yelled is too strong, it's like a mom berating you for not taking out the trash. My guy came back and asked for the cut which was thin. As I was waiting I checked out their sandwich prices and noticed they were pretty cheap and saw their frozen section. They make their own sauces, pastas and meat sauce and whole 1lb pasta dishes that are flash frozen. I bought their spaghetti and meatballs and a San Bendetto tea, all still under the $20 mark.The pancetta was great in my dish. I ended up eating the pasta later and it was good. Definitely better than something you would find cruising the freezer aisle at C-Town. I only wish that I worked nearby to try their sandwiches for lunch.
<review# 811,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/24/2013,3/9/2014,136,166,1,11,7>This place is a hidden jewel in Sunnyside.  They do a lot of catering.  I usually buy a tray of their spinach pies cut into appetizer size for parties.  Its a perfect blend of spinach, feta cheese, and green onions between flaky filo dough.  My family and friends loves these appetizers and expect me to bring this to every family gathering.  Their croissants, and pastries are really delicious too.  Its a great place to pick up breakfast, everything is just so fresh.  I have to say they are always busy!!  The man who does work in the store lack personality because he is really busy but I always make him laugh a little :-)  It a small family operation with a couple of hired people working there.  If you are looking for ambience this is not the place, but if you are looking for great fresh croissants, spinach pies, baklava etc, this is a great place to try.
<review# 812,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/1/2014,3/8/2014,734,760,6,13,12>I don't know what's more terrifying: being in a meat shop or being at a buffet bar with endless, all-you-can-pick raw meats. For Christmas dinner, I came here with my family and for just the four of us, the wait was only around 10 minutes. For those who have had Korean barbecue in the city, you know a plate of not-so-great combinations will easily cost you around $30, the least, and will leave you hungry an hour later. For $31 with an AYCE option and AYCS (all you can stuff), it blows other Korean bbq places out of the water. Sure, the quality is questionable but it surely doesn't taste too different to me. Everything I've ever wanted in my dream Korean bbq experience is waiting for me at the raw bar (got goosebumps as I wrote that): kalbi, pork, lamb, shrimp, mushrooms, onions, etc. But PLEASE, don't get sushi. Just no. Stop. It's called AYCE Korean bbq for a reason--not ACYE one type of gimbap. Don't bother with the soups and kimchee either. Just get straight to the business you came for and finish up with oranges. Also, don't come here with a fresh spritz of Chanel No. 5 because it will be saturated with the heavy aroma of marinated meats--it is inevitable. Very good service, even though only one lady (the Chinese one) served us and was very professional, came whenever we put a new slice of meat on the grill and changed the grill many, many times.
<review# 813,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/1/2014,3/7/2014,127,176,4,9,7>Norma's is the cafe every neighborhood wished it had and it helps make Ridgewood feel complete.One of the things you'll notice when you visit Norma's is the organic sense of home. The staff always greets customers with warm welcomes, and everyone always seems cheerful. Norma's has great tasting coffee, and their sandwich/paninis are delightful. I don't even like paninis and I appreciate the paninis at Norma's. They also have good holiday drinks, special drinks and new things on the menu daily/weekly/monthly. Everyday they offer fresh baked pastries and also carry bagels from a local nyc bagel shop.They also have boardgames, books, things from the community being sold and normal / easy wifi to connect to. These are simple things all other cafe's get wrong but Norma's gets right. If you're ever in Ridgewood make sure you stop by Norma's as this is probably the cafe you've always been looking for.
