They were crisp and light and did not overfill me at all. It was a pleasant surprise to see that they were mostly filled with hot air instead of gut filling meats and veggies. The green pilaf was good, a little dry, but very flavorful. We found that adding some of the chebureki sauce (or even the table-side Sriracha) helped keep the pilaf moist.The kabobs were what made my day. We started "light" with some skirt steak and some fat lamb. Drool. We *finished* with the regular lamb and the boneless chicken. The lamb kabobs were absolutely brilliant - tender and perfectly seasoned. All the kabobs were topped with the pickled onions. Yum.Overall, Cheburechnaya was a great experience. Even though I'm über disappointed in myself for not coming here sooner, I'm glad that I finally showed up. Until the next.PS: The restaurant's website is down. For patrons who are uncertain of Shabbat start and end times, you could find out here: chabad.org/calendar/cand
<review# 824,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/14/2014,5/15/2014,522,450,5,12,10>When Salt & Fat opened a few years ago, I would just sit and stare at their menu and wonder what it tasted like. But not many people wanted to brave such dietary conditions, so I never went. So obviously when a date (who is now my boyfriend, obviously because of his fabulous taste in food) suggested that we go to Salt & Fat, I was unable to contain my enthusiasm. Which might not be attractive given the title ingredients, but whatever. Someone wanted to go with me, and I needed to take advantage of this opportunity.We went on a Friday night with no reservations, and were told there'd be a half hour wait. This turned into more of a 45 minute/hour long wait, but I did not care. I honestly would have waited for longer. We waited in a nearby bar, and popped in after we hadn't heard from them for half an hour. We were seated by a friendly waitress who was attentive enough throughout the entire meal.First came the famed BACON FAT POPCORN. It tasted like a heart attack, but felt calorie-free. It was an addictive delight that I've been meaning to re-create but havent gotten around to yet. I had to stop myself from eating the entire bag lest I look like a glutton.The meatballs were probably the least best part of the meal, but the BLT pork buns were delicious. There were only three of them, which makes for an awkward moment on a third or fourth date, but my now-boyfriend was kind enough to give me the extra bun. He knows the way to this girl's heart. The LI duck breast was savory and moist. I would definitely get it again. We might have had another one of the appetizers (just because everything is so small, and we're hungry people), because I can't remember. We finished the meal with the marshmallow ice cream and rice krispies treat, which made me feel like a kid. We washed down the entire meal with a nice selection of beer for prices I'd expect more in Manhattan.All in all, my friends are jealous of my Salt and Fat date, and my boyfriend and I talk about coming back whenever we have the chance.
<review# 825,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/27/2014,5/14/2014,628,678,16,25,21>UFC was the first Korean fried chicken joint I'd ever heard of, in the mild hype surrounding their 2007 opening - but because of its location far outside NYC's Koreatowns, it was one of the last I tried. Now, after having eaten wayyyy more than my share of Kyedong (yelp.com/biz/kyedong-fri) and BonChon (yelp.com/biz/bonchon-chi) at their best, UFC's consistently "good" KFC isn't so exciting - neither exceptionally juicy, nor crunchy, nor tender. It's still suitable enough to lose your KFC virginity to though. Wings and drums are averagely sized. Choose from 4 coatings - original soy garlic, spicy, BBQ mustard, and sweet & spicy. The sweet & spicy is too sweet, and the BBQ mustard was only interesting in that first bite. The classic half soy garlic, half spicy is still the way to go. (Note: "spicy" is only moderately spicy and involves a thicker than usual glaze that's often too heavy on the gochujang.)What sets UFC apart is their great craft beer list. It's like 70% hipster-cred level, the likes of which I haven't seen east of Long Island City. Heck, this is the only place you can get growlers for miles around. The tap list rotates but they more or less always have the same bottles. It makes UFC a downright enjoyable place to have a drink and a snack in the best traditions of beer + wings. ...That is, if you can tolerate the long wait for the snack. As with any other KFC joint, your chicken can take up to a half hour to prepare. When I saw whole chicken on the menu, I had visions of an entire bird battered and fried into a shining, crackling centerpiece. But ordering a whole or half chicken just gets you equally sized chopped pieces, so you can't tell what part you're eating until you bite in. Curiously, the "whole chicken" is roughly the size of but never pieces together into a whole chicken... unless chickens nowadays have 5 wings and a quarter of a thigh (and who knows at this rate?).In reality, whether UFC's KFC is better than average doesn't matter, since this is the only place in the area that prepares the beloved comestible. And that is why they have my business. Skip the sweet potato fries, which are not the orange, caramelized things we love, but instead pale overcooked matchsticks that no amount of honey mustard could save. The regular fries are as good as at any KFC place, but they come in a stupidly tiny basket: Not worth it.The decor is very nicely done, especially for the area, but too bright on the main floor at night. No matter, since this is a perfect restaurant for flexing that Seamless app while you're on the subway - delivery takes up to an hour, and KFC pairs fantastically with Netflix while you're slouching on the floor of your living room.
<review# 826,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/5/2013,4/13/2014,70,216,5,24,16>Excellent burger. Good drinks. Nice atmosphere. Welcome to the neighborhood!As for the review by Mister W., I hope Yelp removes it or that you have the sense to edit it. It's not a review of the place, but of its name. Mister W: Dutch Kills was the name of the neighborhood since the mid-17th Century. The mixology bar Dutch Kills has been here since 2009 and does not own the name of the town. We can have more than one bar that takes the name of the hamlet; it doesn't constitute any kind of theft. Centraal is Dutch for Central. The name does homage to the neighborhood's origins, and is a more meaningful name than "Windmill." I love both bars. They are excellent for different reasons. I doubt anyone is going to be confused about the difference between a pub and a mixology bar that are located about a mile away from each other. Your criticism is akin to attacking two businesses located on 42nd street for both having "Times Square" in their names. I think you should reconsider a 1-star review that can only hurt this new business simply from a misunderstanding about the name "Dutch Kills," which is not a new invention, but the name of the town.

<review# 828,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/15/2014,4/11/2014,423,264,7,14,8>I've been to a few of the billards in Astoria and Break is by far my favorite. Break is spacious and along with pool they also have an air hockey table, a couple ping pong tables, a foosball table,a dart board, and a hoop basketball game.  During the week pool is FREE as long as you're drinking. I've been here during the week and it is slow. It's a great way to kill a few hours and just have fun. the cheapest thing on the menu is a $3 miller high life (bottle) and maybe a few other domestic beers. I had a couple with a friend and spend two hours playing pool for free on a random summer day. At night and on the weekends they do charge to play pool because there is a larger crowd. I believe it's $18/hour on the weekends. Break can get really packed on the weekends. What really sets break apart from just about any bar in the ENTIRE city is that they show Boxing and UFC fights for free. YUP YUP YUP, F-R-E-E. No more paying $20 just to get into a bar to watch a Pay-Per-View boxing or UFC event for me. THIS IS WHERE I'LL BE. Most recently I came here for UFC 168: Weidman vs. Silva 2. I got here early with a bunch of friends and just sat and enjoyed the prelims because Break was going to get packed.  If you plan on watching a PPV event get here early because by 10:30 they stopped letting people in because they were at max capacity.The service here is on point. The bartenders are all very friendly and they're really good and remembering faces and what you've ordered even thoough the entire place is packed. The bouncers are nice too. Something I don't experience very often. Quite the breath of fresh air.
<review# 829,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/23/2014,4/10/2014,111,198,12,13,11>The brunch scene in Astoria is insane. So many options, but this place is on top for so many reasons. The name really says it all... the comfort food here is bar none. Let's get to the basics first, there is always a wait... don't let it deter you from the amazing brunch experience that awaits you. You stand there, and you wait.Next up, I'm sure by now you've heard that you need to order the DISCO TOTS... at this point I'm not even sure why this isn't treated as 'table bread' here, the amount of tots they must go through in 1 hour alone is probably more tots you've ever seen in your lifetime. YES... they're that wonderful. Order it for the table, done.*warning - the ATOMIC FIRE BALLS... taste exactly how they sound. If you cant handle spicy... just don't even try. For your main dish... know that it will be LARGE. A lot of times I have to share or take a doggy bag, because most dishes are so rich.Favorites include:+SOUTH BY SOUTH WEST BENEDICT (This will shut even the loudest bruncher up... pulled pork.... biscuits....oh my.)+EGG MCRUFFIN (Get it if you can, this is often the first to sell out at brunch!)+FRENCH TOAST (It's french toast. Hi.)+CHICKEN AND WAFFLE (Crunchayyy.)+CORN FLAKE CRUSTED CHICKEN SANDWICH (I love this, and the Green Goddess ensemble is lovely)+BURRITO BOWL (When I had this it was just a burrito... same stuffing though, it's every breakfast food mashed together, drenched in cheese. So, you do the math.)Anything I don't have listed on the main dish list above, is either because I haven't tried it yet, it was updated on the menu (new items are often added), or because I blacked out after eating it and don't remember what it was called.The iced tea and iced coffee is great... my only criticism as a sensitive milk drinker, is they only ever have whole milk. The day they have skim milk... or better yet SOY... I'll high five them.SERVICE:Great... waiters are always friendly and fast, they have a ton of people to get through.AMBIANCE: Very cool... random family type portraits all around, old dolls and LUCHADOR figurines, games, OH... and there is a projector with old music videos on the wall. Love it!!! It's like being inside a tacky, cool grandparents' house. There are several joint tables... so yes, your estranged neighbors will inevitably see you scarfing down insane amounts of food. Or, there are also some separate tables... you will have to take what you can get!LOCATION:I love 30th ave. I also love how this is across the street from New York Sports Club to remind you, that you need to get on a treadmill fast after brunch here. Who cares, enjoy the food.Love it here. One of Astoria's gems for sure.
<review# 830,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/25/2013,4/9/2014,757,559,9,14,12>There is a reason I did not post pictures of the food which is counter my review methodology. Driving home the aroma coming from my take out bag was just tantalizing enough to keep my attention. The three taco combo and one of my favorite soups from any culture, menudo was secured in the passenger seat as we sped away. Menudo is the best cure for a hangover and with the night I had last night with crazy friends who have not been together in a while add in a live band, kegs, bonfires and that was the basics of a super long night.The aluminum wrapped packets were endless as I emptied out the bag's contents onto my dining room table. The Lengua taco was the first on the plate and I generously added spicy guacamole, which I added as a side order for $3.25. Once the taco opened the meat literally rolled out as it was bursting from the tortilla like an over stuffed sausage casing. The last thing on my mind was taking pictures. Tender and flavorful the meat was so prominent. I could only muster up the appetite for one bite of the Chorizo taco as the Lengua was so filling and I was scooping intermittant ladle sized helpings of menudo into my mouth. Unfortunately, the menudo was not up to the standard that Las Palmitas has established for me. It was a touch salty, the tripe chunks were small in size and there was an odd metallic after taste.  At this point I felt so full the couch looked much better than taking pictures of food. After a little siesta, I will be ready to go another round with my lunch/dinner meal which totaled $20.00 which is completely fair for the quality of the ingredients.~Pictures to be posted on my next go round.

I've also picked up a baguette for the road, which he squeezed (and without even tasting) said, "meh." Sadly, I have to agree.Still, Cannelle Patisserie satisfies our cravings for viennoiserie and ties us over until the next time we can get back to Paris!
<review# 832,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/29/2013,4/7/2014,121,334,16,16,11>Since I have been coming here really regularly for the past two months now, I figured it was time to write a review.  (Note:  I have been here more times than the Yelp check-ins say.  I often forget to check-in on Yelp because I'm either too excited or too exhausted!)After a year of being pretty sedentary and hiding behind textbooks and M&A deals, a breakup in August forced me to take a step back and work on "me."  (Classic, right?)  I joined CrossFit Queens, like, a week later, and it has come to play a ridiculous role in my life-- perhaps more than I'd care to admit!  Every Monday, I sit down and plan which classes I'll attend, and then my week basically revolves around that.  From day ONE (the free introduction class with Andy), I knew that this was an amazing fit for me.  Also, you should probably know that over a year ago, I did On-Ramp at another CrossFit gym (when I lived in Brooklyn), so I already knew what to expect AND can give a very truthful review.  CrossFit Queens exceeded my expectations, and continues to do so on a daily basis.  Honestly, by the end of the first week, almost every coach knew my name, and I already had friends in the classes.  (Like, at the beginning, it's HARD to get your lazy ass up and moving.  But the time for the evening class would come around, and I'd think, "Well, I want to see so-and-so today, so I'd better go!")  Of course, after you truck through those first couple weeks of soreness, you get into the habit, and you suddenly wake up and think, "OK, twelve more hours until CrossFit today.  Let's make it through the day."  Trust me.  It's tough at first but it's very addicting.We're all busy.  I get that.  But you know what was awesome?  I got super busy with work and school for a week and a half, and I got a message from CFQ saying, "We miss you!"  And then when I went in next, rather than chide me or make me feel guilty for not being there, the coaches were like, "HEY!  Great to see you!  Sorry that you've been so busy.  Come on in and work all your frustrations out!"  This community is so, so amazing.  Everyone goes out of their way to make new people feel welcomed.  There are great events on the weekends, too-- an added plus.  Since this is in Queens, you'll meet a lot of first responders, military, etc.-- real people who use these skills in real life.I highly recommend this CrossFit gym.  As I live in Corona, there are no convenient CrossFit gyms near me.  (Unless you count walking down Junction Blvd. late at night CrossFit... there will be jumping and running.  lol)  But since there are no CrossFit gyms near me, I did a ton of research on all of them-- in Queens as well as Manhattan and Brooklyn.  I could not be happier with CFQ.  I've found the ideal fit.  (And pssssht, who needs a relationship?  Boys are stupid.)SIX MORE HOURS UNTIL CROSSFIT!  LET'S MAKE IT THROUGH THE DAY!!!

<review# 835,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/18/2013,4/4/2014,545,1338,12,19,19>Every now and then things happen that restore my faith in humanity. That latest thing is dinner at Bun-Ker. Hands down, one of the best Vietnamese restaurants I have ever tried. Keep in mind Bun-Ker is not a traditional Vietnamese run of the mill restaurant with 26 variations of pho and bun complete with a picture menu. Bun-Ker is more simple but with all the flavors and techniques of Vietnamese cooking that you need to experience. You will not be disappointed!I am amazed with what they have done. Bun-Ker provides some really great food at a reasonable price. The décor is cute and kitschy. They transformed a small space into a chic hut with little touches of whimsy here and there. People's business cards adorn boards, daily specials are written on makeshift blackboards (metal trays spray painted with chalkboard paint), and little toy cars ride across handle bars on the walls. The whole place is sort of Disney-like. I felt like I was on vacation or in a magical place. I mean, c'mon it is literally in the middle of nowhere in a section not yet completely transformed by gentrification (check it 7 years later...). Good luck on getting to Bun-Ker without a car. The bus and L train combined with foot might take awhile. I'm curious to see how many apartment complexes and homes are around the corner. If I lived in Ridgewood, I'd be eating at Bun-Ker weekly. From a reliable source, Seamless delivery towards East Williamsburg takes upwards to two hours and is well worth the wait! The popularity of Bunk-Ker (judging from the high 4  1/2 star rating on Yelp and the never ending traffic through the door) has proved love for Bun-Ker is viral. Service is friendly and casual. It was a bit slow at first (they forgot to take our order) but once we got dish one, the ball was rolling.  We ordered the traditional Banh Xeo- crepe filled with shrimp, bacon, and bean sprouts. It was crisp and rich. Wrap it in lettuce, compliment with basil and shiso leaves, and dunk it in fish sauce. Voila! Instant happiness. The rest of our dishes, although meant to be eaten solo, were shared family style. Between three, it was divided into the perfect serving portion per person. Any more people in your table and you may have to double up on dishes.  Highly Recommended:Cha Ca La Vong- crispy ginger turmeric flounder with dill, lettuce, vermicelli, and peanuts. The very thin noodles were angel hair like and gave new meaning to the dish bun. Very refreshing and the fish was not oily.Ca Rig Ga- Vietnamese curry chicken with potatoes, carrots, lemongrass, and roti. Although each dish was outstanding in its own right, this was my favorite. Perfect for a cold winter night. Food for the soul.Bo Luc Lac- cubes of beef, white rice, peanuts, and salad. Very tender, flavorful, and juicy. Loved the peanuts and fried garlic.Bun-Ker provided enough to make me want to go back and visit again. The rest of the menu is just as enticing, it just depends what dish you are in the mood for.All meats are anti-biotic and hormone free and the pork is heritage bred and pasture raised. Sound too frou frou to you for Vietnamese food? Think again. While Bun-Ker is doing their best to provide quality ingredients, hoity-toity attitudes are not prevalent. Water is self serve so stand up, put those legs to good use and bus your own table.

<review# 838,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/14/2012,8/21/2012,238,433,9,13,10>Mister Chicken To Go is the healthiest fried chicken joint in Queens! While words like "healthiest" and "fried" made that sentence sounds like an oxymoron, It is actual quite true. <review# 839,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/23/2012,8/20/2012,286,298,12,15,17>The New World Mall food court never ceases to amaze me with their variety of choices. On my most recent trip I noticed that they now have a stall serving made-to-order xiao long bao (soup dumplings*) and jiao zi (dumplings*) ::cue excited squeal::I ordered a steamer each of the pork XLB yelp.com/biz_photos/LNqx and the crab & pork XLB yelp.com/biz_photos/LNqx. My first impression of Noodle Village's XLB was that they're huge! They were 150% the size that I was expecting, and in Noodle Village's case, bigger IS better because each delectable XLB was filled with a flood of soup. Brownie points to Noodle Village for providing small bowls so that if you spill your soup none of it is wasted. My only complaint is that the soup was slightly more oily than I prefer. Flavor-wise Nan Xiang still reigns king of XLB in Flushing, but Noodle Village provides a faster and worthy alternative to the wait at Nan Xiang and benefits greatly from being in the New World Mall food court. Since the XLB are made-to-order, they'll take about 15 minutes. I suggest placing your order at Noodle Village before visiting any of the other stalls and using your wait time to stake out a table in the food court. You have to pay a $2 deposit per bamboo steamer that is refunded to you upon returning the steamers.-------*Dumpling fun facts: It can be slightly confusing that xiao long bao and jiao zi are both known as "dumplings" in English, because they are obviously not the same thing. Ground meat and/or veggies in a wrapper does not always equal dumpling. Jiao zi literally translates to "dumpling." Xiao long bao is most commonly referred to as "soup dumplings" in English; however, the Chinese do not classify them as dumplings. Their classification is in their name - xiao long bao is a "bao" (closest English translation would be "bun"), and directly translated word for word they are little steamer buns. The difference between a bao and a dumpling is in the shape, the wrapper, and the way that they are cooked. IMO the easiest way to differentiate the two is in the way they are cooked: dumplings are usually boiled and very rarely steamed, while baos are usually steamed and never boiled. (Both can be pan-fried if made with thicker wrappers.)

<review# 849,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/24/2013,3/1/2014,81,129,12,15,10>I can't thank enough for the affordable Parks and Recreation Centers in NYC!!!I have been a member of NY Parks and Recreation center for 3 years now. First of all It is the only olympic sized pool in NYC, its the perfect spot for anyone training for Triatholons and Half Ironmans. Their pool is divided into 3 division with middle one seperated for lap swims. They are usually serious when it comes to lap swim. They have fast, medium and slow lap swim lanes. The life guards keep a watch on the lanes and move the people to slow lanes if they see them swimming very slow.The other day, I got to the pool area, they was a long line for lap swim. I told the life guard I would like to swim in the fast lane. To my surprise there was a man with Snorkeling equipment wondering around in the fast lanes. I couldn't understand what he was upto, he wasn't going to find any corals or fishes in the flushing pool. But, the good part was, as soon the life guard saw him disturbing the other fast swimmers, he asked the guy to move to the common swim area and I got to enter the pool.I like the organization/rules and regulations of this pool. It makes it the perfect spot for me to train for my triatholon. I get my long swims done here without any regrets. The only reason I don't give this pool a 5* is cause their changing and shower area aren't the cleaest. But for the price I am paying, I am very happy with what they have to offer.

Sure you can hear cars and such, but the wide open feeling you get with the skylight and floor-to-ceiling windows makes it all still feel peaceful. The studio was warm, but that was also kind of nice. Nick was the instructor and there was another instructor there to help out and keep an eye on our form. I had plenty of space to move around.This class is an absolute MUST for anyone serious about yoga. Even if you've been practicing for a while, this class would help you. I felt so connected to the movement as well as the stillness. Nick does a wonderful job explaining yoga and how to place your body to achieve each pose. And (as everyone has mentioned) - super cheap! This class was donation based, but the most expensive classes are a mere $5. How can you possibly get better than Yoga Agora?

<review# 856,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/4/2012,7/3/2012,158,189,10,10,10>Being determined to make the most of the April Yelp challenge I searched (for hours) to find a restaurant that I a. wanted to eat at and b. had less than 10 reviews.  I found the two in El Omda. It's on 28th ave away from the deluge of restaurants that saturate Astoria. This might be why it's not as busy as it should be.  Armed with my appetite for different cuisines and a $25 coupon from restaurant.com I headed out on a Sat night with the girlfriend and high hopes.The restaurant itself it on the smaller side. About 10 regular tables and some low tables in the back that have cushions for you to sit on.  They have all sorts of different hanging light fixtures and the place is spotless. You can tell they take pride in their restaurant  and it shows. An  Egyptian soap opera was on in the dining room and i found myself watching it severak times. (it is my conclusion that soaps are bad in any language) We were greeted warmly and told to take any seat we liked. maybe 2 other sets of people were there while we dined. They do not serve alcohol in this restaurant so if you like to have a few cocktails before you eat I'd suggest pre-gaming at home.  They also do not serve pork but the menu is vast and there are many many options so I didn't find it to be limiting in any way.  After perusing the menu over and over again (everything sounded so good) I decided on the liver to start and the capon, the GF had seafood over pasta. Each meal come with a salad which as other reviewers have noted was done really well. The veggies, crisp and the dressing light. It also comes with some pickled vegetables, tahini spread and some really delicious bread.  A nice prelude to the rest of the meal to come.In my food selections I take the road less traveled. Hell I'll go as far as to say getting to my food choices involves  needing a machete, a compass and a torch. No man's land. I am often rewarded for this boldness with new and amazing tastes. And with that  my liver arrived. sauteed in olive oil with cumin and jalapenos (how did they know I love them)  It was out of this world. Really fresh (you know when you get bad liver) and seasoned perfectly.  Next was the capon, " But Chris ?" you ask, "What is capon?" It's basically castrated roosted. Yup I just said that and you can't unread it. They do that to make the meat taste better, less gamey if you will. And apparently it works. It was about the size of a cornish hen and was basically like eating a chicken that was entirely juicy delicious dark meat. And they stuff it with rice and said rice soaks up all of the juicy goodness of the bird.  Nicely done, probably could have been a little more meat but I was content. It came with the vegetable of the day which was okra in a light red sauce, also very very good.   My GF got the seafood over pasta, or as I will now refer to it as " 12lbs of seafood over 2lbs of pasta" Seriously It was a huge portion. ( I have a pic of it posted cuz I'm good like that) Pasta cooked perfectly, seafood really really fresh and a nice red sauce that had a little something extra to it. Very well done.After stuffing myself on delicious eats we skipped desert and opted for some Turkish coffee and Egyptian tea.  The coffee was great, gritty, but not too gritty if you know what I mean and the tea with it's fresh mint added was a nice way to settle my overstuffed stomach. I really really enjoyed my meal here. We were there for close to two hours. Just taking our time, never being rushed never treated like we didn't belong there. The owner came up a few times and asked how everything was. Our waitress was really nice too. offering options and making sure we were well taken care of. Our mission is to highlight the less reviewed, I've done my part, now it's up to you to come here and enjoy what El Omda is serving up.  I know you'll be happy you did because as I've always said, when it comes to food , always trust the fat kid :)

<review# 858,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/16/2012,7/1/2012,545,1338,20,25,23>In sixth grade my friends and I were busted for shoplifting a bottle of liquor from the local grocery store. We stood there in front of the store, escorted by a cop, while we waited for our parents to pick us up. It was idiotic and stupid, but boy did it feel good. The rush, the excitement, the feeling of being on the other side of the tracks. It felt good not to be square.Now don't get me wrong, I am far from being a kleptomaniac but really there is some joy from stolen things... The tip of an ice cream cone, kisses, candy from a baby... And now....THE TRIPE TACOThe waitress sat our tacos in front of us, "Tripe, tripe, and chorizo for you." Topped with guacamole and rolled like a cone, the Taqueria Coatzingo taco is signature and one not to be skipped. On goes the citrus, a little bit of spice, whatever you fancy to liven up your taco... I took a bite and heard a crunch. Interesting. It was more like eating chicharron than something tender and fatty like chorizo. Bite again. So good. Better than I remembered it. Being the visual person that I am, I took a look and saw a crispy filling than was more akin to fried onion rings than sliced up or crumbled chorizo. "Um, guys... I don't think this is chorizo."  "Hey, that's my taco!""Hey, that's MY taco!"My bad. So we did the whole switcharoo. The tacos were a fourth eaten but that's okay. Neither of us had any complaints. My one complaint was that I had to give it back."Wow. I had no idea the tripe tacos were like that. I thought they were going to be gross boiled pieces of tripe.""Are you kidding me? The tripe is like fried pieces of goodness! Why do you think I always get it?""OH." *head hangs down*There is a lot to love about Taqueria Coatzingo. First of all it's extremely casual and friendly. I often sit at the same table every time, can loiter for hours with my friends, and they don't kick me out. They don't mind that my tab barely surpasses $5 or that I divy up every dish (well not the taco... that's mine!). My favorite things to get at Taqueria Coatzingo are really the bigger ticket items: the enchiladas, the beef steak, a cemita... You will leave highly satisfied. I like the rice and I like the complimentary freshly fried chips and spicy salsa.Taqueria Coatzingo is open at all hours in the night and it's always full and busy. Service is a little slow, but what's the rush? The menu is a few pages long. It's gonna take you awhile to get through it... So linger... Linger a little while longer in Queens.

The museum is big enough to keep you entertained, but not so big it becomes overwhelming. Some things to look forward to:- retro arcades and video games- costumes and props from different movies- the evolution of video cameras, tvs, and other equipment- interactive areas where you can dub movies, add sound effects, etc.- collections of old toys and memorabilia from childhood shows- special exhibits (right now it's Jim Henson, which is superb)Like everyone else says, Fridays at 4pm is free, regularly it's $12. This place HAS English in their menus so all you liberal round-eyes can bring your other liberal friends here to impress them on how cool and experimental you are -even though there are like a ton of Shanghainese places everywhere, now.

You'll be transported back in time to a simpler time when teenagers sat at an ice cream parlor on dates, families shared sundaes and candies cost a penny. I observed all that , and more, during a trip last night to Eddie's. (Minus the penny candies. The price has entered the 21st century). I'm almost ashamed to admit having lived in Forest Hills for 4 years and not once venturing into this legendary spot. That, my friends, will change.There was about a ten minute wait for seating. You can sit at either the bar (Do they call it a bar if alcohol isn't served? Counter, I suppose) or grab one of the tables in the back. Choose from a variety of homemade ice cream flavors, toppings and syrups. Drink an egg cream. Behold the cream and cherry on top that could be a dessert in itself. See the refrigerator that's at least 75 years old. Hear the sounds of an ancient cash register. It's like a living museum where you can eat sweets!My scoop of vanilla chip with butterscotch was sinfully good. Almost too rich to finish, I managed to mop up the residual melted bits that escaped the serving cup. Forget scotch, butterscotch is where it's at!Prices are reasonable as well. Two ice cream sundaes and one egg cream came in at $13.75.  The staff was friendly and the whole experience was just overwhelmingly wholesome.

<review# 867,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/30/2013,9/3/2013,227,484,11,11,10>After years of being on my bookmarks list, I finally made it here this year.  Glad to see there is no longer a wait for a table!  Now that I've been here, I came back a few times.  It was that great and memorable.  You get large portions and fresh authentic Peruvian food.Here's some of my recommendations:Parihuela (soup) with clams, mussels, shrimp, octopus, calamari and scallops.  It's a tomato based broth with just a bit of kick and sourness.  It's like the Peruvian version of Tom Yom Soup.  You must get this!  Even on a hot day!Anticuchos - Delicious veal heart.  It doesn't taste like heart, it's very tender, marinated and juicy.Any ceviche's, you won't be disappointed in the freshness of any of their seafood varieties.Entrana Saltada tender sliced skirt steak stir-fried with onions and tomato with rice and french fries - I typically don't like skirt steak, so this is the only place I'll eat it.  Arroz Mariscos (Peruvian Paella) yellow rice mixed with fresh seafood  - Huge portion, get ready to share with 2 people!  This is the best paella I've had in Queens.  It's not typical because it doesn't contain saffron, but you're not missing it because the yellow rice is so good on it's own!Also any of their Tallarin Verde (pesto sauce pasta).  It's Pasta Mixed In A Basil, Spinach And Cheese Sauce.  Sooo good, the best is here!  I can't stop eating this pasta!There's always parking available on the street and the atmosphere of the restaurant is perfect.  One time there were violinist playing music here, I think they wandered in from store to store.  This is my go to place for Peruvian now.  Although I haven't tried their typical rotisserie chicken.
<review# 868,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/27/2013,9/2/2013,316,268,10,18,16>Watch out! Although this place has been sitting on 40th rd for years.. there's a new (to me..) Malaysian place in the game. A place I often pass and ignore to go to the other Malaysian place up the block. You're greeted by a grill up front, cooking up orders of satay and tender skate fish. The accompanying peanut sauce is thick and tasty yet totally unnecessary as the satay meat itself (whether you go with the beef or chicken) is flavored quite well. Order the grilled skate and enjoy dipping the fish liberally into the tongue tingling sambal it comes with. The curry laksa here has the chefs at other places that 'taste good', quivering in their shoes. While it's not as aromatic, the consistency is wonderful and it wins over those I've tried just because it packs good heat. I spent most of the night alternating between sips of the curry broth and the Malaysian iced coffee to cool my tongue down.The char kuey teow with cockles are just right.. with the little morsels tasting fresh rather than "blood" as they do at other places. You can't go wrong with any of the sambal dishes. Although rather mild, the balance of salt, sweet and funk easily remind my Southeast Asian friends of home. Whoever thinks great Malaysian food cannot be found in NYC has not enjoyed some of the dishes offered here. The restaurant is quite small and during most nights, you can expect a small wait for a table - with good reason too. The food is great and has definitely earned a spot into my Malaysian restaurant rotation.
<review# 869,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/22/2013,9/1/2013,325,275,10,14,11>This is not so much a business review, but more about a long term relationship.  Mr Um has been cutting mine and my son's hair since he was little and is now going on 15 years.  Mr Um has had to move his business twice, once to Northern Blvd where he joined up with another shop and now at his current location.  I thought we had lost track of him, but to our surprise last year, we received a text saying he was reopening on 41st Ave.Mr Um is a quiet man that speaks scattered English and we speak very little Korean, but we've had this long lasting customer relationship.  When his shop was on Cherry Ave, he had a business partner, Mr Kim, that was as jovial as Mr Um is stoic.  We lived through Mr Kim's battle with leukemia, joyful at his recovery and sadly at his passing.  My son always wanted Mr Kim to cut his hair.  Mr Um is a model Asian man, likes to woodwork making contraptions to use in the shop and has asked us to translate signs he would put up for his Chinese customers.Mr Um is a classic barber, though using electric clippers, does all his fine work with scissors and finishing off with the straight razor. The best thing about getting a haircut here is to catch up on all the lad mags like Maxim, FHM, Woodworking & Popular Science.  We hope to be customers here for years to come.

<review# 871,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/26/2013,8/30/2013,101,229,9,15,10>The bottom line with this place: excellent portion / price ratio, very good flavor, super fast service, and convenient to my house.  I'm a big fan of Tamashii Ramen.  This new ramen place opened up on Broadway and I've been waiting patiently for weeks walking home from the subway every day and seeing the metal shutters on this place halfway down with people stirring inside getting the place ready for business.  So, when my Dad said he wanted to go to dinner tonight, I suggested we try this place out and we went with my cousin.  It was a good choice.We got the Champon ramen, Syoyu Ramen, Octopus appetizer (Tako), Kara Age (fried chicken with salad), Gyu Don, and some kind of other Don that had this like garlicky pork in it that was really good.  The main ramen dishes are fairly large and the Don dishes are I'd say 60% of the size of the main dishes but about half the cost.In any case, the food was really good and also really affordable.  The Champon had lots of seafood in it (like clams and squid and stuff) and was a bit spicy for my Dad's palate, but most people would consider it mildly spicy.  My Syoyu ramen was good as well.  I'd say that the broth had a miso-y flavor that I'd expect from Syoyu ramen and two slices of pork that were tender and juicy.  The noodles themselves were the best part: firm and bouncy and not overcooked.    My Dad enjoyed the Take appetizer, but it was a bit small.The place itself looks modern with lots of dark wood and hanging vinyl posters that depict all of the different dishes you can order.  It's kind of cool that the menu is on the wall basically (minus the prices, that's what the real menu's for).  One complaint I had is that it was tough for 3 of us to get a table together so they sat us at the bar.  Therefore, I'd say this is more of 1 or 2 person party type of place.  Anyhow, I had an awesome time here and will probably come back a lot since it's reasonably priced and on the walk home from the subway for me.  If you want a quick meal that's cheap, just go with the Gyu Don or another one of the Don dishes.  They have a kimchi one that I want to try that looks good and potentially actually healthy for you to eat.  Otherwise, I plan to try all the ramen dishes on my way home from work.  They also serve sake and beer as well, I think in case that's what you're Jonesing for.The place gets 4 stars and not 5 because there were no dishes that particularly reached out and strangled me with their flavor.  But, I think Tamashii Ramen will fill a much-needed niche  in the neighborhood since I don't know anywhere else in the area that does ramen particularly well in addition to offering several other great choices.

<review# 874,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/17/2013,8/26/2013,70,54,25,22,21>I'm typing this review with fingers still warm and wonderfully greasy from my meal here. It was so good that I couldn't even stop and wash my hands to yelp. I will warn you - do not, DO NOT change your mind about eating here when you see the faded awning or the old-fashioned felt menu with plastic letters and numbers. Do not walk away when you see the grungy tiled flooring or the cheap laminate seating. And do not let the fact that it's bizarrely placed between a quasi-residential area and a sprawling temple lead you away. This place is the real McCoy, and the delicious smells that surround you upon entrance are only the beginning of what promises to be a great meal. There's been much mention about the kindness of the man at the counter and I was delighted to find how true it was. I told him I'm a vegan and admitted that what little I know about South Indian cuisine could fit in the eye of a sewing needle. Completely unfazed, he patiently walked through the short menu with me and explained what was in each one. He also gently directed my greedy eyes away from other things that contained non-vegan ingredients (when you see the menu, you'll understand why it feels okay to be greedy here - the prices are more than decent with most of the items hovering at the $4 mark, and a few offerings that tip the scale toward $7 but no higher). In the end, I settled on a mysore masala dosa and an order of samosas. I was sorely tempted to eat it right then and there, but felt awkward enough about being the lone yellow Asian in a sea of brown people that I finally ponied up the 50 cents to get it wrapped to go. Two quarters are a steep price to have it wrapped as shabbily as it was - in little more than aluminum foil and foam cups and plates - but it was strangely endearing and homespun, the way a friend or neighbor might wrap leftovers for me to take home. Confession - I live about ten minutes away from Dosa Hutt and I fully intended to start eating only when I got home but having those smells wafting around me in the small, enclosed space of my car was driving me wild. So if you caught sight of an Asian girl stuffing her facehole while cruising down Kissena this afternoon, I hope you enjoyed the show as much as I enjoyed eating the samosas. They come two per order, and because I dug in mere minutes after leaving Dosa Hutt, they were still scorchingly hot. Not that that stopped me - I pushed my pain tolerance to new levels as I couldn't help but gobble down bite after bite of pillowy potato and vegetables, swathed with a complex entanglement of spices that I couldn't even begin to identify but HOT DIGGITY DAWG it was good. I dug into the mysore masala dosa when I got home, only to quickly realize the man wasn't kidding when he warned me about its level of spiciness. I foolishly thought my Korean palate would make quick work of any spices this kitchen had to offer, but the dosa had my tongue tingling with mild terror (in a good way, the way of fast roller coasters and scary movies). Like the samosas, each bite spun my taste buds in such a delightful dance, I  couldn't stop eating and instead did as Usher once said - "Gotta' let it burrrrn!" The menu describes dosas as 'crepes', but I would argue that this is much denser with a toothsome heft, owing to the rice and lentils that they use for the dough, and therefore stands up bravely to the task of containing the hot, hearty filling. The mysore masala calls for spicy potato chunks, smattered with sauteed onions, and it's offered with three dipping sauces. I wish I knew more about them to describe them better, but because I don't, I can only identify them as (1) the sweet one, (2) the dark green one, and (3) the light green smoothie-looking one. I diplomatically dipped bites into each cup and found that all three were equally delicious. Even better was finding that they'd included a free small soup of soup which was (of course) also spicy, but delicious and hearty just the same. For eight Georgies, I managed to stuff myself silly and might've even done well enough with just one order. Great food, great find, and will most certainly be back again.

<review# 877,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/13/2013,8/23/2013,142,211,7,12,10>New is old. Old is new. That's particularly the case with Lao Chengdu (whose name translates to Old Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan province). This new Flushing Sichuan restaurant's menu has all the hallmarks of spicy Sichuan cuisine: cold slippery noodles with Sichuan peppercorns, fried vegetables topped with pork bits, boiled bone-in-fish served in cauldron of chili oil, pickled cabbage and other vegetables, dense twice cooked pork, fiery mapo tofu, etc. Lao Chengdu is a restaurant that you'll keep wanting to return to. The menu goes beyond that of standby Spicy and Tasty. It's hard to make generalizations when you haven't tried the whole menu but I found the food to be a bit spicier at Lao Chengdu versus other Sichuan restaurants. Beyond the classics, there were also more rare items like frog legs, offal, rabbit and other delicacy-like items. Super intriguing. I took the simple route and tasted the classics: fried green beans with pork (amazingly balanced with not too much oil), spicy cold noodles (delicious with a rich nutty flavor), beef with celery (served homestyle, a simple dish with balanced flavors) and a few pickled items. All were delicious and worth returning for.

Vera is.  I didn't buy any more deals for the time being, but I definitely see myself going back here and making "My Favorite Beauty Spa" "My Go-To Beauty Spa" because the facial was thorough, revitalizing, and a complete 60 minutes not counting un/dressing and preparations!  I love when the time applies to the full procedure rather than the appointment :)  Plus deep-tissue massages are $35 according to the list of services I swiped (with permission!) on my way out.Go buy yourself the Groupon if it's still available.  Then let's go together - I'll pay for mine in full if someone joins me next time.

<review# 882,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/11/2013,8/18/2013,30,10,10,10,12>Cali Red Lounge is one of the few Flushing Main Street bars which I visit frequently. This Bar/KTV lounge is kept hidden within the confines of the building right next to Busy Mall however once you find the building, you just enter the elevator to the mezzanine level and you're there.Upon entering, a U-shaped counter is in plain sight with couches and tables set-up to accomodate larger groups. Private Karaoke rooms were also available but I myself have never tried out their rig.An abundance of different liquors are displayed on the wall with a few select beer options in the refrigerators. The available cocktails are generally limited to their menu but the owner Jasmine and the bartender Valentina can whip up a custom cocktail, provided the required ingredients are stocked up. Depending on which of the many bartenders makes your cocktail, the drink can range from decent to spectacular. I myself am partial to Jasmine's Irish Cream Coffee on the rocks. The prices are $6 for a beer and $8-$10 for cocktails. Non-alcoholic drinks such as coffee (instant) and tea are also available.The service provided  during my numerous visits has been very accomedating. The bartenders ask you if you want another drink, refill your empty glasses of water or bowls of bar snacks, and even spark up interesting conversation; a perk not found amongst the other bars in Flushing which I have been to.The main lounge area has a selection of various American and Chinese songs where you can easily sing your heart out with a friend. The music is generally loud but not overwhelming, albeit having to raise your voice to have conversation.The incoming crowd is generally young and most of them are down to talk and relax. Based on my own personal experience, you can easily approach someone (assuming there is no language barrier) and just talk about anything or invite them for a game of dice or even beer pong. Because of its hard-to-find location, Cali Red does not get over-packed unless they have special event nights happening.All-in-all, Cali Red is a great place to go to solo or as a group to just unwind from the stress of everyday life. The great service, ambience, and great crowd have made me come back again and again.

<review# 886,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/9/2012,11/3/2012,1515,3352,4,11,7>A wildlife refuge in New York City... YES, it does exist! The serenity of the landscape is invigorating of 9,155 acres of nature's purity.  Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge, a unit of Gateway National Recreation Area and a member of National Park Service, encompassing two freshwater ponds and 325 species of birds have been identified in the park.  With a friend in dire need of an escape from my abject painful life's woes, whom I've been a Queens resident nearly all my existence I have NEVER visited this refuge until now.  Upon check-in at the Visitor's Station all visitors are required to register for a free hiking permit, a waiver to sign to oblige National Park Service's rules:  no bikes in both ponds, no swimming, no fishing, no dogs, no camping, no camp fires, no fire arms to threaten wildlife animals, and no vehicles.  Park Rangers are friendly and attentive with any questions and instructions of the trails.  Parking is free and admission is free.  This Visitor Station render books and lectures for children and avid nature buffs where Ecologists and Park Rangers are spawn.West PondA one and three quarter mile circular loop trail easily to complete under three hours.  Gravel path on open terrain marshy areas of thick, tall grasses and trees with one Observation Blind for surreptitious photography. The trail is indicated with bench markers of numbers where I spotted Canada Geese, a written bird log for any sightings, and many other interesting man-made objects drifted to shore as my party of two wondered off the trail... shh!  Off the trail on the shore we saw an abandon kayak that drifted to Jamaica Bay exposing the inside styrofoam, an abandon boat with the motor filled with seaweed, a car tire, boatloads of sea weed including dried sea weed, many deceased Horseshoe Crabs of all sizes especially giant ones, and pristine sea shells unscathed by man.  The view of Marine Parkway-Gil Hodges Memorial Bridge, and Rockaway Park are visible including parts of Manhattan.East PondAccessible on the other side of Cross Bay Boulevard ONLY by foot thereby, no vehicles, no camping, no animals, no bicycles, no fire arms permitted.  The A train Far Rockaway line is visible crossing and planes landing and taking-off are visible from nearby J.F.K. Airport.  Swans are the main inhabits, lavender growing on coastal marshlands.  Two Observation Blinds are along the gravel and boardwalk path of this Woodland Trail.  As the gravel path goes deeper into the East Pond later then sand path, a section that reminisce of the famous poem "The Road Not Taken" by Robert Frost which philosophically a rhetorical symbolic the choices taken in life and its consequences. I personally love this pond for the size and many birds inhabiting.  A Plover bird is spotted from an Observation Blind in East Pond.  I was also fortunate to spot a huge flock of swans!  Disappointingly we did not see any flora and fauna, nor diamondback terrapin turtles.Note:  Must bring a camera, insect repellent, sunscreen SPF 60+, bottled water, definitely wear long sleeves, long pants, socks, waterproof shoes as the salt marsh areas are murky.  Poison Ivy is very common in a wildlife refuge.
<review# 887,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/4/2012,11/2/2012,364,373,6,11,9>I am  firm believer that every neighborhood should have a park like "Athens Square Park". The park has a playground for kids, a couple of basketball courts, a square where soccer is played and plenty of seating for reading or just relaxing in the sun. This small park is a big part of the culture of Astoria. It is not grand like the majestic "Central Park" in Manhattan or "Carl Schurz Park" on the Upper East Side, but an oasis were you can enjoy a small part of a beautiful summer day.The park is not perfect with manicured gardens, spotless grounds or grand lawns, but it serves this community with a place to relax and enjoy the events of the day. The vast cross section of cultures and ages in Astoria all enjoy this park. This park is a community and the community is part of the park.Now, for some reason a fence just appeared one sunny day around a good portion of this park. I don't know the reasons why, but I hope it is only temporary for needed improvements. Since the fence has been in place, it seem like 60 to 70 percent of the park visitors have vanish.I miss my time chilling here on a sunny day. Please tear down the fence. Athens Square Park is a wonderful local that makes NYC, NYC.Day 4 - "June Challenge: A-B-C!"
<review# 888,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/8/2011,11/1/2012,287,270,3,8,4>Kabob Cafe is a testament to why New York is one of the more incredible cities on this earth. This restaurant is Egypt and America both at once, and the owner/chef/manager ebodies this to a point. Before you even sit down and taste your first morsel of food, you're listening to U2 while perusing the walls for bits and pieces of artwork, including an impressive map of New York, color-coding various neighborhoods by ethnic make-up. "Green is for Irish," Ali tells us, as he welcomes some new customers by telling them what their culinary options are for this evening. "I got that map from a friend of mine who was using it for a documentary." This man is not only an Egyptian chef and restaurant owner, but an Egyptian American promoting cultural awareness and a world where the "other" is a murky concept that needs to be studied, but discarded, to his customers. So we sit down to dinner, already impressed by Ali's personable impact, and are offered an array of choices that Ali spews from the top of his head. We go with the appetizer platter like many other Yelpers, which was reliably delicious, followed by a very tasty artichoke salad, and spiced lamb cheek served with egg, mashed up, and poured onto a plate to be eaten up with pita bread. We wash all of this down with hibiscus tea, which is served cold in a glass with pomegranate and apple, and is perfect as is, even though my alcohol-loving self wishes there were some wine in there, and tries to come up with a way to make sangria out of this later.After all of this feasting, we are still craving some dessert, so we go with the baklava, which is served with an interesting thick honey pomegranate sauce (picture uploaded). All in all, this was such a fantastic experience in every sensory way that I almost want to wait a while before I come back so that I can be impressed all over again. This kind of restaurant is what Yelp was made for.
<review# 889,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/29/2012,10/31/2012,149,276,4,4,4>The cart is right on the corner of 31st Street and 31st Avenue. Sometimes on a warm breezy day, just passing by, you can smell the charcoal smoke in the air. Actually, I think it's what lures the customers in. I been a loyal customer for many many years, because that's how long they been around. On days one doesn't feel like a full meal or needs to eat on the run, this stop makes a good choice. They are not always there but when I pass by and see them, I usually grab at least one. The Souvlaki are tender, just the right size and you can opt to have hot sauce or lemon sauce added. Each stick is topped with a soft and chewy piece of bread (I think Italian bread). The Souvlaki have often come out well. Every time I visit there are usually at least three guys in line or standing around. Sometimes the cart is one guy manned, sometimes two. These guys are old timers man, friendly at times, old timers.
<review# 890,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/20/2012,10/30/2012,286,298,9,16,15>Joju has become one of my favorite places to eat in Elmhurst. Besides being a regular haunt of some of my favorite Queens yelpers, Joju has some seriously addictive banh mi. It's inexpensive, filling, healthy, and delicious. What more could I ask for? Each sandwich is jam packed with fresh cucumbers, pickled carrots and radishes, chili peppers (for those who ask for their sandwich spicy), and fresh cilantro. The baguette isn't too thick or too thin and has just enough crunch. So far I haven't strayed from the #1 classic (Vietnamese ham, headcheese, and pate - SO good), though the #4 bulgogi and #6 pork belly are also hits with my friends. On top of that, Joju's staff is friendly and efficient, the restaurant is kept very clean, and they have free wifi. Seriously, what more could I ask for?*Free fried egg every time you check in on Yelp! **Credit card minimum $10

<review# 893,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/13/2012,10/27/2012,30,56,4,5,4>I am basically a beginner at yoga (attending 10-15 classes in my LIFETIME) and this studio has been the perfect place to start practicing again.  The classes are reasonable priced (1 hour and 15 minute class for $5, and the 7am and 2pm classes are donation based).  Mats rentals and water is $1.  The staff are friendly and the enviornment is very comfortable/nonjudmental.  I often cannot do all the poses, but the instructor always givens alternate poses for those of use who are less skilled like me :)   The only downfall is that you do not get a lot of individualized attention.  I used to practice at a studio on the upper west side where the instructors really went around and corrected your poses. Here they don't do that as much unless you are in a smaller class, but for $5 I think its a great yoga studio, knowledgable staff, and a place well worth trying out.  I do recommend getting there early if your going to a donation priced class or the beginner class on Saturdays because it can get crowded.

<review# 895,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/17/2012,10/25/2012,37,361,5,8,5>Just WOW.  This place was freaking delicious.  Party of 8 on a Friday night.  Place was empty when we came and it scared me a bit, but the food shut me right up.  For appetizers, we split an order of stuffed mushrooms (special of day), grilled calamari, and a large sofia loren pie.  The stuffed mushrooms (4 pieces) were stuffed with scallops and calamari and some other goodies I couldn't distinguish, but it doesn't matter!  I wish they were bigger!  The grilled calamari (5 pieces) comes with an awesome lemon parsley garlic sauce that I kept dipping into.  And of course the famous sofia loren pie...kinda like an awesome "pizza cracker," as my friend called it.  The big chunks of cheese were the best part.  For an entree, I ordered the chicken marsala, which comes with pasta in tomato sauce.  It wasn't overly breaded (+++) and just delicious.  Everyone in my party seemed to really enjoy their dishes as well.  Service wise, big A+.  Waitresses kept checking on us, refilling our water frequently.  For a party of 8 and only 2 chefs, they got our dishes out pretty fast.  Was interesting to see that they tenderized each piece of chicken as the order came up.  Chef even came by to ask us how the food was.  Why can't I have a place like this closer to home???
<review# 896,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/20/2014,8/31/2014,27,64,4,9,8>Salt and Fat is tucked away on a pretty quiet area of Queens Blvd just off the 7 train.  Certainly, it's one of those quiet neighborhood gems that you wouldn't expect to be this far out of LIC or Astoria.  It's unpretentious exterior sets the quiet interior ambience.  It's not a large storefront, and you can easily walk right pass it.  The tapas-style restaurant lives up to its name: lots of salt and fat.  The complimentary bacon popcorn is a perfect example of melt-in-your-mouth flavor topped with salty goodness.  For two people the waitress recommended 4 dishes, and I followed her suggestion by ordering the Scallops, Korean BBQ Wrap, Oxtail Terrine, and Roasted Berkshire Pork Belly.  The scallop was by far the most unique in flavor and my favorite, with its crispy exterior and chewy soft center.  The wrap and pork belly were both solid dishes, and while the oxtail was nicely presented, it felt a little dry.  All of this was washed down with the Homemade Iced Tea, which strangely felt like a better (and perhaps healther) version of McDonald's Sweet Tea.  And just to indulge a bit more we got the Lychee Panna Cotta, which was nothing crazy but a good palate cleanser.  Our waitress was extremely nice and attentive, the atmosphere was relaxed, and Queens scored another win. Worth the hype.

<review# 898,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/29/2014,8/29/2014,86,230,4,13,6>My entire family fell in love with Little Meadows when we did our school tour last year.  There was plenty of interaction between teacher and each student.  As you know, this is huge for little ones but even more important to a child who may need speech therapy.  My children needed prompting to talk and we saw many other schools that barely engaged at all with the students!  Little Meadows is very hands on.  They have several therapists on location (OT, PT, ST, and even a psychologist).  They  have weekly workshops that you can attend.  All of the therapists I've encountered here do great work and always give me time if I need to chat about my boys' therapeutic progress.  (By the way, CPSE doesn't cover feeding therapy.  My children needed it badly and the speech therapist was kind enough to accommodate us.  Going above & beyond their call was something I wasn't expecting but I appreciated it immensely!!)They offer half day & full day classes.  They offer integrated classes that are split between community children and children with mild special needs.  I'm not positive, but I believe they also offer classes for children with more severe special needs.  Their playground is large, safe, and private for their own use.  They have a gym to play in for rainy/snowy days.  Knowing that the school is located in a safe neighborhood is also good to know because the children WILL go on neighborhood walks throughout the year.  Parent involvement is often encouraged. Hands down, the best pre-k school I have visited in Queens.

No other restaurant seems to have the breadth of choices that this one has. Even seemingly "regular" or "normal" dishes are made better. A good example would be the Three Cups Chicken. There are many restaurants serving the same thing in Flushing, but this one, in my opinion, serves the best. The same applies for the bitter melon with salty egg!Service: the tiny restaurant has a relatively large staff. People went out of their way to serve me. <review# 902,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/23/2014,8/25/2014,59,59,5,12,6>I was excited when I heard that a Blink was opening up in Astoria. So I signed up for this Blink location in December and got a month for free, though it's more like 2 weeks since I signed up towards the end of December. Nevertheless, this gym is what I need when Mother Nature decides to create havoc.I am a runner, so the treadmills and cardio machines are my main domain. There are plenty of those on the first floor and the second floor. Let's start on the main floor. The ones on the main floor have personal TVs connected to each one. You have to attach your headphones to the headphone jack to listen to the TVs. (I don't care for that, but for people who need a distraction, it's a nice touch.) To the front of the cardio machines, ab machines occupy that little area. Past the front desk towards the locker rooms is the stretching area. There is a dumbbell rack, resistance bands, medicine balls, foam rollers, bosu balls, etc., which is flanked by full length windows. I have a problem with the windows because people walking outside always peek in - I mean like creepy men who sometimes make eye contact with you mid-stretch or squat or whatever you may be doing. Also, in the 5 months I've been a member there, the windows to the left side has been repaired about 3 times. Besides that, the locker rooms are pretty clean because there's always someone cleaning it. There are four showers and three bathrooms. And there are plenty of lockers and a few benches in front of them.On the second floor, there are tons of treadmills, without the personal TVs, recumbent bikes, elliptical machines, and stair masters. There are also 2 rowing machines by the stairs. The strength and weight machines are also on this floor. (You can hear the guys dropping the barbells by the loud "booming" sounds you hear in the stretching area on the first floor. It's annoying.) There are full length mirrors on both sides of the main room. According to my boyfriend, the strength machines don't really give him as much resistance as he would like.Around the gym, there are sanitary wipes stations so that you can wipe the machine off after you're done. They also sell towels and locks at the front desk. Two refrigerators are situated at the front doors so if you forgot gatorade or water, you can pick some up pre- or post-workout. The guys and girls who work there are really nice and accommodating. The trainers are nice and the cleaning people mind their own business and do their job. Are there some things that I would change or add to this gym? Of course. I think the front windows by the stretching area should be completely fogged so that no one feels "watched" when they're focusing on their workout. Mats would be useful for stretching and lying on the floor in the stretching area, as well. A few times, the gym ran out of sanitary wipes. I don't want anyone to touch my sweat that's splattered all over a treadmill after a hard workout, so I think the wipes should always be stocked. I don't really like the young crowd that shows up here because they are more for showing off their "cute outfits" and socialize than to workout. That's what the mall is for, kids. But for $20/month membership where I can visit any Blink in the city (except the NoHo location), how can I really complain this much?

It was a lot of food for 1 person so be sure to share it!The pita was my favorite part of the dish. Just dip the pita into that delicious white greek yogurt sauce and it's heavenly! If you plan on sitting at one of the tables, the friendly owner will not mind letting you sit down to wait for the food and hand you the plate of food when it's ready! Come give this place a try and I highly recommend that you eat the food there instead of taking it home! This way, you are able to taste the food right there and then!
<review# 904,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/23/2014,8/23/2014,47,10,24,26,24>I've taken advantage of Yelp for so long, with the great reviews written by connoisseurs of the delicious food around the NYC area I'd like to go back and contribute again. I'm not the carnivore I once was and I find myself leaning towards eating more veggies for whatever reason but when I do go out and I'm in the mood to have a hearty, delicious, and well prepared steak I make reservations with S-Prime.I've might have lucked out with the handful of times I've been to S-Prime but I've yet to ever see the place packed.  Regardless, I still make reservations and I always ask to have something ready for me when I arrive; like a specific bottle of wine or an appetizer I'd like prepared upon arrival and the staff never fails to accommodate.  I really enjoy the décor and the spacing between tables is perfect.The staff is always so courteous, from the gentlemen tending our vehicles for valet to the staff refreshing our glasses of water.  I love hearing their specials of the evening because of how enthusiastic they sound when informing us of what's available.  The drinks are nice and stiff without overdoing it and, if I'm not mistaken, the servings are more than adequate. I'm a fiend for the Agave Braised Pork Belly! (Oink-oink!) And truth be told I really don't think I've ordered any other appetizer but I'll try the next time.  I find it fun how S-Prime separates their sides as "Bad" and "Good", which plays to the mood I'm in for the evening.  The Roast chicken as never been over cooked and just held it's moister within the skin perfectly.  But I've only tasted it once because I always go for the 28oz Cajun Rib Eye! I love the seasoning, I love the size, I love the taste... I love it! Admittedly, I have never gone to prime without first taking advantage of the Groupon specials I have purchased; so I haven't felt the blunt cost of the menu and I don't believe S-Prime to be over priced.  As a matter of fact I think they bring a taste of the city to Queens and I can appreciate that.

<review# 906,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/8/2012,12/3/2012,171,248,6,22,5>First, I just want to say how impressed I am with the NYC park system. The membership for the rec centers and pools is only $75 per 6 months. If you swim frequently, this is a DEAL. There is also a gym across the street from the Corona Park Pool, equipped with weight room, cardio equipment,  courts and indoor track. There is also an ice rink in the same building as the pool, but is an extra cost.The pool itself is an Olympic sized pool usually split into 3 sections,  one for private use, one for lap swim, and one open swim. Lap swim can get crowded, but they limit how many people can be in the pool at the same time, so sharing with 4 other people in a lane is not uncommon. Off times seem to be between 11 - 2 PM. Check the schedule before you go to make sure there isn't pool cleaning or a swim event going on. The locker rooms can get a little dirty, but not enough to be super gross. You MUST BRING A CAP AND LOCK or they will not let you in. There are a good amount of showers, lockers, sinks, and toilets. I would bring flip flops if the floors will gross you out. It does for me, but I just barefoot it most of the time.I wish the older folks and the slower swimmers would swim in appropriate lanes. Sometimes the "fast " lane can go quite slow....

<review# 909,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/30/2012,11/30/2012,183,187,9,22,13>After 3 years and maybe 20 haircuts here, it's time for a [long overdue] review. Boy whipped up a wicked style job for my friend's Halloween makeup. And Nicole seems to have a knack with men styles. As other reviews have mentioned, their shampoo job is the best in town. So prep yourself for a good wash & massage. Don't come if you're in a rush, and don't try to skip out on it by washing at home first, that's my best advice to you. Some stylist do go for seasonal continued-education. I thought that's pretty cool. Always learning and updating/upgrading themselves.
<review# 910,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,11/19/2012,11/29/2012,262,613,12,11,10>It's a forest, it's a park, it's Forest Park!Names do sometimes state the obvious and this is one such case. The third largest park in Queens is an ideal spot for tree huggers,dog walkers, hikers and horseback riders.If you are familiar with the other works of the man, the legend, the one and only Frederick Law Olmsted, you'll wonder if his association with the park is mentioned just so Queens can say "Hey, he did something here too!". Unlike Central Park and Prospect Park, Olmsted's touch is felt mainly in one spot, Forest Park Drive. This park is very different than the ones I've just mentioned mainly due to the fact that the hand of alteration is very light, if non-existent. There are trails and for much of the park, that's the only human imprint.Fortunately, the sensation of total isolation is interrupted by nearby traffic on the Jackie Robinson that reminds you that you're in a metropolis of 8 million people. It can also serve as a useful landmark on how to escape the park when night falls.During my more ambitious, healthier days of yore, I ran through this park and found the experience conflicting. For most of the run I was the only person in the environs so a tremendous feeling of freedom coursed through my veins until I stepped in various deposits of horse manure, nearly tripped on wet leaves and left the park a much dirtier man than I entered. Running through the forest trails, in retrospect, was probably not the best of ideas I've had.As a walker of those trails you'll be in for a treat and a lesson in adult archaeology. I've spotted an overabundance of ancient prophylactics in various states: used, unopened, torn and faded from their former glory. Folks, exercise common sense and caution if wandering these grounds at night as I suspect in the deepest center of Forest Park, no one can hear you scream.I've seen photo shoots of models in varying states of undress, prayer cards nailed to trees and mostly people just trying to enjoy this vast natural resource in the heart of Queens.

<review# 912,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/19/2011,11/27/2012,548,384,6,16,10>Since I first uncovered what was really cooking inside Wasabi Point, I racked my brains trying to understand their choice of name; was it an elaborate ruse, or a wayward (or demented) marketing faux pas by the restaurateur equivalent of Terry Gillian? It was none of that; my digressions were beside the point. The word "Wasabi" had not been joined with a proper localization word like "Place", "Joint" or "Abode", but with an ambiguous word that can also be used to ascribe a myriad of meanings. Indeed, the Wasabi-like menu constituents inside of non-Japanese origin WERE the point. Wasabi Point, then, was a cunningly crafted metaphor meant for you to try one of the rarest, choicest, ethnic meals you will ever experience: Bhutanese food. Before I unriddled this Pan-Asian prankster, I had bypassed, ignored, and sauntered by in contempt at their seemingly uninspired admixture of name, food and decor, in the otherwise rich and exuberant ethnic food fauna to be found in the environs. The clear open windows and gigantic green lit logo "Wasabi Point" seemed more proper for a Chinese takeout place than for a respectable Japanese establishment. In my mind of minds, I (and not just me) regarded Wasabi Point as a predictable ringer. But one memorable day, undecided and hungry, we were in one of those I-want-Ramen moods that care not for authenticity, because even ringers can't screw up Ramen. Much.So imagine our surprise when the totality of the menu was carefully dedicated to Tibetan and Bhutanese food; the Japanese options allotted to a tiny section in the back, meant for unrepentant forbearance. We did just that.Having had Tibetan before many times, I decided to go with the unknown; Bhutanese cuisine; a string of soups all of which ended with the word "datse". I went with Sha-Datse which was described as a cheese soup with meat, chilies and potatoes. This was to become one of the best soups that I've ever had in my young life. I now fondly refer to it as "The Devil's Casserole"The cheese is melted in just the perfect way; not too thick, not to thin, laden with the floating potatoes, the meat, and the green chilies in the flesh and in spirit, as much of the flavor was embedded in the soup; a liquefied cheese concoction of such spicy might that it must provide a much needed succor to the Bhutanese inhabitants in the freezing alpine Himalayan parts of the country.After that first taste and tears (it'll make you cry of spice, I promise) two years ago, I've become an unremitting customer, and I've since come to know the Chef, the staff and the menu; their Tibetan menu being one of the bests in town, and I suggest you order a portion of Ting-momo to take with your Datse; to dip the fresh steamed bun on the cheese soup, then adding the red chili sauce available on the side, for a delightfully infernal palate experience. I've since tried Sha-Datse in another unnamed Tibetan establishment in Jackson Heights and it doesn't hold a candle to the one to be found at Wasabi Point. If you live in New York and enjoy trying new food experiences, you owe it to yourself to try  Bhutanese food at least once in your life.As far as metaphors go, I once asked the good people at Wasabi what on Earth were they thinking when they decided to name it as they did; surely they hadn't intended to lure Japanese food aficionados into a Tibetan/Bhutanese surprise? Sadly, it was the fact that people are more commonly prone to go with what they know (instead of what they don't) what led them to bank on one of the most ubiquitous of Asian cuisines in the West. They were, though, thinking about changing the name, thanks in no small part to the large contingent of fans that cherish their excellent Tibetan/Bhutanese fare.Until then,  I refuse to believe that we live among throngs of unadventurous simpletons that would rather stay within their conditioned ramparts instead of reaching out to the glorious diversity that titillates in this wonderful world of ours.I choose to see Wasabi Point as an ingenious metaphor;  meant to pique the interest of Wasabi aficionados only to lure them into far greater levels of spicy bliss. An assessment which I've come to make due to my own undeniably dantesque experiences with the spicy datses. So I leave you with the old and wise literary adage, relearned and reworked for food joints everywhere: "Don't judge a food spot by it's cover"
<review# 913,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/12/2012,11/26/2012,200,154,3,6,9>Since I've never stepped into Seva, this review is solely based on their delivery special. I've ordered it several times, and have never been disappointed. You get an appetizer, entree with basmati rice, and either dessert or mango lassi, all for just $13.50. Two people could very easily share this and be satisfied. Now, I *love* spicy food, but one word of caution: their vindaloo is really, really spicy. By the time I was done eating my food, my nose was running. My poor boyfriend's brow was sweaty, and he could barely eat the stuff.And despite the option of ordering it mild, medium, or spicy, it always comes spicy.Don't get me wrong, it was delicious, but those who can't handle the heat should beware.Delivery generally takes a full 45-60 minutes, but it's always worth the wait. Cheap, filling, consistently delicious... I feel fortunate to have Seva in my neighborhood.

The average price of an order is $5, with the most expensive item topping off the menu at $7. FYI, the delivery minimum is $10.

<review# 918,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/10/2012,9/30/2012,804,1656,11,16,14>Initially, I was mortified when my friends suggested we eat here.
