On the morning before our lunch gathering, I checked out their menu and boy was I relieved. This place not only has vegetarian options, but also a good assortment for the vegan-inclined!On a Saturday afternoon, there were plenty of available seats. The place is pretty dark inside and nothing really to be said about the decor. There is a picture of the Dalai Lama in the back and a TV showing a video loop of the Himalayas. On the weekends, they have a lunch buffet for only $10. What a steal! The dishes are a mixture of Nepali, Tibetan, Indian and Bhutanese food. There is white rice, tingmo and bhaley bread. The tingmo bread reminds of a Chinese flower roll called "hua juan" and the steamed bun without any filling called "man tou."For the available entrees, they had paneer butter masala (cheese dish), dal (lentils with ghee on top), aloo tama bodi (bamboo shoots, black-eyes peas and potatoes, aloo dum (potatoes with cilantro), 2 meat entrees (I didn't even bother to look) and also kheer (rice pudding). For $10, it was a great deal and we all ate happily and were quite full. Service was a bit slow, but they were able to split our bill 4 ways (we are such a pain). I'll definitely come back with my family to try out this place. They are quite curious about Himalayan food!

<review# 921,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/19/2012,9/27/2012,16,43,13,5,6>Chris H., my main slam piece, already reviewed this but I must add in my two cents.The night of July 3rd, I was craving an El Rey de Oro torta al pastor so we headed through the mini-park to my absolute favorite taco truck. We were happily chatting away, waiting for our turn to order, when I dramatically held up my hand in pause. "Look at the truck," I said, my voice filled with confused fear. Chris took in the altered menu, the lack of weather-protecting overhang, the strangers manning the truck and realized that this was an impostor truck! Where was El Rey de Oro??We momentarily debated about whether or not this was a result of taco-truck wars or a truck coup but decided that our favorite truck had probably just taken a holiday for the Fourth. Assuming that you couldn't go wrong with an al pastor torta, I opted to order from this sub-truck.My callous assumption was wrong and that torta only helped to highlight how truly lucky I am to have El Rey in my hood almost every night. Their ingredients are always very fresh, their meat seasoned to perfection and the people who operate it are incredibly friendly. I even tried the beef tongue (lengua) taco last night and loved it. But, after eating the non-El Rey torta, I felt not the satisfying fullness that I normally experience...only the kind of deep disappointment that accompanies settling for less. That night, I contemplated what my life would be like if this new truck had permanently knocked El Rey out and I did not like the future. When I saw the familiar lights of El Rey on July 5th, I rejoiced and vowed to never order from another truck in that spot again. It was just like those scenes in romantic comedies when the guy loses the girl, realizes that he could never live without her and makes a grand romantic gesture to seal their future together forever. Except, instead of a ring, I just bought another taco.

<review# 924,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/5/2012,9/24/2012,60,352,4,6,4>The apply dubbed "Queens Comfort" is just that. Comfortable. The menu is pretty much comfort food. Heavy. Cream. Built purely for taste. But it might just make you shake her by the shoulders little bit. "Mommy. Why did you wrong me all those years!?" The sandwich was an explosion of flavor. It was the highlight of the plate. The spicy fries that accompanied it were phenomenal. Yes, the pulled pork sandwich actually went beyond phenomenal. Unfortunately for this place, I've spend most of my adolescence south of the Mason- Dixon. But for all you Yankees, this is as close as you're going to come to down home heaven.

<review# 927,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/8/2013,7/14/2013,46,286,3,8,6>Court Square Diner is always a solid choice and has earned its iconic status of being an LIC staple. You can even drive past it when you play Grand Theft Auto 4.I've had a good time every time I've gone, and it's never empty despite being a 24 hour place. The room looks good and always seems to be sparkling clean. Love its proximity to the Court Square 7, E, M, G trains. I live by Queensboro Plaza, so I could walk there if I wanted to, but most of the time it's a cinch to just take the 7 train one stop. The service is generally pretty good. Though the menu isn't the most extensive of all diner menus I've seen, it still has plenty of options, with some fantastic burgers and desserts. My girlfriend is a fan of the curly fries. There's really no better place to sit down and have a meal after checking out 5 Pointz and PS1. It's good after a night of partying, or a late lunch the next day. It's close enough to pubs on Jackson Ave. (Dutch Kills, The Shannon Pot, Brooks 1890) to where it would be a nice place to get a snack or dessert at the end of a bar date where you hit it off and hung out long enough to need more sustenance than a beer or mixed drink can provide. It's quiet and calm enough of a place where you could comfortably order a cup of coffee and have a nice booth to sit and read.In short, Court Square Diner is versatile enough to be basically whatever you need it to be.
<review# 928,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/25/2013,7/13/2013,118,243,5,7,6>Who's not curious about a Malaysian restaurant with over 200 reviews with 4.5 stars in NYC?! I had my share of Malaysian restaurants which none stood out. My boyfriend and I were craving for Malaysian so we were on our way to Sentosa (just because of its convenience in location ). Last minute, we decided to be a little more adventurous and headed to Taste Good. It was a little hard to find it but once we entered the restaurant, it definitely reminded us of a regular Chinese restaurant. It's a small restaurant but a very busy one with both Asian and non Asian customers waiting near the front door. One thing that stood out was the wall of food pictures taped everywhere and it was BYOB.There were so many dishes we wanted to try but we ended up ordering the following: Roti Canai - not so crispy and unambiguous shaped as the other restaurants. I actually prefer the pancake cooked this way because you can't really soak the paper thin pancake into the curry without it dissolving. Basic curry sauce. I agree that the portion is relatively small but again, I feel that I'm used to the gigantic paper thin pancakes served elsewhere. Singapore Kari Laksa - Their signature dish - spicy coconut curry noodle soup. I'm not sure how the noodles are supposed to be cooked but the pearl/rice noodles had no texture. The broth was amazing; creamy and spicy! I also loved the fried tofu soaked with the broth. I would order this again with egg noodles next time. Hokkien Udang Mee - What I call "prawn mee". Very good. Not as fishy but also not as bland compared to other restaurants.Hainanese Chicken - first time eating the chicken somewhat hot. We really enjoyed it especially with the chicken flavored rice (must do). Although I wish they told us they would be charging us extra (+$1.75) for ordering dark meat... Overall, it was worth the trip. Definitely so much better than the other Malaysian restaurant (Penang) which is basically around the corner from Taste Good.

<review# 934,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/3/2013,7/7/2013,343,884,5,14,7>For now I'll just say that this location far exceeded my expectations in all aspects.  I used to go to Blink NoHo, but was anxiously awaiting the grand opening of this Queens location.  I'll be honest -- based on my experience at Bally's in Kew Gardens, and Planet Fitness in Richmond Hill...I was definitely less than confident that Blink Queens would be comparable to Blink NoHo.Perhaps it's just early in the game and not many people have joined, because each time that I've been to Blink, it's been relatively quiet, with only a few people scattered about.  And that's not to say that this location couldn't handle the masses...because it can.  If you've been to Blink NoHo, this location is easily at least twice its size.  There are literally multitudes of machines -- all of the same machines that you'd see at NoHo, except more.  PLUS a handful of stairmaster machines, if you're into that sorta thing.  Personally, I find myself wanting to die after just three minutes...but that says more about me than the machine.The staff is also comparable to the NoHo location as far as competence is concerned.  Always upbeat, friendly, and eager to assist.  You will NOT find staff like this at any other gym in the area.And the locker rooms, oh the locker rooms! <review# 936,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/9/2011,3/9/2012,23,266,5,7,9>Every time I come to Flushing, I am always looking for a new food adventure. Flushing is becoming one of my favorite places to visit. It's like a Chinatown but with a sense of newness. No matter the weather it's always appropriate to have a bubble tea. This place sells a few teas. I specifically recall the "Two Ladies" and "Three Guys." I ordered the regular bubble tea---the milk tea with tapioca pearls---but come to think of it, if I noticed the "Three Guys" before I placed my order, I might have ordered that ;-) Why? Well, take a guess? Because it's a nice combination. It is a milk tea with tapioca pearls, pudding and grass jelly---and intense combination I've never heard of before. ^_^It was a rainy day when I came here and while wanting to dodge the rain for a bit, I decided why not buy a bubble tea. I had a long day and definitely needed a soft drink. This place, unlike Ten Ren took a bit longer to make their teas. There was only two people in front of me but it took them a bit longer to make my tea and I only ordered the regular milk tea.Some would argue that all bubble tea places are made equal. Being a bubble tea fan myself, I would not. Some places make their bubbles teas with too much milk, sugar, or too watery. This place was suitable to my tastes. Not to sweet. It was just right and it was nice. ^_^I have never heard of this chain before but they seem to come up with good and interesting bubble teas. I will give the others a try next time I come to Flushing. One of the things I like about this bubble tea place aside from the bubble tea I bought is that they seal the top of their cups and you just poke a straw in to drink it. I find that prevents spillage and I always prefer bubble tea places that seal their cups instead of just placing a lid. I also notice the bubble teas in Flushing taste very different from the ones they make in Chinatown and Brooklyn. I never knew bubble tea can taste different based on their geographical locations. One of the major factors I judge whether or not bubble tea is good is based on how well they make their tapioca. If its soft and chewy, it's good. If it's hard or dry, it's not. I wonder what other bubble tea places around here I should try.

<review# 938,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/25/2011,3/6/2012,406,1092,4,9,6>You don't see too often Northeast Chinese food (dongbei cai). Fu Run is one of the few places serving this sort of cuisine, which is known for lamb ribs, cilantro salads, braised pork belly, carrot and lamb dumplings, and crispy lamb. Common spices range from cumin to red chillies used in a lot of dishes.Tofu & Seafood in Casserole - $10.95 - along with a medley of small baby scallops, artificial crab meat, shrimp and soft tofu in a chicken-like broth. Casseroles are usually thicker in consistency, but this was more of the soupy variety.The ambiance is simple, 10-15 tables sprawled out across the floor with glass ceiling to floor windows on one side of the restaurant. There is a small room for private parties or that can also be utilized for a large group. It's a step up from your typical Chinese restaurant with pink tablecloth. It's what I would consider, more with the modern times. Regardless, Fu Run is all about the food, not the decor.Leek & Pork Dumpling (12) - $5.95 - Your ordinary run of the mill dumplings. Nothing was very fascinating about these, nor was anything very disappointing. I would pass on this and save the dumpling cravings for Nan Xian Xiao Long Bao or Joe's Shanghai.Liang Pi (Country Style Green Been Sheet Jelly) - $8.95 - This was one of the dishes that everyone had on their table. A cold dish consisting of wide flat noodles (at first glance, it looked like jellyfish) complimented with cucumber, julienned cucumbers, carrots, chopped cloud ear mushroom, egg, and some bits of pork, with sesame oil and a wasabi (mustard) oil. It's simple, yet very refreshing and earthy all at the same time. There is little to minimal heat from what you might expect from wasabi/mustard.Zi Ran Yang Pai (Muslim Lamb Chop) - $21.95 - marinated and braised lamb chops complimented with a crispy skin, topped with black/white sesame seeds and cumin . It's very fatty inside, and the meat falls right off the bone. The seasoning on the outside can be a bit overpowering and very unusual, almost like an Indian spice, so don't expect your typical Chinese dish here. It's a distinguished taste that may not suit everyone's palates, but it's good nonetheless if you are accustomed to such spices.Lao Hu Cai (Tiger Vegetable Salad) - $5.95 - My favorite of the dishes and a very common dish found on almost every patrons table. This consists primarily of cilantro along with tiny salty white dried-like shrimps, scallion, and a sesame oil or rice wine vinegar. It's delicious and a must have.Fu Run is definitely unique from what you would normally expect from Chinese food, but the food is very refreshing and quite delicious. I would say most of the dishes are an acquired taste for some, but if you have an open mind and diverse palate (cilantro, cumin, etc.), I would definitely recommend checking this place out. Prices are fairly cheap, portions are decent, and service is quick.
<review# 939,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/28/2011,3/5/2012,108,1039,6,7,9>You know when you tell someone where you're from and they inevitably try to find some common ground? So they end up asking you if you know of this little "secret" place that's one of the few places they know. When you tell people you live in Astoria, Artopolis is one of those places.Unlike most of those other "secret" little gems that people who have very little knowledge of your neighborhood tend to always insist you visit, Artopolis actually holds its own.Tucked into a back corner of what can only be described as a New York style strip mall, this little bakery / cafe may not look overly inviting from the curb.Don't let that deter you though, once you get inside you'll find some friendly and inviting staff members that will guide you through their assortment of goodies. Whether you're just there to catch up with friends at their little cafe tables or you're picking up some goodies for home, the staff generally know what to recommend.There's usually a consistent stream of customers and as such if you happen to go in when everyone is occupied you might be standing around awkwardly for a bit until they free up before you can figure out what certain pastries are and to get them properly boxed up.The various flavors of baklava are always a hit and pretty much every other offering here.Pricing is generally by the weight instead of piece which is a nice change and as a result I would say the value is great here.

But to have the ability to get beer brewed right in your backyard is amazing. I went to them on a Saturday night and was able to tats almost everything on tap. Every brew tasted was excellent and unique in it's own way. Rarely do I go to a brewery and find my palette embrace every individual sample tasted. Finback hit the spot. I had a hard time picking which brews would fill my 2 growlers. I settled on the Moby and the porter which were top quality. I recommend that anyone with any interest in great tasting beer to come here. Staff was really friendly and answered all my questions. There was also parking in front and plenty of space to sit and enjoy that great beer. I give 2 thumbs up to Finback and promise I will be back to try all or Atleast as many of their future releases as I can.
<review# 947,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/24/2014,10/30/2014,241,315,14,13,14>Sentosa has always been a popular place for the young n old. I remember back in my handsome(r) teenager days, Sentosa was *the* meeting spot for me and my friends. Friend broke up? Sentosa. Friend got into Harvard? (fk u) Sentosa. Friend wanted to bring new bf/gf to be judged and assimilated into our friend circle? Sentosa.I have been through thick and thin with Sentosa so my review might be a bit partial. But thats most Yelp reviews, right?Sentosa is a very clean restaurant with an English friendly staff.  Despite its popularity, it usually requires no wait to be seated, thanks to its two floors. Its good for intimate dates as well as large parties. The menu swings towards the Chinese side of Malaysian cuisine with a lot of rice and noodle based dishes. Naturally, you can still find your nasi lemak and roti canai here. Some popular dishes include:Roti canai - a thin crispy pancake that softens up when you dip it into the potato curry sauce. Filling, oily, and just awesome. You can feed it an extra $1.50 and evolve it into a Roti Telur, which is infused with a thin layer of egg. I love eggs (get me some of dat brotein nam'sayin?) but I would recommend the clean and unadulterated canai. Hainanese Chicken - The epitome of Chinese cultural domination. HC is a very flavorful and oily white chicken dish. You can get this as a rice dish or get a bigger portioned family style. If you're new to Malaysian cuisine, its worth trying at least once. Otherwise, nothing special about Sentosa's rendition.Nasi Lemak - This is like the dry version of Korean's bibimbap with Malaysian style seasonings. The coconut rice is served with a small side of anchovies, white chicken (like HC), egg, and exotic tasting spices(?) and cucumbers. Like HC, if you're new to the cuisine you should try at least once. Personally I've never grown accustomed to the sides that come with Nasi Lemak. Pineapple fried rice - You didn't think an Asian would recommend fulied lice but I love this dish. Its served on a half pineapple thats big enough for 2-3 people. It has a mild-medium (depending on your tolerance) spice with a heavy taste of ... what do you know? pineapple! Oil rice - It comes with some dishes but is offered as a side for abukfiddy ($1.50). Its rice thats drowned in (not too much) oil. Your guilty pleasure. Sentosa is a comfort pick. It has a pretty diverse menu with something for everybody. Yes yes you can have beef with broccoli. The price is fair and the atmosphere is good. So come! And bring your friend(s). If you see a gang of no-longer-threatening-looking-almost-30-yrs-old Asian kids, come say hi.

<review# 950,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/19/2014,10/27/2014,139,121,14,11,9>Tourists go to Joe's Shanghai.  People who actually want good siewlongbao (pork soup dumplings) go to Nan Xiang.  Flanked by 66, Bangkok and a cantonese restaurant whose name I can never remember, Nan Xiang is one of Flushing's brightest spots for a great meal.As many a Yelpologist has mentioned, the wait can get long during peak hours.  My friend and I went after the prime dinner rush, so we were given a number and seated in about five minutes.  Always crowded and always bustling, we gave our order immediately and waited for our soupy goodness.  We had the pork soup dumplings and the noodles with beef in spicy chili oil (first for me), and we weren't disappointed.  The dumplings are consistently delicious, and the noodles were deliciously greasy and thick.On several other occasions, I've had the cold cucumber dish and the duck tongue (DUCK TONGUE!), and those are great for contrasting the steamy fatty dumplings.  I generally go for an order of the pork dumplings and an order of the crab ones, and you really can't go wrong with either.Is it authentic Shanghainese? Beats the heck out of me.  I'm a whitewashed Korean. Is it delicious? Ohyoubetcha. Is it better than Joe's Shanghai? Ohyoubetcha...er? If you go to Nan Xiang based on my review, and are disappointed, kindly let me know, and I will apologize, and give you the opportunity to buy me dinner somewhere else.
<review# 951,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/20/2014,10/26/2014,2398,639,10,13,10>The new Arunee Thai location is very pretty.  Wooden mocha colored tables complement unfinished wood paneled and brick walls which also host asiatic murals.  Track lighting is true to the old locationvs intimacy but the light of day coming from the front door is refreshingly different.  Thai iced tea is served in mason jars with a straw and lunch specials go for under ten dollars and include lunch boxes.  The sit down bar allows for ample seating.  On a monday afternoon, there were approximately 35 customers being served.  The restaurant looks pretty and clean.  A call to the restaurant was picked up on the second ring.  Some new reviews complain that wait times have grown due to the new business at the new location's rise in diners but such is to be expected by such an extreme transformation in one of Jackson Heights' only Thai restaurants.The tom yum soup had mushroons and scallions and was small but not too spicy.  While that might disappoint some, it was not bad at all.  Peanut sauce covered the salad.  Plate presentation on appetizers reflected the price points.  I had no complaints but it is an area that could be improved given the beauty of the restaurant and even the water pitchers. The bar is a full liquor bar. Food is consistent with the old location, which was very good.I hope this location does well.

<review# 956,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/20/2011,5/11/2012,183,187,8,11,10>Hello, Mala Xiang Guo!  Yup, that's the new dish in town (town aka New World Food Court), and every table's got one!  Lemme intro you to the newbie:$6 for basket of veggies of your choice - the defaults include cabbage, black fungus, mushrooms, tofu, lotus root, taro, etc etc.  Fill the small basket with whatever veggies you want, and shuffle down to the "meats"$8 per lb for meat/seafood of your choice (except lobster, that's $13 each) - the defaults include beef (MUST GET), chicken, lamb, tripe, pig blood, fish, crab, shrimp, spam, etc etc.  Watch out for how much they're putting in and try to estimate your party's needs.NOW, tell them how spicy you want this hot mess and they bring it to the back to stir fry it up real quick.  The line is long, but it moves quite quickly.  Pay at the register and pick up 1 white rice per order (extra rice is $1, but you can try to confuse them by going back with the receipt later and say you didn't get your rice.  Chinese...).  It's best you go find yourselves (cannot be eaten by just 1 person, bring food buddies) a table, and return a few mins later for pick up (and tell them you want rice (again)).  May I suggest you get a can of Wang Lao Ji (Mando), or Wong Loh Gut (Canto) to go with your madd pot.  There are all kinds of interesting spices inside that can make your tongue numb and brain trippy.  It's also healthy to wash all the heat down with a nice can of Chinese cooling tea so your throat don't get all messed up, and pimply-faced.*They use recyclable eco-friendly bowls made of compressed leaves.  Don't throw them out!

These things are these half moon shaped fried dough things that are very similar to empanadas. Tastes slightly bitter but still satisfying.There are many other unfamiliar menu items I definitely will try in the future. This is simply a great place to check out for those with an adventurous appetite!

It's always a full body workout with upper body and lower body alternating throughout the 1 hour session.The music also varies throughout each session which I appreciated. It ranged from a kind of dance music to reggaeton to reggae to hip hop and it wasn't loud but it was motivating.Just from the 3 weeks I can see a difference in how much stronger my upper body is and my general ability to make it through a grueling class. I'm a big fan of meat, but the entrees taste similar to the real thing and I'm pleasantly surprised. The zucchini roll (with "sausages") was one of the highlights among the dinner. And as for the dessert, if you have a sweet tooth, definitely try the passion fruit and the berry dessert.
<review# 970,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/30/2013,1/29/2014,225,493,7,9,10>Visiting on Black Friday it was nearly empty, some people at the bar and a couple of other tables were eating dinner.We started off with the chili cheese fries, which were exceptional.  Even under the cheese sauce and chili the fries were super crispy and delicious on their own.  The cheese sauce was just thick enough and the chili was stupendous. It had a hint of spice and was so flavorful.  I can see myself eating a big bowl of the chili and being very happy.As for the entrees, the brisket flavor was good, but it was a bit on the tough side.  It wasn't the melt in your mouth type of brisket I love.  Speaking of melt in your mouth that's where the ribs come in. The rib combo comes with both the sticky and dry rub varieties.  The sticky was my favorite, no the dry rub was, no the sticky...I just couldn't decide.  The sticky version are baby back ribs and glazed in a delicious, slightly sweet BBQ sauce.  These were fall off the bone tender with a nice smokey flavor.  The dry rub version were St. Louis ribs; the rub was packed with flavor and the true pork flavor shined though.  Again the meat fell off the bones.  Entrees are served with baked beans and coleslaw.  The beans are a bit sweet. The coleslaw was quite good; nice and crisp.  I substituted the beans for collar greens on the combo plate.  These were more of a pickled collar, so that packed acidity with some heat which was a nice complement to the BBQ.They serve some solid dishes, that make you feel all warm and fuzzy inside.

<review# 975,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/18/2013,1/24/2014,1988,418,8,11,12>I absolutely Love this park! It's great for walking, jogging, dog walking, scooter riding, picnicking, baseball, tennis, or just chilling out and relaxing! It's a fantastic size, considering it's a Queens park. There are three baseball fields, a roller hockey rink, tennis courts, a track, a playground for the little ones, a hand ball and bocce ball court (which is currently being renovated), and a delightful green landscape, which seems to last even amongst the colorful fall foliage. There are a bunch of benches and some tables as well. I love watching the cute old Italian men play bocce ball, and the senior citizens who sit at the tables and play cards (or other various senior games). I also love watching all the people walk their dogs. 9 times out of 10, when they hear me owwwwwing and awwwwwing, they ask me if I want to pet the furry, four legged, cutie pie, and of course I sit there and ogle over it! The only thing I strongly DISLIKE about this park is the abundance of pigeons. Obviously, it's not the parks fault, and therefore five stars will remain, but I just can't stand these rat like birds. I don't know anyone who hates pigeons as much as I do. I don't even like the word. It makes me so mad that they always flock to this park. They gross me out terribly and sometimes while I'm here, I think they purposely walk in front of me... SICKENING! I yell and scream, clap my hands, and stomp my feet like a mad woman to get them out of my sight. If there's any commotion in the park, it's probably me trying to scare off these disgusting creatures. I love this park because it's never too crazy. It's always very calm and serene. There's never much of anything going on, just locals hanging out, walking their dogs, getting exercise, or coming to relax. Also, if you look towards the huge open field, you can see the Freedom Tower in the city (check out my pic). Another thing that makes this park great is fact that the bathrooms are half way decent. I mean they're not spectacular, but there's always toilet paper, the smell is minimal, and the sink works. Do beware the last few times I've come here there hasn't been soap. If you haven't been here before I urge you to come check out this lovely park, but please leave your bad habits and rambunctiousness at home (or bring it to Flushing Meadow Corona Park lol).

<review# 978,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/18/2013,8/2/2013,226,636,9,12,10>Prior to visiting De Mole, when I got my Mexican food cravings, I'd take the short walk to El Rey taco truck and call it a night. We trudged out in a foot of snow during the recent snow storm and came here for an amazing date night. When we stepped inside, there was only one other party was there and this place is intimate and has a classy decor, which only lead to a really romantic experience. We started off with a really nice bottle of white wine (Less than $30 for a 2006 Chardonnay? Say Word?!) and the fish ceviche.  I felt like I've tried a million shrimp ceviche that all tasted the same, but this ceviche was out of this world. Finely minced veggies and cubed flaky white fish. Could of had this just as an entree alone. For my actual entree, I went with the carne asada, which was BOMB. I was a little reluctant at first, since a lot of places overcook the beef and it's like a piece of rubber by the time it hits your table. Mine was cooked perfectly, seasoned just right and really tender. Came with some grilled veggies and the always tasty rice and black beans. The best part was - it was greasy or super duper filling to the point that I was bursting at the seems. Will I still frequent taco truck for a quick fix? Of course. But when I'm trying to get my formal on and have a nice, sit down Mexican meal in the hood, De Mole will be my first choice!

<review# 980,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/3/2013,7/31/2013,32,170,7,10,9>This would be my neighborhood restaurant, if I lived in the neighborhood. Great price for the portions and really fast service.I recently went here to recover from New Year's- craving some red meat. I got the steak cubes rice dish and a lemonade (a little lemon to detox the liver and digest meat). Don't let the word "cube" fool you! These were kinda like sirloin tips, sauteed with onions, with a soy/worcestershire/shallot or garlic? sauce, garnished with slices of cucumber and tomatoes. The beef was cooked a nice medium, and the sauce soaked into the rice and onions. The sauce was SO good. I thought I was full halfway through the plate and then slowly made my way through ALL of it. I don't like onions, but even ate a few- they were soft and marinated by the sauce. The lemonade was mild, not too sweet, but a nice contrast. I've pretty much eaten all the standards on their menu and recommend:-the pho with rare beef (with hoisin and chunky chili sauce mixed together for dipping please!)-pork chops and rice-vermicelli bun bowl with spring rolls on top(thick white noodles)-shrimp or beef (beef rolls) vermicelli (angel hair white noodles) lettuce mint wraps-mixed vegetable stir-fry & a side of pork chop  I'm not too crazy about:-summer rolls (I'll have to try these again, for some reason they sometimes lack flavor, and they always come out later than the rest of the food since they take longer to make- soaking the wrappers)-the grilled beef on rice (it's good, but I always expect the beef to be nicely grilled steak. It's actually sesame rolled up beef, with a scallion in the middle. Carefully made, but not the texture that I usually want).

<review# 987,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/6/2012,6/22/2012,393,406,15,11,11>Thanks to Dutch Kills, all it takes to become a native New Yorker is ten minutes and $14.There is no logical explanation for the location - this stretch of Jackson Avenue merely serves as a conduit between the Queensboro and PS1. But, behind the white neon "Bar" sign is an oasis of class.The small interior is full of old wooden booths with a few seats at the bar. You're here for one reason - the drinks. The team behind Milk & Honey created Dutch Kills so there is no messing around with the cocktails. They are expensive, strong and delicious.I've had the Native New Yorker and the off-menu American Trilogy, and both were awesome. As crazy as it sounds, the ice is one of the best parts of the drink. It's hand cut and ends up in tiny round shavings. They also come with an Inspector Gadget-like metal straw that has a stirring spoon on the end.This is a great place for strong cocktails and a speakeasy vibe without the lines and fuss that this would have in Manhattan. Also, its a fun way to enjoy yourself while your car is being towed without your knowledge.

I would walk by daily, wondering what occasion would be an excuse to go in.There are so many new places in my new neighborhood that I wanted to try, but I always ventured elsewhere (never disappointed with the choices I made).Even the owner noticed my interest, during the day, while he was prepping the place for the evening business. Although I hadn't even stepped foot into his establishment, he always had a friendly greeting for me.The perfect excuse finally happened. On a Sunday morning, I had a huge breakfast at the Bayside Diner, and I didn't want to deal with cooking, or going out for dinner.My significant other suggested we go to Mosaic, and it was a sublime experience! A glass (or two) of Pinot Grigio, accompanied by a plate of Italian Pepper Salami, Sopressata cured w/ wine & garlic, Jarlsberg and smoked Gouda cheese w/ Lungfish Caviar. I can't wait for next Sunday.
<review# 992,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/4/2012,6/17/2012,230,472,1,8,4>I was skeptical.This place is owned by someone who owns a few Thai restaurants in Manhattan. That they would set up a branch on an obscure corner in an obscure working class neighborhood in Queens seemed an odd business move, especially as the prices are practically the same as any Thai place on 9th Avenue.The giant crystal chandelier, ultramodern white furniture (why does almost every new Thai restaurant look like this now? Is this what Bangkok is like?), over-the-top sculpted food presentation (rice comes out formed into an oblique cone, egg rolls in a vase garnished with a nest of carrot shavings), adult contemporary music on the stereo (Adele, that song from Aladdin) all felt out-of-place in this modest, down-to-earth, home-style neighborhood where showiness isn't a part of the daily routine.However...The service was ultra prompt, attentive, and friendly. There was thankfully no television, which seems to be unfortunately rare in these parts. The view of the surrounding streets is fantastic if you sit up in the big picture window toward the front corner. The food is excellent. Really, really flavorful and well-cooked. The aforementioned spring rolls were crispy, not greasy. I asked for the red curry with vegetarian duck to be served "spicy," and it actually was spicy, for once (unlike at some Thai restaurants where it still comes out pretty medium). Bold flavors and aromas, firm vegetables. Enormous portions. I was highly, highly satisfied with my meal here and won-over... some of the better Thai food I've had anywhere in a while, and far less obnoxious to eat in than some of the crowded ones in Hell's Kitchen near my office.Prices are higher than Thai Village a few blocks away (although the lunch specials look like a steal), but the food is a real step-up.We'll definitely be back here.
<review# 993,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/11/2012,6/16/2012,1195,408,3,9,6>Found a new nook to get some home cooking, if I feel like paying for it.  And would I pay for it, you ask?  The answer from me: a resounding "YES."Granted it is a bit difficult to get to (let's face it... anywhere in Queens is difficult to get to), but that's beside the point; and they do delivery anyway.  It is an unassuming little joint in a very "neighborhoody" kind of street, a few blocks removed from the hustle and bustle (if you can even call it that) of Steinway and 30th ave (west side).I came in at 5:00 pm and got out at 7:00 pm on a Wednesday, with me and only one other customer (a lady) showing up between those times; shows how less traveled that road is during that time on that day.  Quickly made friends with my fellow patron (yes, we were both Filipino) and we were promptly served our food within minutes of ordering.  The lumpia is exactly how mom used to make them (and still does)... little cylinder shaped flavor grenades that explode with each bite.  And Marty's fried chicken (Chef Recommended) was great; unbreaded chicken quarters with crispy skin with tender and moist (but not oily) meat... you could make a strong argument that this was better than Max's fried chicken (unofficial national fried chicken branch of Las Pilipinas).  I also opted for an adobo fried rice bowl, while my newly found lady friend selected the bagoong fried rice bowl (both chef recommended).  The bowl has quite a substantial amount of toppings and meat (I could barely see the rice in the bowl is how loaded the portion was).  I tried both, and you cannot go wrong either way.The restaurant's tag line is "Filipino Comfort Food" (or something to that effect), and damn was I comforted AND comfortable after my meal here.

<review# 995,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/11/2012,6/14/2012,364,373,8,8,9>Time to review a serious restaurant with delicious food and Vesta comes to mind. It is an out of the way establishment on 21 Street and 30th Ave in Astoria. Vesta's calling card is an Italian influence restaurant with farm to table food which is nicely decorated with local vendors for their artwork and interior construction.I have been here a few times with Wifey and each time we have had fabulous food, intriguing wines and wonderful service. I just dig a neighborhood restaurant that is part of the community. They do things a little different, which is always great with me. I like a little creativity, simple dishes done right and outrageous service when I go out for serious food. This is want makes a good meal outstanding.On our recent visit we started our meal with a "Potato & Pancetta Pizza with caramelized onions, apple & goat cheese @ $13". This Pizza had the texture and flavor that we take for granted on a regular basis. The caramelize onions were pureed and spread throughout the Pizza as the sauce. I thought it was a bean sauce, but was corrected when I asked the waiter. The crust was crispy and the ratio of ingredients had the balance of flavors. The Pizza was all good.Wifey had "Pappardelle with pancetta, ramps, shaved grana cheese & egg yolk @ $15" as her entree. All I can say it was OUTSTANDING. It took me years to appreciate al dente pasta and when I did; I fell in love. The Pappardelle was perfectly cooked and the flavors stood out with the texture of the pasta. The pancetta provided some nice flavor and it was well balanced with the grana cheese. Super delicious dish.I had a very simple dish, "Lasagna with three meat ragu (Sunday Dinner Style) @ $15". Every Lasagna dish I ever had, was so heavy that it stuck to my ribs. The Lasagna at Vesta was light and so delicious, that it just melted in my mouth. It was as good as it gets. Can you imagine Lasagna as a delicate dish? Nice, very nice. The three meat ragu was tasty and was not acidic at all. The lasa noodle layered with ragu and a top of parm cheese just exploded with all the deliciousness in my mouth. Like I said, very lite and with flavor.As we enjoyed this delicious meal, we shared a couple of bottles of red wines from Toscana. I tend to order wines from Italy by region rather than Vintage. I am a big fan of Italian Wines and found this region of Italy to be a winner. Dessert = Baby Jesus Cake = Order This = Delicious = Trust Me!!!!!!!!!Service was outrageously excellent. Our server did a great job. He was knowledgeable and very patient with us, since we were not ready to order a couple of times. He checked on us and let us chill at the end as we enjoyed our wine.I love the fact that you could walk down the street from your apartment and enjoy a great meal. The neighborhood restaurant is a staple of New York City and every borough has some gems. Here in Astoria we celebrate Vesta. If you just stop by for pizza or a three course meal at Vesta; you will experience wonderful food, delicious wine and outstanding service. Mangia & Buon Appetito!

Pretty nice piece of steak. In my photo, the eggs kinda cover the steak. Take my word for it, the steak was pretty fair size for a breakfast platter and for it's price.Drinks - Mimosas and Bloody Mary's! The mimosas comes with a slice of strawberry and some blueberries in the bottom of the glass. As for the Bloody Mary's, they offer two types. Virgin Bloody Mary and one with sake. I've tried both and wasn't too thrilled with the sake one. The sake tasted weird to me in the Bloody Mary. Even though there was no alcohol in the Virgin Bloody Mary, it tasted a lot better. It was nice and peppery.Service - Entire staff is very friendly. We never waited long to be seated. The waitresses here are very sweet.Music - This is probably the best part and my main reason of coming to Jack & Nellie's for brunch. They offer live music during brunch hours. They usually play some soothing acoustic stuff, guitar, violin, double bass, mostly string instruments.Verdict - Hands down, my favorite brunch spot in Forest Hills! They do it all here for brunch. You get the total package. Good food, good drinks, good music, good service, and good prices! Menu is short and simple and they occasionally have specials. You can't ask for anything more out of a place like this. Jack & Nellie's is a real neighborhood gem in my book.
<review# 997,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/13/2014,6/21/2014,5,28,8,14,12>This place is fantastic. People in Manhattan may consider this place a "hole in the wall," but if you're from Queens, most likely you will think that Lali Guras is like exactly like a restaurant in your home country.First off, getting inside is pretty intimidating. AND IT'S AWESOME. I came in with 2 friends, and was seated within 15 seconds. Those 15 seconds included the waitress eyeing our seats, and asking the patrons who were already there to scoot over to make room for us. Baller status.The menu is simple. For all of our sakes, order the chicken thali. Or if you're a vegetarian, get the vegetable thali. Okay quick lesson (as if you haven't read this from other people's reviews):Thali: various dishes that make up one big dish. At Lali Guras, the thali consists of: - dal (lentil soup)- achard (spicy pickled condiments)- papad (crispy wafer)- chicken/vegetables (whichever ever is your main dish)Oh, and this is all only $8-9? But that's not the best part...THERE ARE FREE REFILLS OF FOOD. But after your second helping, you'll be stuffed.-- Sidenote --I truly loved my experience here. I think I found the man who eats with his hands (that Jason C. pointed out) and sat diagonally from him. He was awesome. He stared at me attempt to eat with my hands, laughed at me, and then TAUGHT me! Let's be real, y'all, food is the universal language. No words between us -- just food and laughter. Thanks, Lali Guras!---Cailin's Recommendation:- Chicken Thali - $8
<review# 998,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/2/2014,6/20/2014,681,925,9,16,13>Oh Sweetleaf, you provide me with the appropriate fuel I need at any point during a given day: coffee in the morning and hand-crafted cocktails at dusk [1].  And when I'm not in the mood for coffee, your Strawberry Black Iced Tea is what I'm craving.  And I'm always craving cocktails (especially if there's gin in them), so that is a non-issue.The owners of Sweetleaf teamed up with Richard Boccato of Dutch Kills to curate a cocktail menu that features both the best of Dutch Kills as well as some new coffee and tea based cocktails.  My personal goal has been to try one of each cocktail on the menu; needless to say this has taken multiple visits and I still have a way to go.  Highlights: the refreshing Long Island City special, car bombs that taste like banana bread (yes, really), the Kona Swizzle which blends rum and coffee into a cocktail that tastes like a boozy latte, and any of the cocktails that feature ginger (with whiskey, gin, or otherwise).Sweetleaf's ambiance certainly echoes the opulence of the neighboring luxury highrises.  Unlike the leasing office of a luxury highrise though, Sweetleaf's staff and management - whether it's for caffeine to start my day or a nightcap to end it - are nothing but friendly and warm and take great pride in the beverages they make.  And you can't argue with the bartender creating special birthday coffee-based shots with you and throwing one back with you and your friends, either.[1] Sweetleaf begins alcoholic beverage service (and stops serving coffee) at 6pm.

Regardless of the space, I enjoy their food so adapt; go early and pick an end table with easy buffet access. :)

They aren't perfect circles or anything. They each had their own unique shape. Authentic. BUT I don't know if its because I saved them for the very end or if they were not too great all along but there were cold when I began eating them. So they didn't have that delicious soft and warm buttery taste I was looking for. I probably would order them again though and eat them first just to double check.There were a lot of people here for such a small place. Families with children. A large group of friends. A lot of variety and many different backgrounds. That was cool. I love to see different cultures in one spot. Means its great across the board. Over all I had a really good time here. I enjoyed my food and the delicious drinks and the atmosphere was laid back. Perfect for a Saturday morning. I'll definitely be returning.

<review# 1002,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/21/2014,6/16/2014,115,88,5,10,6>Front Toward Enemy has just raised the bar for the cocktail scene here in Astoria. A beautifully manicured bar adorned with leather upholstered booths and pallet boarded ceilings. Whereas most cocktail bars in NY are small and exude that feel of exclusivity, FTE is expansive and welcoming. It has a true feel for what a cocktail bar in Astoria should have in my opinion. The staff were helpful and prompt. When our bartender realized he may have missed an ingredient from a drink, he informed us and supplied us with the proper drink on the house. Sacrificing cash for craft. From what I was told, many of the bartenders came from Dutch Kills. The quality was the defining hint. The drinks were decadent and beautiful, but in no way broke the bank. All cocktails were fairly priced at $12 a pop. I, naturally veering into whiskey cocktails, sampled the M18, Bow & Arrow, and the Spiked Whiskey. While all were amazing drinks in their own right, the Bow & Arrow was by far the favorite. Actually, it may be my favorite drink that I've had in recent memory. The combination of mezcal and bourbon may be preposterous, but they mixed elegantly. The drink tasted of a bitter butterscotch. It was perfect for my palate as well as my friend who normally steered clear of my drink choices. Front Toward Enemy is the superb addition to the eccentric and diverse collection of bars and restaurants in Astoria as well as to the cocktail scene. PS - The Chickpea Fries are euphoric.

<review# 1009,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/3/2013,10/1/2013,225,493,6,8,7>A wonderfully warm, cozy and simplistic space that doesn't feel like it belongs on Queens Blvd.  We were there on a very quiet night.  The bar seems to attract lots of solo patrons, which is nice in an area with so many apartment buildings..  We were greeted and shown to our table.  The wine list isn't huge but there is a variety to choose from.  We started with a Finger Lakes flight and some oysters.  The wine was brought immediately, but the oysters took forever.  So long, that I actually thought they had forgotten to place the order, which they didn't.  Considering there were only 2-3 other patrons, I'm not sure what happened.  I was starting to get annoyed and thinking maybe we should just go.  Luckily the oysters arrived and I have to say they were awesome.  Super fresh and flavorful.Since things started to pick up, we decided to order some more.  The crab and avocado small plate was delicious.  We also opted for the white garlic mussels which were tender and tasty.All in all I left quite happy and would be glad to return.
<review# 1010,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/22/2013,9/30/2013,96,157,5,7,6>Located in the back of Cha time bubble tea, it's a small "stall" located amongst two other eateries. The "food court" is very hot -- my friend and I could not stay after ordering our chicken & bubble tea because there is no air conditioning - but the chicken was worth itFreshly made upon ordering, the chicken bits are crispy on the outside while remaining juicy on the inside. I tried the curry while my friend got the salt&pepper (I plan on trying the plum next time I go here). The salt&pepper was nothing special, but the curry was pretty darn good. They give you a lot of popcorn chicken (they cut them in half) for the cheap price (I believe it was around $3 dollars). My friend and I were pretty full after devouring one each. Will definitely be returning -- but not when its excruciatingly hot outside.
<review# 1011,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/8/2013,9/29/2013,188,156,7,8,8>This review is for the Fruit Tarts Only!   I've ordered Fruit tarts from quite a few bakeries but Lulu's has got to be the best. The care that they put into the presentation of the beautiful tarts is just above and beyond. Everyone that tried this dessert was impressed.The variety of fruit is great compared to any other tarts i've tried, blackberries, plums, raspberries, kiwi, pineapple, grapes, strawberries, oranges and blueberries! My favorite part is also that they cover the crust of the tart in dark chocolate, so unique! ALSO, no crumbling when you cut into this baby. I can't wait to come and try some of their other treats! I feel like LuLu's will be rated among my top picks of bakeries in Queens.
<review# 1012,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/30/2013,9/28/2013,127,319,5,9,7>This is probably the best Chinese car service I have ever taken. I've used it getting to and from airports, after-hours car service for work, and for personal uses. The prices are super cheap compared to other companies. Recently, I took it from Brooklyn to Queens for $36. A cab would usually cost at least $50. Other car companies turned me down because there's better business within the manhattan area, but New Golden House has several cars lined up. I usually only wait no more than 15 minutes for a ride. I spoke to them in Cantonese and they assigned me with a Cantonese driver too.  My mandarin speaking friends usually get mandarin speaking drivers too. It may be a coincident but I think otherwise as I've taken this car service several times. They really try to cater to you.I've also used Yes Car Service, Korean and Chinatown Car Services, Carmel (American option), and yellow taxi cabs, but nothing topped New Golden House's service! Most of the car service companies have an issues traveling within the boroughs and give nasty attitudes, but not New Golden House.
<review# 1013,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/30/2013,9/27/2013,76,31,12,20,10>As someone who lives around the corner, I've been waiting for CityRib to open for some time now. I had hyped it up to my friends, and myself, for the 1+ year that the "Coming Soon" poster went up. A lot could have gone wrong with so much built up anticipation.I'm happy to say that biases aside, I was very pleased with the outcome. In only three weeks, I've eaten there four times, giving me a pretty well-rounded perspective on the quality of service and food.Service-wise, everyone is very friendly and hospitable. From the hostesses and bar staff, to the servers and bus boys, even down to the management company staff, everyone who I came in touch with was very nice and did what they could to make the experience enjoyable. Even though it's classier than the local competition, everyone was still very down to earth. It's still Jamaica, Queens after all.In every instance the food came to the table expeditiously, as well as the drinks.Let's start with the drinks, which were developed with the oversight of one of the bartenders over at Bathtub Gin in Chelsea. A mixology bar I'm quite familiar with. The craftsmanship -- while not as treasured for me as those made at Sasha Petraske's bars -- blows the doors off of anything else you're going to find in the neighborhood. I wouldn't call myself a true connoisseur, but I'd say I appreciate the complexities a well-made beverage more than the average person; and CityRib delivers on this. The Stone Street Mule and Rufus King Cocktails are go-to favorites for me. Here's to hoping they add something akin to a Scotch or Bourbon Buck to the menu.In terms of food, I'll make it simple: Delicious. I've had a lot of barbecue here in New York, and down in BBQ-heavy locales like Virginia and Texas. I would count CityRib, for my taste, among the best. Sometimes it can be a hit or quasi-miss, however, depending on what you order. I've had the brisket, pork ribs, pork shoulder, and chicken; the pork shoulder being my favorite. The ribs are also delectable. Not fall off the bone good, but it's foolish to say all barbecue should be prepared that way. That said, the brisket can be a gamble depending on how you like it. The first time I had it, it was so soft and tender I nearly died. The second time, however, it was a bit on the tougher side. As it turned out, if you want the more tender center cut, you need to specify. Otherwise, you could end up with the chewier, but still good, ends. Some don't like rarer meat, however. So, it's more so a preference play.The BBQ chicken is good. But that's kind of hard to screw up. So, don't expect your mind to be blown.In terms of sides, I've tried the sweet potato fries, collard greens, and mac & cheese. Do yourself a favor and just get the mac & cheese. As far as I'm concerned, there's a old fat black woman -- who affectionately goes by "big momma" -- in the back cooking up pans of these delicious morsels.Jamaica has needed this for such a long time. There are plenty of people who live in the area and have longed for something better than Applebee's. We aren't satisfied with the Wendy's and McDonald's of the world, and openly welcome new restaurants looking to shake things up Downtown. CityRib will be getting my business on a regular basis.
<review# 1014,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/13/2013,9/26/2013,39,146,6,7,7>Finding a compromise between me and the beau is very hard. I don't eat meat, he doesn't eat seafood. I don't like potatoes, he doesn't like rice. Can't we all just get along??? Well I thought a steak/seafood place would be the best halfway point for one of our date nights. The place looks pretty fancy out and we very much appreciated the valet parking since finding a spot over there is MURDER. Anyways scouting the menu I soon realize this is much more a place to cater to the seafood lovers. Our waiter was prompt but he just seemed kinda down. Not friendly but not rude but just kinda there. I ordered the fish tacos, clam chowder and shrimp stuffed with crab meat, side of rice please. Boyfriend got the NY strip and potatoes. Fish tacos were delicious, with a wonderful side of guac, sour cream, and slaw. Clam chowder was alright, nothing spectacular. The shrimp and crab meat on the other hand was superb! The beurre blanc sauce on the shrimp was delicious, and the entree came with some mixed veggies wrapped in sliced plantains, which were also very tasty. My boyfriend said his steak was very tender and was good (not great), but he did devour his broccoli in garlic and oil. We finished the meal with a piece of chocolate cake and banana cream pie. We could have done without dessert. Banana cream pie had a very mild flavor and tasted more like cream than anything else. The bill came out to about $120 which wasn't bad for the type of fancy schmancy vibe this place had going. Hopefully I can drag him back here so I try the rest of the seafood menu. Hopefully.
<review# 1015,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/6/2013,9/25/2013,42,92,6,8,7>Lately, I've been on the hunt for the best Thai food in Queens. Zabb Elee was my first stop and with sheer luck, they are open until 3am! Awesome.It's a relatively small restaurant in the heart of Jackson Heights. Parking wasn't an issue at 11PM but I can only imagine how it would've been if we had gotten there earlier. Here are the things we ordered: Servings were very generousThai Iced Tea - 4/5 A bit too sweet for my taste but I find that this is standard. Nevertheless, very good.Lychee - 5/5 So good! I would get this next time instead of Thai Iced Tea.Green Papaya salad with dried shrimp - 4/5 Loved it! Perfect balance of citrus and saltiness. They do ask you beforehand how spicy you like it. We said mild and it was still pretty hot! Thank goodness for Thai iced tea to diffuse all the heat. Phad Thai - 4/5 Best one I've had in a while. It is not too sweet and I like that they put toppings on the side so you can choose which ones to mix. It also doesn't have that bright orange color so no artificial color (great in my book)Pork Loin over rice - I can't comment on this since I gave up pork for lent. Mr. S did like a lot as he finished his plate!Taro in coconut milk (Hot) - 4/5 I happen to love taro so I thought this was good. I would've liked the taro to be more tender as I had a hard time cutting through it with a spoon. Overall I would go back here again especially when those late-night cravings hit me. I love that they open late and very affordable. Service was fast and very friendly. They didn't try to rush us by waiting for us to ask for the bill (unlike others)
